webTitle: Gunners and Hammers to draw while Foxes triumph

fields.headline: Gunners and Hammers to draw while Foxes triumph
fields.standfirst: Mike Hodgkinson, our man with a placepot, a perm and a cheeky smile, on which way the big game at Highbury will go.
fields.trailText: Sunday's clash at Highbury is the pick of the weekend's Premiership games and will go a long way to deciding which side joins Leeds in snapping at Manchester United's mercurial heels
fields.body:
Sunday's clash at Highbury is the pick of the weekend's Premiership games and will go a long way to deciding which side joins Leeds in snapping at Manchester United's mercurial heels during the run-in. Both Arsenal and Liverpool have grounds for thinking they can take this one but the league leaders should emerge most satisfied with the result - a likely draw at 12-5 with Hills.

Liverpool will certainly have the psychological edge as they're unbeaten in five league trips to N5 - and three of those sorties produced wins. They will also be in top spirits after last week's defeat of Leeds and will reportedly be chanting the mantra "Bradford, Bradford" to their opposite numbers in the tunnel before the game. Arsene Wenger at least has Dennis Bergkamp, Tony Adams and Silvinho back in contention but will definitely miss Patrick Vieira who has not responded too well to treatment on his dodgy knee.

The case against Liverpool can be summed up in three words - Owen, Fowler and Redknapp. All three are sidelined until March at the earliest. However, who needs snipers when you can rely on the big guns? Liverpool have scored 11 goals from outside the box this season, more than any other Premiership side, which makes Patrick Berger one to consider for first-scorer honours. Even more so in the light of Gerard Houllier's recent instructions to the Czech hero "to go inside a bit more" where he feels more comfortable. "I am now in a position to have more shots on goal," says Berger. The hint should be taken.

If you fancy more attractive odds, take defender Sami Hyppia to nod one in from a set piece. He's already score two first goals for Liverpool this season and only needs one more to earn you a healthy profit. If he doesn't manage it on Saturday, stick with him until May.

Leicester should not be opposed when they travel to Vicarage Road on Saturday. Martin O'Neill's indefatigable Foxes have returned victorious after three of their last four trips to Watford - the team Rodney Marsh recently described on Sky Sports as the worst in the Premiership. Never one to mince his words, Marsh. But in this case the statistics give him full support. The Hornets have conceded 25 goals in their last nine games, 20 more than they let in over their opening nine.

Stan Collymore is unlikely to play but Emile Heskey and Tony Cottee are set to renew their partnership up front for the first time in the year 2000. Cottee has been suffering calf and eye troubles, but is back in full training, while Heskey's knee problems appear to have cleared up nicely. One or the other or them should fire Leicester to a win at a best priced 11-10.

A seven-match losing run in the Premiership away from home doesn't augur too well for Bradford's chances at Upton Park on Saturday, but two crucial factors will give them a fighting chance - the Hammers' injury troubles and the Yorkshire side's defeat of Arsenal last week.

Harry Redknapp will be fielding a third-choice 'keeper - Shaka Hislop is struggling with a hamstring injury and his deputy Craig Forrest is away on international duty with Canada. So Hammers fans will have to think up a song or two for former Rochdale keeper Stephen Bywater. Paulo Wanchope is on international duty, and even if Paolo Di Canio starts he'll be playing through the pain barrier of a hamstring injury. On the other hand, it's asking too much for Bradford to repeat their Arsenal heroics way from Valley Parade, so go for the draw - at 13-5.

Recommended treble Arsenal v Liverpool - draw
Watford v Leicester - away win
West Ham v Bradford - draw

webTitle: Clash of African giants reopens old wounds

fields.headline: Clash of African giants reopens old wounds
fields.standfirst: Security tight for the third meeting of Nigeria and South Africa
fields.trailText: Despite the existance of a somewhat brief 'history', players from Nigeria and South Africa yesterday rushed to play down fears that there would be ill-feeling during their semi-final clash this afternoon. Football Unlimited will be covering the match live from 3pm.
fields.body:
Players from Nigeria and South Africa yesterday rushed to play down fears that there would be ill-feeling when the two sides meet here this afternoon in their eagerly anticipated African Nations Cup semi-final.

Millions of Africans are expected to make up a near-record television audience, thousands will be huddled around their transistor radios, while hordes of ticketless Nigerians will gather in the thatched huts situated at the entertainment village outside the sold-out 55,000 all-seat Surulere stadium to watch on big screens.

The bitter legacy of a political dispute between Nigeria and South Africa have raised the stakes although players from both teams, who are staying in the same hotel, are adamant there will be no bitterness.

"When [Mark] Fish and I met in the lobby we hugged with affection," said Sunday Oliseh of Juventus, the Nigeria captain, referring to the South Africa defender.

Lucas Radebe, the South Africa and Leeds United captain, added: "Most players on both sides are friends; like me and Kanu, Fish and Sunday Oliseh. So this game is a friendly affair."

Adding to the spice of the meeting, however, is the fact that this is only the third meeting between the teams, the first of which took place here in October 1992, after South Africa had returned from its international isolation for its government's apartheid policies.

The Super Eagles won that World Cup qualifying match 4-0 while the second leg, in Johannesburg, finished 0-0.

Talk of grudges has been in the air since 1996, however, when a diplomatic row between former South Africa president Nelson Mandela and Nigeria's military ruler, the late general Sani Abacha.

Mandela had criticised Abacha, who defied international opinion in 1995 and ordered the execution of the Nigerian writer Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight other Ogoni activists for the alleged murder of four pro-government Ogoni chiefs, the upshot of which was that Nigeria was suspended from the Commonwealth.

South Africa subsequently withdrew its invitation to Nigeria to contest a four-nation tournament before the 1996 Nations Cup, and Abacha retaliated by withdrawing the Super Eagles, then the defending champions, from the tournament.

The Dutchman Jo Bonfrere, Nigeria's coach at the time and once again in charge, said: "I felt sad we didn't play in that 1996 finals. Now we finally meet. I'm happy and I want to see a true game of sportsmanship."

The Confederation of African Football also banned Nigeria from the 1998 tournament in Burkina Faso, where South Africa finished as runners-up, and all efforts to stage another match between the two teams have since failed.

Radebe, who played in both previous meetings, commented: "The Nigerians have always claimed we couldn't call ourselves champions in 1996 because they weren't at the tournament. So we'll like to make a point of beating them now."

Fish, his partner at the back, added: "The Nigerian defence is suspect. I was not that impressed with their [quarter- final] game against Senegal. They were fortunate to score late, which gave them their footing to fight back. I believe we can beat them."

Nigeria's 18-year-old Julius Aghahowa, who scored both goals in that 2-1 win against Senegal, replied: "It's going to be a tough game, but ask any layman and he'll tell you we'll win. We don't lose at home."

Indeed they don't, and boast a proud undefeated home record stretching back to 1981, when Algeria beat them 2-0 in a World Cup qualifying match. They have not lost a Nations Cup match since their 2-1 loss to Ghana in 1992.

This afternoon the sides will be without key midfielders, however, Nigeria's Austin Okocha and South Africa's Eric Tinkler both sitting this one out after being sent off in the quarter-finals.

South Africa's coach Trott Moloto also has worries about both of his strikers, Shaun Bartlett of FC Zurich and Quinton Fortune, the Manchester United reserve. Bartlett, the tournament's top scorer with four goals, has flu while Fortune is nursing an injury.

Nigeria's forward Victor Ikpeba, scorer of two goals in their opening group game against Tunisia - who meet Cameroon this evening in the Accra semi-final - may also miss out after a row with Bonfrere for substituting him in the 0-0 draw with Congo.

Ugly incidents during that Congo game, in which home fans hurled plastic bottles on to the pitch to protest against Nigeria's performance, and after the Senegal match, which sparked a pitch invasion, have further heightened security fears, although Nigeria were duly fined $10,000 for the latter incident.

A statement from the Nigerian organisers was issued yesterday, which simply said: "We appeal to the fans to be civilised in their support and we're providing maximum security for the game." Fingers will be crossed that it will not be needed.

webTitle: Giggs friendly could be a first for Hughes

fields.headline: Giggs friendly could be a first for Hughes
fields.trailText: Wales manager Mark Hughes hopes to succeed where all his predecessors have failed later this month by becoming the first manager ever to dare to field Ryan Giggs in a friendly international.
fields.body:
Never one to shirk a challenge, the Wales manager Mark Hughes hopes to succeed where all his predecessors have failed later this month.

A visit to the footballing minnows of Qatar on February 23 hardly suggests history in the making. But, should Ryan Giggs play in Doha, Hughes will become the first manager ever to dare to field the Manchester United winger in a friendly international.

"The last time I saw Ryan was at the Mike Tyson fight in Manchester," said Hughes yesterday after naming the 26-year-old in an 18-man squad. "We had a good discussion there. He was positive about playing and made it clear that he wants to be with us. He was adamant he was going to come."

Giggs' inclusion in the starting line-up would raise a few eyebrows, not least at Old Trafford. In a Wales career spanning nine years, he has only appeared in European Championship and World Cup qualifiers. Now all that is apparently set to change.

"He's a very proud Welshman and when he's fit he will play for his country," said Hughes. "Everyone knows that Ryan has had a lot of injuries, but he has missed a lot of games for Manchester United, not just Wales."

Quite what Sir Alex Ferguson will make of it all remains to be seen. The United manager has made a point of protecting his injury-prone star since he burst on to the scene in 1991 and will hardly relish releasing the player a week before resuming their Champions League campaign.

Now the winger is due to fly out to Qatar immediately after United's top-of-the-table game with Leeds at Elland Road on February 20. On his return, United face a trip to Wimbledon in the Premiership before Bordeaux visit Old Trafford.

"Whatever has been the perceived situation in the past, whenever I have discussed the situation with Sir Alex Ferguson he has always been happy for Ryan to play for Wales," insisted Hughes.

"I know that managers are not very receptive to their players going away on international duty, but they know that times are allocated for internationals and they have got to respect that. The players can tell their wives, their girlfriends and their managers that when those dates come up they are with me.

"I want my best players for every game. I will go down any avenue to get my players together - I don't get enough time with them anyway."

Another midfielder who could make his first start in Qatar is Tottenham's Simon Davies. The 20-year-old, who recently moved to White Hart Lane from Peterborough for £800,000, makes the transition from the Welsh under-21s. "Simon is an exciting player," added Hughes. "This trip gives me the chance to have a good look at him."

The Leeds midfielder Matthew Jones, who won his first full cap against Switzerland last June, retains his place in the absence of Leicester's Robbie Savage. Savage will play in the Worthington Cup final against Tranmere on the Sunday after the Qatar friendly and has been allowed to miss the trip.

The Wolves defender Ryan Green, 19, who broke Giggs' record as Wales' youngest international in 1998, has asked for a transfer after making just one appearance for the First Division club.

webTitle: Di Canio on the carpet over Villa gesture

fields.headline: Di Canio on the carpet over Villa gesture
fields.trailText: Paulo Di Canio was yesterday charged with misconduct for his one-fingered salute during West Ham's Premiership game against Aston Villa last month.
fields.body:
After the infamous Paul Alcock incident, Paolo di Canio must have hoped he had seen the last of Lancaster Gate. But the Italian striker can look forward to another visit to Football Association headquarters after falling foul of a crackdown on insulting gestures.

Di Canio was yesterday charged with misconduct for his one-fingered salute during West Ham's Premiership game against Aston Villa last month. His actions, caught on camera, were badly timed.

Earlier this season it would have been fine. Manchester United's David Beckham was given only a warning for aiming a V-sign at Leeds fans in August. But apparently Di Canio has not been reading the club mail: an FA warning went out in November.

"At the beginning of this season we had a number of cases involving gestures deemed obscene or insulting, and David Beckham was one of them. We dealt with those by way of warnings," said the FA spokesman Steve Double.

"But in November we wrote to every club saying we were drawing a line under that procedure and from then on players would be charged where there was clear evidence of making gestures.

"Having been fairly softly-softly, and seeing it was still happening, we wanted to make our position clear. The police have drawn very strong parallels between player behaviour and crowd reaction, and made it known to us that strong action was needed."

On January 13, two days before Di Canio's misdemeanour, Tottenham's Tim Sherwood was charged with misconduct for gestures he made towards the crowd at Newcastle. Yet West Ham were angered by a decision they called "unjust".

"We're very disappointed the FA has chosen to take it further," said the company secretary Graham Mackrell. "I don't think that was necessary." They will consult the Professional Footballers' Association.

West Ham's manager Harry Redknapp described the incident at the time as "a load of nonsense" and Di Canio has protested his innocence. He has written to the FA and is thought to have stressed that the gesture was not aimed at the Villa fans, who were barracking him after an incident in a Worthington Cup tie between the teams four days earlier.

Villa's supporters believe he dived in that quarter-final to earn a penalty he subsequently missed. But the FA is unlikely to be concerned at whom the gesture was aimed.

Di Canio had to be restrained when Villa's goalkeeper David James refused to shake hands at the end of the match. That was not included in the referee's report but Di Canio will want to tread carefully after being suspended for 11 matches for pushing Alcock, a referee, while playing for Sheffield Wednesday.

Last night his agent Matteo Roggi was not breathing fire. "I spoke with Paolo half an hour ago. He was very calm; he didn't mention anything about this. It means that Paolo has got nothing against his charge.

"When something has to do with Paolo, it always becomes bigger. But if he has done something bad and they have charged him, no problem. He will pay for what he has done, as happens to everyone."

York City have parted company with their manager Neil Thompson. The club, relegated last season, are 21st in the Third Division.

webTitle: Barnes faces the bullet from Celtic

fields.headline: Barnes faces the bullet from Celtic
fields.standfirst: Dalglish jets in for crisis talks after the worst result in the club's history
fields.trailText: John Barnes is expected to be told today that his apprenticeship as a football manager will no longer be conducted at Celtic after thousands of vitriolic fans protested over Tuesday night's 3-1 Scottish Cup defeat by Inverness Caledonian Thistle.
fields.body:
John Barnes is expected to be told today that his apprenticeship as a football manager will no longer be conducted at Celtic. His dismissal, after less than half a season in the job, is the only option the club has following the protests of thousands of vitriolic fans after Tuesday night's 3-1 Scottish Cup home defeat by Inverness Caledonian Thistle.

The fans bombarded the media yesterday, forcing a local radio station to install new lines, and their anger was felt throughout Glasgow. Schools reported excessive absenteeism while Celtic season-ticket holders were incensed that their bank accounts had already been debited by the club for the next round of the cup, in which they will not be involved.

At the same time the share price of Celtic plc, already at a low, continued to fall, wiping £3m off the club's value during morning training. By the end of the day the situation was even bleaker as the share price fell to 197.5p, a drop of 7% since the opening of the market. When the season started they were worth 320p a share.

Celtic's football director Kenny Dalglish flew back to Glasgow from the Spanish golfing resort of La Manga, where he had been watching the Nordic Cup tournament in search of new players. He was immediately involved in talks with the chief executive Allan MacDonald, who had been in meetings with the plc board.

After those talks MacDonald issued a statement that said: "Last night's performance was totally unacceptable to myself and fellow directors and simply not good enough for the Celtic support." That must lead to the logical conclusion that Barnes will go.

His situation was not improved when, in a radio interview, he claimed that the club was "still in the FA Cup". The talented former England international, who once coached the kids at Eton but whose appointment had always been regarded as high risk, has been cast as the villain of the piece.

Billy McNeill, captain of the 1967 European Cup-winning team and twice Celtic's manager, is considered to be the conscience of the club. He refused to blame Barnes directly, but said: "I may be old-fashioned in this but I do think that the supporters want to see players on the park who understand the history and the traditions of the place.

"That means that the team should be made up mainly of Scottish and Irish players who appreciate what is at stake here. There are too many foreigners in there."

The problem Barnes faces is that the allegations about his competence are specific and have been aired for months. In particular they concern the amount of money he has spent on players whom the fans regard as sub-standard for a club of this stature. They include Eyal Berkovic, Stilian Petrov, Olivier Tebily and Bobby Petta, acquired in a spending spree of over £15m. Celtic have recouped only £3m by selling Craig Burley to Derby County, a move with which the fans also disagreed.

fields.headline: The team
fields.standfirst: The men from Inverness Caledonian Thistle who laid waste to Celtic
fields.trailText: 1: Jim Calder, goalkeeper. A 40-year-old part-time builder who was the proverbial brick wall Celtic could bypass only once. Almost off-loaded to non-leaguers Strathspey Athletic six weeks ago. Last played against Celtic in 1985 as a centre-forward when Inverness Caley were a Highland League club.
fields.body:
1: Jim Calder, goalkeeper. A 40-year-old part-time builder who was the proverbial brick wall Celtic could bypass only once. Almost off-loaded to non-leaguers Strathspey Athletic six weeks ago. Last played against Celtic in 1985 as a centre-forward when Inverness Caley were a Highland League club.

2: Michael Teasdale, defender. Formerly with Dundee, he supported Celtic as a boy but has now made more than 150 appearances for Inverness.

3: Stuart Golabek, defender. Joined the club in the summer from local rivals Ross County but was born in Inverness.

4: Bobby Mann, defender. A real leader on the park who joined Inverness a year ago from lowly Forfar and has proved his quality.

5: Richard Hastings, defender. Accomplished Canadian international who caught a plane at 5am this morning to join his international colleagues on Gold Cup duty. Has games against Costa Rica and South Korea on February 13 and 15.

6: Paul Sheerin, midfielder. Looked to have missed his chance of the big time when released by then manager Graeme Souness at Southampton after three years. Joined Inverness from Alloa and converted vital match-sealing penalty last night. A committed Celtic fan, he had 38 friends and family at the match.

7: Ross Tokely, midfielder. Only 20 years old, he joined Inverness from Highland League outfit Huntly and has already been tipped for a greater things.

8: Mark McCulloch, midfielder. Inverness captain who recently passed the landmark of 100 games for the club after moving north from Dunfermline.

9: Barry Wilson, striker. Claimed Scottish football's last goal of the previous Millennium and the first of this, but nothing will have pleased the former Raith front man more than last night's opener.

10: Charlie Christie, midfielder. Acts as the club's community coach and was actually a Celtic reserve during the club's 1988 double-winning campaign as understudy to first-choice pairing Andy Walker and Frank McAvennie.

11: Dennis Wyness, forward. A recent £25,000 recruit from Scottish Premier League relegation strugglers Aberdeen. Some revenge for Celtic, having recorded an aggregate of 18-0 over the Dons in their three meetings this term.

webTitle: England at one with the elements

fields.headline: England at one with the elements
fields.trailText: With what was arguably their only faultless performance in this triangular one-day series, England went through to Saturday's final at the Wanderers, where they will play South Africa.
fields.body:
With what was arguably their only faultless performance in this triangular one-day series, England went through to Saturday's final at the Wanderers, where they will play South Africa.

Yesterday's final round-robin match, against Zimbabwe, was abandoned without a ball being bowled. This left England and Zimbabwe level on four points and because they had beaten each other in their two previous matches, net run-rate decided the issue; England's was better by 0.15 of a run, 0.03 against Zimbabwe's minus 0.12.

To say England blazed their way to the final, therefore, might be overstating matters. Squeegeed their way there, more like, having won only two of their six scheduled matches.

Yet in the context of captain Nasser Hussain's eve-of-match, Henry V-like rallying cry the England players did everything that was asked of them. There were no wides, no no-balls and no silly batting collapses. They were utterly focused.

In short, England played a blinder. While the Zimbabwe players frolicked and gambolled on the outfield, like children in a summer's meadow, in an effort to get play under way, the England boys glowered miserably in the bunker of their dressing room.

The last thing they wanted to do was go out of this competition by losing some 25-over regatta. They had failed to qualify for the Super Six stage of the World Cup because they had forgotten about the importance of their run-rate. And to be fair to them this was a factor they had in mind during their one-sided victories over South Africa in Bloemfontein and Zimbabwe in Kimberley.

Hussain said last night: "It is not often you can accuse me of throwing my wicket away, but that is what I have done in this series in order to get our run-rate up to where it is. We can't be criticised because it has rained for three days.

"Today, at the end, the umpire Cyril Mitchley called us together and said he didn't think it was fit. He said that if both teams really wanted to play they could put down mats and sawdust and stuff.

"Andy Flower obviously wanted to play. I thought it would be a bit of a farce and I didn't want to play. Nobody wants to go through like that.

"I still think that if we had played as we can, we would have beaten Zimbabwe here today even in a short game, and it would have been nice to take some confidence and form into the final. Now we feel very keen to get out of the hotel and actually do something."

Flower saw it differently. "I feel very disappointed. We were very hyped up for this game. We can't do anything about the weather, but I thought the conditions were okay to play from about 6.30.

"I think cricketers are a little precious some of the time. I think cricketers should be a bit tougher and play in conditions that aren't perfect. Having said that, I don't blame Nasser for taking the stance he did and in the same situation we would have had the same attitude. I just feel there should be more leeway when conditions are not quite perfect. We cricketers tip-toe around a little too much."

The rain did stop falling before the scheduled 2.30pm start, but the downpour had taken its toll. This is the third time in two tours that England's matches at this ground have been hit by the weather: the recent Test was reduced to 1 days' play, and the match here four years ago was also hit. Curiously, no other touring team has had weather problems at Centurion.

"We talked to both captains," Mitchley explained. "Having said that, it was down to the umpires and we felt that conditions were not fit. The pitch was okay and so were the run-ups. But there were damp areas on the edge of the square and the shorter the game the more of a circus it can become."

webTitle: Triple delight for Mohamed Al Fayed

fields.headline: Triple delight for Mohamed Al Fayed
fields.trailText: Neil Hamilton has been ordered to pay £500,000 towards the reported £2 million costs for his failed libel action against Harrods owner Mohamed Al Fayed, it was disclosed today.
fields.body:
Neil Hamilton has been ordered to pay £500,000 towards the reported £2 million costs for his failed libel action against Harrods owner Mohamed Al Fayed, it was disclosed today.

The high court has said Mr Hamilton has until 4pm on February 24 - a fortnight - to make the interim payment on account towards Mr Fayed's legal costs.

Mr Hamilton said tonight: "Of course I am aware of it, I consented to the order."

He was not prepared to make any further comment.

The order comes after Lord Harris of High Cross, who co-ordinated the former Conservative MP's "fighting fund" for the case, was given until February 25 to disclose the names of backers who had donated more than £5,000.

Mr Hamilton announced last month that he would not be mounting an appeal against the jury's decision in the action. He said he was "penniless" and an appeal would cost him tens of thousands of pounds.

It was the third legal ruling to go Mr Fayed's way today. The Court of Appeal decided that the Sun's publication of stills from a security video of Princess Diana and Dodi Fayed visiting a Parisian villa were in breach of copyright, and ordered The Sun to pay £45,000 in legal fees.

Mr Fayed has also won the right to challenge a decision denying him a judicial review of home secretary Jack Straw's refusal to grant him a British passport.

The right to mount the challenge comes after a high court hearing last October which upheld Mr Straw's decision that Mr Fayed was not fit to be a British citizen.

A spokesman for the home office said: "We are aware of the judgment but as this is part of an ongoing legal process we do not have any comment at this stage."

Mr Fayed said: "I have always held that Mr Straw's decision against me was unjust, unfair and biased, but I have always had great faith in British justice and remain quietly confident that my application will succeed in the end."

fields.headline: Nigeria 2 - 0 South Africa
fields.trailText:
Teams

Nigeria: Ike Shoronmu; Celestine Babayaro, Furo Iyenemi, Taribo West, Godwin Okpara, Finidi George, Sunday Oliseh, Mutiu Adepoju, Tijani Babangida, Nwankwo Kanu, Raphael Chukwu.

South Africa: Andre Arendse; Lucas Radebe, Mark Fish, Pierre Issa, Dumisa Ngobe, Thabo Mngomeni, John Moshoeu, Quinton Fortune, Helman Mkhalele, Shaun Bartlett, Siyabonga Nomvete.

Referee: Gamal el Ghandour (Egypt)
fields.body:
Teams

Nigeria: Ike Shoronmu; Celestine Babayaro, Furo Iyenemi, Taribo West, Godwin Okpara, Finidi George, Sunday Oliseh, Mutiu Adepoju, Tijani Babangida, Nwankwo Kanu, Raphael Chukwu.

South Africa: Andre Arendse; Lucas Radebe, Mark Fish, Pierre Issa, Dumisa Ngobe, Thabo Mngomeni, John Moshoeu, Quinton Fortune, Helman Mkhalele, Shaun Bartlett, Siyabonga Nomvete.

Referee: Gamal el Ghandour (Egypt)

1 GOAL Nigeria 1 - 0 South Africa A sensational start as Tijani Babangida scores after just 40 seconds for the favourites Nigeria, whose rugby-style huddle seems to have psyched the players up considerably as they kick off. The ball is worked forward to Babangida lurking on the left flank, and he cuts inside, accelerates unexpectedly and unleashes a low right-foot shot from the edge of the area which zips into the bottom right-hand corner of Andre Arendse's goal.

9 South Africa hit back and Quinton Fortune's free-kick from the right is headed out by Nigeria's towering defenders.

12 The game begins to settle into a pattern as South Africa sit deep before launching their fleet-footed midfield at a rigid Nigerian back four which nevertheless holds firm.

16 Finidi George concedes a free-kick on the left, taken by Manchester United's Quinton Fortune, but the Nigerian goalkeeper Ike Shorunmu saves easily.

20 Babangida suddenly finds himself through on goal as the South African defence loses concentration but Arendse is alert to the situation and the Oxford United goalkeeper plunges bravely at his feet to save. The danger is not yet over as the ball breaks to Raphael Chukwu but when a cool head is needed he blasts the ball over the bar.

27 Finidi works a short corner on the right, Furo Iyenemi gets his head to the ball first but it goes wide.

29 As Nigeria attack again Finidi's shot from a central position flies past the post. South Africa fight back and create their best chance so far, but Siyabonga Nomvete's shot from the left of the area hits the side netting.

35 GOAL Nigeria 2 - 0 South Africa Babangida scores again. In a typically direct Nigerian attack down the right, the ball is swiftly worked across the edge of the area to Babangida who is unmarked on the left. A quick look up, a stroke of the right foot and the ball is curling around Arendse and into the far top corner of the net.

45 Half-time and although South Africa have striven manfully, Nigeria have rarely been threatened. The onus is clearly now on the Bafana Bafana to attack, with Nigeria sitting comfortably around the halfway line and looking to close the game down.

45 South Africa restart and Alex Bapela wastes no time in dealing with the threat of Babangida, chopping the Ajax striker down in full flight to earn the Mamelodi Sundown forward the first booking of the match.

47 Nwankwo Kanu creates space on the right, Chukwu breaks free and as the goalkeeper advances he once more fails to keep a clear head, shooting hurriedly the wrong side of the post.

51 South Africa are looking more positive now and Bapela pops up in front of goal only to have his fierce shot well saved by Shorunmu.

53 Some Manchester United-Arsenal rivalry surfaces as Fortune is warned by the Egyptian referee Gamal Ghandous for a nasty foul on the Gunner Kanu.

57 Babangida is taken out again, this time by Mark Fish of Bolton Wanderers right on the edge of the area. Fish is booked, but after much consultation the Nigerians mess up the free-kick.

60 South Africa miss two golden opportunities, Fish's run and pull-back from the right touchline setting up Nomvete who mis-hits the ball in front of goal. It spins across to the unmarked Shaun Barlett but the FC Zurich striker blasts hopelessly wide.

64 South Africa are pushing forward desperately and Nomvete sees another good chance go to waste, his shot being hit straight at the goalkeeper. The striker then just fails to connect with a right-wing cross but it seems the game is drifting away from South Africa as the missed chances mount.

69 Nigeria substitution The star of the African Nations Cup so far, Julius Aghahowa, replaces Chukwu to rapturous applause. His first act is to set up Finidi for a shot which goes just over the bar.

74 A searing run by Babangida leaves Aghahowa with only the goalkeeper to beat but his shot is too low and Arendse beats it out with his knees. Nigeria are back in the ascendancy.

77 South Africa substitution Steve Lekoelea replaces the disappointing Fortune.

79 Nigeria's Godwin Okpara is booked for time wasting.

80 South Africa substitution Pollen Ndlanya replaces the misfiring Nomvete.

85 Babangida is named man of the match, unsurprisingly, as the heart begins to go out of South Africa and the trumpets of the celebrating Nigerians on the terraces grow ever louder.

89 Victor Ikpeba, who expected not to play after a row with the coach Jo Bonfrere, underlines Nigeria's superiority with a rasping shot which skims off the top of the crossbar.

96 Full time: Nigeria 2 - 0 South Africa. An unfeasible amount of injury-time but an emphatic performance by Nigeria. Can anyone stop them now?

An unfeasible amount of injury-time but an emphatic performance by Nigeria. Can anyone stop them now?

fields.headline: Welsh oust Blair's man
fields.standfirst: 'Reject' Morgan steps in as Michael forced to quit before vote of no confidence
fields.trailText: February 10 2000: 'Reject' Morgan steps in as Michael forced to quit before vote of no confidence
fields.body:
Rhodri Morgan was last night set to become first secretary in the Welsh assembly at his third attempt after Alun Michael was forced to resign the post minutes before a vote of no confidence was carried against him in Cardiff.

Within hours of doing so the man whom Tony Blair made his reluctant standard-bearer in Wales had any last hope of survival dashed when Labour's 28 assembly members made clear they would not re-submit his name to the assembly.

Instead they made the popular Mr Morgan acting first secretary, then agreed unanimously to put him forward for the job itself. Previously Mr Michael's economic minister, Mr Morgan will be ratified on Tuesday. There will be a price: wider consultation, especially with the Liberal Democrats.

Downing Street and Labour HQ at Millbank are acutely aware that Ken Livingstone, front-runner to be Labour's candidate for "devolved" mayor of London, will be watching for further attempts to steer events.

So they were quick to embrace Mr Morgan as as man they could do business with. "He's earned his spurs, there's no question of not being able to deal with him," said one party official. Mr Blair's spokesman said: "I know you think we're an absolute bunch of control freaks. But devolution has happened."

In the most dramatic day of political infighting since devolved governments took over in Wales and Scotland, Mr Michael finally abandoned a series of increasingly desperate manoeuvres to cling to office that left Mr Blair wrong-footed 150 miles away in Westminster.

The prime minister, who had backed Mr Michael to succeed Ron Davies despite grassroots support for Mr Morgan, knew at lunchtime of his protege's intention to stand down.

But he dared not reveal it when faced with William Hague's taunts at Commons question time lest Welsh voters concluded that - yet again - Downing Street and Millbank were calling the shots. Mr Blair was left looking silly.

In the event Mr Michael resigned at 3.08pm, minutes after the prime minister had expressed his "full confidence" in him. It allowed Tory MPs - who quickly heard the news on their pagers - to demand that Mr Blair promise not to interfere in the choice of Mr Michael's successor.

In reality the situation had long since slipped beyond Downing Street's control. Opposition assembly members in Cardiff used an attack on what was seen as Whitehall's lack of support for EU funding for south and west Wales to press home what was chiefly a personal attack on Mr Michael's uncharismatic and over-centralised style of management.

Last night Labour AMs met in secret session to decide how best to fill the leadership vacuum created by Mr Michael's decision to jump before being formally pushed by the combined 31-27 majority of the Tories, Plaid Cymru and Liberal Democrats. One Labour AM abstained.

Mr Michael, 57, the MP for Cardiff South and Penarth, became Welsh secretary and Downing Street's man in Wales after Ron Davies was forced to resign over his "moment of madness" on Clapham Common in October 1998.

But he only narrowly beat Cardiff West's Mr Morgan, 60, in Labour's electoral college. Under the proportional voting system, Mr Michael then scraped home as an AM only via the top-up list of members with no assembly constituency.

It was a shaky start that he failed to put right by bridge-building with either Labour voters or AMs in the minority administration he chose to set up - after spurning Lib Dem overtures for the kind of coalition created in Edinburgh.

Last night Plaid Cymru signalled that it would not now table the motion to strip the first secretary of his powers, and give them to the assembly as a body, as it would have done if Mr Michael had insisted on being renominated to the top post.

The assembly's speaker, Lord Dafydd Ellis-Thomas, rebutted suggestions that devolution was being reduced to chaos. "This is the beginning of true devolution because the assembly has asserted its views," he said.

webTitle: A bombshell, then oblivion for Alun Michael

fields.headline: A bombshell, then oblivion for Alun Michael
fields.trailText: February 10 2000: Just as opposition leaders prepared to oust him, the Welsh leader turned the tables in a final move that shocked Cardiff - and Westminster
fields.body:
Everybody had been expecting a day of high drama. No one had thought it would be quite as dramatic as this.

After months of threats from opposition parties to bring him down over the issue of European funding Alun Michael was playing to a packed audience, all there to see him meet his fate.

The assembly arithmetic was against him, members of his own Labour group were said to be plotting against him and opposition leaders had been sharpening their metaphors before sticking in the knife. It looked as if he would be forced to resign by a no confidence vote. Instead, Tony Blair's choice to lead the Labour party in Wales got his retaliation in first.

In a stunning move he formally submitted his resignation to the assembly's presiding officer Dafydd Elis Thomas, insisting that it was for Labour and not the Plaid Cymru-led opposition to determine who should lead the minority Labour administration in Cardiff. As journalists packed the assembly's public milling area, hoping to hear him explain his decision to stand down, Mr Michael slipped out of the chamber by a side entrance and into what may turn out to be political oblivion.

Last night he announced his intention to stand down as leader of the Labour party in Wales.

But it was not only the power of office which slipped quickly from his hands. The immediate effect of his demise was the stripping of the privileges that went with the high position. He will no longer have use of a spacious office overlooking Cardiff bay. His chauffeur-driven car also goes. In place of the £97,000 salary he has drawn as first secretary he will have to get by on the £34,000 paid to assembly members plus one third of his salary as an MP. Last night Mr Michael could have been forgiven for looking back ruefully on the Labour devolution dream and for asking how it had so quickly turned sour.

In truth it could be said he was dealt a bad hand. Relatively unknown, he was parachuted into Wales at Downing Street's behest after former Welsh secretary Ron Davies's "moment of madness" on Clapham common in October 1998. Opposition parties had kept up a non-stop barrage of criticism over his choice of a vegetarian agriculture secretary, his handling of the European funding issue and over what they claim was a dictatorial style of leadership that failed to take account of the fact that Labour is a minority power in the assembly.

But the former home office minister also had to live with the resentment felt by many Labour party activists in Wales at the way in which he was shoehorned into the role at the expense of the popular Cardiff West MP Rhodri Morgan.

Resentment at Millbank's handling of the leadership issue cost Labour dear at assembly elections last year and indirectly cost Mr Michael his job by delivering the party only 28 of the assembly's 60 seats. Disaffection saw many traditional Labour supporters go over to the nationalists. Plaid Cymru captured 17 seats.

Mr Morgan, who has loyally filled the role of economic development secretary in the Michael administration, has now been installed as acting first secretary. After twice losing out in contests for the party leadership - first to Ron Davies, then to Mr Michael - he now looks set at last to get his wish.

Opposition parties expect him to take a more robust line with the treasury on funding for the poorest regions of Wales than Mr Michael is said to have done. Yesterday in an emotional speech to assembly members Mr Michael rejected opposition assertions that he had failed to deliver for Wales. And with a certain flourish he made it clear it was not for them to choose the Labour leader.Turning to hand his written resignation to the presiding officer seated behind him he added: ""It is for the Labour party, my colleagues in the assembly Labour group and the representatives of the wider party to decide who should be presented to this assembly as our candidate for the role of first secretary."

This dramatic move caught not only gloating opposition members but even members of his own party on the hop. There was also understandable confusion and embarrassment for Labour in Westminster where it appeared at first that Tony Blair was unaware of his placeman's actions. Even as the prime minister was publicly praising the Welsh first secretary in the house, Mr Michael was delivering his well concealed bombshell.

Tories, alerted by vibrating pagers in pockets, delivered gleeful taunts believing they had caught Mr Blair with his parliamentary pants down. The prime minister's official spokesman later insisted that Mr Michael had communicated his desire to step down during a lunchtime conversation. Whatever the truth, the remarkable scenes added to the already fevered state that only a dramatic political event seems able to inspire.

Back in Wales as they emerged from the chamber, stunned Labour assembly members said they had no idea about Mr Michael's move. Val Feld, the Labour assembly member for Swansea east, said she felt Mr Michael had probably stepped down to spare the party further pressure. "He was clearly in a very difficult position. It was a complete surprise." Amid confusion in the chamber, the presiding officer insisted - to the fury of Labour members - on calling for a vote to be taken on the no confidence motion, which was carried by 31 to 27 with one abstention.

As the dust settled, Mr Blair found himself saying words which nine months ago he would have shuddered to utter. "Rhodri Morgan has impressed everyone with the total loyalty he has shown to Alun. His record in government has also been highly effective," he said. "I welcome his nomination as acting first secretary."

fields.headline: Magnanimous Morgan defends Blair
fields.trailText: February 10 2000: Rhodri Morgan, who is set to become the new first secretary of Wales, today was a picture of magnanimity as he defended prime minister Tony Blair against accusations of being a control freak.
fields.body:
Rhodri Morgan, who is set to become the new first secretary of Wales, today was a picture of magnanimity as he defended prime minister Tony Blair against accusations of being a control freak.

Generous and conciliatory in victory, Mr Morgan played down the notion that his third - and first successful - attempt to become first secretary represented a huge embarrassment for the prime minister.

"I don't think that's our first concern in Wales, to be honest, Mr Morgan said. "You could argue that it is the final proof that the canard that the Welsh assembly is being operated by remote control from 10 Downing Street is definitely untrue."

Mr Morgan replaces Alun Michael, who resigned yesterday minutes before losing a vote of no confidence in the most dramatic instance of political infighting since devolved governments took over in Wales and Scotland. Mr Michael was widely seen as the prime minister's man in Wales after former first Welsh secretary Ron Davies was forced to resign over his "moment of madness" on Clapham Common in October 1998. Mr Blair chose Mr Michael over Mr Morgan.

Despite being passed over, Mr Morgan refused to gloat and praised Labour for its initiative on devolution.

"Everybody refers to the Labour government under Tony Blair as being a bunch of control freaks," he said, "but actually they have given away more power than any other government in the last couple of hundred years."

Mr Morgan added: "It's an odd kind of control freak that gives away power to Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland and to London. This is part of a constitutional modernisation programme and I am glad to be part of it in Wales."

He rejected close comparisons between the Welsh assembly leadership drama and the London mayoral contest between Labour maverick Ken Livingstone and Frank Dobson, who is desperately fighting perceptions that he is Mr Blair's "stooge".

"I think the key thing is that if you are going to run for office, whether it is a big city like London or a small country like Wales, you have to show 110% commitment," Mr Morgan said. "I don't doubt that all of the candidates have that, but the perceptions are sometimes different."

Tory leader William Hague said Mr Michael's resignation illustrated Mr Blair's half-hearted attitude to devolution. "So far he has said he is in favour of devolving power in principle but he's not actually done it in practice. He tries to keep hold of all the levers of power, in London, and Scotland and Wales."

Mr Morgan is expected to be formally declared as Labour's candidate to fill the first secretary vacancy. Labour's candidate is almost certain to become first secretary in the election for the post. That election is expected to take place in the assembly early next week. Mr Morgan yesterday hinted that he would form a coalition with the Lib Dems, whose six seats would allow him to form an administration with a majority in the assembly.

webTitle: Barnes sacked as Dalglish holds the fort

fields.headline: Barnes sacked as Dalglish holds the fort
fields.trailText: John Barnes has been sacked as manager of Celtic. Barnes, along with assistant coach Eric Black, has had his contract at the club terminated. Terry McDermott will leave Parkhead by mutual agreement. Director of football Kenny Dalglish will take temporary charge of first team affairs.
fields.body:
John Barnes has been sacked as manager of Celtic. Barnes, along with assistant coach Eric Black, has had his contract at the club terminated. Terry McDermott will leave Parkhead by mutual agreement. Director of football Kenny Dalglish will take temporary charge of first team affairs.

At a press conference held this afternoon to announce Barnes' departure, Dalglish defended his protege's tenure. "John Barnes is an admirable fellow and someone I think will go on in later years to establish himself as very successful in managing a football club," he said. "Unfortunately it won't be at Celtic Football Club."

Dalglish was also strong in his support for McDermott, who had been the subject of some criticism in the press and labelled with the tag of Celtic's 'social manager'. "For people to suggest he was a social manager is an absolute joke. Terry worked hard for the club and received tremendous respect from all the players."

However, Dalglish reserved his most passionate words for the Celtic players. Claiming they shared an equal responsibility with the coaching staff for the club's current plight, Dalglish said: "The supporters demand that the players who wear the shirt wear it with pride. We want players who are totally committed. If they aren't they don't deserve to be here. We can accept bad results and performances but we can never accept anything less than 100% commitment."

Barnes' dismissal will not come as any surprise. His position has looked untenable since Celtic's shock 3-1 home defeat at the hands of Inverness Caledonian Thistle on Tuesday night, but rumbles of discontent have been echoing around Celtic Park almost ever since Barnes' appointment as manager last July.

There have been disputes over Barnes' tactics, over his coaching qualifications, and more recently over the standard of player he brought to the club: Eyal Berkovic, Olivier Tebily and Stilian Petrov are three of the big-money buys who have failed to impress the Parkhead faithful.

The club have given no indication as to how long it will take to find Barnes' permanent successo, chief executive Allan MacDonald insisting, "we won't sacrifice quality for speed."

fields.headline: NatWest surrenders today
fields.standfirst: Shareholders line up to support Royal Bank of Scotland takeover bid
fields.trailText: Shareholders line up to support Royal Bank of Scotland takeover bid
fields.body:
Royal Bank of Scotland was last night on the brink of a historic £23bn takeover of NatWest bank after a marathon battle with its closest rival, Bank of Scotland.

The NatWest board, chaired by Sir David Rowland, is expected to concede today that it has won insufficient support to retain NatWest's independence as leading shareholders pledged their support for Royal Bank.

Financial advisers to Royal Bank and NatWest began negotiations yesterday to try to agree to an orderly takeover ahead of the Valentine's day deadline by which shareholders must decide the fate of the clearing bank.

The NatWest board, which held an emergency session yesterday morning, had been reluctant to recommend a Royal Bank bid because of its sickly share price.

Royal Bank's shares fell a further 15% to end at £9.04 yesterday. Even in any acknowledgement of defeat, NatWest will find it difficult to "agree" to a deal.

Peter Burt, the chief executive of Bank of Scotland who started the audacious assault on NatWest in September, returned to Edinburgh from London where he had been due to lobby NatWest shareholders for support, although he was said to be still not quite ready to admit defeat.

Bankers explained the fall in Royal Bank's share price as signalling an expectation of victory yesterday as the City digested pledges of support from fund management groups Schroders, Mercury and Standard Life, which yesterday said that Royal's bid was less risky that the competing one from BoS. Tiger, a fund management group owning just under 1% of NatWest, also backed Royal Bank.

Overall, Royal Bank was thought to have mustered support from 35% of NatWest's shareholders although admitted to 18% publicly.

BoS has not issued a similar statement but Phillips & Drew, the seventh largest shareholder in NatWest, has backed Mr Burt and his team.

Royal Bank's falling share price served to slash the price of its offer, made up of cash and shares, to £12.70.

BoS' shares rose by 57p to 670p, increasingly the value of its offer but reflecting expectation that it might become a bid target, while NatWest's rose by 6p to £11.50, still below the level of Royal's bid.

The largest shareholder in NatWest, Prudential, which holds a 5% stake, refused to make its decision public last night. But that failed to quash rumours that it, too, would put its weight behind the Royal Bank bid.

The Pru has been in a difficult position after its management signed a commercial deal with BoS to sell insurance in NatWest branches if its bid were successful

"The market clearly has decided that it does not wish NatWest to remain independent, and you have to conclude that Royal Bank is ahead of BoS," a senior fund manager said last night.

But despite the apparent weight of support for Royal Bank, veterans of the fierce battle remained reluctant to call the endgame, and still worried about the possibility of a split vote, especially if Pru backed BoS. However, given the violent move in yesterday's share prices, it was apparent that if BoS was eventually the victor it would be the most stunning turnaround in recent corporate history.

BoS now faces speculation that it will become a takeover target, despite a low cost base making it difficult for a predator to achieve cost savings.

Speculation continued to linger in the market that Lloyds TSB, which is due to report its 1999 profits tomorrow, would find it difficult to resist a bid for Royal Bank which would spoil its takeover of NatWest. The City pointed to the two-week gap between clinching any deal with NatWest and a Royal Bank meeting of its shareholders to back the deal as a predator's window of opportunity.

BoS has not issued a similar statement but Phillips & Drew, the seventh largest shareholder in NatWest, has backed Mr Burt and his team. Royal Bank's falling share price served to slash the price of its offer, made up of cash and shares, to £12.70. BoS' shares rose by 57p to 670p, increasingly the value of its offer but reflecting expectation that it might become a bid target, while NatWest's rose by 6p to £11.50, still below the level of Royal's bid. The largest shareholder in NatWest, Prudential, which holds a 5% stake, refused to make its decision public last night. But that failed to quash rumours that it, too, would put its weight behind the Royal Bank bid. The Pru has been in a difficult position after its management signed a commercial deal with BoS to sell insurance in NatWest branches if its bid were successful "The market clearly has decided that it does not wish NatWest to remain independent, and you have to conclude that Royal Bank is ahead of BoS," a senior fund manager said last night. But despite the apparent weight of support for Royal Bank, veterans of the fierce battle remained reluctant to call the endgame, and still worried about the possibility of a split vote, especially if Pru backed BoS. However, given the violent move in yesterday's share prices, it was apparent that if BoS was eventually the victor it would be the most stunning turnaround in recent corporate history. BoS now faces speculation that it will become a takeover target, despite a low cost base making it difficult for a predator to achieve cost savings. Speculation continued to linger in the market that Lloyds TSB, which is due to report its 1999 profits tomorrow, would find it difficult to resist a bid for Royal Bank which would spoil its takeover of NatWest. The City pointed to the two-week gap between clinching any deal with NatWest and a Royal Bank meeting of its shareholders to back the deal as a predator's window of opportunity.

fields.headline: Oxfam quits campaign in protest
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Plans for a flagship United Nations conference on tackling the education crisis in developing countries were thrown into confusion last night when a leading aid agency resigned from the conference's international organising committee.
fields.body:
Plans for a flagship United Nations conference on tackling the education crisis in developing countries were thrown into confusion last night when a leading aid agency resigned from the conference's international organising committee.

With two months to go before the conference in Dakar, Senegal, Oxfam announced it was pulling out of the Unesco-led committee because the plans so far offered nothing for the world's poorest children, 125m of whom are not at school.

Accusing the international organisations and western donors of a lack of political will, the agency said that the draft blueprint for the Dakar conference was "woefully inadequate".

"This conference should be doing for education what the earth summit did for the environment, which is putting it at the top of the agenda and coming up with practical strategies," said Kevin Watkins, senior policy officer at Oxfam. "At the moment, it is seen as a teddy bears' picnic for international bureaucrats."

The Dakar forum marks the 10th anniversary of the international pledge on basic education for all, which was supposed to have been achieved this year.

In many countries education enrolment rates have got worse rather than improved since 1990 and the target date has been moved to 2015. However, aid agencies doubt that even this target will be met unless world political leaders throw their weight behind it.

"The draft framework is little more than a set of vaguely worded reaffirmations of past principles and already agreed human development targets. It lacks any strategy for mobilising the resources or achieving the wider reforms needed to deliver on the right to education," said Oxfam's letter of resignation.

It added: "Having shamefully failed to deliver on the commitments they made 10 years ago, governments are being asked to sign on to a blueprint that commits them to nothing - and which will deliver nothing."

Oxfam is particularly critical of the lack of any financial targets in the draft framework. The agency estimates that the cost of delivering universal primary education is $8bn ($4.9bn) a year for the next 10 years, and wants the west to stump up half of that sum, in return for firm commitments from developing countries that they will cut spending on arms and put the money into education instead.

Dieter Berstecher, the head of the organising committee at Unesco, said Oxfam's appeal for a $4bn global education fund was unrealistic.

"The remedies are not cash payments from the north but more commitment from governments in the south," Mr Berstecher said, adding that Oxfam's contention that third world education was in crisis was not helpful.

"There is a lot of good news," he said.

webTitle: Lobby briefings part of new Downing Street site

fields.headline: Lobby briefings part of new Downing Street site
fields.standfirst:
The new site reviewed by Victor Keegan

Download the Number 10 screensaver

Downing Street site
fields.trailText: Downing Street spin doctor Alastair Campbell's daily briefings to the Westminster lobby - hitherto known only to a few political correspondents - will soon be available online.
fields.body:
Downing Street spin doctor Alastair Campbell's daily briefings to the Westminster lobby - hitherto known only to a few political correspondents - will soon be available online.

The move is part of a relaunch of the Number Ten Downing Street site today. The new site includes live broadcasts of the weekly Prime Minister's questions from Parliament, a 3-D tour around the building, regular online interviews with ministers (Health secretary Alan Milburn is scheduled to be the first) and extensive background to current issues.

The Downing Street site was last launched two years ago and was extensively criticised for dated design and - like other government sites - being updated irregularly. On that point, the site's administrators say that updates will be instant.

"The net is part of the media now," says Campbell. "Any major organisation that doesn't communicate on the net isn't doing its job properly."

However, there are concerns that the site's three staff will not be able to cope with the problems of moderating the new consultation boards (where the public can be involved in government policy planning) as well as administering a constantly changing site.

Redesigned by Bates Interactive, the new media agency which is behind the widely acclaimed Foreign & Commonwelath Office site, it's cost the taxpayers over £75,000 - and the website's annual budget is £133,000.

The site also plans to produce a gallery of Number 10 artwork and as well as a foreign language section.

webTitle: Boo's Swedish founder to spend more time with his family

fields.headline: Boo's Swedish founder to spend more time with his family
fields.standfirst:
Boo.com
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: One of the three founders of Boo.com, the troubled online sportswear retailer, has decided to return to his native Sweden to "spend more time with his family".
fields.body:
One of the three founders of Boo.com, the troubled online sportswear retailer, has decided to return to his native Sweden to "spend more time with his family".

Executive chairman Patrik Hedelin has taken on a non-executive role and will no longer be involved in day to day operational activities with the London-based company, a spokes woman confirmed. Mr Hedelin, who last year co-founded Boo.com with Ernst Malmsten and Kajsa Leander and is understood to hold around 15% of the equity, said he would remain in close contact with the company and offer "strategic advice".

Boo.com raised a record sum for a European start-up but has been dogged by technological problems and bad publicity. However, Mr Hedelin insisted that his decision to return home had nothing to do with Boo's difficulties.

"It was always clear that I would move back to Sweden at some stage," 30-year-old Mr Hedelin said last night from his home in Stockholm.

"I have a wife and two young children here and wanted to spend more time with them. Ernst and Kajsa understand that. We remain close and will talk about the company often."

He said that he may pursue other internet opportunities as long as they did not conflict with his commitments to Boo.

Mr Hedelin, a corporate financier by profession, played a key role in helping Boo.com attract investment from backers including LVMH chairman Bernard Arnault and the Benetton family.

He said Boo's new finance director, Dean Hawkins, who used to be second-in-command at Adidas, will take on his operational commitments.

Boo.com is in the process of reducing its 400-strong staff by around 25%, Mr Hedelin confirmed. Some 35 jobs will be lost with the closing of an online magazine.

"In the race to launch we built up very fast and are now reducing our cost base," he said. "Moving to breakeven quicker will help our valuation. Every fast-growing start- up suffers a bit of turbulence and it has been a rough week or so. But all the staff have been reassured about what we are doing and we are confident for the future."

Pointing to a recent report from Credit Suisse First Boston, which rated Boo as having the best fulfilment record of any online retailer in the US over Christmas, he said: "Some of things we are achieving are incredible."

webTitle: Straw urged to act in race case

fields.headline: Straw urged to act in race case
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The family of two black men found hanging in Telford demanded yesterday that the home secretary intervene to take away from West Mercia police the control of the investigation after a loss of faith in the force's ability to carry it through.
fields.body:
The family of two black men found hanging in Telford demanded yesterday that the home secretary intervene to take away from West Mercia police the control of the investigation after a loss of faith in the force's ability to carry it through.

But West Mercia police rejected demands that they hand over to Scotland Yard the investigation into the deaths of Harold "Errol" McGowan and Jason McGowan. The men had died within six months of each other after an alleged campaign of racial harassment.

Yesterday, Peter Hampson, West Mercia's chief constable, met the family who say that they want to meet the home secretary to urge him to order West Mercia to surrender control of the investigation to Scotland Yard.

In a statement yesterday Sinead McGowan, the widow of Jason, said: "We reiterate that the family has no confidence in West Mercia police to carry out a proper investigation. We can confirm that New Scotland Yard were willing and prepared to take on the investigation if the chief constable agreed. Peter Hampson admitted that he did not ask the question. We are now considering withdrawing our cooperation from the force that ignores the family's wishes."

The McGowans' latest demand followed an agreement by West Mercia to reinvestigate the two deaths and to call in Scotland Yard for advice, after family protests.

The family says police were too quick to dismiss the death of Harold McGowan, 34, in July 1999, as suicide, since he had been subjected to harassment and death threats by a white racist gang. Jason, 20, his nephew, who investigated his uncle's death, was also found hanging.

Mrs McGowan has lodged a complaint with the police complaints authority saying the inquiry into Jason's death was bungled through racism.

webTitle: New CPS job for race case lawyer

fields.headline: New CPS job for race case lawyer
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The crown prosecution service is to make a donation to the Stephen Lawrence Memorial Fund and will promote a top crown prosecutor, to avoid an embarrassing race discrimination hearing by an employment tribunal this week.
fields.body:
The crown prosecution service is to make a donation to the Stephen Lawrence Memorial Fund and will promote a top crown prosecutor, to avoid an embarrassing race discrimination hearing by an employment tribunal this week.

If the race discrimination case had gone ahead, the director of public prosecutions, David Calvert-Smith, would have had to undergo cross-examination by Maria Bamieh, who has already won two tribunal cases alleging race discrimination and victimisation by the CPS.

She won a record payout of £30,000 for injury to feelings last week after an employment tribunal in Bedford found that the service was determined to get rid of her and wanted to "rub her face in the dirt". The tribunal said the conduct of the CPS fell below the standard "we would have expected of a corner shop".

The service has been hit by 22 claims of race discrimination since 1993. Last month it launched an independent inquiry under threat of a formal investigation by the commission for racial equality.

Black and Asian lawyers accused the service of institutional racism and claimed they were unfairly denied equal access to promotion.

Ms Bamieh, a senior lawyer, has been the most persistent in those accusations.

She was offered £110,000 to leave the CPS, but was determined to keep her job.

Papers disclosed to the Bedford tribunal show that Mr Calvert-Smith told her at one meeting that if she were promoted now, it would seem that a troublemaker had won.

Yesterday the CPS said it had apologised to her and would promote her to a more senior position in the diversity unit.

"The settlement is seen by both parties as a real opportunity for a clean break to take place and a fresh start," a spokesman added.

fields.headline: Rise of the silver surfers
fields.standfirst: The net is not just for the young. Andy Farquarson meets the old folk at home with the new technology
fields.trailText: The net is not just for the young. Andy Farquarson meets the old folk at home with the new technology
fields.body:
'The internet is totally addictive: the more you delve into it, the more possibilities you find," says Roma Gaite. The sprightly 83 year old is seated at the computer in the foyer of Archer Court, a development of self-contained retirement flats close to Salisbury city centre.

We are joined by Stephanie Brown, 58, who has come to check her email. Both women are newcomers to the internet and part of the UK's growing army of "silver surfers" - older people who are discovering the wired world. "I'd never thought of getting online until I came to Archer Court," says Roma. "In fact, I'd never used a computer until last year."

"The internet is certainly not just for the young," says Stephanie. "Why should they have all the fun?"

Gabrielle Brooks of the charity Age Concern would concur. "Communications technology can enrich the life of all age groups," she says. "Every forecast predicts the number of British silver surfers will increase dramatically in the next year or two." In the US, the over-55 age group has been the fastest growing sector of American internet users.

Stephanie Brown mainly uses the Archer Court computer to keep in touch. "My brother in Belgium is very busy, his phone is usually tied up and he gets little time to write letters. But he always looks at his email at work and finds mine among it," she explains.

Roma Gaite's first love, however, is the web. "I find it easier and quicker to pick up the phone than to email," she says. "I am much more interested in exploring the internet. There's so much to learn and it keeps my mind active." Roma, Stephanie and their fellow residents enjoy free internet access as part of a Bournemouth university pilot project to bring internet skills to older people.

The university's history of technology unit has teamed up with Archer Court's builder McCarthy & Stone, Britain's largest specialist provider of retirement housing. Other partners include NTL, the cable company, which supplied the internet service and online-time, and Dixons, which has donated five refurbished computers.

The pilot project has been very successful, says James Poxon of McCarthy & Stone. "We have installed computers in five of our developments and dozens of people at each site have used them. The residents are lively-minded individuals and quickly overcome any initial reserve. Once they see that pressing the wrong key doesn't matter, there's no stopping them."

Frances Cambrook, a Bournemouth university research fellow, has trained the McCarthy & Stone residents in computer skills, web navigation and e-communication. "In future, people will carry IT skills from work into retirement. But just now, most older people are having to learn how to use the internet if they are to avoid becoming part of the information-poor.

"Besides, communications technology can provide productive leisure activity - and that aspect is ideally suited to retired people who have the time to exploit it." The social potential of communications technology is particularly attractive to older people." There are often four or five of us round the machine," says Stephanie Brown. "We offer one another help, hints and suggestions, and share our experience. The computer has become part of our social life and the sessions are great fun."

Roma Gaite agrees: "It's a myth that the internet isolates users. Here it has helped bring people together, to re-inforce the community spirit." The Bournemouth project is one of several initiatives tailored to older people. Last year, for example. Age Concern set up the UK's first chatroom for over-50s. Its Baby Boomer Bistro is an online virtual cafe where users can discuss everything from politics to poetry. Specialised areas include higher education, a debating forum, the environment and spiritual matters.

The charity also runs a network of regional Age Resource Desks giving local information to older people. Linked to the government's IT for All"initiative, many of the desks provide tuition in new technologies, IT training and computer "taster" sessions.

The Saga Group, which provides services to the over-50s, offers computer skills special interest holidays. "These have proved very popular," says Michael Pritchett, Saga's head of digital media, "and the technology and internet column in Saga Magazine attracts more interest among our two million readers than almost any other feature. The internet is increasingly accessible and older people are flocking to it. It's gaining momentum all the time."

This would come as no surprise to Roma Gaite. "The internet has a tremendous amount to offer us," she says. "Surfing is exciting, fascinating and fun however old you are."

 Further information can be obtained from: Age Concern 0208 765 7610; McCarthy & Stone 0800 919 132; Saga Holidays 0800 0565880
www.babyboomerbistro.org.uk

fields.headline: Going, Coming and Staying put
fields.trailText: THE END IN THE EAST END
fields.body:
THE END IN THE EAST END

Surprise! John Barnes has been sacked as Celtic manager two days after his team's abject capitulation against Inverness Caledonian Thistle. Kenny Dalglish, Celtic's director of golf and football, is understood to be taking charge of Celtic's next game, at Dundee, and legendary defender Danny McGrain has been promoted to assistant manager with coach Kenny McDowall.

Barnes' eight-month reign has been beset by problems. His players revolted over an innovative 4-1-1-1-1-1-1 formation. Henrik Larsson was ruled out for the season with a shattered leg. Rangers took a ten-point lead in the league. And big-money buys such as Eyal Berkovic, Olivier Tebily and Stilian Petrov were described either as "failures" or "****ing useless ******s", depending on whether you were reading opinion pieces in the press or talking to a drunk bloke in an Irish theme pub in Glasgow's East End.

Tuesday night's Cup howler against Caley Thistle was always going to be a gaffe too far for the fast-talking Englishman, especially when reports of the row Celtic enjoyed at half-time were published. According to the Mirror, bother started when Mark Viduka threw off his boots, accused Barnes of tactical naivety and was substituted. Keeper Jonathan Gould disagreed, arguing that Berkovic was the man at fault and should step down instead. This suggestion caused Barnes to retort: "Shut up! You've not come off your line for six months!" Blimey.

And so it's over. But the Fiver thinks there's a lesson to be learned here for both Barnes and Celtic. Because after letting in two during the first half, Celtic only conceded one during the second. See, talking does help.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

SING-A-LONGA STANLEY

Stanley is out. The six-month bedroom siege is over and this morning, his mother's eyes welling with tears of pride, Stanley became a Fox. Martin O'Neill believes Stanley will be a "magnificent asset" to the club: "We've given him a chance. What really happens now is up to him." But in this moment of intense joy, it seems inappropriate for the Fiver to warble on. Instead we'll let Stanley do the talking himself. Accompanied by a medley of inspiring pop classics.

"Obviously, most people regard taking me on as a risk, for whatever reasons, but it's a case of me forgetting the hype and getting on with my football." Take a chance take a chance take a take a chance chance. "I want to play well and score goals. I want to be regarded as one of the best goalscorers in the country." That's what my daddy told me when I was just about knee high.

"As long as people are fair with me, I have never not admitted when I have done things wrong. But there has been a lot of myth." Stonehenge, where the virgins lie, and the prayers of devils fill the midnight sky. "All I am saying to people is I want to be given the opportunity to have a future." A good heart these days is hard to find, so please be gentle with this heart of mine...

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Away from the park we don't socialise and we don't talk. But newspapers have been trying to say that if I get the ball, I won't pass to him and if Teddy gets it he won't pass to me. MURRAY NOT MINTED ENOUGH

Three ways to cover up a humiliating failure to sign a top international striker: 1) get the manager of your local rivals sacked; 2) get some seriously substantial legal documentation which proves you could have bought him if you'd wanted to; 3) offer up a lame excuse.

Rangers guvnor David Murray is so big time he only went and used all three excuses today after abandoning an ambitious £12m move for Dynamo Kiev striker Sergei Rebrov. First John Barnes waved bye-bye. A taste for vodka at breakfast? A love of pontoon and strip poker sessions with Andriy Shevchenko and Andrei Kanchelskis? It could be anything. Apart from the fact that a bunch of Euro no-hopers in a league Aberdeen can't get relegated from aren't the most attractive proposition in the world, of course.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Norwegian international striker Andreas Lund is set to join Wimbledon. Lund, who plays for Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's former club Molde, has been linked with both Coventry and Spurs in the past. Molde manager Olav Boksasp said today: "Wimbledon and Molde have agreed on an outline agreement over the transfer of Andreas Lund."

According to reports, Bixente Lizarazu of Bayern Munich and France underwent a strenuous medical at Anfield yesterday.

Middlesbrough have joined the list of English clubs prepared to sign Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink if his stay at Atletico Madrid comes to a premature end.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

The FA will not be investigating allegations that former chiefs Sir Bert Millichip and Ted Croker profited from their alleged involvement in PEL Stadium Seating following the Hillsborough disaster. PEL made millions from converting terraces to seating areas as recommended by Lord Justice Taylor's report into the tragedy. Millichip had no involvement in PEL while he was FA chairman and is seeing legal advice. Former FA chief executive Graham Kelly has insisted that the late Croker's name will also be cleared.

Scotland and the Republic of Ireland are to meet in a friendly in Dublin on Tuesday May 30.

Hibernian have completed the signing of 28-year old central defender Martin McIntosh from Stockport for £250,000.
