webTitle: Bad mouthing  Muse excluded from Beckett extravaganza

fields.headline: Bad mouthing  Muse excluded from Beckett extravaganza
fields.trailText: Samuel Beckett's muse and regular collaborator Billie Whitelaw has been excluded from an ambitious television plan to film his 19 plays.
fields.body:
Samuel Beckett's muse and regular collaborator Billie Whitelaw has been excluded from an ambitious television plan to film his 19 plays.

An array of acting and directing talent has been lined up to transfer all the plays to celluloid for the first time, but Whitelaw, who created many of the roles, is not among them.

Names such as Emma Thompson, John Malkovich, Alan Rickman, Jeremy Irons, John Gielgud, John Hurt and Judi Dench are in line to star in the films with directors including Richard Eyre, John Boorman and Tom Stoppard. Although some of the casting decisions are yet to be confirmed, the plans are largely in place.

Each of the plays, which range from the two-act Waiting for Godot to the 45-second Breath, will be filmed this year.

The Irish broadcaster RTE is the biggest contributor to the £4m project to create a lasting collection which will be broadcast in Ireland this autumn, and next year on Channel 4.

The executive producer of the project, Joe Mulholland confirmed that RTE and the production company Blue Angel are not in negotiations with Whitelaw.

He said: "Many people have been approached and it's a question of choosing the best people for the particular plays."

He said it was still possible that the actress, famed for her interpretation of Beckett's work, might form part of the millennium project.

However, some of Whitelaw's best-known roles in Beckett's plays have already been allotted to other actresses. Two films, What Where and Endgame, featuring Michael Gambon and David Thewlis, have been shot by directors Damien O'Donnell and Conor McPherson.

Artist Damien Hirst will film Breath, a 45-second long scream, while Not I will star the Hollywood actress, Julianne Moore, directed by Neil Jordan. The role, for which Whitelaw had to have her head clamped for her early performances, features a disembodied, heavily lipsticked mouth confessing its memories to a listening auditor.

Mr Mulholland decided to film the works after the success of the Dublin Gate Theatre's production of the full canon, which travelled to New York and the Barbican under the artistic direction of Michael Colgan.

Mr Colgan's role was key to persuading the notoriously strict Beckett estate, which will only allow his plays to be produced with a strict adherence to his stage directions. His production company, Blue Angel, is behind the films.

Several of the plays will be broadcast by Channel 4 in its schools schedule following the addition of Beckett to the national curriculum. But Mr Mulholland said he was keen for the films to bring Beckett to a wider audience. "We hope this will make his work far more accessible to far more people," he said.

Terse essays in obscurity

Act Without Words 1

A mime for one actor, Samuel Beckett's text is entirely stage directions, such as: "The man is flung backwards on stage from right wing. He falls, gets up immediately, dusts himself off, turns aside, reflects. Whistle from right wing. He reflects, goes out right."

Happy Days

A woman literally sinks into the ground while she continues to discuss trivialities.

Come and Go
A playlet or "dramaticule", in Beckett's words, it contains 121 words, spoken by three characters.

Rockaby
One of his last plays, it lasts 15 minutes and is famous for the image of Billie Whitelaw as the woman rocking herself to death to the sound of her recorded voice.

Not I
A disembodied "mouth" recalls memories to a silent "auditor"; a challenge which forced Billie Whitelaw's head to be clamped to stop it moving for the first performance.

fields.headline: Torrential African storms kill 50
fields.trailText: South Africa began sending emergency relief by air yesterday to neighbouring Mozambique where floods have swollen rivers, isolated cities and left 100,000 people homeless.
fields.body:
South Africa began sending emergency relief by air yesterday to neighbouring Mozambique where floods have swollen rivers, isolated cities and left 100,000 people homeless.

More than 50 people have drowned across southern Africa and tens of thousands of acres of farmland has been washed away after rivers burst their banks. Torrential rain has fallen in the region continuously since the weekend.

In South Africa, the national parks authority closed swamped rest camps in the Kruger national park. More than 17in of rain has fallen in the past four days there.

"There is no way to reach the north of the park from the south inside the park," said its chief warden, Antoinette van Wyk. Parts of the commercial capital Johannesburg have been severely affected.

In Botswana, dams were overflowing and mud huts in villages disintegrating.

The Mozambican capital Maputo, with a population of a million, was cut off by the rising waters and entry to the city was said to be impossible.

South African officials said helicopters and boats were plucking people left clinging on to trees, stranded on rooftops and even standing waist-deep on top of agricultural machines.

Mozambique's president, Joaquim Chissano, said yesterday that his government would appeal to the international community for assistance.

Many people are missing and the final death toll is expected to rise sharply. Vast areas of Maputo and nearby Matola have been turned into swamps and health authorities have warned of outbreaks of malaria and cholera.

A water treatment station has broken down, making clean water scarce in Maputo, and pumping stations in other areas have been swept away. At least 32,000 acres of crops in southern Mozambique have been lost to floods, said Armindo Chivangue, an official of the natural disasters management institute.

No emergency food supplies were needed, Mr Chivangue said, but farmers would need fresh supplies of corn, bean and vegetable seeds after the floods.

The Norwegian prime minister, Kjell Magne Bondevik, in Mozambique on an official visit, announced yesterday that Norway would make £60,000 available to help the flood victims.

The country's main north-south highway, which had been impassable because of flooding for five days, was provisionally repaired yesterday.

Many of the homeless were sheltering in schools, community halls and on rugby fields.

Forecasters warned that the low pressure weather system was moving towards South Africa's Free State and North West provinces. The rains have been described as the heaviest since 1958. Some rivers are at their highest for 50 years.

More than 100 foreign tourists have been stranded in luxury South African game reserves between Mpumalanga and the Northern Province.

 Paul Fauvet is a Reuters correspondent

fields.headline: Today man's £310,000 for Blair book
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: James Naughtie, who presents Radio 4's Today programme, has signed a deal believed to be worth £310,000 to write an unauthorised account of the relationship between Tony Blair and Gordon Brown.
fields.body:
James Naughtie, who presents Radio 4's Today programme, has signed a deal believed to be worth £310,000 to write an unauthorised account of the relationship between Tony Blair and Gordon Brown.

Details of the book were being kept secret last night, but it is understood that Mr Naughtie will examine the heart of the government by focusing on the relationship between the pair. He was not thought to have told either man about his deal last night.

Literary sources speculated yesterday that the publisher, Fourth Estate, had paid too much for a political book after the company took part in a closed auction with eight other publishers.

Usually only a former prime minister could generate enough interest to attract such a fee. However, Mo Mowlam was reported to have sold the rights to her autobiography for £350,000 in December.

To avoid accusations that Mr Naughtie might compromise his position as co-presenter of Today by writing the book, it will not be published until after the next election.

Yet BBC sources suggested last night that the deal might still put some noses out of joint. Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's press secretary, is known for his eagerness to express displeasure at Today's treatment of the government and would be swift to react, warned one insider.

Mr Naughtie's fellow Today presenter, John Humphrys, caused controversy last year with his book Devil's Advocate. Senior BBC executives were livid at his open criticism of the corporation's news organisation.

Sources close to the deal said it would generate interest for its novel take on politics rather than for scandal. A source said: "The publishers got very excited about the idea of a book about politics which won't just appeal to political people."

Mr Naughtie has known Mr Blair and Mr Brown for a number of years from his time working for the Scotsman newspaper. He used to share a flat with Mr Brown.

A source said he intended to cover the rivalries and politics of the Labour party through their personal relationship and hinted that there would be previously uncovered stories.

webTitle: Spot the source: Harry Potter explained

fields.headline: Spot the source: Harry Potter explained
fields.standfirst: In this essay taken from the current print                                                edition of the London Review of Books, appearing online exclusively at Books Unlimited, comparative mythologist Wendy Doniger investigates why we love the wizard of Hogwarts
fields.trailText: Comparative mythologist Wendy Doniger investigates why we love the wizard of Hogwarts
fields.body:
Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban by JK Rowling (Bloomsbury, 317 pp, £10.99, 0 7475 4215 5)

Young Harry Potter's parents are dead. So far, so good: many of the heroes and heroines of the classics of children's literature are orphans, while others have invisible, unmentionable or irrelevant parents. The sorrow of grieving, not to mention the terror of helplessness, is quickly glossed over in favour of the joy of a fantasised freedom. (A particularly sharp 13-year-old patiently explained to me that if Harry's parents weren't dead, there would be no point in writing the book: it wouldn't be interesting, no matter how many creative details there were.)

The problem, for Harry Potter as for most orphans in children's books, is not the absence of parents but the presence of step-parents. American children have protested, in places as sophisticated as the New Yorker's 'Talk of the Town', against this insult to their intelligence.

A stupider fight has been waged by parents (some of whom identify themselves as 'born-again Christians' and are known to others as the Mullahs of the Midwest) who have outlawed the Harry Potter books in American schools; legal challenges have been filed in at least eight states, and some evangelical ministers have preached against the books' satanic allegiance. Apparently, their astonishing popularity is taken as evidence of a Faustian bargain, the work of the devil. (How else can you get on the New York Times bestseller list?)

In an ironic twist, some parents have cited the First Amendment and argued that witchcraft (i.e. the Potterian heresy) should not be taught in school because it is a religion; somehow this has failed to ignite the watchful passions of the American Civil Liberties Union. 'I realised that it's for my own sake that I'm not listening,' one child whose parents forbade him to listen to Potter readings reported. 'There's a lot about witchcraft and evil and spells and magic. I was taught at church that that was not good.' No doubt C.S. Lewis's Narnia books slipped through because of their thinly veiled Christian message (Aslan as the Lamb of God), not to mention their anti-Muslim message (the worshippers of the evil Tash are dark-skinned men in turbans). On the other hand, when Lewis's books were first published, covens of real witches were not as prominent as they are now; always popular, Narnia is enjoying a resurgence in Harry's wake.

Events at Columbine High School last year may explain the reaction of some American parents who have opposed the Harry Potter books. The students who shot and killed their classmates said they were out to get the school bullies, and were themselves part of a widespread teen cult inspired to some degree by The Matrix (the students dressed like the film's heroes). The Matrix invoked the ancient criteria of rule-breaking excellence - innovation, courage, creativity - but also of lawlessness and anarchy: the film imagines a world of computers that create an alternative reality through the kind of mind control that is also at the heart of Harry Potter's magic. (The Matrix even exploits the banality of magic: the oracle is a woman just like your aunt, who bakes cookies and has magnets on her fridge.)

The alternative reality of The Matrix is made possible by a new, computer magic (nouveau-Orientalist rather than vieux-Brit) which is both the medium of the film (its stunning special effects) and its message, the antinomian ethic of the new capitalism. This greedy, solipsistic ethic extends far beyond the film; television advertisements for some computer products boast of 'breaking the rules, remaking the rules'. This is understandably scary stuff for the more repressive sort of parents (who may also be troubled by the popularity of the premise of their own dispensability in books such as these). It gives them nightmares that make them want to burn Harry Potter at the stake.

Harry Potter, too, has moments of computer magic: a more banal version of his magic map which shows people moving on its surface is available at most Hertz and Avis headquarters, not to mention in high-tech alarm systems. But most of the magic is of another kind, dependent on education and mental training. Indeed, where the protests go wrong is in assuming that, since magic does not seem to obey the rules of either science or religion, it has no rules at all. This is certainly not the case. Harry Potter must abide, not only by the complex moral rules of magic, but even by the moral rules dictating when to use, and when not to use, magic. More important, the world of Harry Potter is deeply coloured by a Victorian code of public-school loyalty that offers a positive antidote to the 'no holds barred' capitalism of the computer world which some parents have wrongly conflated with the world of magic.

In its original form, the code represented a kind of parity among the privileged, a noblesse oblige that gave a veneer of democracy to an imperialist and militarist class. This code, 'Never let the side down' and, above all, 'Never snitch', was seldom invoked in 20th-century America - except, perhaps, during the McCarthy trials. It was replaced by the sauve qui peut mentality best epitomised, for me, in a wonderful game called 'So long, Sucker', invented by four economists in 1964; the object of this game for four players is to get someone to go into partnership with you and then double-cross them.

Though these books have not (yet) been burnt, they have gone underground: a new plaincover edition has appeared in the UK, for grown-ups who don't want to be seen reading a children's book. (I was reminded of the old Mad Magazine edition printed to look like a black and white school notebook.) The 'adult' edition (an ironic twist on the contemporary meaning of 'adult', designating hard-core pornography) costs two pounds more but has already sold more than 20,000 copies. Clearly this is pretty hot stuff, subversive literature. 'Some old witch in Bath had a book that you could never stop reading!' one of Harry's friends informs him. 'You just had to wander around with your nose in it, trying to do everything one-handed.' That old witch must have been called Rowling.

American children have protested, in places as sophisticated as the New Yorker's 'Talk of the Town', against this insult to their intelligence. A stupider fight has been waged by parents (some of whom identify themselves as 'born-again Christians' and are known to others as the Mullahs of the Midwest) who have outlawed the Harry Potter books in American schools; legal challenges have been filed in at least eight states, and some evangelical ministers have preached against the books' satanic allegiance. Apparently, their astonishing popularity is taken as evidence of a Faustian bargain, the work of the devil. (How else can you get on the New York Times bestseller list?) In an ironic twist, some parents have cited the First Amendment and argued that witchcraft (i.e. the Potterian heresy) should not be taught in school because it is a religion; somehow this has failed to ignite the watchful passions of the American Civil Liberties Union. 'I realised that it's for my own sake that I'm not listening,' one child whose parents forbade him to listen to Potter readings reported. 'There's a lot about witchcraft and evil and spells and magic. I was taught at church that that was not good.' No doubt C.S. Lewis's Narnia books slipped through because of their thinly veiled Christian message (Aslan as the Lamb of God), not to mention their anti-Muslim message (the worshippers of the evil Tash are dark-skinned men in turbans). On the other hand, when Lewis's books were first published, covens of real witches were not as prominent as they are now; always popular, Narnia is enjoying a resurgence in Harry's wake. Events at Columbine High School last year may explain the reaction of some American parents who have opposed the Harry Potter books. The students who shot and killed their classmates said they were out to get the school bullies, and were themselves part of a widespread teen cult inspired to some degree by The Matrix (the students dressed like the film's heroes). The Matrix invoked the ancient criteria of rule-breaking excellence - innovation, courage, creativity - but also of lawlessness and anarchy: the film imagines a world of computers that create an alternative reality through the kind of mind control that is also at the heart of Harry Potter's magic. (The Matrix even exploits the banality of magic: the oracle is a woman just like your aunt, who bakes cookies and has magnets on her fridge.) The alternative reality of The Matrix is made possible by a new, computer magic (nouveau-Orientalist rather than vieux-Brit) which is both the medium of the film (its stunning special effects) and its message, the antinomian ethic of the new capitalism. This greedy, solipsistic ethic extends far beyond the film; television advertisements for some computer products boast of 'breaking the rules, remaking the rules'. This is understandably scary stuff for the more repressive sort of parents (who may also be troubled by the popularity of the premise of their own dispensability in books such as these). It gives them nightmares that make them want to burn Harry Potter at the stake. Harry Potter, too, has moments of computer magic: a more banal version of his magic map which shows people moving on its surface is available at most Hertz and Avis headquarters, not to mention in high-tech alarm systems. But most of the magic is of another kind, dependent on education and mental training. Indeed, where the protests go wrong is in assuming that, since magic does not seem to obey the rules of either science or religion, it has no rules at all. This is certainly not the case. Harry Potter must abide, not only by the complex moral rules of magic, but even by the moral rules dictating when to use, and when not to use, magic. More important, the world of Harry Potter is deeply coloured by a Victorian code of public-school loyalty that offers a positive antidote to the 'no holds barred' capitalism of the computer world which some parents have wrongly conflated with the world of magic. In its original form, the code represented a kind of parity among the privileged, a noblesse oblige that gave a veneer of democracy to an imperialist and militarist class. This code, 'Never let the side down' and, above all, 'Never snitch', was seldom invoked in 20th-century America - except, perhaps, during the McCarthy trials. It was replaced by the sauve qui peut mentality best epitomised, for me, in a wonderful game called 'So long, Sucker', invented by four economists in 1964; the object of this game for four players is to get someone to go into partnership with you and then double-cross them. Though these books have not (yet) been burnt, they have gone underground: a new plaincover edition has appeared in the UK, for grown-ups who don't want to be seen reading a children's book. (I was reminded of the old Mad Magazine edition printed to look like a black and white school notebook.) The 'adult' edition (an ironic twist on the contemporary meaning of 'adult', designating hard-core pornography) costs two pounds more but has already sold more than 20,000 copies. Clearly this is pretty hot stuff, subversive literature. 'Some old witch in Bath had a book that you could never stop reading!' one of Harry's friends informs him. 'You just had to wander around with your nose in it, trying to do everything one-handed.' That old witch must have been called Rowling.  To read more online essays from the current edition of the London Review of Books visit the LRB. The extensive online archive of essays from past editions includes John Lanchester on the rise of Microsoft, Alan Bennett's Diary and much more.

webTitle: How much can you pay for . . .

fields.headline: How much can you pay for . . .
fields.trailText: Wedding invitations
fields.body:
Wedding invitations

This sort of thing would not be at all appropriate if you were planning a small wedding at your local register office, with a few hot dogs and cans of beer afterwards. The only way to justify ordering Alastair Lockhart wedding invitations is by shipping your guests to Rome by Concorde and holding the whole thing in St Peter's, with enough caviar for dinner to fill a few swimming pools. £1,200 for 100 cards? They're on handmade paper, mind you, with handdrawn calligraphy and hand-painted flowers, but really, is all that sweat and squinting worth more than a grand (or, more likely, about 10 grand, if you're inviting 600-800 of your closest friends, and including return-of-post envelopes)? You can reach Alastair Lockhart on 0171-581 8289 if you think it is.

fields.standfirst:
The Guardian's directory of online shopping is at www.shoppingunlimited.co.uk

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Of the 100 fastest-growing companies in the world, Tesco Direct has the best website (www.tescodirect.com). At least, that's the conclusion of a survey by the London School of Economics, which liked its customer service, ease of use and product range. So far, the service is predominantly geared to London and the south-west, but the whole country should be covered by the year's end.
fields.body:
Of the 100 fastest-growing companies in the world, Tesco Direct has the best website (www.tescodirect.com). At least, that's the conclusion of a survey by the London School of Economics, which liked its customer service, ease of use and product range. So far, the service is predominantly geared to London and the south-west, but the whole country should be covered by the year's end.

Sainsbury's service (www.sainsburys.co.uk) is also limited, servicing those inside the M25 only.

Asda may be leading the way on discount prices, but is lagging behind when it comes to online shopping. You can't order atwww.asda.co.uk, but there is a home delivery service available that uses a CD-rom. Call 0845 300 7777 for details.

Iceland's online shopping service (www.iceland.co.uk) is the most extensive, reaching 97% of the country. There is a minimum order of £40 but the delivery is free.

Last week Waitrose extended its e-business, offering organics and flowers at www.waitrose.com. Fruit and vegetables can be ordered online Tuesdays to Fridays, and delivered anywhere in mainland UK in 48 hours.

Somerfield (www.somerfield.co.uk.) plans to launch its e-business next month.

fields.headline: In your face
fields.standfirst: A computer that can recognise millions of faces was hailed as a crime-fighting miracle by a London council. But as retailers adopt the same technology to beat shoplifters,  Sally Kinnes  asks if we really want to be watched so closely
fields.trailText: In the long-standing war between retailers and shoplifters, the retailers have just upped the ante. To the already elaborate barriers of security guards, security tags and CCTV cameras, they have added a technology so sophisticated that it can scan a million faces a second, find an individual in a crowd, ignore the background and, by cross-checking against a database, identify precisely who it is.
fields.body:
In the long-standing war between retailers and shoplifters, the retailers have just upped the ante. To the already elaborate barriers of security guards, security tags and CCTV cameras, they have added a technology so sophisticated that it can scan a million faces a second, find an individual in a crowd, ignore the background and, by cross-checking against a database, identify precisely who it is.

The system, called Satnet, can be rented for about £350 a month, and in a couple of weeks Liberty's of Regent Street in London will become the first shop in Britain to attempt to use it as legal evidence - in a "burglary" case.

"When someone is apprehended for shoplifting, a photograph is taken which maps their face," says Christopher Taplin, chief executive of ShopGuard, the company that is renting out the technology. "This is then put into a database; even if no charges are brought, the shop has the right to decide they don't want that person in their store and can serve an exclusion notice on them." If they come back and are caught in the act again, they are in trouble: if you steal while trespassing, the charge changes from shoplifting to the more serious offence of burglary.

"That's one advantage for the store," says a spokeswoman for Liberty's. "It also helps identify people who are trying to give a false name."

Sophisticated though the technology is, it is only as good as the database on which it searches for matching faces. ShopGuard is building its database from scratch. "All the faces come from stores that are members of the system," says Taplin. So far, only eight or nine shops in London's West End are members and, since its launch in November, only about 50 people have been put on the system. But the more shops that join the scheme, the more effective it becomes; potentially, the database could be enormous. It is not unknown for shops to have 500 people on their banned list, and this week it was reported that a teenager charged with stealing a pair of tracksuit bottoms (value £35), has been banned from every shop in Britain.

Although facial recognition technology is new to retailers, the London borough of Newham has been on to it for months. In October 1998, it became the first place in the world to use the technology in public places. Whereas the retailers wait for someone to be apprehended, then check to see if they are on the database, Newham goes one step further. It uses its CCTV system to send information back to the computerised database, and actively scan for criminals. If a face fits, the police are alerted.

"Just as the police put a ring of steel round the city when we had a terrorist threat, checking every vehicle that came into London, so we are trying to get a ring of steel round our shopping centres," says Bob Lack, operations manager for security systems at Newham council.

In the first six months of the trial, crime fell by 35% in the places being surveyed by CCTV. But in the second half of last year, car crime in the same area increased by 15%. "This kind of surveillance doesn't stop crime," says Liz Parratt, spokeswoman for the human rights group Liberty. "It just moves it elsewhere."

The government, however, has been sufficiently impressed to give Newham £170,000 to extend its programme. Until now, it has only been able to link one of its 247 CCTV cameras to its database. From June, it will be able to have live links from 30 to 40 cameras at a time.

Facial recognition technology was developed by US academics, among them Joseph Atick. Formerly a professor of mathematics at Rockefeller university in New York, Atick decided to exploit his work commercially in 1994, when he co-founded a company called Visionics, which is marketing the technology under various names around the world .

Mimicking the brain, the software scans and measures distances between the major landmarks of the face, reducing them to a heap of pixels. It works because each face is as unique as a fingerprint; even identical twins have measurable differences when you look this close. Plastic surgery would fool the system, but it would have to be extensive. "It would need to be a nose job, a forehead lift, and an eye tuck," says Atick. "It takes a lot to change the shape of a face."

The software has a huge memory. "Humans have the capacity to remember about 4,000 faces - after that, you're not sure if you've seen a face before or not," says Atick. "This system can remember millions." But it's not infallible - the software needs to see an image that includes one full eye and one partial eye if it is to make an accurate ID. And if a face is angled more than 35% away from the camera, in any direction, it gets confused.

In 1998, £604m of goods were stolen from shops in Britain, and deterring theft is an obvious application. But there are many others. "You can use it for controlling access, so your face become a key," says Atick. "It's already being used widely in America on ATM machines, so your face is your PIN number.

"It can look for known hooligans in a football crowd, or identify high-spending customers in shops. It could look down the aisle and see a frequent and valued customer, so the shop can send a salesperson to the shop floor to assist them. There are a couple of pilot schemes doing that."

Whether favoured customers would appreciate being spied on like this is a moot point. It's one thing to build up a relationship with a shop; quite another to realise they are watching every move you make. Parratt believes high street surveillance has gone far enough already.

"There is an increasingly difficult issue about the excessive surveillance of public places," she says. "At Liberty, we don't think that, in general, CCTV is a bad thing, and it can be very useful in the prevention and detection of crime. But we need to keep it in proportion. Its use in terms of personal safety is overrated."

On Monday, in a BBC2 documentary called Death of Privacy, Simon Davies of the human rights group Privacy International claimed Britain has the most extensive public surveillance system in the world. Soon, he said, there will be "technology that intimately knows each one of us".

There is an old argument that the innocent have nothing to fear, but Parratt doesn't buy it. "If you say that, then there's never an argument against surveillance, and I wouldn't want to be under surveillance 24 hours a day. Also, CCTV systems are completely unregulated. There are a number of voluntary codes of practice and local authorities adhere to guidelines, but the trouble is that they are fine for the good guys, but do nothing to catch the bad guys. What's important is that there should be a public debate. Otherwise, in a few years' time, we could find we're in a place we don't want to be."

webTitle: Straw will personally decide on hijack victims future

fields.headline: Straw will personally decide on hijack victims future
fields.trailText: Home secretary Jack Straw signalled today that he would personally seek to send back all those on board the hijacked Afghan aircraft, after the peaceful end to the four-day drama at Stansted airport early this morning.
fields.body:
Home secretary Jack Straw signalled today that he would personally seek to send back all those on board the hijacked Afghan aircraft, after the peaceful end to the four-day drama at Stansted airport early this morning.

In a special Commons statement, Mr Straw announced he was taking the extraordinary step of personally deciding on any applications, in a bid to head off right-wing criticism that Britain was seen as a "soft touch" on asylum seekers.

"Subject to compliance with all legal requirements, I would wish to see removed from this country all those on the plane as soon as reasonably practicable," he told the Commons.

"As a matter of public policy, I believe that the clearest and unequivocal signals must be sent out so as to discourage hijacking, whatever its motive," Mr Straw said.

"While I must and will act in accordance with the law, I am determined that nobody should consider that there can be any benefit to be obtained by hijacking."

Of those on the plane, 60 had so far told immigration officers they wished to apply for asylum along with 14 dependants. The remainder had yet to make their wishes known.

Mr Straw pledged to "respond resolutely to any attempts like this to use terrorist methods, whether the aim is to advance a political cause or to benefit the individuals concerned".

He explained that the hijacked plane had been allowed to land at Stansted in accordance with Britain's "international obligations". There had been "serious concerns about the safety of those on board, given the threats that had been made earlier to kill passengers, uncertainty over fuel levels and reports of technical problems".

Mr Straw said no political demands were made at any time following the plane's arrival at Stansted, although statements were made to negotiators about the political situation in Afghanistan.

No undertakings "of any kind concerning asylum" had been given by government representatives during the negotiations and "the surrender from the plane was unconditional".

Shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe told MPs a deterrent to future hijacks would be to ensure Britain's asylum procedures were not "noticeably softer" than those in surrounding countries.

"Why the United Kingdom?" Miss Widdecombe asked. "Why did it decide that it would land here and try to take advantage of our asylum procedures? Is it that those procedures are known to be rather more congenial than some which appertain in other countries which are nevertheless still signatories to the 1951 convention [on refugees] and to the ECHR (European court of human rights)?"

She welcomed the home secretary's decision to decide the asylum applications personally but stressed that speed was of the essence.

Mr Straw agreed speed was important in processing asylum seekers' claims and said special arrangements had been put in place with that aim.

Liberal Democrat spokesman Simon Hughes said rules should be set down if the home secretary was going to start "calling in" immigration and asylum applications on a regular basis, as he recently did with boxer Mike Tyson.

"Can we have rules that govern that just as one does for calling in planning applications, rather than you simply being able to pick and mix with nobody knowing whether they are going to get special fast treatment from you or the normal treatment from somebody else?"

fields.headline: Bank of England hikes rates
fields.standfirst: Interest rates explained
fields.trailText: Manufacturing industry and mortgage holders greeted the Bank of England's decision to raise interest rates with criticism today.
fields.body:
Manufacturing industry and mortgage holders greeted the Bank of England's decision to raise interest rates with criticism today.

The Bank's nine-member monetary policy committee (MPC) voted to increase the official cost of borrowing by a quarter point - from 5.75% to 6% - taking it to its highest level for 13 months.

The decision, intended to keep prices in check and prevent inflation rising again, was widely expected in the City. If, as expected, mortgage lenders raise their rates in line with the increase, the cost of a £60,000 mortgage will rise by about £9 a month.

Although underlying inflation, at 2.2%, is still comfortably below the government's 2.5% target, the MPC fears that strong consumer demand, rising pay and the booming housing market could cause prices to increase.

However, manufacturing unions warned that the rise could lead to a further strengthening of the pound, adding to the difficulties faced by exporters.

The general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, Sir Ken Jackson, said the rate rise would "choke" exports in the Midlands and the north. "House prices in the south are driving up interest rates," he added, "but each rise hits exporters throughout the regions."

Shadow chancellor Michael Portillo said: "As Gordon Brown has been so quick to take credit for previous rate reductions, it will be interesting to see whether he is quick to take responsibility for today's interest rate rise.

"Presumably he will, since only last week he publicly instructed the bank to raise rates. It is tough for manufacturers to take this rate rise because they have already been hit by billions of pounds of extra stealth taxes and regulations under Labour."

TUC general secretary John Monks said the rise was "disappointing", adding: "As the MPC has been under pressure to raise rates more steeply, industry and the regions will be grateful that they have chosen the less painful option. Industry needs a period of interest rate stability to ensure a balanced economic recovery."

The Confederation of British Industry (CBI) said it believed the rise was unnecessary, as previous rate increases had been enough to keep the lid on inflation. "This is more bad news for manufacturers," said the CBI's chief economic adviser Kate Barker.

"Companies are working hard to cope with the exchange rate, but this rise in interest rates will be an additional handicap. It will be a setback to fragile confidence as firms try to take advantage of growth in global markets.

"Many companies will find the rise hard to understand when inflationary pressure remains so low in most sectors."

However, the Institute of Directors (IoD) gave a sympathetic response to the MPC decision, saying it "understood" the reasons for the rise.

Ruth Lea, head of the IoD's policy unit, commented: "While we recognise the real burdens placed on business by higher interest rates, we accept they need to rise to in order to maintain the low inflation stability which is essential for business to thrive. The alternative, tighter fiscal policy, has clearly been ruled out by the government."

The MPC will make its detailed report on the outlook for inflation on February 17, while minutes for this week's meeting will be published on February 23, giving a full insight into the committee's thinking.
fields.bodyText: Manufacturing industry and mortgage holders greeted the Bank of England's decision to raise interest rates with criticism today. The Bank's nine-member monetary policy committee (MPC) voted to increase the official cost of borrowing by a quarter point - from 5.75% to 6% - taking it to its highest level for 13 months. The decision, intended to keep prices in check and prevent inflation rising again, was widely expected in the City. If, as expected, mortgage lenders raise their rates in line with the increase, the cost of a £60,000 mortgage will rise by about £9 a month. Although underlying inflation, at 2.2%, is still comfortably below the government's 2.5% target, the MPC fears that strong consumer demand, rising pay and the booming housing market could cause prices to increase. However, manufacturing unions warned that the rise could lead to a further strengthening of the pound, adding to the difficulties faced by exporters. The general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, Sir Ken Jackson, said the rate rise would "choke" exports in the Midlands and the north. "House prices in the south are driving up interest rates," he added, "but each rise hits exporters throughout the regions." Shadow chancellor Michael Portillo said: "As Gordon Brown has been so quick to take credit for previous rate reductions, it will be interesting to see whether he is quick to take responsibility for today's interest rate rise. "Presumably he will, since only last week he publicly instructed the bank to raise rates. It is tough for manufacturers to take this rate rise because they have already been hit by billions of pounds of extra stealth taxes and regulations under Labour." TUC general secretary John Monks said the rise was "disappointing", adding: "As the MPC has been under pressure to raise rates more steeply, industry and the regions will be grateful that they have chosen the less painful option. Industry needs a period of interest rate stability to ensure a balanced economic recovery." The Confederation of British Industry (CBI) said it believed the rise was unnecessary, as previous rate increases had been enough to keep the lid on inflation. "This is more bad news for manufacturers," said the CBI's chief economic adviser Kate Barker. "Companies are working hard to cope with the exchange rate, but this rise in interest rates will be an additional handicap. It will be a setback to fragile confidence as firms try to take advantage of growth in global markets. "Many companies will find the rise hard to understand when inflationary pressure remains so low in most sectors." However, the Institute of Directors (IoD) gave a sympathetic response to the MPC decision, saying it "understood" the reasons for the rise. Ruth Lea, head of the IoD's policy unit, commented: "While we recognise the real burdens placed on business by higher interest rates, we accept they need to rise to in order to maintain the low inflation stability which is essential for business to thrive. The alternative, tighter fiscal policy, has clearly been ruled out by the government." fields.headline: Office Antics
fields.standfirst: Office work dull? None of your colleagues appreciate your humour?
fields.trailText: Office work dull? None of your colleagues appreciate your humour?
fields.body:
Amuse yourself. Points are awarded on a degree of difficulty basis but you can award yourself extra points for creative execution.

One point gags

Run one lap around the office at top speed

Groan out loud in the bathroom cubicle (at least one other "no Player" must be in the bathroom at the time.)

Ignore the first five people who say "good morning" to you.

Phone someone in the office you barely know, leave your name and say "Just called to say I can't talk right now. Bye"

To signal the end of a conversation, clamp your hands over your ears and grimace.

Two point gags

When someone hands you a piece of paper, finger it, and whisper huskily "Mmm, that feels so good!"

Leave your zipper open for one hour. If anyone points it out, say, "Sorry, I really prefer it this way."

Walk sideways to the photocopier.

While riding an elevator, gasp dramatically every time the doors open.

Three point gags

Say to your boss, "I like your style" and shoot him with double-barrelled fingers.

Babble incoherently at a fellow employee then ask "Did you get all that, I don't want to have to repeat it"

Page yourself over the intercom (do not disguise your voice)

Kneel in front of the water cooler and drink directly from the nozzle (there must be a 'non-player' within sight).

Shout random numbers while someone is counting.

Four point gags

At the end of a meeting, suggest that, for once, it would be nice to conclude with the singing of the national anthem (extra points if you actually launch into it yourself).

Walk into a very busy person's office and while they watch you with growing irritation, turn the light switch on/off 10 times.

For an hour, refer to everyone you speak to as "Bob".

Announce to everyone in a meeting that you "really have to go do number two".

While an office mate is out, move their chair into the elevator.

Five point gags

In a meeting or crowded situation, slap your forehead repeatedly and utter, "Shut up, damn it, all of you just shut up!"

At lunchtime, get down on your knees and announce "As God is my witness, I'll never go hungry again".

In a colleagues diary, write in 10am: "See how I look in tights".

Carry your keyboard over to your colleague and ask "You wanna trade?"

Repeat the following conversation 10 times to the same person: "Do you hear that?" "What?" "Never mind, it's gone now".

Come to work in army fatigues and when asked why, say, "I can't talk about it."

Six point gags

Posing as a maitre d', call a colleague and tell him he's won a lunch for four at a local restaurant. Let him go.

Find the vacuum and start vacuuming around your desk. Hang a two-foot long piece of toilet roll from the back of your pants and act genuinely surprised when someone points it out. Rollerblade around the floor throwing sweets.

webTitle: Saeed Anwar replaces Wasim as Pakistan captain

fields.headline: Saeed Anwar replaces Wasim as Pakistan captain
fields.trailText: Wasim Akram has resigned as captain of Pakistan. Saeed Anwar will take charge for the first ODI against Sri Lanka at Karachi on Sunday.
fields.body:
Wasim Akram has resigned as captain of Pakistan. Saeed Anwar will take charge for the first ODI against Sri Lanka at Karachi on Sunday.

Wasim has stepped down voluntarily, citing "increasing domestic commitments". His decision comes after a disastrous tour of Australia, which saw Pakistan defeated in all three Tests.

A press release issued by the Pakistan Cricket Board said that Wasim "considers it as his privilege and an honour to represent Pakistan and will be available as an ordinary member for the forthcoming series and more.

"He aspires to reach his cricketing zenith by breaking the world Test record for maximum wickets and enjoys full support of the cricket management in Pakistan. The Pakistan Cricket Board fully respects his commitment and aspirations."

fields.headline: The wretched of the earth
fields.standfirst: Former Afghanistan correspondent for the Guardian Derek Brown speculates on what fate awaits the hijackers of the Afghan airliner at Stansted
fields.trailText: 1pm: Former Afghanistan correspondent for the Guardian Derek Brown speculates on what fate awaits the hijackers of the Afghan airliner at Stansted
fields.body:
Air piracy, whatever the motivation for it, is a hideous crime. On that we can all agree. The men who brandished guns and grenades before 150 terrified passengers and crew of the Ariana aircraft, and brought them to a foreign land at peril of all their lives, deserve neither sympathy nor leniency.

We do not know yet what drove the hijackers to their desperate action. At first, it was thought they hoped to hold the passengers hostage against the release of Ismail Khan, an Afghan warlord imprisoned by the Taliban regime.

In recent days, a more mundane motive has been suggested, namely that the hijackers were simply desperate to escape the horrors of life in Afghanistan.

That speculation has sparked a tangential debate about asylum seekers - a subject which seems to bring out the very worst in us.

The Conservative leader William Hague very properly is demanding information this morning about the exact status of the hijackers and indeed of their hostages, some of whom may well apply for asylum.

But he went on: "We don't want, we must not allow, this country to reinforce its growing image as a soft touch for asylum seekers... This cannot become the way to seek political asylum on top of all the other ways that exist already."

This kind of language is irresponsible as well as distasteful. The idea that the skies above Stansted will be darkened by squadrons of incoming hijackers is patently ludicrous. But more insidious by far is the notion of Britain as "a soft touch" for refugees.

There is nothing "soft" in the life of a refugee. Those who are forced, by terror or by economic deprivation, to flee their own country are by definition at the bottom of the heap of humanity.

Sure, there are some, maybe many, in the growing tide of asylum seekers in this country who have come to con the system; to exaggerate their plight in the hope of a handout. But we can safely dismiss that as a factor in the Stansted hijack.

Whatever crazed and desperate schemes are dreamed up in Kabul, they do not include elaborate scams to get hold of giro cheques in Britain. Before we can begin to understand what drove these men to commit their crime, we must know a little about, quite literally, where they are coming from.

Afghanistan is a wasteland. It has endured more than 20 years of superpower proxy conflict and vicious civil war. It has been devastated by the Soviet army and by the mujaheddin resistance armed by the west, principally the USA and Britain. It is now torn and bleeding, without any recognisable government.

Justice in Afghanistan is an ugly thing. When the Taliban came to power, they dragged the last communist dictator, Najibullah, from his refuge in a Kabul UN compound, shot him and hung his bloody corpse from a lamp-post.

Both the Taliban and their equally brutal opponents make a virtue of public hangings. Abdul Rashid Dostum, a warlord in the north whose allegiance changed with the breeze, adopted a favourite Russian punishment: he strapped those who offended him to tank tracks, and had them pulped.

These and many other horrors are part of what Afghanistan has become, and we helped make it so. Hague's heroine, Margaret Thatcher, was as ardent as any in her support of the obscurantist bigots who tore their country to bits.

This is not to suggest that all Afghans are barbarians. Far from it; it is a plea for some understanding and sympathy for the millions who live in the wreckage of an ancient seat of civilisation.

Sending back the hijackers, and indeed those of their victims who apply for asylum, would make us accomplices in the terror which now grips Afghanistan.

Related documentary
Stansted hijack: special report

fields.headline: Trimble's accuser backs down
fields.trailText: Documentary maker Sean McPhilemy yesterday withdrew his claim that David Trimble, the Northern Ireland first minister, knew who was behind a series of sectarian loyalist murders at the time they were committed.
fields.body:
Documentary maker Sean McPhilemy yesterday withdrew his claim that David Trimble, the Northern Ireland first minister, knew who was behind a series of sectarian loyalist murders at the time they were committed.

He told the high court in London he could not maintain the allegation because he had no evidence, but he still believed Mr Trimble knew what was going on.

He said he was also sure that Mr Trimble became aware of, and tried to cover up, a murder conspiracy involving RUC officers.

Mr McPhilemy, 52, was giving evidence in his libel action against the Sunday Times over an article that condemned his 1991 Channel 4 programme about a secret committee coordinating the assassination of republicans as a hoax.

Mr McPhilemy says the article ruined his career.

The newspaper denies libel and stands by its claim that the programme was "little more than a collage of unsubstantiated rumours".

The programme did not reveal the names of the alleged members of the committee but they were identified later in a book by Mr McPhilemy.

The hearing continues.

webTitle: 24 hours to save the peace process

fields.headline: 24 hours to save the peace process
fields.trailText:
Irish prime minister Bertie Ahern today briefed Northern
Ireland's first minister David Trimble on efforts to break the
deadlock on IRA decommissioning with time running out for the
new Ulster executive.
fields.body:
Irish prime minister Bertie Ahern today briefed Northern Ireland's first minister David Trimble on efforts to break the deadlock on IRA decommissioning with time running out for the new Ulster executive.

London, Dublin and Ulster's politicians have 24 hours to save the power-sharing cabinet before parliament suspends the north-south institutions created by the Good Friday agreement. A bill freezing devolved institutions and re-imposing direct rule from Westminster is expected to pass through the House of Lords today and become law tomorrow unless the politicians can find a solution to the impasse.

The Ahern-Trimble meeting was part of a frantic last-minute scramble by British and Irish leaders and Northern Ireland politicians to find a formula to end a dispute over IRA disarmament that could badly damage peace efforts. "We are conscious of the governments trying to put something together," a unionist source said as Mr Trimble set off for the Irish capital.

With the IRA having signally failed to produce any weapons, the interested parties are believed to be pressing the IRA into making a declaration restating their commitment to the peace process. Mr Trimble is under pressure to resign as leader of the Ulster Unionist party (UUP)unless there is progress on IRA disarmament.

He faces a showdown with his party at a crucial meeting on Saturday of his 850-strong ruling UUP council. Britain is preparing to suspend the executive, amid fears that Mr Trimble's resignation would trigger a total collapse of the Belfast executive. Suspension is seen as the least undesirable option.

But even if the IRA gives commitments that satisfy the British and Irish governments, they could fail to satisfy Mr Trimble and his UUP, who insist on an early weapons handover.

"My assessment of the Ulster Unionist council is that unless there is actual decommissioning it would be very difficult to see how this operation [coalition] could be sustained in its present form," a unionist official said.

webTitle: Tomas Gutierrez Alea: Memories of Underdevelopment

fields.headline: Tomas Gutierrez Alea: Memories of Underdevelopment
fields.standfirst: Derek Malcolm's 100 greatest movies. This week, number 54: Tomas Gutierrez Alea's Memories of Underdevelopment
fields.trailText: Of all the dozens of films produced in Cuba through Castro's insistence on the importance of the cinema, Memories of Underdevelopment is the most sophisticated. So much so, in fact, that those opposed to the revolution tend to call it a magnificent and unrepeatable fluke, produced as it was by a film institute that was virtually a Marxist ministry. Those in favour cherish it as a landmark that avoids almost all of the radical cliches.
fields.body:
Of all the dozens of films produced in Cuba through Castro's insistence on the importance of the cinema, Memories of Underdevelopment is the most sophisticated. So much so, in fact, that those opposed to the revolution tend to call it a magnificent and unrepeatable fluke, produced as it was by a film institute that was virtually a Marxist ministry. Those in favour cherish it as a landmark that avoids almost all of the radical cliches.

The director was Tomas Gutierrez Alea, a middle-class university-educated Cuban who went along with the revolution despite some of the doubts about emerging bureaucratisation displayed by the equally bourgeois protagonist of his film. This is Sergio, a wealthy man who decides to stay behind when his family leaves for the US. The time is 1961 and the film is placed between the exodus after the disastrous Bays of Pigs invasion and the missile crisis of the following year.

The film centres on Sergio's thoughts and experiences as he is confronted by the new reality. He is fundamentally an alienated outsider, scornful of his bourgeois family and friends but also of the naivety of those who believe that everything can suddenly be changed. He continues to live as a rent-collecting property owner and, in his private life, chases women with an almost neurotic fervour.

He is, in fact, the sort of man with whom we can easily identify from our experience of European films and literature. The difference is that he is placed in exceptional circumstances and finds it difficult to understand them. Memories is one of the best films ever made about the sceptical individual's place in the march of history.

None of this would have been enough if Alea hadn't constructed his film so richly, and in excitingly cinematic rather than literary terms. Documentary and semi-documentary footage is presented as Sergio would have seen it and the fictional story that goes along with it is very European in its narrative style.

There are even clips from a porno film - there were many made in Cuba under Batista - and Alea himself and the author of the original novel comment on what is going on in Sergio's mind. As one admiring critic has said, "the film insists that what we see is a function of how we believe, and that how we believe is what our history has made of us".

Memories was Alea's fifth film, and probably his most famous, though at least three others received international attention. Death of a Bureaucrat was an ironic satire on the way revolutions stiffen into deadly bureaucracies; The Last Supper showed how the black slaves of Cuba in the plantation era were reconciled by religion to a life of bondage; and Strawberry and Chocolate was a brave and popular film that, despite Castro's disdain for homosexuality, dared to have a stolid party cadre befriended and changed by a gay man.

Alea was clearly no ordinary product of the revolutionary cinema. He died recently of cancer and was honoured by a government he often seemed to criticise - and even more by ordinary Cubans, who flocked to his films.

webTitle: A question of principle on Austria

fields.headline: A question of principle on Austria
fields.trailText: The ascent to power in Austria last week of Jörg Haider's Freedom party poses a fundamental challenge to European society. It is, as the Portuguese prime minister, Antonio Guterres, said, "a question of principles and values". Portugal, which currently holds the European Union presidency, has been at the forefront of opposition to the Haider ascendancy, having realised that the shabby deal in Vienna between the two losers of last October's elections, Wolfgang Schüssel's conservative People's party and Mr Haider's far-right movement, has a significance reaching way beyond Austria. The deal will give a boost to extreme rightwing groups in other European countries. It potentially threatens the identity and cohesion of the EU and of other pan-European institutions that arose from the ashes of Europe's fascist era.
fields.body:
The ascent to power in Austria last week of Jörg Haider's Freedom party poses a fundamental challenge to European society. It is, as the Portuguese prime minister, Antonio Guterres, said, "a question of principles and values". Portugal, which currently holds the European Union presidency, has been at the forefront of opposition to the Haider ascendancy, having realised that the shabby deal in Vienna between the two losers of last October's elections, Wolfgang Schüssel's conservative People's party and Mr Haider's far-right movement, has a significance reaching way beyond Austria. The deal will give a boost to extreme rightwing groups in other European countries. It potentially threatens the identity and cohesion of the EU and of other pan-European institutions that arose from the ashes of Europe's fascist era.

Mr Haider's mendacious repackaging of the old agenda of hate, racism and fear challenges every individual, too, to say clearly what he or she believes, and to act on it. For if we accept the possibility of human progress, then we must accept and draw on the lessons of the past. There can be no prevarication, no fudging, no blasé, comforting pretence that the threat is overstated and will soon recede. Nor can there be any accommodation. We should all know where that historically leads. For Mr Haider, emboldened by his success, makes no secret of the fact that he hopes to take the chancellorship outright next time around.

In this context the swift decision of 14 EU member governments to quarantine the 15th, Austria, is welcome. This is not a case of bullying by Brussels. The démarche was undertaken without prior reference to Romano Prodi or his European Commission. Nor is it a right-left issue, or in any sense an ideological battle, for no party holds exclusive rights to bigotry. The criticism that is raining down on the wretched Mr Schüssel - whose ambition to become chancellor overwhelmed his responsibility to his country - comes from democrats of all persuasions, appalled by a grotesque distortion of the people's will. It is a great shame that the Freedom party's 27% share of the vote has translated into half the government posts. It is a great pity that Viktor Klima, leader of the largest party, the Social Democrats, which belatedly called for fresh elections, failed to show more nous. It is chilling that after all that has passed since Anschluss, so many Austrians, ignoring history, appear to prefer a smug, revisionist chauvinism that can find a senior role in its political system for a man who admires Hitler's employment policies and praises former SS officers.

The assertion that external, anti-Haider pressure constitutes a gross interference in Austria's internal affairs does not bear scrutiny. For Austria does not somehow inhabit a moral universe all its own. "It is an expression that we stand for a Europe based on shared values [that] Mr Haider has constantly violated," said Gerhard Schröder, Germany's chancellor. His foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, added: "The EU cannot accept that xenophobia and rightwing extremism become part of government." Italy's prime minister, Massimo D'Alema, said simply: "Europe has certain criteria and values that unite it."

It was plain that, in the end, outsiders could not dictate to Austria the composition of its government. But it remains equally plain that as a member of the Western democratic community of nations as much as the EU itself, Austria, like a wayward child, had to be left in no doubt what the consequences of its actions would be. Now those warnings have been effectively ignored, and the deserved isolation and ostracism of Austria will begin.

For individuals, companies and governments that would uphold the values of a free society, there must be no business-as-usual with Austria while Mr Haider and his cohorts hold sway. This imperative is both a personal and collective responsibility. It is a question of principle.

webTitle: Fear of fraud deters most Europeans from buying online

fields.headline: Fear of fraud deters most Europeans from buying online
fields.standfirst:
Consumers - Credit cards are not designed to stop web theft

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Security concerns are holding back e-commerce - especially in Europe, which is regarded as being less net-savvy than the US.
fields.body:
Security concerns are holding back e-commerce - especially in Europe, which is regarded as being less net-savvy than the US.

According to a Forrester research report last week, only 4% of internet users in France, Germany, Sweden, the Netherlands and Britain have bought anything online, and 40% of users say they do not intend to buy anything online in the next six months.

Consumers imagine anonymous computer geeks stealing personal information and credit card details as they travel across the internet, or cracking website defences and extracting them directly from the web trader's computers.

Last year PricewaterhouseCoopers said fraudulent e-commerce transactions made up half the annual fraud total in the US.

Fears centre on credit cards, the main method of payment online. In face-to-face transactions, signatures and the card's magnetic strip and hologram act as protection against fraud. Online, a hacker need only have the card's number - and take a guess at its expiry date - to make purchases.

Anthony Abraham, of the Canadian-based watchdog Fraud Watch, says: "The credit card has always been meant to be used in person, where a person can actually go to a store, which can ensure that his signature is the one on the back of the card."

Fraudsters use credit cards anonymously, often to buy "virtual" goods like software and pornography which can be downloaded rather than posted to a real address. They don't even need to steal a credit card, or the number: programs on the internet will randomly generate working credit card numbers.

The most likely remedy will be the smartcard, a credit card with an embedded microchip, which can be inserted in the side of a computer or mobile phone before an e-commerce transaction. That will, at least, confirm the purchaser physically has the card.

Until smartcards become widely available, use only UK-based websites which have a "real world" address (not a PO box) and sport encrypted connections. And pay by credit card: you will be liable for only the first £50, at most, of any fraudulent transaction.

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.trailText: e-state agents | Spice up your life
fields.body:
Buy a house over the web
Last week we saw a rash of medical sites emerging on the web. This week we have a spate of estate agents - or at least two new sites - joining them.

Launching on Monday is www.easier.co.uk The site will act as a property marketplace, where neither buyer nor seller pays fees. Estate agents normally take a fee of between 1% and 2%. According to Easier, that means sellers are coughing up on average around £2,100, including VAT, on the sale of their home. Getting rid of the fees, says Easier, will revolutionise the domestic property market.

When homes go on sale in Easier's searchable database, potential buyers can make contact with the sellers via fax, email and soon by pager and mobile phone messaging. Easier will make its money by passing its users' details on to other companies involved in the house buying and selling process - from mortgage vendors to removal companies.

Colchester businessmen Matthew and Simon Jackson have a similar idea and plan to launch www.homefreehome.co.uk They claimed to have launched the site last week, but when Online visited on Tuesday, there was nothing but a pre-registration page. Let's hope the site runs more smoothly after the launch.

Find your US cousins
Occasionally you find a single web page that proves more interesting than anything in the big, expensive, super-hyped portals. Here's one of them. Hamrick software's surname distribution page shows you how many people per 1,000 share your surname across each of the US states. Type in your name, find out where your kin have settled, and curse when you find it's somewhere hot and sunny.

QuickTime with Spices
Those of us still boring disbelieving friends and colleagues with details of just how great the Spice Girls were on tour last year have a new weapon in our armoury. The whole of their final London gig at Earl's Court was recorded for posterity, and now the full QuickTime video is available for downloading at the Spices' website. The pictures might be matchbox-sized, and potentially ruined by the sight of gyrating geek journalists, but otherwise it's still a spectacular show - if a little expensive to download in full, I found.

Creds and credibility
The concept of online cash is nothing new, and one which has yet to really take off - why bother when you can use your existing credit card? But if you're under 18, and don't have your own flexible friend, e-cash might offer a welcome alternative to raids on the folks' wallets. That's certainly the hope of Y-creds, yet another e-payment system that hopes to become the online currency of choice for teenagers, despite its desperate-to-be-cool-vicar name.

The idea is simple: parents use credit cards to buy credits, which teenagers then use to buy stuff at participating websites (the current exchange rate is 1,000 Y-creds to £10). The crux, of course, lies in how many - and which - retailers sign up to take Y-creds. There were only two shops when we looked earlier this week, but we're promised at least five more soon.

Wearing well
London Fashion Week kicks off this Sunday. Find details of the events at the festival's predictably trendy website at www.londonfashionweek.co.uk

fields.headline: Peaceful end to Stansted hijack
fields.trailText: The Stansted hijack crisis ended peacefully today when the armed hijackers gave themselves up after releasing all their hostages unharmed.
fields.body:
The Stansted hijack crisis ended peacefully today when the armed hijackers gave themselves up after releasing all their hostages unharmed.

Essex police assistant chief constable Joe Edwards announced that Britain's longest hijack was over shortly after 6am - more than three days after the Afghan airliner landed at the airport.

"The hijack is now at an end," he said, after a second wave of 65 passengers were freed by the gunmen.

Mr Edwards said: "Within the last few minutes we removed the last people off the hijacked aeroplane.

"We are checking to make sure the plane truly is empty, but I believe the hijackers have now surrendered. About 65 people have just left in the second phase."

The final phase began shortly before 6am when a second wave of passengers began leaving the jet.

Many of the 65 hostages approached waiting police with their hands in the air before they were guided to a safe area of the airfield.

Their appearance followed an earlier release, shortly after 3am, when 85 men, women and children walked down the rear steps of the Ariana jet, which was hijacked during an internal flight on Sunday.

The first release came minutes after two hijackers had left the Boeing 727 to hold a face-to-face meeting with negotiators.

The passengers were taken from the concrete apron of the Essex airfield by bus to an undisclosed destination for medical checks.

Police have established a reception centre at a nearby hotel and Red Cross officials arrived yesterday with games, books and soft toys for the 23 children who left their homes in Afghanistan on Sunday.

Immigration officials were said to believe that most of the travellers would be seeking to stay in Britain.

At least three of those already released by the hijackers are understood to have applied for political asylum.

And there was a deepening suspicion that the events of the past five days might have been part of a plan to enable the hijackers and their families to escape from the fundamentalist Taliban regime ruling Afghanistan.

Reports from Kabul of links between the passengers and hijackers - including suggestions that 40 of them were from the same family - increased speculation that the whole incident was an organised bid for political asylum.

Asked about the reports, Mr Edwards said: "I think that may be simplifying a more complex situation."

His colleague, assistant chief constable John Broughton, indicated that the hostage gang would be charged.

"We are now into a very complex and involved criminal investigation," he said. "What we now want is to put together all the pieces that we can, ultimately so that we can bring this matter into the criminal jurisdiction."

Home secretary Jack Straw welcomed the conclusion of the hijacking.

"I am naturally relieved that the hijacking incident at Stansted airport has been peacefully resolved without loss of life or serious injury," he said.

"We owe a great debt of gratitude to Essex police... It is a testament to their excellent work and negotiating skills and the professional work of all those involved that this dangerous situation has been brought to a peaceful end."

fields.headline: Magnanimous Morgan defends Blair
fields.trailText: Rhodri Morgan, who is set to become the new first secretary of  Wales, today was a picture of magnanimity as he defended prime  minister Tony Blair against accusations of being a control  freak.
fields.body:
Rhodri Morgan, who is set to become the new first secretary of Wales, today was a picture of magnanimity as he defended prime minister Tony Blair against accusations of being a control freak.

Generous and conciliatory in victory, Mr Morgan played down the notion that his third - and first successful - attempt to become first secretary represented a huge embarrassment for the prime minister.

"I don't think that's our first concern in Wales, to be honest, Mr Morgan said. "You could argue that it is the final proof that the canard that the Welsh assembly is being operated by remote control from 10 Downing Street is definitely untrue."

Mr Morgan replaces Alun Michael, who resigned yesterday minutes before losing a vote of no confidence in the most dramatic instance of political infighting since devolved governments took over in Wales and Scotland. Mr Michael was widely seen as the prime minister's man in Wales after former first Welsh secretary Ron Davies was forced to resign over his "moment of madness" on Clapham Common in October 1998. Mr Blair chose Mr Michael over Mr Morgan.

Despite being passed over, Mr Morgan refused to gloat and praised Labour for its initiative on devolution.

"Everybody refers to the Labour government under Tony Blair as being a bunch of control freaks," he said, "but actually they have given away more power than any other government in the last couple of hundred years."

Mr Morgan added: "It's an odd kind of control freak that gives away power to Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland and to London. This is part of a constitutional modernisation programme and I am glad to be part of it in Wales."

He rejected close comparisons between the Welsh assembly leadership drama and the London mayoral contest between Labour maverick Ken Livingstone and Frank Dobson, who is desperately fighting perceptions that he is Mr Blair's "stooge".

"I think the key thing is that if you are going to run for office, whether it is a big city like London or a small country like Wales, you have to show 110% commitment," Mr Morgan said. "I don't doubt that all of the candidates have that, but the perceptions are sometimes different."

Tory leader William Hague said Mr Michael's resignation illustrated Mr Blair's half-hearted attitude to devolution. "So far he has said he is in favour of devolving power in principle but he's not actually done it in practice. He tries to keep hold of all the levers of power, in London, and Scotland and Wales."

Mr Morgan is expected to be formally declared as Labour's candidate to fill the first secretary vacancy. Labour's candidate is almost certain to become first secretary in the election for the post. That election is expected to take place in the assembly early next week. Mr Morgan yesterday hinted that he would form a coalition with the Lib Dems, whose six seats would allow him to form an administration with a majority in the assembly.

webTitle: Move to appease teachers over pay

fields.headline: Move to appease teachers over pay
fields.standfirst:
Training offers fail to stem revolt on salary by results
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government acted yesterday to appease teaching unions opposed to its controversial performance-related pay system, by offering a long-awaited package of training and support.
fields.body:
The government acted yesterday to appease teaching unions opposed to its controversial performance-related pay system, by offering a long-awaited package of training and support.

But the new draft standards for threshold assessment, also published yesterday, linking teachers' pay to the achievements of pupils, were condemned by teaching unions.

The National Union of Teachers complained that under the system teachers would still have to be assessed on test and exam results while having no control over other factors affecting the progress of pupils.

Ministers insisted that the draft standards - which allow classroom teachers whose pupils have made satisfactory academic progress to move up the pay scale - were not a crude system of payment by results.

In the draft standards, the government has dropped reference to "progress towards national levels of achievement", with teachers now having to show that pupils have made progress "as good or better than similar pupils nationally". Under the threshold guidelines, teachers who are eligible for the upper pay range will receive a consolidated pay rise of £2,000 in September, in addition to the 3.3% pay award announced by the government last week.

Estelle Morris, the schools standards minister, said it was critical that the impact teachers had on pupils' progress was measured. "This is not payment by results but a commonsense view that the assessment would be incomplete if we did not consider the progress of pupils as well as the quality of teaching."

The minister also announced a consultation paper on teachers' professional development, which includes a national framework for standards. For the first step, the government is considering piloting bursaries to allow experienced teachers to take a "sabbatical" away from the classroom for development activity and research.

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the NUT, said the proposals for expanding professional development were welcome, but that "the contrast between the government's professional development proposals and payment by results could not be more stark".

The general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, David Hart, said that the government "still unwisely wished to compare individual pupil progress with the national picture".

But Peter Smith, general secretary of the Association of Teachers and Lecturers, said: "Teachers have nothing to fear from the threshold arrangements. It's a travesty to suggest that the government is proposing crude payment by results."

 David Puttnam, the Oscar-winning film producer and chairman of the fledgling General Teaching Council, told MPs yesterday that teachers needed to be loved until they felt "10ft tall". Lord Puttnam told the all-party education select committee that the new body would act in the interests of the profession to rebuild its self-confidence and status. He said he expected it to mirror the "healthy scepticism" with which many teachers viewed Ofsted, the watchdog headed by Chris Woodhead, the chief inspector of schools.
