fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Julianne Moore tipped for Hannibal role, Sylvester Stallone plans racing picture, Rachel Leigh Cook to play zany Josie, and Berlin Film festival opens with Wenders premiere
fields.body:
 Julianne Moore is the latest name bandied about as the possible female lead in Universal's troubled adaptation of Hannibal. According to Variety, the star of Safe, Boogie Nights and the upcoming The End of the Affair is the current favourite to play FBI agent Clarice Starling now that former interpreter Jodie Foster has definitely confirmed that she will not be reprising her Oscar-winning role. With the script - which crucially changes the ending from Thomas Harris's source novel - finally complete and Anthony Hopkins confirmed to again play the part of Hannibal Lecter, the casting of Starling remains Universal's last hurdle. "The last piece is putting the female lead in," admitted studio spokeswoman Terry Curtin. She would not be drawn on whether Moore was considering the role, or if other speculative applicants such as Cate Blanchette or Angelina Jolie were still in the frame.

 Sylvester Stallone is planning to produce and star in a Days of Thunder type movie centred around America's thriving Champion Auto Racing Teams (CART). "CART's brand of open-wheel auto racing provides some of the most thrilling, emotionally involving and inspiring forms of sport in the world," the actor told reporters at a weekend racing event in Florida. Later this year, the beefcake actor will be seen in an Americanised remake of Newcastle crime classic Get Carter, but he recently confessed to spending the last few years "in limbo", rejected by the Hollywood establishment and searching for a new direction.

 Hot on the heels of Mike Myers's proposed Scooby Doo feature comes news of a live-action version of kitsch Seventies favourite Josie and the Pussycats. The kids cartoon, produced between 1970 and 1972, revolves around the misadventures of a zany girl band who pre-dated the Spice Girls by some quarter of a century. The picture is currently in pre-production at Universal with a view to commence shooting in the summer. Rachel Leigh Cook, who took the lead in last year's high-school comedy She's All That, is to take the lead as Josie.

 The actress Reese Witherspoon is to make her debut as a film producer on the Phoenix-backed picture Slow Motion later this year. Witherspoon, who has won plaudits for her work in Election, Pleasantville and Cruel Intentions, will also star as a college student who falls into a fraught relationship with her room mate's skirt-chasing father. Slow Motion is based on the semi-autobiographical novel Playing With Fire by Dani Shapiro.

 The 50th Berlin International Film Festival opened last night with the premiere of Wim Wenders's The Million Dollar Hotel, a sprawling asylum drama starring Mel Gibson and based on a script co-written by U2 frontman Bono. Wenders attended the screening and compared the Berlin of today with the factionalised city he immortalised in his 1988 Cold War fable Wings of Desire. Wenders described returning to the new Berlin as a moving experience. "It would be an honour for any director on the planet to be here," he said. "But for me it is highly emotional."

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: Upwardly mobile
fields.body:
Upwardly mobile

Followers of Consumer may have taken wry pleasure in the news that complaints about mobile phone companies now equal those about traditional baddies such as second-hand car dealers. So irresistible is the prospect of Bach bleeping from our back pockets that the operators' fragile customer services are overloaded, as Gabriel Holland of London has learned. Her handset was recently stolen and in the hours before she reported the fact to Mercury One 2 One someone managed to dial £546-worth of international calls. This came as a surprise given that when she signed the contract she had turned down the option of making international calls. When she asked for details of the calls, she was told to wait until her next bill arrived. "I now have a new smart card, yet my line has been suspended until I pay the bill - without knowing what I'm supposed to be paying for. And I can't get any response from the customer service line."

Consumer has more luck via One 2 One's press office, which says there must have been a registration slip-up. "It shouldn't have been possible to make international calls, given the customer had opted out," says a spokesman. All charges will be waived.

Only connect

Helen Mallinson of Lancashire returned from holiday to find her mobile was displaying an "IMSI failure" and no longer worked. She rang BT Cellnet and, after a long wait on the helpline, was told they had not disconnected her, so it must be a problem for the manufacturer. She rang Phillips, who said the fault was with the network. Two operators at Cellnet's customer services promised to reconnect her but after two weeks the line was still dead.

BT Cellnet says the problem is sorted and Mallinson has been given a £20 call credit. "We had difficulties transferring all her details over to a replacement phone," says a spokesman. "This has taken too long to resolve."

A sorry tale

The latest on mobile phone telesales firm 1st Line. After we printed the saga of Steven Hurst of Nuneaton, who returned a free-trial phone to 1st Line's billing arm Cellular Operations but is now being threatened with legal action for outstanding line rental, a woman from Cellular called Consumer and asked for Hurst's details. He would, she promised, receive a conciliatory call. A week later the only call has been from a 1st Line saleswoman, offering a free phone and two months' line rental if he switches from BT Cellnet to Orange.

C&W: calls still queueing

There is a bright side: at least Cable & Wireless doesn't have a mobile phone network. Andy and Annie Gothard of London have had both their lines disconnected and only one has been reconnected despite 54 minutes spent waiting on the customer helpline. A reconnection appointment was missed; C&W claimed the engineer had gone to the wrong address (which turned out to be a shop-based foot clinic). Attempts to secure a new appointment resulted in a 29-minute wait and a £7 mobile phone bill. C&W have now sent a bill demanding payment within seven days of the date on the invoice. The trouble is, the missive was posted five days after it was dated.

Write to us at119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 0171-713 4731, send a fax on 0171-239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com

fields.headline: This time it's for real
fields.standfirst: A decade ago, you risked being splattered with red paint or kicked to the ground if you wore fur in public. Today the New York catwalks are dripping with animal pelts - and only the hardcore campaigners seem to care. So when did compassion go out of fashion?
fields.trailText: It was the hottest ticket in town and the audience had dressed for it. fields.byline: Emma Brockes, Jess Cartner-Morley and Laura Craik
fields.body:
It was the hottest ticket in town and the audience had dressed for it. Front row at Sean "Puffy" Combes's first menswear show in New York, sat fellow rappers Missy Elliott, Lil Kim and Jay Z, all straining to see what the megastar had put together for the catwalk. The answer? Fur. Lots of it. Wasn't Puffy worried that the star sensibilities in the audience last weekend might bridle at his parade of skins? Unlikely: a good few rabbits had gone into Missy Elliot's soft fur coat and Lil Kim was trailing fur sleeves and matching fur-trimmed culottes all over the seat.

The history of the fur trade can be told through the bumper stickers it has inspired. "Fight, fight, fight, forever more" versus "compassion is the fashion". "Support the fur farmers" versus "Jesus was a vegetarian". This is not a history of man against raccoon or rock against furrier's window. It is a history of information. As mink makes a stunning appearance on the catwalks of New York this week, campaigners on both sides of the fur war are reaching for their volumes of statistics, to prove how healthy/ animal trapped the industry is.

"I can't emphasise how important it is that more and more designers are using fur," says Jan Brown of the British Fur Trade Association. "In the 1999 collections, 220 designers were using fur, five times more than in 1985 when records started. We are expecting that figure to rise to 400 for the 2000 collections." There's more. "Over the past few years there has been a rise in the value of fur of roughly £7m. Mink prices have risen by 15% in Copenhagen. In 1993 production of mink pelts was at 2.6m. In 1998 that had risen to 28.6m." According to the fur industry, since French Elle declared "it's OK to wear fur again" in 1995, the line on the profits graph has soared.

That's the view from the red corner. In the white corner, activists at Peta, People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, are brandishing some rather different figures. "World mink production has dropped by 10%," says Andrew Butler, the group's spokesman. "Evans Inc, the economic barometer of the United States fur industry, recorded a net loss of $1.7m for its third quarter last year." There are no definitive statistics for world sales of fur - the industry is too canny to release them - and so the battle of fudged figures and partial truths rages indefinitely.

Evidence from the New York shows this week supports Jan Brown's figures. For those accustomed to British sensitivity on the subject, the volume of fur in evidence is quite a shock. Puffy, Oscar de la Renta, Marc Jacobs, Tommy Hilfiger, Bottega Veneta and Carolina Herrera are just some of the designers who have sent fur down the catwalk already this week. Mary J Blige was last seen running from show to show in a pale blue fur coat with dear little rabbit claws dangling off the collar. A few years ago, British models could be relied upon to avoid fur - this week, they have been prancing down catwalks happily bedecked in the stuff. At Carolina Herrera, where even the black skinny-rib jumpers came trimmed with thick mink cuffs, Karen Elson wore a brown-and-white striped mink blouson jacket, while at Marc Jacobs, Erin O'Connor, winner of Model of the Year at 1999's Elle Style Awards, sported a fluffy collar of Tuscan lamb.

The question posed by this is two-fold: how far does catwalk fashion influence high-street buying when there are lingering ethical issues involved and, how far did fur go out of fashion in the first place? The second question is easier to answer. The impact that anti-fur campaigners had on the industry in the early 90s was undeniably severe. Who can forget Belinda Carlisle and her backing singers posing starkers behind a banner that read "we'd rather go-go naked than wear fur", or David Bailey's advert for Lynx, showing a model spattered with blood as she minced her way down the catwalk in a fur coat. "In the late 80s, fur sales plummeted by 50%," says Andrew Butler at Peta. "You couldn't wear fur in Britain in the early 90s," says Caroline Cox, head of cultural and historical studies at the London College of Fashion. "In London, there used to be massive refrigerators in department stores to keep the fur coats in. Between Queensway and Westbourne Grove you can still see the building where people used to pay to store their fur coats. It is now £350,000 flats. That world has completely disappeared."

The reasons why this world has disappeared, is vital to the question of whether it is possible for it to re-emerge. Cox is sceptical about the motivations that drove the popular fur boycott, suspecting fashion had more to do with it than principle. "You had the whole green, new age scene starting up, which turned out to be a fashion-oriented movement. You had people like Ozbeck putting out his White Collection in 1990, which introduced recycled clothing into the mainstream. Not wearing fur was not an entirely deep and meaningful statement." In Ozbeck's White Collection, all the garments were white, a symbolic attempt to illustrate the face of ethical clothing. It self-detonated slightly when someone pointed out that cotton is a cash crop which ruins developing countries and ethical consumers had to look for something else to appropriate. "In fashion it is impossible to be ethical," says Cox. "So people did it symbolically by renouncing fur. It was a fashionable statement, so of course it has become unfashionable and fur is starting to reappear."

There is an argument being made that it never disappeared entirely, at least, not in cold countries or on the catwalks. "European women have always worn fur," says Cox. "In Paris and Milan. In Russia, every single person in the winter wears a fur hat. We are lucky to be able to renounce fur because of central heating." Even Peta is willing to concede that its efforts did not close down the industry entirely. "A lot of dinosaur designers like Oscar de la Renta and Karl Lagerfeld kept right on going," says Butler. "There have always been a handful of selfish designers who continue to work in fur."

The question of how much impact young designers who are now joining the "dinosaurs" will have on high-street sales, is unclear. Certainly in New York's still snow-piled streets this week, fur coats and hats are as common as Gap fleeces in London. The message is clear: if you want to stay warm and chic in the freezing New York winter, fur is where it's at. Rappers, society ladies and the average Joe in New York are swathed in it. In fact, the lust for luxury fabrics at high-street prices has been fashion's biggest story over the past two years and has made the return of fur almost inevitable. The renaissance of traditional Milanese fashion houses such as Fendi, whose heritage is steeped in the fur and leather trade, has swamped the high-end stores and magazines with fur. Traditionally, high-end fabrics have become so ubiquitous on the high street - cashmere in New Look, leather in Top Shop, pashminas in Marks & Spencer - that those wishing to stay one step ahead of the pack have moved on to Fendi's fox-fur bags and Gucci's lizardskin shoes.

Animal skins have crept back into our wardrobes too: the craze for animal-inspired prints and "harmless" animal-related trims such as feathers, paved the way for the real thing. Last season, Prada experimented with ostrich feathers; this season, it's using the bird's skins and no one is batting an eyelid. "When Sophie Wessex wore the fur hat it was a media shock horror story, but I don't think the public were bothered about it at all," says Cox, who sees a connection between the rise in the pro-fox hunting, countryside lobby and the possible revival of fur wearing. "The rural alliance has brought together all these ghastly old tories and wearing fur is now almost an anti-Blair statement."

It is getting easier for wool- wearing liberals to buy fur too now, since developments in the treatment of newly harvested fur have allowed the pelts to be manipulated to remind you as little of the animal they were stripped from as possible.

"It is so much easier for designers to use now," says Jan Brown at the British Fur Trade Association. "You can dye mink and sheer it so that you can use both sides and it looks like velvet."

Fur manufacturers have learned to bypass customer squeamishness by creating blended fabrics that use fur for cachet and texture while delicately avoiding the issue of animal suffering. Saga Furs of Scandinavia, the largest fur marketing association in the world, says that demand for mink shearling, the soft leather underside of the mink, has never been higher. Tommy Hilfiger and Michael Kors have both used mink shearling in their autumn/winter collections.

Reversible fox, which has a nappa finish on the leather and so can be worn on either side, is expected to feature tomorrow on the catwalk of designer Vera Wang, principally known in the UK as the woman who designed Posh Spice's wedding dress. And fellow American label Halston is expected to integrate knitted fox, woven from a yarn that is 70% blue fox hair spun with thread, into the collection.

But popular polls continue to show support for the anti-fur movement. In 1998 the RSPCA found 84% of poll respondents were against using fur. The year before, 70% in a GMTV poll voted against it and 91% in a Cosmopolitan magazine survey. The fur farming prohibition bill has gone through its second reading in the House of Commons and is now at committee stage. Even the fashion world is not entirely convinced by the rehabilitation of fur-wearing. Up-and-coming New York designer Katayone Adeli admitted that she had intended to use fur in the collection she is showing this week, but when she saw the pelts, they turned her stomach. She used fake fur instead. Most people still recoil when faced with upfront evidence of the horrific origins of this fabric: when John Galliano put a fox's head on a garment, the picture made newspapers worldwide, despite the fact that fox fur is now a fairly common fabric on the catwalk.

Still, it isn't the popular cause it once was. A decade ago, it seemed likely that fur would disappear along with an older generation of society ladies. But far from being limited to Upper East Side stalwarts like Herrera and de la Renta, fur is being adopted by a generation of designers who were barely out of college in the days when those wearing mink risked being doused in red paint: Marc Jacobs, current fashion wunderkind, and Bottega Veneta, new darling of the smart young New York set, both showed fur this week. The only thing animal welfare campaigners can take heart from is the fickleness of the industry: perhaps next season, it will be fashionable to care again.

Most people still recoil when faced with upfront evidence of the horrific origins of this fabric: when John Galliano put a fox's head on a garment, the picture made newspapers worldwide, despite the fact that fox fur is now a fairly common fabric on the catwalk. Still, it isn't the popular cause it once was. A decade ago, it seemed likely that fur would disappear along with an older generation of society ladies. But far from being limited to Upper East Side stalwarts like Herrera and de la Renta, fur is being adopted by a generation of designers who were barely out of college in the days when those wearing mink risked being doused in red paint: Marc Jacobs, current fashion wunderkind, and Bottega Veneta, new darling of the smart young New York set, both showed fur this week. The only thing animal welfare campaigners can take heart from is the fickleness of the industry: perhaps next season, it will be fashionable to care again.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's paper talk, with a special Glaswegian twist
fields.trailText: Crisis at Celtic
fields.body:
Crisis at Celtic

After Celtic's 3-1 Scottish Cup defeat at the hands of Inverness Caledonian Thistle, all the papers agree that Celtic will today sack boss John Barnes. But who will take charge when he goes?

The Sun Football director Kenny Dalglish will be asked to take control of team affairs.

The Star Joe Kinnear is hot favourite to take over.

The Express If Kinnear doesn't take over, expect ex-boss Tommy Burns to take charge.

Other rumours

Daily Mail Middlesbrough have joined Spurs in the race to sign Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink. Atletico may accept £5m for a player who cost them £12m in the summer.

The Express Noel Whelan is a £3m target for Leicester. But Coventry don't want to lose the player, and hope to extend the 25-year-old striker's contract - which still has 15 months to run - at the end of the season.

Optasoccer Manchester United have been linked with 24-year-old Sampdoria goalkeeper Matteo Sereni. Arsenal and Real Madrid are also interested.

Arsenal are keeping an eye on wonder-kid Leandro Atilio Romagnoli. The 18-year-old Argentinian is the playmaker at San Lorenzo.

The Mirror Coventry are keeping tabs on £3m Bolton midfielder Claus Jensen. The Danish international is earmarked as a possible replacement for the ageing Gary McAllister.

Daily Star Reading have bid £400,000 for Chelsea midfielder Mark Nicholls. Royals boss Alan Pardew is keen to make Nicholls' current loan move permanent, but Chelsea want more cash for the 22-year-old.

fields.headline: Nazi war criminal loses appeal
fields.standfirst: Special report: Nazi war criminals in Britain
fields.trailText: Retired British Rail ticket collector Anthony Sawoniuk, who was given two life sentences after becoming the first man to be convicted in the UK of Nazi war crimes, today lost his court of appeal bid for freedom.
fields.body:
Retired British Rail ticket collector Anthony Sawoniuk, who was given two life sentences after becoming the first man to be convicted in the UK of Nazi war crimes, today lost his court of appeal bid for freedom.

Three judges, including the lord chief justice, Lord Bingham, ruled his two murder convictions safe. The jury, reduced to 11 through illness, found him guilty unanimously on the first charge and by an 10-1 majority on the second.

Sawoniuk, 78, from south-east London, who claimed his Old Bailey trial last April was an "abuse of the process of the court", was present in the dock as the decision was announced.

He denied murdering Jews in his hometown of Domachevo, Belarus, 57 years ago while serving in a local police force controlled by the Germans.

His counsel, William Clegg QC, had told the appeal judges that the trial judge, Mr Justice Potts, "erred in law" on a number of issues.

He said the judge erred in law in failing to stay the two murder counts on the ground "that the continued prosecution of the appellant amounted to an abuse of the process of the court".

Mr Clegg said there had been a "delay that was unprecedented in the history of our criminal courts of 50-something years between offence and trial".

"We submit that no fair trial is possible after 57 years," he said.

Sawoniuk told the jury during his trial: "I never killed nobody in my life. I never did and I never dreamed of doing it. I am not a monster. I am an ordinary, working class, poor man."

He is the only person to have faced a full trial after an inquiry by the war crimes investigation unit set up as a result of the War Crimes Act of 1991.

fields.headline: Setting Britain's interest rates
fields.trailText: Who decides interest rates?
fields.body:
Who decides interest rates?

The Bank of England's monetary policy committee meets on a monthly basis to set UK interest rates, after the chancellor, Gordon Brown handed over day-to-day control of monetary policy to the Bank five days after Labour's election victory. It was the probably the biggest monetary policy change for more than 50 years: since the Bank of England Act 1998 replaced the 1946 Bank of England Act.

There are nine members of the MPC. Five are from the bank of England, including the governor, Eddie George, and deputy governor Mervyn King. The chancellor appoints four others, who serve fixed terms of two or three years. These currently number two academics and two full-time committee members: Cambridge university professor Willem Buiter, professor Charles Goodhart, Dr DeAnne Julius, and Dr Sushil Wadhwani.

What happens if the MPC disagree?

The MPC takes its decisions on a majority vote, with the governor holding the deciding vote if the committee is split. How each member votes is recorded in the meeting minutes, which are published a week after the decision is announced.

There have been significant rows in the past. Last autumn, the four independent committee members were refused research resources they requested from the deputy governor. Some of the independent members argued that higher productivity was easing long-term inflation pressures, but felt they had insufficient resources to support their case.

The Bank of England backed down, and Eddie George announced each outside member would in future have two economists assigned to them to assist with their research. The MPC also now discusses the work of the Bank's economics team and set its priorities when they release their quarterly inflation report.

Does the government get involved?

Before Mr Brown's decision, setting interest rates was the responsibility of governments.

The government invariably influences the committee in several ways. The MPC is formally charged with delivering price stability. After its foundation, the government instructed it to help maintain its inflation target of 2.5%. It also must "support the government's economic policy, including its objectives for growth and employment."

Members of the Treasury can attend meetings but they are not allowed to vote on the committee's decisions.

There is always speculation about how much influence the government tries to wield over the committee. The Treasury sometimes publicly signals the decisions it wants taking. At the end of January Gordon Brown made a statement on monetary policy at the monthly meeting of European Union finance ministers in Brussels, in which he hinted that rates could rise to head off the threat of inflation.

Michael Portillo recently reversed the Tories' opposition to an independent central bank. He promises that the Conservatives would go further than the government and establish more clearly the independence of the committee's members. Mr Portillo wants to establish a parliamentary committee dedicated to scrutinising the MPC (it is currently done by the Treasury select committee), increasingly accountability and holding the power to scrutinise and confirm committee appointments.

Why did Gordon Brown give up his own power to set rates?

Many observers were amazed that, after an 18-year battle to get its hands on the levers of economic power, Labour threw away the most important one within days of coming to government.

But as Labour pledged in its manifesto, it desired economic stability, creating the correct conditions for economic growth, above all else. Taking the politics out of deciding interest rates could help avert a future cycle of boom-and-bust.

Politicians are wedded to electoral cycles and getting re-elected. Often political needs clash with the best interests of the economy. A government may want to stoke the feelgood factor or wow voters with generously low mortgage rates just before an election, when the economy requires a healthy dose of deflation.

The disastrous aftermath of Black Wednesday, when Norman Lamont was humiliatingly forced to withdraw from the ERM in 1992, and the 1980s boom, stoked by Chancellor Nigel Lawson's inflationary policies, added to the impression that politicians were not to be trusted with interest rate decisions.

What do critics of the Bank argue?

There is an economic argument and a political argument against the existence of the MPC. The economic critique offered by the centre-left over the last two and a half years asserts that the Bank's hawkish, conservative concern to keep inflation down at all costs has made it too ready to increase interest rates.

The inequalities in Britain's economy have been heightened, critics argue, by the Bank's decisions. Recent interest rate rises have aimed to stop the economy and housing market overheating in the south east. But in the north, the economy is less prosperous and companies need low interest rates to encourage them to borrow and invest in their businesses.

Raising interest rates also keeps the pound strong. A high pound, making British exports expensive abroad, has continued to decimate the country's manufacturing base, something which Labour pledged it would put a stop to.

The political argument against the committee suggests that unelected officials should not be in charge of interest rate policy. As shadow chancellor Michael Portillo's proposed reforms indicate, some believe there is a lack of democratic scrutiny and control of the committee.

While part of the Treasury committee's role is to scrutinise the MPC, the US central bank, the Federal Reserve, which sets US interest rates, is watched over by two powerful banking committees, one for the House of Representatives, the other for the Senate. The House committee has 50 members, a support staff of 65, and a £4.8 million budget.

fields.headline: The cleanup has begun
fields.standfirst:
Victor Keegan, editor of Online, gives his verdict on the new site

Lobby briefings part of new Downing Street site

Downing Street's new site
fields.trailText: Victor Keegan, editor of Online, gives his verdict on the new site
fields.body:
Downing Streets re-launched web site is a slick attempt to promote government policy while at the same time providing a navigable gateway through the jungle of online public services. Five years ago the UK government was leading the field with widely praised public access sites like open.gov.uk but then lost the plot and was taken apart last year by the National Audit Office.

Now the cleanup has begun. The new site will do much to restore Whitehalls tarnished web reputation even though the  commendable  idea of making it the first-stop for all government information will inevitably spark fears that this is another extension of Downing Street thought control.

Among the features are sections for news (to be updated more frequently than the previous site), magazines (including Tony Blairs interviews in journals you might have missed), live video links for prime ministers question time (with the actual text attached if you wait a day or so), an impressive multidimensional virtual tour of some of the rooms and even a (politically sanitised) version of the daily briefing Alastair Campbell, the prime ministers senior spokesman, gives to journalists.

There are interactive facilities to cross question ministers, a special site where children can say what they would do if they were PM and an archive containing everything from manifesto commitments (all 177 of them) to biographies of former prime ministers.

It will never match Buckingham Palace in popularity as a web site but it ought to do considerably better than the modest 6,000 to 7,000 visitors a day the previous one enjoyed. It is a good looking site, carefully designed with minimal graphics (except of HIM) to speed up access. It was operating very slowly immediately after launch yesterday, and access to some of the archived material was very flakey, but hopefully thats just teething pains.

What it doesnt have, of course, is access to unpublished government papers of the kind advocates of real freedom of information would like.. (Dream on) It remains to be seen whether the small staff (3 compared with the BBCs 160, as Alastair Campbell was quick to point out yesterday) can produce enough fresh material to keep the clicks going. It deserves to succeed.

webTitle: A sporting chance of a cure

fields.headline: A sporting chance of a cure
fields.standfirst: After too much exercise lays  Michael Brooks low, he looks for remedies on the internet
fields.trailText: After too much exercise lays Michael Brooks low, he looks for remedies on the internet
fields.body:
You've overdone it, haven't you? That new year's resolution to take more exercise seemed like such a good idea. For a few weeks you managed to keep going, and you saw the turkey fat begin to melt from your waistline.

Then your ankles swelled, your ligaments tore, your shoulder gave out, your tennis elbow returned, your knee popped or - as happened to me -your shins splintered. Well that's what it felt like. Walking upstairs became agony, walking down again was worse. I have developed a bandy gait in order to try and keep the weight off my calves. Too much well-intentioned tennis, football and jogging, and now someone seems to be sticking needles through my legs.

Friends told me to go to a sports injury clinic or physiotherapist, but either option will surely cost more money than I want to spend (my body is a temple without an offering plate). Maybe an online check-up, for the price of a local phone call, would be a sensible first option?

I started at Medisport. It couldn't be simpler: you click where it hurts. Each area of the site's body map leads you to description of symptoms and details the possible cause of injury. Then you get advice on managing and treating the problem. They recommend the RICE method - rest, ice, compression and elevation - for managing a low grade injury in its early stages (not that mine is low grade, of course). There are illustrated details of exercises, biological information about what's going on with your body, and advice for helping it heal: vitamin C, surprisingly, is one tonic.

At www.fitnessfind.com there is a huge array of topics, easily accessible from the opening page: no map, but almost every part of the body seems to be covered, as well as different kinds of sport. It has also collated links to a vast array of articles and information available at other sources. Titbits include how to avoid overtraining, arthritis hazards, excessive sweating, and 101 ways to stay fit when you're injured.

At Thrive online there is a searchable database of injuries and treatments, as well as direct access listings for the more common problems, like decompression illness and twisted testicle.

It is, of course, the season for recovering from winter sports injuries. If the slopes have knocked you about, try www.zyworld.com/aviemed These are the web pages of a six-strong medical team based at the foot of the Cairngorms. As well as the obvious ski injury advice, it also has some interesting statistics on the newer dangers of snowboarding.

Snowboarders, it seems are almost twice as likely to injure themselves as skiers, and twice as likely to fracture their bones. The typical profile of an injured boarder is (unsurprisingly) a young, inexperienced male. He will no doubt be gratified to learn that he boasts a pattern of typical injuries very different to those incurred by skiers.

Some US ski sites offer something extra: tips on suing your fellow skiers when they have knocked you from your feet. James Chalat has a law practice in Colorado that specialise in skier on skier collision cases www.skisafety.com. One client won $2.4m from another fumbling skier. Be warned: skiing in the US might hurt your wallet even more than your body.

Of course, you may have opted to start the year with a safe, impact-free sport, such as swimming, and then been shocked by the onset of "swimmers ear".

Help is at hand at www.sinuscare.com, where you can learn how to combat the fungi and bacteria that can cause infections in the ear canal.

There is advice on making your own eardrops with rubbing alcohol as the base. It also tells you about larger biological hazards: of the many types of insects that can get into the ears - gnats, moths, and cockroaches are apparently the most common. Gnats need special attention: they get tangled in the wax and cannot fly out.

One thing I failed to find was a directory of UK sports injury clinics willing to take away my money and my pain. The National Sports Medicine Institute of the United Kingdom has a site, but with little useful information. It does at least give a telephone number, which would help those needing to find local care.

My particular torment, it seems, is caused by shin splints. On the web I have found sound advice: rest (can do, no problem), and a series of exercises to help prevent a recurrence when I start training again.

I plan to start the exercises as soon as I've per fected my resting technique. After all, I should heed the advice given at www.drugbase.co.za

"Common sense, and the self-discipline of knowing when to stop, or when not to start, a session of physical activity are two essential factors in avoiding any kind of injury." I'm sure they're right. I should find the self-discipline to be able to listen to what my body is saying. Pass the peanuts.

webTitle: Blair Witch Project embroiled in litigation

fields.headline: Blair Witch Project embroiled in litigation
fields.trailText: Artisan, the production company behind The Blair Witch Project, finds itself embroiled in legal action over licence fees
fields.body:
Kids, be warned. Before you take your Super-8 camera out into the woods with your mates for a little bit of spooky film action fun pay heed to the legal action that Artisan, the production company behind The Blair Witch Project, now finds itself embroiled in. For the second time in as many weeks the company, which made $140m from last year's sleeper, is taking action against a company for reneging on its licence fees. Artisan is suing the United Artists Theatre Circuit, alleging that the chain failed to pay $3.1m in ticket receipts during the horror hit's summer run.

The lawsuit says United Artists agreed to pay 90 percent of the gross ticket receipts and to faithfully report the price charged for admission and the total number of tickets sold. The chain "failed and refused, and continues to fail and refuse, to make full payment of the licence fee due and owing to Artisan," according to the suit. The company has also begun similar action against Regal Cinemas for almost $6m in damages, alleging the same failure to pay licence fees.

But the litigious company has also found itself on the receiving end of legal action. Former Blair Witch Project partner, Sam Barber, has been told he can now proceed with his claim that he was deprived of an executive producer credit on the film. A US district court judge has refused to grant a motion to dismiss the lawsuit filed by Artisan Entertainment and other defendants. In denying the motion, the judge ruled that Barber could proceed with his claim that the failure to include his credit was unfair competition in violation of federal law.

For the second time in as many weeks the company, which made $140m from last year's sleeper, is taking action against a company for reneging on its licence fees. Artisan is suing the United Artists Theatre Circuit, alleging that the chain failed to pay $3.1m in ticket receipts during the horror hit's summer run. The lawsuit says United Artists agreed to pay 90 percent of the gross ticket receipts and to faithfully report the price charged for admission and the total number of tickets sold. The chain "failed and refused, and continues to fail and refuse, to make full payment of the licence fee due and owing to Artisan," according to the suit. webTitle: Sky stakes out its net ambitions

fields.headline: Sky stakes out its net ambitions
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: British Sky Broadcasting yesterday staked its claim in the internet with plans to spend £250m on the development of online services which build on its television brands over the next 12 to 18 months.
fields.body:
British Sky Broadcasting yesterday staked its claim in the internet with plans to spend £250m on the development of online services which build on its television brands over the next 12 to 18 months.

The company also confirmed the establishment of a joint venture with telecoms company Kingston Communications to pump pay-TV and internet services down telephone cables in a further departure from its core satellite distribution business.

Investors reacted enthusiastically to the plans, along with unexpectedly high subscriber numbers during the past six months, which nudged 4m for the first time. BSkyB shares ended the session 18% higher at £19.15p, continuing a rise which has seen the price almost double since the beginning of the year.

BSkyB chief executive Tony Ball said the £250m would be invested in building up sky.com and skysports.com as well as developing new portals around news and entertain ment. Mr Ball said he aimed to make the sports site Britain's most popular from its present third place by the year's end.

"We see the convergence of media as a huge opportunity," he said. "I want to leverage Sky brands on all devices, whether PCs, broadband, TV or on mobile handsets." The company is close to a deal with BT Cellnet to provide content for its internet-enabled mobile phones.

The cash will also be used to buy stakes in existing web businesses which can provide content for the Sky services. Among the announcements yesterday was BSkyB's investment in books and music e-tailer Streets OnLine and Static, an interactive TV design consultancy. The company also launched a Sky branded online sporting goods retailer.

BSkyB experienced record subscriber growth in its direct to home service during the last three months of 1999 of 384,000, taking the total to just under 4m, of which 2.1m were digital. Mr Ball said the total could feasibly reach 5m by the end of the year. Another 4.4m people subscribe to Sky channels through either cable or terrestial rival ONdigital.

The increasing costs of acquisition, including the price of the free set-top box campaign pushed BSkyB into the red for the first half, recording a loss before tax of £61.5m compared to profits of £53.2m last year. Turnover was 13% higher at £849.7m.

Shares in Kingston climbed 24% to £12.52, which means that Kingston-upon-Hull city council, the company's major shareholder, is now sitting on a stake worth around £2bn.

fields.headline: Geoffrey de Ste Croix
fields.standfirst: Historian who unravelled the mysteries of the class struggle in the ancient world and the decline of the Roman empire
fields.trailText: Geoffrey de Ste Croix, who has died aged 89, was one of the most distinguished and unusual ancient historians of his or any other generation. The vigour of his writing sprang from righteous indignation at the propertied classes' exploitation of the less fortunate: the way that fat cats have flourished at the expense of lean mice.
fields.body:
Geoffrey de Ste Croix, who has died aged 89, was one of the most distinguished and unusual ancient historians of his or any other generation. The vigour of his writing sprang from righteous indignation at the propertied classes' exploitation of the less fortunate: the way that fat cats have flourished at the expense of lean mice.

His first book, The Origins Of The Peloponnesian War (1972), also contained a political and military history of Sparta from archaic times to the end of the 5th century. For any serious student of the subject, there are two essential authors: Thucydides and de Ste Croix.

In 1981 he published the Isaac Deutscher Memorial Prize-winning The Class Struggle In The Ancient Greek World. Hailed for its contribution to Marxist theory, the author's Marxism recommended itself even to those unsympathetic to such views. He saw the exploitation of free and unfree labour by the propertied class as history's motive force, yet his was a class struggle in which there might be no awareness of class, and no overt struggle. The book covers 14 centuries, culminating in an explanation of the decline and fall of the Roman empire in the west.

Geoffrey, or "Croicks" as he mockingly referred to himself, did not start his academic life until he was 40. Born in Macao, he was educated at Clifton school in Bristol, and from 1926 to 1940 practised as a London solicitor. Wartime RAF service took him to Egypt, where he refreshed his knowledge of the ancient languages. He read ancient history at University College, London, and from 1950 to 1953 taught at the London School of Economics and Birkbeck College. He was then appointed fellow of New College, Oxford. There, for a quarter of a century, he taught Greek history.

His lectures were characterised by clarity of exposition. They expounded themes - slavery, finance, food supply - tackled by no other ancient historian in the Oxford of his day, and he gave classes on neglected subjects such as Greek science. He was proud of his contribution to the campaign to persuade the all-male Oxford colleges to to admit women. In the 1970s and 80s, he lectured in Cambridge, Poland - where, said a colleague "he harangued people about how their government misunderstood Marx" - Holland, France, Sweden and the US.

His scholarship was astonishing. When in 1985 his pupils presented him with Crux, his festschrift, the editors had to disregard more than half his interests to produce a coherent volume. His knowledge ranged from pre-colonial Greek exploits of the 8th century BC to the Arab conquests of the 7th century AD; biblical studies from Genesis by way of Job to Revelation, to say nothing of Marx and Marxism.

His early articles, The Character Of The Athenian Empire (1954/5) and Greek And Roman Accounting (1956), are classics; equally valuable are those on the persecution of the Christians, ancient maritime loans, and Roman religion. His Early Christian Attitudes To Property And Slavery (1975) provides an idea of the arguments of The Class Struggle In The Ancient Greek World.

The last 15 years of his life were spent on two large-scale books, Early Christian Attitudes To Women, Sex and Marriage, and Essays In Early Christian History. It became clear that neither would be completed, so he recast their most important parts in 12 essays, Radical Conclusions, to be published by Oxford University Press.

Powerfully built, with a great dome of a head, he competed at Wimbledon in 1929, and once defeated Fred Perry. His country walks might cover nine miles; on his return he would be refreshed by tea, served in two mugs, alternately replenished.

His scholarship was formidable, but he was not. Candid, straightforward, he had an austere charm and a sharp sense of humour. Lunch with Geoffrey at New College meant meeting him at 12.45 and talking throughout the afternoon; goodbye at 5.45 was perhaps the record. To the end he retained an urge to communicate, yet he always listened. One came away a better scholar, perhaps even a better human being. He was a great recommender and condemner - "you can't do better than to use a Pilot pen, but do make sure it's a V5"; "the crap written by that dreadful man Y". Yet he was always courteous, even to the character who, noticing that his leg was in plaster, remarked to him : "No more boppin', then".

He described himself as "an atheist, politely militant", and was increasingly militant with advancing years. St Paul replaced Plato as his "greatest enemy of the human race", and later that distinction went to Jahweh, the Old Testament Jehovah, whose cruelties never ceased to appal him. Yet he was always anxious not to offend sincere believers, and spoke with respect of the best Christian scholarship. He found little to quarrel with in liberation theology: Jesus was OK, his dad was appalling.

In his final years he bore infirmity with courage, including failing sight which must have been the most frustrating. "My memory has preceded me to the grave," he observed. He had once remarked that his doctor had advised him not to work more than 16 hours a day, and he worked to the very end.

An inspiring teacher, a magnificent scholar, one sensed his loathing of inhumanity, and his belief in democracy as a curb, however imperfect, on the oppressors. Few contributions to ancient history are read much longer than a generation. There are exceptions, such as Edward Gibbon and George Grote; Geoffrey, I suspect, will join that company.

He rarely spoke of earlier sorrows - an unhappy first marriage, and his daughter's suicide - but often of what brought him happiness: his love of music, his pride in his garden, the achievements of his family and, above all, his devotion to his wife Margaret, who survives him, as do his two sons.

Geoffrey Ernest Maurice de Ste Croix, historian, born February 8 1910, died February 5 2000

webTitle: A feud in full: John Updike, Norman Mailer and John Irving v Tom Wolfe

fields.headline: A feud in full: John Updike, Norman Mailer and John Irving v Tom Wolfe
fields.standfirst: Why are three US literary heavyweights lining up to stick the knife into Tom Wolfe? Julian Borger reports from Washington
fields.trailText: The literary world loves a good punch-up, and as feuds go, this is the Rumble in the Jungle and the Thrilla in Manila all rolled into one. Just about every contender for the US heavyweight writers’ crown has weighed in and the fight has turned very nasty very quickly.
fields.body:
The literary world loves a good punch-up, and as feuds go, this is the Rumble in the Jungle and the Thrilla in Manila all rolled into one. Just about every contender for the US heavyweight writers' crown has weighed in and the fight has turned very nasty very quickly.

The feud has brought together John Updike, Norman Mailer and John Irving to take on an uppity pretender from the South, Tom Wolfe. And the prize, as usual, is literary greatness - entry to the 20th-century pantheon alongside the likes of Hemingway and Steinbeck.

Wolfe, having worked his way through the ranks of journalism, has staked his claim in the last two decades of the millennium with two blockbuster epics. The first, Bonfire of the Vanities, took on class and race struggle between Wall Street and the Bronx. His long-awaited second tome, A Man in Full, which came out in 1998 after a 17-year pause, did the same for the South.

The public loved both books and has bought well over a million hardback copies of A Man in Full, which narrates the fall from grace of an Atlanta property developer, Charlie Croker. But is it art? And more to the point, is it that Holy Grail of US literature: "The Great American Novel"?

The concerted response to both questions has been a contemptuous "no" from Updike, Mailer and Irving, hitherto the leading lions in the literate-but-accessible category. They say they are defending literary standards, but their defence has been down and dirty.

John Irving, at 57 the dauphin of the trio, was by far the most brutal. Of Wolfe's efforts, he said: "It's like reading a bad newspaper or a bad piece in a magazine. It makes you wince." The author of The World According to Garp added that on any page of a Wolfe novel, he could "read a sentence that would make me gag".

John Updike in his New Yorker review went in for the kill. "A Man in Full," he imperiously concluded, "still amounts to entertainment, not literature, even literature in a modest aspirant form."

Norman Mailer, writing in the New York Review of Books, compared reading the weighty Wolfe novel to making love to a 300lb woman: "Once she gets on top it's all over. Fall in love or be asphyxiated."

The message has been blunt and clear: Wolfe may sell a lot of books but he belongs on the airport shelves alongside Stephen King and all those self-improvement manuals, not in the hallowed hall of the greats.

Wolfe, however, is not the sort to turn the other cheek and slink back to his keyboard. He has instead launched a one-man verbal onslaught against his detractors, flinging entrenched reputations aside with a ferocity that has scandalised even the jaded and scarred New York book world.

"It's a tantrum. It's a wonderful tantrum," he said on the same talk show that Irving used to attack him. "A Man in Full panicked [Irving] the same way it frightened John Updike and Norman. Frightened them. Panicked them."

He described Updike and Mailer as "two old piles of bones". As for the youngest of his three opponents, he points out: "Irving is a great admirer of Dickens. But what writer does he see now constantly compared to Dickens. Not John Irving, but Tom Wolfe . . . it must gnaw at him terribly."

The feud has evidently drawn blood all round, but it is still only in its early rounds. Wolfe has a score-settling essay in the pipeline, called The Three Stooges (no prizes for guessing who). It will be published later this year in a collection of short pieces, Hooking Up, which will also include a side-swipe at an old enemy: the New Yorker, which Wolfe views as the kingpin of a literary establishment which has tried for so long to keep him out in the cold.

The Wolfe-Mailer feud is by far the oldest and cattiest of the three. As far back as 1989, Mailer remarked: "In my mind, there is something silly about a man who wears a white suit all the time, especially in New York."

Wolfe brushed off the sartorial attack, simply pointing out that "the lead dog is the one they always try to bite in the ass". To which Mailer quickly responded: "It doesn't mean you're the top dog just because your ass is bleeding."

Deep below the multiple layers of bitchiness, it is possible to pick out a substantive battle over the future of American novel. The line followed by Updike, Mailer and Irving is that there is a qualitative leap from journalism to literature which Wolfe has tried but failed to complete.

Updike puts the argument most clearly in his New Yorker deconstruction of A Man in Full: "So much local information, so many well-lighted settings, so much news do not quite knit into a novel powered by the human spirit as it gropes and struggles for focus. Wolfe has perhaps too many opinions for a novelist: his characters have a hard time breaking out of the illustrative mold in which they are cast."

Wolfe does not disown his past as a hack. Instead, he claims to have transformed his former trade into something higher - New Journalism, a breathless running-commentary narrative style he pioneered in books like The Right Stuff about the early astronauts. It is a style which has left its mark on a generation of magazine writers.

Now Wolfe is arguing that the New Literature should grow out of the New Journalism, embracing "full-blooded realism".

"In abandoning social realism, novelists also abandoned certain vital matters of technique. As a result, by 1969 it was obvious that . . . magazine writers - the very lumpen proles themselves! - had also gained a technical edge on novelists. It was marvellous," Wolfe wrote.

Wolfe's literary enemies, the feisty novelist insists, are being left behind by his march on realism. "All three have seen the writing on the wall," he said, "and it reads: A Man in Full."

It is bitter dispute, spattered with the bile of old men with one eye on their rivals and the other on posterity. With the exception of Irving, all of them are in the late evening of their lives and can see the end coming. They are clearly in a rush, anxious to land a few last blows before the question of greatness is taken out of their hands for good.

webTitle: Beach trouble rumbles as premiere hits London

fields.headline: Beach trouble rumbles as premiere hits London
fields.trailText: The Beach made a triumphant debut in London last night as the controversy surrounding the making of the film continued to rumble in the background
fields.body:
The Beach made a triumphant debut in London last night as the controversy surrounding the making of the film continued to rumble in the background. As crowds thronged around Leicester Square to catch a glimpse of the movie's star, Leonardo DiCaprio, activists in Thailand showed little sign of abandoning their attempts to highlight the production's alleged damage to Maya Beach, the picture's principal location. Environmental activists look set to continue with their $2.6m lawsuit against Fox (the film's backers), the Thai Forestry Commission and the Thai Agriculture Ministry.

Based on the novel by Alex Garland, The Beach tells the tale of an American backpacker who discovers an idyllic commune on a remote Thai island. But the film's production team are accused of causing irreparable damage to Maya Beach, on Phi Phi Le Island, part of the nation's National Park, by stripping away the native grass, widening the beach and importing non-indigenous coconut trees. A report in South Asia's Nando Times highlights allegations that the beach is now eroding, and quotes a local man Surat Saewkok as claiming that: "The beach is falling apart in front of us. The film people have gone and are going to make money selling the movie, but the villagers are here paying the price." Contesting the activists's lawsuit, Fox lawyer Dusit Wallee takes a more tactful line. "We only need to give the beach time to recover," he told the Nando Times. webTitle: Back from the dead and underhand tactics

fields.headline: Back from the dead and underhand tactics
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: Has a team following-on ever won a Test? asks Dave Kennealy
fields.body:
Has a team following-on ever won a Test? asks Dave Kennealy

It has been done twice - both times by England! The only occasion in the 20th century was the famous match at Headingley in 1981, when Ian Botham turned the match on its head with a rollicking 149 not out after England, following on, had been 135 for 7, still 92 behind Australia. Botham's heroics lifted England to 356, a lead of 129. Bob Willis, with 8 for 43, then bowled Australia out for 111 and England had won by 18 runs. The other time was in 1894-95, when England (325 and 437) came from behind to beat Australia (586 and 166) by ten runs after following on at Sydney.

In the famous "underarm" incident, who were the two batsmen at the time? And when Richard Hadlee took 9 for 56 against Australia, who took the other wicket? asks Dave Arthur

The batsmen at the end of that Australia-New Zealand one-day international, which was played at Melbourne in Feb 1981, were Brian McKechnie (0*) and opener Bruce Edgar (102*). It was McKechnie who faced the notorious underarm delivery, bowled by Trevor Chappell on the orders of his brother Greg (his other brother, Ian, criticised the action from the TV commentary box). New Zealand had needed six off the last ball to tie the match, and McKechnie threw his bat to the floor in disgust.

The bowler who spoiled Hadlee's chances of taking all ten wickets at Brisbane in 1985-86 was offspinner Vaughan Brown. He couldn't keep Hadlee out of the limelight though: it was him who took a tricky catch to send back Australia's Geoff Lawson and give Brown what turned out to be his only Test wicket.

Apart from Jim Laker, has any other bowler taken ten wickets in a Test innings? asks Derek Tempest

Yes, but it was more than 42 years and 1000 Tests later. Anil Kumble, the Indian legspinner, took 10 for 74 against Pakistan at Delhi in 1998-99. Amazingly, Richard Stokes, an Englishman who had been taken to watch Laker's match as a schoolboy in 1956, was there in the crowd to see Kumble repeat the feat.

Who is the only British Prime Minister to have played first-class cricket? asks Natalie Pepper

This was Sir Alec Douglas-Home, later Lord Home, who was Britain's Prime Minister in 1963-64. Earlier, as Lord Dunglass, he had played a few games for Middlesex. He was a fast-medium bowler - Gubby Allen, a captain of England, thought him "decidedly useful" - who took 12 first-class wickets in all. He also toured South America with a non-Test-playing MCC team in 1926-27.

Can you tell me who played international cricket for both England and South Africa? asks Tony Munday

There have been two men who played for both sides: Fred Hearne and Frank Mitchell. Hearne played two Tests for England in South Africa in 1888-89, and then settled there: he then played four Tests for South Africa. Two of his brothers and his son also played Test cricket. Mitchell appeared twice for England in South Africa in 1898-99, the switched sides and played three more Tests for South Africa. He captained SA's team for the Triangular Tournament in England in 1912.

While watching the last day of the fourth Test between South Africa and England at Cape Town, I was confused by an umpiring decision. What is the difference between bat-pad and pad-bat, and which can be given out caught or lbw? asks Joel Bregman

They are technical descriptions to indicate whether the ball hit the bat or the pad first before going on to strike the other one. You can't be given out lbw if the ball hits the bat first (or at least you shouldn't!) but you can be given out caught if the ball hits the pad first, as long as it hits the bat (or the glove holding it) as well.

I enjoyed England's tour of Australia in 1998-99, when I attended both the Melbourne and Sydney Tests. When is England's next tour Down Under, and when will the Test dates be announced? asks Michael Parkinson (no, not that one)

England's next tour of Australia is scheduled for the winter of 2002-03. Precise dates should be released early in 2002, but the likelihood is that the Melbourne Test will be played over the Christmas period and the Sydney one shortly after the New Year, as these have become traditional dates in the Australian sporting calendar.

Apparently a relative of mine was quite a famous cricketer. Can you tell me anything about him? asks Paula Pretlove

The only person of that name to have played first-class cricket in England is John Frederick Pretlove, who was born in 1932. He appeared first for Cambridge University (1954-56), then played for Kent until 1959. He was a left-hand batsman who scored ten first-class centuries in all. He was also a useful football and fives player, and more recently was Kent CCC's president. If you want to try to find out whether he is a relative you could try to contact him by contacting Kent's chief executive at paul.millman.kent@ecb.co.uk

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

fields.headline: Is this the reel thing?
fields.standfirst:
They could be contenders for Oscars but the stars of three films based on truth may find themselves out for the count as the subjects of the real stories hit back

www.oscars.org
fields.trailText: Three films based on true stories may find their hopes of winning Oscars damaged by angry claims from the real-life subjects that too much fiction has been mixed with the fact. With the announcement of the Academy Awards nominations for 2000 approaching, media slanging matches and civil lawsuits are threatening to harm the chances of three of the top contenders.
fields.body:
Three films based on true stories may find their hopes of winning Oscars damaged by angry claims from the real-life subjects that too much fiction has been mixed with the fact. With the announcement of the Academy Awards nominations for 2000 approaching, media slanging matches and civil lawsuits are threatening to harm the chances of three of the top contenders.

The Hurricane, Boys Don't Cry and The Insider, three films based on true stories, are all in the running for prizes in a year when there are no clear favourites and the field is more open than usual.

The Hurricane, starring Denzel Washington, deals with the true story of the black boxer Rubin "Hurricane" Carter, who was convicted of murdering three white people in a bar in New Jersey in 1967 and, following a long campaign to prove his innocence, was eventually freed in 1985.

Boys Don't Cry, starring Hilary Swank, is based on the story of Brandon Teena, a young woman from Nebraska who tried to pass as a man and was killed in 1993 at the age of 21 by two men furious at her deception.

The Insider, starring Russell Crowe, tracks the life of tobacco executive Jeffrey Wigand, who blew the whistle on the corporate behaviour of his former employers Brown and Williamson.

Washington, Swank and Crowe are all thought likely to win Oscar nominations for best actor or actress.

It is The Hurricane that has provoked the angriest rows. They started in December when a former New York Times reporter, Selwyn Raab, who had worked on the case in its early days, attacked the film as fiction. The film's producers hit back with a full-page advertisement in the film business daily Variety, defending the film. Now the row has switched to the internet with another reporter, Cal Deal, setting up a site that casts doubts on both Carter and the film.

"This is not intended to be a balanced presentation, just an accurate counterweight to the Hollywood justice system," says Deal in the introduction to the site. The judge at Carter's trial weighs in with a list of inaccuracies, as do relatives of the victims.

Carter, who lives in Toronto, is on a speaking tour but his lawyers have indicated that they may speak on his behalf this week.

Boys Don't Cry, while critically acclaimed, has also attracted criticism from those who played a part in the real story. Lana Tisdale, Teena's lover, who is played by Chloe Sevigny (herself a contender for best supporting actress), is suing the makers of the film because she claims that her role was misrepresented and that she is portrayed in a false and damaging light as someone who failed to stop a murder. The author of a fictional account of the story is also suing the producers.

The Insider, well reviewed although not a big money-maker, also has been criticised for its portrayals of characters. Mike Wallace, a veteran CBS broadcast journalist, was unhappy with the way he was shown in the film. His part is played by Christopher Plummer, who could win a nomination as best supporting actor.

Wallace is shown in an unflattering light compared with Al Pacino's crusading television journalist. The tobacco company, Brown and Williamson, has also complained about fictional events showing it in a sinister light.

Films based on true events have, of course, always attracted such controversy. In Britain, In the Name of the Father, the story based on the Guildford Four case, was criticised for tweaking the facts, and Hilary and Jackie, about the relationship between the cellist Jacqueline du Pré and her sister, provoked angry responses from many of Du Pré's friends who felt she had been unfairly portrayed.

The reason the rows are particularly relevant this week is that there is a feeling they may scare off Academy voters who do not want the organisation associated with a film that is going to be heavily discredited.

Similar controversies surrounding films such as The People vs Larry Flynt, about the pornographer of that name, and Mississippi Burning - the story of the murder of three civil rights workers - are thought to have damaged those films' chances in the Oscars race. The latter was attacked for concentrating on white rather than black protagonists.

The producers of Boys Don't Cry, the Hurricane and The Insider have been at pains to point out that the film-making process does not allow for exact representations of the facts. But how much the films have been affected by the disputes will be known next Tuesday, when the Oscar nominations are announced, and at next month's ceremony.

In a separate row, members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences' foreign language film committee were urged by leaflet not to attend the screening of the Austrian entry, Northern Skirts, last weekend in protest at the elevation to power of the far-right Austrian politician Jörg Haider and his Freedom party. It was stressed that the boycott was not directed at the film-makers but at Mr Haider himself. According to Variety, some academy members duly declined to attend the screening.

 How the big three rate

The Hurricane

Director Norman Jewison

Leading actors Denzel Washington, Vicellous Reon Shannon, John Hannah, Deborah Kara Unger

Production Universal Pictures and Beacon Communications

Washington has already won best actor at the Golden Globes for The Hurricane. The film was described by one critic as 'lucid, highly suspenseful', but others have been less effusive. Bob Dylan sings Hurricane on the soundtrack. Took $38m (£24m) at the box office in its first five weeks

The Insider

Director Michael Mann

Leading actors Russell Crowe, Al Pacino, Christopher Plummer

Production Touchstone Pictures

'Riveting,' say the critics, who praise Crowe's performance. But critical acclaim has not translated into box office receipts

Boys Don't Cry

Director Kimberly Peirce

Leading actors Hilary Swank, Chloe Sevigny, Peter Sarsgaard, Brendan Sexton III

Production Independent, low-budget, distributed by Fox Searchlight

Swank won best actress at the Golden Globes in January. 'Exceptional and exceptionally disturbing debut film,' said one review. Has taken $4m in four months

fields.headline: Ralph Lauren joins fur frenzy
fields.trailText: Ralph Lauren jumped headlong into the fur debate with a menagerie of an autumn/winter collection in New York yesterday that featured astrakhan, shearling, crocodile skin and knitted lamb.
fields.body:
Ralph Lauren jumped headlong into the fur debate with a menagerie of an autumn/winter collection in New York yesterday that featured astrakhan, shearling, crocodile skin and knitted lamb.

"The lines are clean and the shapes are pure; it's a modern sort of elegance that is as sure as it is discreet," said Lauren.

The animal rights activists who invaded Oscar de la Renta's show the day before, however, would probably find nothing discreet about a floor-length fur coat utilising the modish technique of "knitted shearling", but Lauren's clients loved it and gave the designer a standing ovation.

The collection even received a royal seal of approval from the Duke of York, who was seated in the front row.

It was a strong collection from the designer who personifies Ivy League style. This season for Lauren elegance equals black, and lots of it. But slim-cut black suits were brightened up with skinny red patent leather belts and matching boots, and plunge-back black jersey dresses were cut to cling to the body. Model Alek Wek shone in an inky-black quilted velvet coat with a high Queen Amidala-like collar, proving that velvet can be just as lustrous as mink in the right hands.

Save for a lone angora hooded jacket, sportswear was absent from the collection, with Lauren opting instead for a casual daywear ensemble of Fair Isle turtlenecks, Donegal tweed jackets, and faintly metallic leather trousers or skirts.

For evening these misty shades made way for gold, bronze and red, with sequinned T-shirts and long velvet skirts. Last out was the Brazilian model Gisele Bundchen in a gold-mesh bikini top - the perfect photo opportunity.

webTitle: The best strip joint scene:  Summer of Sam

fields.headline: The best strip joint scene:  Summer of Sam
fields.trailText: New York, 1977. Richie (Adrien Brody) takes new girlfriend Ruby (Jennifer Esposito) to his place of employment, Male World. In the foyer, his boss Midnight (Michael Imperioli) sits on the phone, lightly fingering his stetson.
fields.body:
New York, 1977. Richie (Adrien Brody) takes new girlfriend Ruby (Jennifer Esposito) to his place of employment, Male World. In the foyer, his boss Midnight (Michael Imperioli) sits on the phone, lightly fingering his stetson.

"What you got this time?" he mutters. "Because I heard it before from you and I got trouble from you - that's because you send me chicken. I don't need no chicken, I don't need no trouble from the law, thank you very much."

He looks up, noticing Richie.

"Hey."

He returns to the phone.

"Let me get back to you, OK? I'm working, I'm working. Somebody's gotta make some money here."

He replaces the receiver.

"Hell-o Richie."

"Hey - this is Ruby."

"Hell-o Ruby."

"Midnight, let me do a show tonight. One show."

"One show? I got rules, Richie, and you know the rules - five shows a day, seven days a week."

"I know."

"Oh, you know. But if I break the rules for you, I'm going to have every crabby little punk coming up here wanting to dance every time they need a dime bag."

"This girl's special to me."

Midnight places his hand on his heart.

"Oh! Well, then you appeal to my sense of romantic. Let me see how special she is - "

He leans around to take a look at Ruby.

"What colour panties you have on, honey?"

See also: Hardcore, Lenny, The Player's Club

Don't see also: Striptease

Pointless trivia: Michael Imperioli - who also plays Christopher in The Sopranos - co-wrote Summer Of Sam with Spike Lee.

Jörg Haider surrounds himself with women. But, says Kate Connolly , he is more interested in what they can do for him than what he can do for them

The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Jörg Haider, leader of Austria's far-right Freedom Party (FPO), once said that politics was no place for a woman, adding: "I've never met an erotic female politician. It does damage to almost all women."
fields.body:
Jörg Haider, leader of Austria's far-right Freedom Party (FPO), once said that politics was no place for a woman, adding: "I've never met an erotic female politician. It does damage to almost all women."

So it is strange that in recent years women have increasingly been able to make a career in the FPO. Haider had no less than five female deputies when his party entered a government coalition with the conservative People's Party last week. His most loyal sidekick, Susanne Riess-Passer, 39, has been made vice chancellor of Austria. A further two FPO women have been given powerful portfolios; one in charge of social affairs, the other appointed economic state secretary.

However, Maria Rösselhumer, author of a recent book ,The FPO and Women, is sceptical about how much women's prominence in the party reflects its commitment to equality. She believes Haider is simply trying to secure the female vote for his male party and its male issues. Haider's "heroines", she points out, have strongly opposed quotas as a means of boosting female representation - "Ability and not the sex should be the determining factor," says Theresia Zierler, spokesperson for FPO women.

Women in the Freedom Party have always spoken out against the need for a women's minister. Rösselhumer says their attitudes are a "stab in the back for the achievements of present day female-friendly politics". Some of Haider's fiercest critics of recent weeks have been women who, incidentally, make up only 39% of FPO voters. The female vote has been falling for the party for the last 18 years. Barbara Prammer who was women's minister until last week, when she not only had to clear her office but saw her portfolio "sucked into" the social affairs ministry, says the internal make up of the FPO makes it impossible to class it as Frau-friendly. "Haider has always wanted to send women back to the stove," she says, and calls Haider's "children's cheque", which would put £280 a month into the pockets of mothers, an election gimmick.

She and others are concerned that the slow but sure progress made for women in recent years, such as the 50-50 housework law where couples have to split the chores, is in danger of losing ground. Already, for example, proposed pension laws show that women will be worse off under the new government. "When the FPO talks of women it really means well-behaved mothers," says Elfriede Hammerl of the Liberal Forum party.

Many political observers have also dismissed as propaganda the presence of women within a party which has an ostensibly male, even homoerotic outlook. Its followers can trace their initial contact to the party back to the days when they belonged to fraternities, or Burschenschaften , whose post-pubescent members gathered to fence, drink beer and go mountaineering. Haider was a member, so was his new justice minister, Michael Krüger, and the general secretary, Peter Wesenthaler. A former Haider confidant, the blond, blue-eyed Christian Scheider says in a documentary about the FPO, The Election Campaigners: "We have a friendship which extends beyond the normal call of duty."

So which women does Haider trust? There is, first and foremost, his mother, Dorothea, a former member of the Nazi party's League of German Girls (his father was in the Hitler Youth). A disciplinarian, she persuaded her son to abandon his dream to be a professional actor and instead encouraged him in his political career. Then there is his sister, Ursula Haubner, who was tipped to become the new social affairs minister; and, of course, his wife, Claudia, who eschews the limelight and seems much less concerned about her looks than her husband. She also, reportedly, has a more liberal outlook, as do their two adult daughters. Finally there is Vice Chancellor Riess-Passer, known within FOP as the King's Cobra for her apparent ability to get rid of anyone whose loyalty flags.

To give Riess-Passer the highest office of any woman in Austrian politics was a shrewd move on Haider's part. If anyone accuses him of not giving women a chance, he can, of course, point to this shining example.
