fields.headline: Taliban fuels asylum theory
fields.standfirst:
Taliban fuels hijack asylum speculation

Stansted hijack: special; report
fields.trailText: The Afghan authorities in Kabul admitted for the first time yesterday that asylum may be the motive behind the hijack of one of its planes to Stansted airport.
fields.byline: Will Woodward, Ewen MacAskill  and  Jason Burke  in Islamabad
fields.body:
The Afghan authorities in Kabul admitted for the first time yesterday that asylum may be the motive behind the hijack of one of its planes to Stansted airport.

Mullah Ahmadullah, the head of the national carrier, Ariana, claimed the armed hijackers were closely linked to a large family group aboard the Boeing 727. He said that an airline worker called Najibullah, who was released when the plane stopped in Tashkent, had disclosed that the hijackers had spoken, laughed and shared food with a family of between 30 to 40 who had boarded the plane claiming to be on their way to a wedding in the north of Afghanistan.

He described how shortly after takeoff from Kabul one of the men stood up as if to go to the toilet but walked into the cockpit. As he did so, the rest of the hijackers stood up, brandished their weapons and calmly asked the passengers to put their hands on their heads and stay seated.

The hijackers' weapons are believed to have been smug gled aboard the plane by female passengers who concealed them under the voluminous burqas - full-length cloaks - that Taliban regulations force women to wear.

Taliban authorities yesterday arrested at least four workers at Kabul airport for helping, or allowing, the hijackers to take weapons on to the plane. It was unclear whether they had been arrested for merely failing to ensure security or whether they were alleged to be complicit in the hijack.

They included officials of Ariana and female workers from the security department at the airport.

Credence was added to the asylum theory by the presence at Stansted of Hope Hanlan, the British representative of the United Nations High Commission for Refugees. Her role is to give a view on asylum applications.

As the hijack approached its fourth day at Stansted, negotiations between police and the hijackers stabilised after a short burst of panic among the hijackers in the early hours of the morning when four crew members, including the pilot, escaped through the cockpit window.

Negotiators feared the hijackers, who are armed with hand guns, could start shooting passengers. It is understood threats were made.

Police, who described the chaos that followed as the lowest point in the hijack, said the situation had "changed for the better" yesterday.

Assistant chief constable Joe Edwards said: "The escape of the flight crew clearly upset people on board the aircraft and altered the very calm nature of the negotiations that have taken place. We had to work really hard last night to restore trust. We have done that, we're back on an even keel."

Asked about the possibility that the hijackers were asylum seekers, he said: "Putting labels on people isn't going to be very helpful." He said the spec ulation may have been heard by the hijackers.

Three of the nine hostages released at Stansted before yesterday have applied for asylum. But the home office insisted the hijackers had still to make any specific demands, other than for food and sanitation.

There was a nod from the authorities that the hijackers, though described as armed and dangerous, were relatively amateurish and not representatives of a hardline Islamic faction.

A UNHCR spokesman said the police had "not formally requested asylum but if the issue comes up, they would seek our help."

Ms Hanlan, who was phoned at 3am on Tuesday with a request to help, will provide expert opinion on human rights in Afghanistan to help British authorities judge asylum claims.

In a 1996 hijack of a Sudanese plane, successfully negotiated by police at Stansted, the then UNHCR representative, Philippe Lavanchy, was called in. The six Iraqi men involved in the hijack received jail terms but were cleared two years later on appeal and are living in London waiting a decision on their asylum applications.

Afghanistan is one of the top sources of asylum seekers coming to Britain, with refugee status being granted in about a third of cases. An average of 360 applications a month have been lodged in the UK by Afghans since October.

At 3am yesterday - about four hours after the men escaped - a steward fell as he was pushed down the stairs of the plane.

By the time the hijackers broke off talks at 4am to get some rest, an uneasy peace had been restored. At 6am, when contact was resumed, talk returned to "housekeeping" matters such as refuelling the generators and bringing food on board.

When breakfast was deliv ered shortly before 9am two hijackers emerged from the plane for the first time, training guns on two hostages who picked up the food.

Shortly after 5pm last night, two figures emerged from the aircraft and carried out what looked like an inspection.

Some 151 people remain onboard the plane, including 21 children, nine crew and what police believe to be six to 10 hijackers.

It was hoped that the escaped men - the captain, 54, the second captain, 50, a first officer, 53, and a flight engineer, 54, all Afghan nationals - would provide vital information about the hijackers.

The captain's escape makes it virtually certain that the plane will not take off from Stansted with the hijackers on board.

The Boeing 727 was captured during an internal Afghan flight on Sunday and arrived at Stansted airport in Essex at 2.01am on Monday with 165 people on board.

webTitle: Arms firm linked to Rwandan army chief

fields.headline: Arms firm linked to Rwandan army chief
fields.standfirst: Labour's ethical foreign policy: special report
fields.trailText: A British company that supplied arms to Rwanda during the country's civil war has been linked to the former army chief arrested in Britain on suspicion of genocide.
fields.body:
A British company that supplied arms to Rwanda during the country's civil war has been linked to the former army chief arrested in Britain on suspicion of genocide.

Investigations following the tragic events of 1994 show that soldiers in the provinces where Tharcisse Muvunyi was a senior commander used military equipment which was almost certainly supplied by Mil-Tec, an Isle of Man company which arranged the shipment of more than £3.3m of hardware to Rwanda.

Muvunyi, 46, was remanded in custody at Bow Street magistrates court in London on Monday, following his arrest at the weekend by officers acting on a warrant from the United Nations international criminal tribunal for Rwanda. He has been implicated in the deaths of more than 100,000 people. and has been living in Britain for almost two years.

He will be transferred to the tribunal, in Arusha, Tanzania, unless he appeals.

Ammunition found by British television documentary makers at a massacre site in Butare province, where Muvunyi operated, was taken back to Britain for analysis, which showed that it had come from Albania. Research by aid organisations, the UN, and journalists has not established that any firm other than Mil-Tec supplied arms from Albania to Rwanda in 1994, when 800,000 Tutsis, along with moderate Hutus, died at the hands of members of the Hutu majority.

Mil-Tec's directors fled Britain when the deals were revealed. They were never prosecuted, because the Conservative government had omitted to incorporate the UN arms embargo against Rwanda into Isle of Man law. In addition, the arms shipments did not require export licences, since Mil-Tec was brokering the deals rather than supplying the weapons.

Oxfam, which recently compiled a report on arms shipments to Rwanda, said the rules governing arms brokering should be tightened. It argues that a white paper on the subject, prepared by the department of trade and industry in 1998, but not yet enacted, does not go far enough.

Ed Cairns, senior policy adviser for Oxfam, said: "Any reasonable person would be appalled to hear that a British- based company armed the killers in the Rwandan genocide and did so with impunity. The sad fact is that similar deals could happen again because the British government has failed to outlaw such activities of Mil-Tec and their ilk. Until the government toughens up the law on arms exports to sensitive destinations, brokered arms will continue to fall into the wrong hands."

Muvunyi's lawyers are expected to announce by the end of this week whether he will appeal against his transfer to Tanzania. The UN tribunal indicted him last week on five counts of "genocide and crimes against humanity" allegedly committed while he was a military commander between April and June 1994.

It is alleged that Muvunyi, while a military commander in Butare and Gikongoro provinces, sanctioned the murder of 25 children living in a convent. The nuns tried to protect the children, but the killers found them hiding in cupboards and above ceilings. They were led out with promises of cake, forced to lie down in the back of a lorry and driven to a forest where they were butchered.

In court on Monday, Muvunyi's solicitor said that he denied any involvement in genocide and had tried to prevent killings in the region. After the civil war Muvunyi fled the country. The UN tribunal for Rwanda, set up in the aftermath of the genocide, indicted him last week following pressure by human rights activists.

fields.headline: Straw unmasked as 'flaccid liberal'
fields.standfirst: Jack Straw online - special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw was finally unmasked as a "flaccid liberal" when he only just flunked the Guardian Unlimited website "woolly liberal" test yesterday.
fields.body:
Jack Straw was finally unmasked as a "flaccid liberal" when he only just flunked the Guardian Unlimited website "woolly liberal" test yesterday.

In his first online chat on the web since he became home secretary, Mr Straw rejected calls from Guardian readers to legalise cannabis, but also hinted the government would not rush to reintroduce his plan to restrict the right to choose jury trial. Downing Street insisted in the wake of the defeat by the Lords on January 20 that a new bill would be reintroduced into parliament "by the end of February at the latest". Mr Straw, however, said he would be bringing back the mode of trial bill before the end of the parliamentary session - which lasts until November. "I can't say for certain whether it will before the end of this month."

Mr Straw admitted that the answers he had given to the website's 10 point "woolly liberal" test showed him as a flaccid liberal. "You'd like the world to be a little better - you just don't want to have to make the effort yourself. But don't kid yourself - that shrivelled and underused liberal conscience impresses nobody," was the website verdict.

webTitle: PM curbs arms sales to Congo war zone

fields.headline: PM curbs arms sales to Congo war zone
fields.standfirst: Labour's ethical foreign policy: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has ordered a tightening of arms exports to countries involved in the Congo civil war which has claimed tens of thousands of lives.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has ordered a tightening of arms exports to countries involved in the Congo civil war which has claimed tens of thousands of lives.

The move follows government embarrassment over The Guardian disclosure last month that Mr Blair had intervened to allow the go-ahead of spare parts for Hawk jets to Zimbabwe, which has one of the biggest armies in the Congo. Hawks have been used in the conflict.

Mr Blair said British companies wanting to export arms to the Congo and the six countries surrounding will be subject to new rules.

One ministerial source described Mr Blair's statement as "very strong" and that the new criteria were stringent.

The decision to allow the sale of the Hawk spare parts is not being revoked. But Mr Blair said that in future such exports will be subjected to the new rules, even if it means breaking existing contracts.

A government spokesman refused last night to give any indication of what equipment to Central Africa would be affected. "We never disclose such things," he said.

The initial decision to allow the export of the Hawk spares upset ministers and Labour backbenchers, and was made against the advice of the foreign secretary, Robin Cook. The international development secretary, Clare Short, also opposed the sale.

Mr Blair, in a parliamentary written answer, said that following an inter-departmental review "the government's policy on export licences for countries intervening in the conflict in the Democratic Republic of the Congo has been tightened." The United Na tions security council is looking at a proposal to send in more than 5,000 troops as monitors of the fragile ceasefire.

As part of the new policy, Mr Blair said: "We will not grant export licences for new military dual-use equipment where there is a clear risk that it would be used in the DRC." Jeeps and other equipment that have a civilian as well as military role will fall into this category.

In a further toughening of the approach to Central Africa, open arms licences will not longer be granted to companies seeking to export to the seven countries involved. An open licence means that if permission is given for the export of one item, such as a tank, all repeat orders automatically go through, as well as spares. From now on, every item, including spares, will be individually scrutinised.

Mr Blair said that the British and European Union criteria for arms sales will be rigorously implemented and applications for licences will be examined on a case by case basis.

Mr Blair said: "This will include applications to provide spares for UK equipment already supplied under pre-existing contracts. In reaching decisions on such applications, we will take into account the wider implications of forcing UK comapnies to break existing obligations."

The prime minister's response on spares is ambiguous.

The government, having previously said its hands were tied by existing contracts, admitted for the first time it is now prepared to break these. But Mr Blair at the same time also acknowledged the argument of the department of trade and industry, the ministry of defence and the arms companies that to do so would damage Britain's reputation for reliability.

Jenny Tonge, Liberal Democrat international development spokeswoman, said last night: "I welcome any real tightening of policy, but greater transparency is still required on this issue. Obviously the DRC is a conflict zone and we need an absolute assurance that Britain is not assisting a military regime in attacking its neighbour."

Dr Tonge argued that the sale of arms to Zimbabwe is not compatible with the EU code of conduct on arms exports.

In a further toughening of the approach to Central Africa, open arms licences will not longer be granted to companies seeking to export to the seven countries involved. An open licence means that if permission is given for the export of one item, such as a tank, all repeat orders automatically go through, as well as spares. From now on, every item, including spares, will be individually scrutinised. Mr Blair said that the British and European Union criteria for arms sales will be rigorously implemented and applications for licences will be examined on a case by case basis. Mr Blair said: "This will include applications to provide spares for UK equipment already supplied under pre-existing contracts. In reaching decisions on such applications, we will take into account the wider implications of forcing UK comapnies to break existing obligations." The prime minister's response on spares is ambiguous. The government, having previously said its hands were tied by existing contracts, admitted for the first time it is now prepared to break these. But Mr Blair at the same time also acknowledged the argument of the department of trade and industry, the ministry of defence and the arms companies that to do so would damage Britain's reputation for reliability. Jenny Tonge, Liberal Democrat international development spokeswoman, said last night: "I welcome any real tightening of policy, but greater transparency is still required on this issue. Obviously the DRC is a conflict zone and we need an absolute assurance that Britain is not assisting a military regime in attacking its neighbour." Dr Tonge argued that the sale of arms to Zimbabwe is not compatible with the EU code of conduct on arms exports.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: A useful lesson on the effectiveness of the much-feared whips comes from Glasgow MP George Galloway. In December 1998, when George spoke passionately against the bombing of Iraq, an unfamiliar figure from the whips office sat next to him, eventually hissing "sit down and shut up"
fields.body:
 A useful lesson on the effectiveness of the much-feared whips comes from Glasgow MP George Galloway. In December 1998, when George spoke passionately against the bombing of Iraq, an unfamiliar figure from the whips office sat next to him, eventually hissing "sit down and shut up".

At this George turned to the Speaker and declared "I will not be silenced, this is a free parliament" - a quote much repeated at the time. He took care not to find out the chap's name, thinking no more of him until last Tuesday when, poised to abstain in the vote on suspending the Northern Ireland executive, the same whip came over and told him that if he did so it would be a disgrace and he would be in the gravest trouble. This time the threat had an effect. George abandoned his plans to abstain and (for the first time) voted against the government. The man in question is about five foot six inches, balding with a moustache and so anonymous that none of the senior whips recognise his description. If you know his name, let us know and we'll gladly bring his merits to wider attention.

 That fine campaigning journal Psychic News reports a miscarriage of justice. Its front page splash reveals that Australian palmist Andrew Fitzherbert is appealing against his conviction for the murder of Dr Kathleen Marshall, president of the Queensland Cat Protection Society.

He believes the real killer lies within the seething cauldron of hate that is the Australian cat-lovers circle: according to a Sydney tabloid, the QCPS was "a den of spite" packed with members who hated Dr Marshall, while she also had "many enemies among the cat-hating contingent". Given all this, it does seem scandalous that the palmist was convicted on such flimsy evidence as the finding at the scene of the crime of his blood and DNA, and we wish him well with the appeal.

 The BBC's highly confidential log for Sunday, January 30 has been passed to us, and it seems, alas, that the documentary Blair's 1000 Days was not a great hit. Of 28 calls received, 24 "felt that this programme was nothing more than a party political broadcast for the Labour party and are unhappy that the licence fee is used to produce programmes such as this". Ouch. The one sample quote given ("it seems the BBC must be getting paid by the Labour party") comes from a viewer listed simply as Mr G Brown.

 My eye is drawn to an advert in Monday's media section. "Bagshot, Surrey: television production company requires Assistant to Head of International Programme Sales." Gosh, how glamourous. "Salary: £11K pa" Eleven thousand, eh? How amazingly generous. Although there is no mention of the firm's name, the field is rather narrowed by the fact that there is, so far as anyone knows, only one TV company in Bagshot. That, of course, is Ardent, owned by His Royal Highness Prince Edward, who only recently was complaining to the Americans about his fellow countryman's hatred of success.

 Meanwhile, there is other royal news. Crown Prince Pavlos of Greece and his wife the Crown Princess are expecting their third child, according to a press release from Robert S Leaf Consultants. But this is just tremendous news, and we ring Grainne Keegan to ask if we might speak in person to the Crown Prince, who lives in America, to congratulate him on his fecundity, and to ask what crown he imagines himself to be prince of, given that his father is that old creep non-King Constantine, whose throne the Greeks so wisely abolished in 1974.

 Hats off to the Dobson campaign team, who react to the Co-op's decision not to split its pro-Ken vote in the electoral college with great style. It is, says the Dobbo camp, "an outrageous abuse of democracy". Oooh, Dobbo, you amaze us. No, really, you do. You bleedin' well amaze us.

fields.headline: EU opens Windows 2000 inquiry
fields.standfirst:
Microsoft
E-finance: special report
The European Commission: special report
Microsoft on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Microsoft faced the prospect of a battle with regulators on both sides of the Atlantic last night after the European commission said it was to investigate the latest version of the software company's operating system, Windows 2000.
fields.body:
Microsoft faced the prospect of a battle with regulators on both sides of the Atlantic last night after the European commission said it was to investigate the latest version of the software company's operating system, Windows 2000.

Mario Monti, the new competition commissioner, said the inquiry followed complaints from users and competitors that the new software would give Microsoft a dominant position in the market.

The inquiry comes just seven days before the launch of Windows 2000.

Microsoft yesterday pledged to cooperate with the inquiry but insisted it would not derail the launch.

Microsoft was informed of the investigation only last week, and was not given any prior warning of the public announcement yesterday. It has four weeks to respond.

Mr Monti said information supplied to the commission suggested that Microsoft had designed parts of Windows 2000 in a way "which will permit it to leverage its dominance in PC operating systems on to other markets".

He said these other markets would include server operating systems and "ultimately e-commerce".

The investigation throws open the possibility that Microsoft will become embroiled in a long-running and expensive battle with regulators in the same way that it has been drawn into a protracted and damaging dispute with the United States justice department.

Microsoft said there might be a connection between the commission's action and the investigation in the US - given that competition officials often shared information and strategy.

John Frank, Microsoft's director of European law and corporate affairs, said the common link between the investigations appeared to be "Sun Microsystems lobbying rather desperately to slow down Windows 2000".

However, the US justice department insisted that it had no prior knowledge about the announcement from Brussels. An official said the American inquiry was still dealing with legal issues and that the next hearing would be held on February 22.

Mr Frank said that the company took the European inquiry "very seriously", and he was confident that Microsoft could address the commission's concerns.

The commission's inquiry is examining whether Microsoft has "bundled" its Windows 2000 operating system with other Microsoft products so that its competitors' products are put at a disadvantage.

Three years in development, Windows 2000 is designed for business computers and networks and uses a different software architecture to Windows 98, used by householders.

Microsoft will reject the allegations by arguing that Windows 2000 can be used in a "mixed environment" with, for example, a rival Unix operating system.

Mr Frank said that Microsoft products would be "dead in the water" if they did not work well in a mixed environment, given that many corporate users require this flexibility.

The company was also under an obligation to ensure that its personal computer and server software work well together, given that clients require this compatibility.

Mr Monti sought to dampen speculation about the inquiry by noting that it would be "hugely premature" to discuss sanctions against Microsoft.

But should the allegations be proved Microsoft would be made to change Windows 2000 and could face fines.

fields.headline: Financial websites could be next
fields.standfirst:
eGame - With CNN, Yahoo! and Amazon hit, Guardian writers explore the hackers' minds and future targets

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Investigators have narrowed down the source of the initial attack on some of the world's biggest internet sites to 50 computer addresses, it was disclosed yesterday as more e-commerce and information providers were hit.
fields.body:
Investigators have narrowed down the source of the initial attack on some of the world's biggest internet sites to 50 computer addresses, it was disclosed yesterday as more e-commerce and information providers were hit.

Yahoo, the first site to be brought down on Monday by floods of useless information, was working with the Federal Bureau of Investigation to trace the hackers involved, but experts said that to do this it might not be enough to have the suspect computers' IP (internet protocol) addresses.

"Because the computer has been tracked doesn't mean that the machine is the culprit," said Sharon Machlis of Computer World magazine. "Some computers have the same IP all the time but someone could be spoofing them or seizing control of them. What you need to know is whether there is evidence in the machines of the guilty parties."

Corporations and universities were most vulnerable to having their computers hijacked for the assaults, in which dozens or hundreds around the internet are instructed to bombard a target site, which runs out of memory and slows down or closes.

ZDNet, an information tech nology site, and ETrade were both hit for a time yesterday, joining a progressively less exclusive club. Already hit on Tuesday were the commercial retailers Amazon.com and Buy.com, the auctioneer eBay and the media provider CNN.com. It emerged yesterday that the cyber assaults had slowed down traffic across the net by as much as 20%.

"The FBI is probably trying to mobilise everybody they have," said a US internet security consultant, Ira Winkler. "This is exactly what they've been fearing."

Analysts were waiting to see where the hackers might strike next. "With the e-commerce side already under threat, it's logical that financial sites will be the next target," said Jyoti Banerjee, chief executive at TBC Research.

"So far consumers have been held up from buying CDs, so for the end user it doesn't cause much disruption. But hackers are just as capable of holding up trading in shares. If you lose trade in the markets it makes a very big difference." The disruption to Buy.com happened on the day of its initial public stock offering. Its chief financial officer, Mitch Hill, said the intrusions had been traced to computers in Boston, New York and Chicago.

An FBI spokesman said it was too early to confirm that the attacks were linked, but those in the business were sure that they were.

"I have no doubt that these are coming from the same individual or group," said John Vranesevich, founder of antionline.com, a website that deals with security and hacking.

The biggest challenge to the previously inexorable march of the internet coincided with a conference in San Jose, California, of the North American Network Operators' Group -with denial of access top of the agenda.

Denial of service attacks can be launched without much technical skill by employing freely available programs such as Tribe FloodNet, hiding them on servers around the internet and then activating them simultaneously.

Experts were divided on the hackers' motives. Vesey Crichton, European marketing and strategy director for the AltaVista search engine, suggested that they could be driven by a number of urges or a combination. "They might want to show the vulnerability of the internet. Someone could be annoyed about all the hype and the feeling that the general public doesn't understand what they're doing on the net.

"They could be wistful for the net as it was, when it seemed to be just for a closed community, as opposed to how it is now. Or it could be pure malice. They could be anywhere. People think 'America' because we have the highest number of users and the most e-commerce and you get most attention here. Whether they are caught depends on how much information the companies have who have been hit, or perhaps someone will start bragging about it."

Ted Julian, founder of @Stake, said: "There's no such thing as absolute security on the net just as there isn't in real life, but we can do a better job: we need better routers and better links so that we can better detect an attack before it happens."

 Victims and villains

Belgium

A hacker calling himself Red Attack threatened to switch off the power supply for two hours last September. When Electrabel, the Belgian power company, warned of the dangers of turning off the energy, the hacker simply proved he could carry out his threat by entering the computer code. The month before, a hacker broke into the computer system of the Générale de Banque via its website. He got into customer accounts but never made a transaction

Lloyd's of London

The firm had to close down its website in early January after a hacker twice tried to break into its system. The hacker got into the website, leaving two messages, but could not tap into Lloyd's computer system: the website was run by an independent company and was therefore unconnected. The site offered information on brokers and agents but was not a vehicle for online business transactions

TV shows

Hackers infiltrated the computer systems of the UK quiz show Who Wants to be a Millionaire this month, trying unsuccessfully to steal questions and tamper with the choice of contestants

Citibank

In 1992 Vladimir Levin masterminded the first bank raid to use the internet, withdrawing more than $12m (£7.5m) from Citibank accounts. Levin hacked his way into Citibank on an old computer in a St Petersburg accountancy firm and transferred large sums to accounts in countries around the world. He used a web of Russian expatriates to launder the stolen money. Levin was arrested in 1995 at Stansted and extradited to the US, where he is serving a prison sentence. The FBI recovered most of the money

Itar-Tass

The Russian news agency's website was defaced last December by hackers protesting against Russian action in Chechnya. They posted the message: "We're here to fight evil and our power is growing" and signed themselves Princes of Darkness and Angels of Freedom. At the time, Itar-Tass backed the military campaign

Microsoft

The free hotmail electronic mail service was broken into last September. Hotmail, hosting more than 40m users, had to shut down for five hours after a security problem was reported: email accounts could be read by anyone. A group called Hacker's Unite posted a web address which gave anyone who inputted a particular user name access to hotmail accounts. After logging on, people could send, receive and delete emails in that account. The group claimed it wanted to draw attention to Microsoft's "spotty security"

The CIA, the Pentagon and the US government

Spurred on by the movie Wargames in 1983, hackers, cyber terrorists and foreign governments have tried to break into the computer systems of the Pentagon, the CIA and other sensitive government departments. Success rates vary and security is constantly being tightened. There are thousands of attempts to crack military secrets every year and attacks have seen the web pages of the White House, FBI and departments of defence, energy and interior taken down for repair

DTI and UK government

Hackers have twice broken into files at the depart ment of trade and industry, once in 1996 and again this year when a DTI computer was programmed to re-route email. The home office investigated nine cases of hacking break-ins last year, one of which was the leaking of the Macpherson report on the Stephen Lawrence murder inquiry. The Northern Ireland office investigated seven. In August 1996 hackers ran up a £1m phone bill for Scotland Yard, but did not access any files

The Scottish and Welsh parliaments

Scottish hackers cracked Scotland's official government website last September. They replaced a picture of the first minister, Donald Dewar, with one of the Scottish nationalist Alex Salmond. The group cracked the Welsh parliament's website too

Yahoo!

In 1997 hackers got into the Yahoo! website, replacing the home page with a ransom demand. Unless the noted hacker Kevin Mitnick was released, it said, a computer virus would be embedded in all Yahoo!-users' computers. The company dismissed the threat as a hoax

webTitle: FBI and multinationals no match for 100,000 hackers

fields.headline: FBI and multinationals no match for 100,000 hackers
fields.standfirst:
Criminals -The rise of the 'script kiddie' is blamed for a surge in attacks

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: There were audible sighs of relief from corporations and governments across the globe when 2000 dawned with little sign of the millennium bug and the computer meltdown doomsayers had predicted.
fields.body:
There were audible sighs of relief from corporations and governments across the globe when 2000 dawned with little sign of the millennium bug and the computer meltdown doomsayers had predicted.

But barely had exhausted IT operatives put their feet up after a punishing schedule of Y2K-compliance work than a series of alarming breaches of computer security began in Japan and the United States.

It has already been a vintage year for hacking. On January 21 the celebrated hacker Kevin Mitnick was released from prison after serving five years for five fraud offences related to breaking into the computer systems of multinational giants including Sun Microsystems and Motorola.

"I saw myself as an electronic joyrider," Mr Mitnick, 36, told CBS television following his release. "I don't consider myself a thief."

Neither did the hacking community. Hackers campaigned for his release by breaking into websites and daubing them with demands to "free Kevin". A campaign website pointed out that while hackers face harsh penalties, manslaughter in the US can be punished with as little as two years in prison.

Mr Mitnick could not have taken part in the current spate of hacking even had he desired to - his release conditions forbid him access to any computer. But there is a growing community of young hackers carrying on where he left off. Ira Winkler, the president of the Information Security Advisory Group, estimates that the number of hackers worldwide has grown from 35,000 two years ago to 100,000 today.

Late in January hackers began a high-profile campaign to crack open Japanese government websites. On at least five sites, links were inserted to porn websites.

The Japanese government's computer systems are widely viewed as vulnerable compared to those in the US. Tokyo has pledged to tighten security to US levels over the next three years and announced the creation of a 30-strong special police force to combat hackers. A digital signature bill aimed at verifying internet users' identities is also to be submitted to parliament.

This spate of hacking has coincided with a new law which came into force in Japan this month making it illegal to access sites without the proper clearance. As the US has found, all attempts to tighten security on the internet serve to redouble the efforts of those who seek to break and enter computer systems or demonstrate free speech on the internet.

But the hacking that brought down a host of bluechip US websites, including Yahoo! and Amazon, seems not to be part of any political manifesto but is more the result of a new phenomenon: the rise of the "script kiddie".

Dozens of US teenagers have been accused of internet vandalism in the past few months alone. A group of teenagers recently boasted to the US media that they steal AOL identities and masquerade as other users "just for the pure joy of trying to ruin friendships by insulting friends who have no idea they are talking to a hacker and not the victim". They also caused a serious credit card scare by obtaining users' card details.

And in Norway in January a 16-year-old was arrested for allegedly creating and distributing a software programme which enables the piracy of DVD movies.

Another teenager, calling himself "Maxus", hacked into CD Universe's computers, stealing 300,000 credit card numbers. Maxus began publishing the company's customers' card numbers on his website after it refused his demand for a "Christmas present" of £62,000.

Most of these teenage cyber criminals broke or entered into corporate computers by parroting relatively simple computer "scripts" picked up freely on the internet. The "denial of service" attacks brought down Yahoo! and others by swamping the corporations' servers with multiple requests for information, so that other users could not access the site. Denial of service can also be created by "mail bombing" - flooding computer servers with mass emails.

"What we're seeing is adolescent pranks going mainstream," observed the MIT network manager, Jeff Schiller. The US justice department is attempting to stop children growing up to be script kiddies with a $300,000 (£186,000) cybercitizen partnership campaign, aimed at promoting responsible, law-abiding surfing.

Many script kiddies in the US are caught swiftly, often because they boast of their hacking exploits on the internet or are betrayed by their internet names.

Jay Satiro, 19, was jailed for a year after hacking into AOL's computers and replacing programmes with his own. He was banned from using a PC for five years.

But hackers are able to cross national boundaries with ease. After the FBI was called in to investigate Maxus's attempts at extortion, a CD Universe spokesman, Brett Brewer, said the hacker had been identified as a teenager in Russia, but had not been apprehended.

The elitist hacking community distances itself from the script kiddies. A statement by Hacker Quarterly described the recent attacks on corporate US sites as "malicious assaults on infrastructure" which "have nothing to do with hacking at all".

Hackers prefer the term "crackers" to describe those who break and enter into computers illegally to vandalise internet property or steal information.

"The world of hackers is 95% non-criminal," the US-based hackers' thinktank L0pht claims. "It is a world of people exploring the edges of technology and building things. The crazy thing is, the government is making more and more of that exploration illegal."

The "hacker ethic" heralds "information sharing" as a "powerful positive good".

This contrasts, hackers say, with crackers, who tend to gather in tight-knit, secretive groups. Crackers are proud of their sophisticated code-cracking - but they keep quiet about it, unlike the hacking community, who make no secret of their distaste for government regulation of the internet and the lucrative hardware and software businesses run by Microsoft, IBM and others.

The current spate of hacking will spur corporate America to close up computer "back doors" - the crackers' holy grail that allows them access to a computer system as often they like, even when the security system is enhanced or updated.

But as long as America's computer-literate teens can cripple multinational and government websites, the glamour of hacking will continue to lure script kiddies to have a crack at infamy.

fields.headline: Yahoo! rocked by yahoos
fields.standfirst:
Even the internet has its share of vandals

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The bombardment with junk messages of internet sites like Yahoo!, the highly popular gateway to the web, and eBay, the electronic auction house, is both puzzling and instructive.
fields.body:
The bombardment with junk messages of internet sites like Yahoo!, the highly popular gateway to the web, and eBay, the electronic auction house, is both puzzling and instructive.

It is puzzling because of the difficulty in fathoming the motives of digital saboteurs striking at some of the core values of the world wide web. CNN, one of the victims, offers news free, and Yahoo!, despite its hyper-inflated worth on the stock market (a cool $98bn) has steadfastly stuck to basic net values of mutualism and encouraging people to go where they want to go.

It is instructive for two reasons. First, it shows how vulnerable the web is, and will continue to be, to the actions of mindless minorities bent on exploiting its openness for their own means. No amount of policing will ever be able to stop it because once one hole is plugged, others soon appear. In essence it is no different from any other kind of hooliganism - it is just that the global reach of the internet enables minorities to create disproportionate havoc. But it is also instructive in underlining how much the net has shifted the balance of power from producers to consumers. On this occasion, the motives were malign. It could have been different: there might, for instance, have been co-ordinated complaints from consumers with a real grievance who could all click together or - even more powerfully - not click at all as a collective boycott of products deemed too expensive or unsafe.

Net consumers are already negotiating discounts by buying in bulk and the fact that a single click could reveal a cheaper source is a global force keeping inflation down. The Seattle summit is a reminder of what can be achieved when individual lobbies link together through the web. This is not to deny that the net needs some sort of police force to prevent the events of this week from happening again. But in the end that may be the exception which proves the rule that the internet is on the side of the consumer.

webTitle: Polese looks for the will to win

fields.headline: Polese looks for the will to win
fields.standfirst:
Marimba chief offers lessons to budding Britain.coms

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Internet entrepreneurs should be prepared to fail and wear it as a badge of courage - is the tip from one of Nasdaq's newest stars, Kim Polese.
fields.body:
Internet entrepreneurs should be prepared to fail and wear it as a badge of courage - is the tip from one of Nasdaq's newest stars, Kim Polese.

The 38-year-old chief executive of Marimba, an internet infrastructure company capitalised at $1bn, believes that fear of failure is the main reason which has, until now, held back the boom.com in Britain and Europe.

"Some of the most successful US internet entrepreneurs have gone through miserable failures, and I mean 'crash and burn'. In silicon valley, failure is a badge of courage.

"My perspective, though, is that in the UK bankruptcy is a terrible disgrace."

Polese admits there has been a dramatic change to that attitude since her last visit to London six months ago. Now goldrush fever has spread to UK and European internet start-ups, and more venture capital firms, fund managers and small investors are prepared to take risks.

At least 200 British net-related initial public offerings are expected this year, with analysts forecasting at least half will fail. Polese thinks the US has reached the other end of the scale: "A lot of dumb money is chasing bad investments".

For all the talk about failure, it is not something Polese has ever tasted herself. She founded Marimba with three other engineers in 1996.

The company was offered a break through venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, which was prepared to back it. It now owns about 13% of Marimba's stock - worth some $130m.

Polese says they knew they had a product, named Castanet, which was at the "cutting edge and forefront of a new wave of technology".

While it sounds like a good marketing slogan there is no doubting the founders' track records at Sun Microsystems, where they played leading roles in establishing the Java programming language.

Even so, Marimba's main competitors are substantial and formidable. The list starts at Microsoft, Backweb and Computer Associates.

Polese would argue there is no other company which can replicate its service. Maybe, given that Marimba's shares have doubled since they were listed on Nasdaq last April at $20 each.

The company counts Renault, Ford and Intuit among clients using its software, which allows firms to install and automatically update and maintain software applications internally or across the internet. Marimba claims it can save some companies millions within a year.

Would a break-up of rival Microsoft benefit Marimba? Polese is not saying.

From its small base, Marimba has grown quickly - reporting $31.1m in sales last year. Of this some 10% are outside the US. The company wants this proportion to grow to 30% in the next few years.

Polese believes Europe is not too far behind the US in internet technology, and with web access on mobile phones could even leapfrog ahead.

The company may consider a London listing, although a more likely avenue is to gain greater exposure across the continent with Nasdaq Europe.

"We see huge growth opportunities in Europe - and not only for our business," says Polese.

She has worked in silicon valley for 15 years, and is forthcoming about her opinions on change in the industry. One point affecting the success of internet companies is recruiting talented staff and keeping them. "Any chief executive will tell you that it's the greatest challenge of silicon valley right now.

"There is a mercenary aspect. People are not staying at one business very long."

There is also the lack of women entering technology firms. She lists as role models John Chambers, chief executive of Cisco, and John Dore of Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers. Polese herself stands out as one of the few women chiefs in silicon valley. She expresses disdain when asked how she feels about that as a question that is asked too often.

"Hopefully people will look back on the nineties and realise what a fifties question that is," she says.

webTitle: Detectives despair of solving cases with no sure motive

fields.headline: Detectives despair of solving cases with no sure motive
fields.standfirst:
Security - Easy access to the internet may be its undoing

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: "Do you have pizza delivery men in Britain?" asked Bruce Schneider of Counterpane Internet Security, which is based in San Jose, in the heart of Silicon Valley outside San Francisco.
fields.body:
"Do you have pizza delivery men in Britain?" asked Bruce Schneider of Counterpane Internet Security, which is based in San Jose, in the heart of Silicon Valley outside San Francisco.

"What has happened to Yahoo! is as if someone who didn't like you ordered 100 pizzas to be delivered to your house all at the same time. How do you defend yourself against that?"

Mr Schneider, whose company is working on a new security mechanism and liaising with other computer security companies, said that internet firms were now realising that they are almost powerless to resist a coordinated attack. Mr Schneider said that one of the greatest problems was that the hackers were not disrupting the internet companies for gain.

"It's not being done for profit," said Mr Schneider, who is one of a growing number of people entering the security side of the internet world in response to the near panic caused by the disruption. "Nobody's making any money." He said tracing malicious hackers was similar to pursuing hit-and-run criminals as opposed to kidnappers, as there appeared to be no clear motive.

"You've got to step back," he said. "If this is being done from eastern Europe there is no way to track them down. If it's being done in the United States then there is a possibility."

The task is vast, he said. Security and forensic experts visit the company that has been targeted and attempt to trace back the audit logs to see where the attack originated.

Like the companies they service, the security firm's day starts at 8am and can often finish late into the night. It is a badge of honour for many young internet companies to work "24-sevens" (24 hours a day, seven days a week) - which merely adds to the complications in assisting with security. This is painstaking work and requires the co-operation of small internet companies in a field that has still not worked out how to police or protect itself.

"This is malicious vandalism rather than mischief," said Mr Schneider, whose company was founded four years ago as it became clear that computer security was not being taken seriously by many start-up companies in Silicon Valley. "At the moment no one knows how to defend against it. Blackmail is a possibility - but I would hope that doesn't happen."

He said that there was no immediate solution in sight. One of the great strengths of the internet, its accessibility, is also turning out to be one of its great weaknesses. "There have been conferences on these attacks and we are trying to share knowledge," said Mr Schneider. But he acknowledged that there was no speedy solution in sight. "It's like curing malaria," he said. "You've got to drain the swamps."

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Capital Internet start-ups seeking finance could benefit from a matchmaking service launched yesterday offering ambitious e-entrepreneurs a forum for talking to venture capitalists.
fields.body:
 Capital Internet start-ups seeking finance could benefit from a matchmaking service launched yesterday offering ambitious e-entrepreneurs a forum for talking to venture capitalists. Matchco.co.uk claimed it would be the first online venture partnership of its kind to match young business people with hi-tech ideas with suitable venture capitalists. The service offers e-businesses access to professional support, advice and guidance on key issues from business experts plus a hand holding facility by a mentor in a secure environment.

 Sale The Press Association news agency is inviting bids for Ananova , its internet and new media division, which some analysts estimate could fetch up to £500m. PA chief executive Robert Simpson said that a decision had been taken to refocus the company on its core business of supplying news to publishers. Bidders could include any of PA's four largest shareholders Trinity Mirror , Associated Newspapers , News International and United News & Media .

webTitle: New questions over man hired to save dome

fields.headline: New questions over man hired to save dome
fields.standfirst: The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: New questions were raised last night about the suitability of Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, the Disney executive hired to rescue the crisis-hit Millennium Dome, after fresh discrepancies were discovered in claims that have been made for the 34-year-old Frenchman.
fields.body:
New questions were raised last night about the suitability of Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, the Disney executive hired to rescue the crisis-hit Millennium Dome, after fresh discrepancies were discovered in claims that have been made for the 34-year-old Frenchman.

Mr Gerbeau was hired at the weekend after the sudden sacking of the chief executive, Jennie Page, who took the blame for what had been seen as a series of public relations disasters that had marred the opening of the centrepiece of the United Kingdom's millennium celebrations.

He was brought in after a sequence of mishaps that ruined the opening night, a range of overwhelmingly poor reviews, and the publishing last week of attendance figures for the first month that fell well below expectations.

Guardian inquiries raise fresh doubts over claims made in the announcement of Mr Gerbeau's appointment issued by Brunswick public relations for the New Millenium Experience Company.

He was described as "being promoted five times culminating in his role as vice-president".

Disney annual reports for the time that Mr Gerbeau was employed there do not list him as a vice-president of the park. Inquiries suggest he was employed as one of 40 directors.

He was described as "working across the entire range of management functions relevant to running a world-class visitor attraction".

In fact Mr Gerbeau was responsible for ticketing, parking, running the attractions and customer relations. He was not responsible for strategy, marketing, pricing, merchandising and public relations - all areas where the dome is seen to be wanting.

He was described as "heading a team of six directors managing a team of up to 2,000".

Disney sources who worked alongside Mr Gerbeau point out that the company management structure precludes directors being in charge of other directors, although he was relatively senior.

He was described as "awarded an MBA at Sciences-Po (Paris), achieving top position in his class".

Yesterday the college confirmed this was not true. He came second.

At the time of the announcement he was hailed by dome executives as the "saviour of Disneyland Paris".

In fact he was not even a member of the "Challenge 94" team of troubleshooters who saved the park.

Last night one former colleague from Disney, who once promoted Mr Gerbeau, said: "Make no mistake, PY is a great operator at his own level. But he is out of his depth. I don't want to damage his career, but the truth has to be told."

Mr Gerbeau worked at Disneyland Paris from 1991. But he left in November 1998 to do an MBA.

His mentor at Disneyland was Phillippe Bourguignon, the man who is acutally credited with saving the theme park but who left in 1996 to run Club Med.

Mr Gerbeau's MBA focused on the workings of Club Med.

Michael Faber, a Tory member of the Commons culture, media and sport committee, which will stage an inquiry later this year, said: "I have spoken to a number of Gerbeau's former colleagues and clearly there are some unanswered questions about his qualifications, in particular in the areas of marketing and promotion, which are the dome's greatest problems."

Michael Faber, a Tory member of the Commons culture, media and sport committee, which will stage an inquiry later this year, said: "I have spoken to a number of Gerbeau's former colleagues and clearly there are some unanswered questions about his qualifications, in particular in the areas of marketing and promotion, which are the dome's greatest problems."

fields.headline: Chechen villages take war underground
fields.standfirst:
Behind the rebel fighters is a powerful resistance network - right under the Russians' noses
Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Launching the final phase of its battle to subdue the rebel state of Chechnya, the Russian military declared last night that all but the southern mountains had been "liberated from terrorists". But with hundreds of rebels secretly sheltering in villages in the area Russia purports already to control - the north - this confident declaration may prove premature.
fields.body:
Launching the final phase of its battle to subdue the rebel state of Chechnya, the Russian military declared last night that all but the southern mountains had been "liberated from terrorists". But with hundreds of rebels secretly sheltering in villages in the area Russia purports already to control - the north - this confident declaration may prove premature.

Across the plains of the Russian-occupied sector, the resistance has become a powerful movement - working imperceptibly beneath the cover of daily village life to support those fighting overtly for independence.

In one typical village at the heart of the separatist state this network unites elderly men - too old to fight but responsible for sending food and medical supplies to the front - women who can give first aid to the wounded, younger men keeping watch on the nearby roads and whole families offering shelter to resting rebels.

Operating with quiet efficiency beneath the eye of the Russian command, this underground system is a real problem for the army.

There is no way of dividing the Chechen population into two neat groups of civilians and fighters - the distinctions are much more subtle and Moscow's soldiers are finding it impossible to navigate the grey areas in between. The army's response is to treat all Chechen citizens with uniform suspicion.

Magomed, 37, a grey-bearded man in a tall Astrakhan hat, coordinates resistance activities in one village. He looks no different to dozens of other local men loitering on street corners muttering about the trials of the war, but over a lunch of boiled chicken legs he listed his responsibilities.

"I fought during the last war, but this time I was put to work here," he said. During the siege of Grozny - when Russian troops formed a supposedly impenetrable ring around the Chechen capital - he helped to send medicine through Russian lines to the rebels trapped inside.

When thousands of Chechen fighters abandoned Grozny en masse this week, he organised places to shelter during the retreat - trying to ensure that the guerrillas' arrival in villages was discreet enough not to endanger local people.

This man also knows how to get badly injured fighters through checkpoints to the better equipped hospitals in the neighbouring region of Ingushetia. Occasionally, Russian prisoners of war are brought to the village; Magomed knows where to hide them.

Khava, a local nurse, worked with a colleague last week to bandage eight fighters who had stumbled through a minefield in their retreat from the capital.

"They were all seriously injured - mostly with bad leg wounds - but we had almost nothing to treat them with. So we organised a collection among the villagers and gathered enough money to buy some more bandages from the bazaar," she said.

A few streets away, Akhmed, 27, claimed that injuries from the last war prevented him from fighting; instead he helped to organise shelter for rebels in the forest outside the village. Most nights he makes the perilous three-hour walk through streams and ditches to their base to give them provisions (maize pies and potato cakes fried by his sisters).

When necessary, his mother Tamara will roll out flat mattresses on the floor of their basement kitchen to give travelling rebels a few hours' rest.

Akhmed also works as a link in the Chechen communication network, which has developed into a reliable system for passing commands and information to dispersed fighters. Evasive about how the network operated, he would refer to it only as "gypsy post".

Later, a junior rebel commander from Grozny pulled a sophisticated radio unit from a plastic bag; it was useful, he said, for monitoring Russian messages as well as for transmitting his own.

In recent weeks the Russian presence here has dwindled; only a handful of soldiers are visible by the road at the edges of the village. The army tried to cleanse the area of rebels late last year - making house to house searches - but since then its diminished presence has made the work of resistance volunteers much easier.

On Monday dozens of hiding fighters felt secure enough to emerge together in daylight for the funeral of Zahid Abdullayev, a Chechen rebel who died of pneumonia after lying too long in the snow. Small groups of men walked slowly through the shattered village streets to the dead man's house - past the bombed out chemist, past the old ice-cream shop, now riddled with shrapnel holes and empty, past the burned out shell of a tank abandoned by the central square.

One group of men arrived singing a moving, low chant asking Allah for forgiveness for the fighter's soul. Inside, a group of 40 men were performing zikr - a chanting and dancing ceremony in honour of the dead man. The men, all wearing heavy black boots, stamped their way rhythmically around the edges of the room, singing more prayers.

If the remaining Russian troops in the area were aware of the presence of this concentration of mourning rebels at the heart of the village they chose to turn a blind eye. But had they wanted to, it would have been almost impossible for the soldiers to act. Fighters and civilians danced together; there was no way of telling them apart.

webTitle: Dial a mimic at NHS Direct

fields.headline: Dial a mimic at NHS Direct
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Staff at NHS Direct, the government-backed telephone service where nurses offer 24-hour health advice, were forced to mimic answering machines when the automated call service broke down between Christmas and new year.
fields.body:
Staff at NHS Direct, the government-backed telephone service where nurses offer 24-hour health advice, were forced to mimic answering machines when the automated call service broke down between Christmas and new year.

They were given an official message to recite to callers while pretending to be a machine in order to get people to clear the lines.

An answering service which is supposed to automatically answer when the number of incoming calls reaches a set level failed to work, leaving staff to offer the options the computerised service normally would.

A department of health spokesman said: "The provider experienced technical problems and decided rather than just leave callers with an engaged signal, they would use call handlers to deliver the same options: call back or stay on the line. They were essentially operating as any other site but with live call handlers rather than a recorded message."

The problem occurred at the call centre covering Surrey, Sussex and parts of Kent between December 27 and new year and breakdowns lasted several hours. If callers became suspicious, staff were told to simply repeat the message like automatons.

The service experienced problems when it became inundated with calls from peo ple seeking advice on the flu outbreak.

The unusual steps taken to deal with the deluge of calls were discovered by the medical journals Doctor and Hospital Doctor. An earlier survey carried out by Doctor had found that callers could not get through to more than a quarter of the 17 helpline sites over Christmas.

Callers to at least five centres heard messages telling them to call later or contact their GP instead of being connected to a trained nurse, as a "red alert" system was activated.

NHS Direct, which the government hopes will reduce the number of patients calling at surgeries, cost £31m to run last year and dealt with 177,000 calls over Christmas.

fields.headline: Shipman may appeal over media 'bias'
fields.standfirst: Shipman trial: special report
fields.trailText: Harold Shipman is considering an appeal against his conviction for murdering 15 women patients, his solicitor said last night.
fields.body:
Harold Shipman is considering an appeal against his conviction for murdering 15 women patients, his solicitor said last night.

Ann Ball said any appeal was likely to be based in part on prejudicial press speculation before the trial that police planned to charge Shipman with up to 170 murders, and which could have influenced the jury. In the event, he faced only 15 murder charges.

Ms Ball, from the Manchester office of the law firm Hempsons, said it was irrelevant that police now put the number of suspicious deaths at 175. "It's different once there has been a conviction for them to say that," she said. "It's for the jury to consider only the charges on the indictment."

She said other grounds of appeal could be that the indictment was overloaded with charges, and that the charges should have been split into separate trials: one for charges relating to the killing of Kathleen Grundy and the forging of her will, a second for the cases where bodies had been cremated, and a third for those relating to bodies that were exhumed.

Shipman, who received 15 life sentences for murdering the 15 middle-aged or elderly women with lethal injections of morphine or diamorphine, has until the end of this month to lodge papers for an appeal.

Ms Ball said other grounds under consideration were the use of "similar fact" evidence at the trial. As a general rule, evidence of a defendant's misconduct on other occasions or his propensity to behaviour of a certain type cannot be put before a jury. But the judge can decide to admit it if its force in proving an issue in the case outweighs its prejudice to the defendant.

A further ground might be that the summing up on the law by the judge was unfair or unbalanced.

The convictions at Preston crown court were part of an investigation by Greater Manchester detectives into 136 suspicious deaths. Since the convictions on January 31, a further 39 complaints have been made to police, bringing the total to 175.

In an interview with the Law Society Gazette, Ms Ball, who specialises in defending doctors and dentists accused of misconduct, reveals today that Dr Shipman is not the first alleged murderer she has represented. She has also acted for a doctor accused of murdering her own child, and her firm represented John Bodkin Adams, the Eastbourne doctor suspected of murdering a number of elderly women patients in the 1950s. He was charged with only one murder and acquitted.

She reveals that as Shipman was charged with more and more murders she had no inside information on what the final tally was likely to be. "I had absolutely no more idea than the next person. I was reading the papers as avidly as anyone else."

To those who ask how she could defend an alleged serial killer, she says: "No one would criticise a doctor who rendered a defendant medical treatment, or a newspaper vendor who sold a paper. It is essential for the workings of the judicial system that those charged should be represented.

"I may turn a client away because their work is not the sort of work I do, but I don't turn clients away because I don't like the sound of their story."

Shipman was moved on Monday to the top-security Franklands prison in Co Durham after prison governors learned that the mother of two warders at Manchester prison may have been one of his victims.

webTitle: Lifting the lid on cigarette poisons

fields.headline: Lifting the lid on cigarette poisons
fields.standfirst: Smoking: special report<
fields.trailText: The 600 secret ingredients in cigarettes, including chemicals an MP claimed are used to make cyanide, are to be published by the health department.
fields.body:
The 600 secret ingredients in cigarettes, including chemicals an MP claimed are used to make cyanide, are to be published by the health department.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, last night promised to make the list public in a new anti-smoking drive.

Bigger health warnings on packets are also planned with a ban on terms such as low tar and mild amid fears that they give smokers a false sense of security.

Mr Milburn said a European-wide directive being drafted will also reduce maximum tar contents, limit nicotine levels and put a ceiling on carbon monoxide. Details of the 600 additives were supplied to the health department under a March 1997 voluntary agreement.

Mr Milburn said a code system used by tobacco manufacturers prevented his department or smokers knowing which ingredients were in specific brands.

But he vowed to put pressure on the industry to identify what was in each type of cigarette. "I don't want to be the only person with this information," Mr Milburn told the Commons health committee.

"People have a right to decide whether or not to smoke. But they also have a right to know what they are smoking. This points the way to much greater disclosure."

Stephen Hesford, Labour MP for Wirral West, claimed the 600 ingredients included components of cyanide and amonium which is used to speed up nicotine intake.

Less threatening contents named by Mr Milburn included sucrose, cocoa, butter, liquorice root and citric acid. The full list is to be put on the health department's web site.

He pledged the government's full support for the proposed European directive strengthening health warnings and imposing tougher restrictions on what cigarettes contain.

"We want to ban the use of terms such as low tar and mild which have the effect of giving the impression that they are not as dangerous as other tobacco products."

Mr Milburn proposed a permanent body of scientists to review any new evidence about the medical impact of smoking.

The government is to use a £50m advertising drive to persuade smokers to give up and dissuade young people from taking up the habit.

Research suggests that smoking is increasing, said Mr Milburn, particularly among young people.

Smokers who qualify for free prescriptions will be able to get a week's worth of nicotine replacement gum or patches.

He said the £15 cost of further weeks was less than the £25 someone with a 20-a-day habit would pay.

"Smoking kills, passive smoking is deeply dangerous and nicotine is addictive," Mr Milburn said.

webTitle: 'Cosy club' of doctors to go as GMC steps up ways to reassure public

fields.headline: 'Cosy club' of doctors to go as GMC steps up ways to reassure public
fields.standfirst: Shipman trial: special report
fields.trailText: The General Medical Council yesterday kick-started sweeping reforms to reassure the public after the Shipman case that it has the interests of patients at heart and not solely the protection of doctors.
fields.body:
The General Medical Council yesterday kick-started sweeping reforms to reassure the public after the Shipman case that it has the interests of patients at heart and not solely the protection of doctors.

The proportion of lay members of the GMC's disciplinary committees will be stepped up dramatically, from less than a third now to 50%. Two reviews of the way the council operates were also announced.

Sir Donald Irvine, GMC president, said that some of the council's present procedures were "arcane".

A programme of reform already under way is being accelerated after much criticism of the GMC's role in the case of Harold Shipman, the GP who last month received 15 life sentences for murdering patients. Some of the sniping has come from ministers, who for some time have been making veiled threats to disband the GMC, tear up the self-regulation of the profession and pass the policing of doctors to others.

Shipman came to the attention of the GMC in 1976, after he had been convicted of falsifying prescriptions to obtain morphine for his own drug habit. Following advice from psychiatrists, the GMC let him off with a warning letter. In 1998 officials were told that Shipman was being investigated for murder and then that he had been charged.

The GMC's lawyers advised the council that its regulations would not allow it to suspend Shipman from the medical register while a criminal investigation was under way.

Today the GMC's professional conduct committee is expected to announce Shipman's interim suspension. Six weeks later it can strike him off unless he appeals against his conviction.

The slow-moving, cumbersome bureaucracy of the GMC, which as a statutory body cannot change its regulations without a change in the law, has become notorious and has angered many who have tried to bring complaints against doctors. It has also led to long delays; there are 160 cases waiting to be heard by the professional conduct committee and the number has been rising.

Sir Donald made it clear yesterday that he wants a modern, open GMC to allay the disquiet of the public, the government and some doctors.

"We have been asking ourselves do we have the kind of structure and governance which really helps a modern regulatory body achieve its task?" he said. The answer was no. "There are structural procedures that are getting in the way even with the best will in the world."

He said the GMC had been known for its "cosy club atmosphere". After the Shipman verdict, there was "certainly a sense of urgency" for change. The GMC agreed to press for changes in the law to allow the suspension of any doctor be ing investigated by the police. It also wants to be able to suspend any doctor working inadequately.

One of the reviews will examine the "fitness to practise" procedures. "The law that governs our working is arcane, far too complex and one of the causes of the delays and frustrations that really upset everyone," said Sir Donald.

The other review will examine changes to the structure of the GMC. The council has also agreed to bring in doctors and lay people to help cut the year-long waiting list covering disciplinary cases.

The Consumers' Association welcomed the proposed reforms but said they did not go far enough. It wants an increase in lay members not just on disciplinary panels but also on the GMC's ruling council.

Sally Williams, of the association, said: "The GMC has got a long way to go before public confidence will be fully restored in its ability to put patients before doctors."

fields.headline: Fresh video of seized journalist
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Russian television broadcast further video footage yesterday of the journalist who was turned over to Chechen rebels last week in a prisoner swap organised by the military.
fields.body:
Russian television broadcast further video footage yesterday of the journalist who was turned over to Chechen rebels last week in a prisoner swap organised by the military.

The short film showed Andrei Babitsky - a leading Russian war reporter seized by troops as he covered the Chechen conflict from the capital, Grozny, last month - looking strained and exhausted. He said little except that he wanted to go home.

His family has not heard from him since January 15.

The Russian government said he had been arrested on January 25 for not having the correct war accreditation. Last week the government released video footage showing him being traded to Chechen rebels for two prisoners of war. Authorities said they bore no responsibility for his fate.

The latest film was sold to Radio Liberty, Mr Babitsky's employers, yesterday for £186 by an unidentified middleman. It quelled fears that Mr Babitsky was dead but gave no answers about his location or who is holding him. In the short film, which Mr Babitsky said was shot on Sunday, he added: "Things are as normal here as they can be normal in war conditions. People who are with me are trying somehow to help me. I really want to go home. I want all this to end as soon as possible. Do not worry, I will be back home soon."

Further confusion arose when Sharip Yusupov, a representative in Moscow of the Chechen president, Aslan Maskhadov, said the reporter was held by a rebel unit controlled by the Chechen warlord Aslambek Ismailov but that he could soon be transferred to the west.

Mr Babitsky's colleagues were suspicious of the video. Mario Corti, the head of Radio Liberty's Russian service, said: "I think this was an operation of the secret services. I don't think those who offered the tape were representatives of the Chechen rebels."
