fields.headline: Complainers who are facing ruin
fields.standfirst:
Developers threaten individual objectors as well as local councils

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: It is not easy to sympathise with the residents of Kensington and Chelsea. They are, after all, the people who inflicted upon us first Alan Clark and then Michael Portillo. You can't help imagining that the entire borough consists of armour-plated socialites who close their eyes when they talk to you, and sleek bankers with second homes and crocodile smiles.
fields.body:
It is not easy to sympathise with the residents of Kensington and Chelsea. They are, after all, the people who inflicted upon us first Alan Clark and then Michael Portillo. You can't help imagining that the entire borough consists of armour-plated socialites who close their eyes when they talk to you, and sleek bankers with second homes and crocodile smiles.

But, like most of the affluent parts of London, Kensington and Chelsea has surprisingly deep pockets of poverty. Thirty-eight per cent of the inhabitants of the Earl's Court ward, for example, live in social housing.

Like impoverished people throughout Britain, one of their major concerns is traffic. The lives of the poor are blighted by inequitable mobility: the capacity of the rest of the world to move past them, and their own incapacity to move away. In 1997, the government insisted that the borough turn three of its roads into "red routes": narrow urban motorways designed to speed up the traffic. Local people knew that the traffic volume, the noise and pollution outside their homes would increase, and they started casting around for the means to challenge the government's decision. Before long, they discovered that they had only one option: to take the council to court in the hope of forcing it to hold a public inquiry.

They lost, and the four people who brought the case now face costs of some £150,000. Two weeks ago, the council decided that, if necessary, it would send in the bailiffs. If you kill through careless driving, you can expect to get away with a £500 fine. If you challenge the schemes which generate the traffic, you can expect to be ruined.

There is scarcely a more expensive pursuit in Britain than objecting to development. A few weeks ago I was handed a copy of a letter sent by solicitors for Sainsbury's to a man who had contested a compulsory purchase order. "We recognise," the solicitors tenderly informed him, "that these situations are often uncomfortable for an objector without an interest in the land ... especially because such a person is not protected against any award of costs." Warnings like this are common. Developers threaten both individual objectors and local authorities, insisting that if they don't receive approval for their schemes, they will go to appeal. If they win, the council could face costs of hundreds of thousands of pounds. Councillors have been warned that if they don't approve certain development schemes, they could be individually surcharged.

In every other country in the European Union, local people can use the planning system to object to development. In Britain, only developers can appeal against a council's decision: the arguments of objectors are officially inaudible, even when the council has granted planning permission for a scheme not envisaged in its local plan. Appealing to the ombudsman is useless: objectors have to demonstrate both that the local authority is guilty of maladministration and that the development would have been rejected if the case had been handled properly. Even if they succeed, the ombudsman has no powers to enforce her decision. Judicial review is formidably expensive and unlikely to work: applicants have to demonstrate that a council's decision was "unlawful, perverse or procedurally improper".

The control of development is the single most important determinant of our quality of life. It decides whether or not a city or a district has sufficient employment, and whose needs that employment meets. It determines whether the poor are housed, whether children have open spaces in which to play, whether the air is breathable, the streets safe, the community extant. When we are unable to object to development, the key decisions about how we live are taken by people who hope to profit from our exclusion.

Before the general election, Labour pledged to give British people a right of appeal against development decisions not approved by the local plan. But, like the robust freedom of information act the party promised, planning reform now appears to have been re-classified by No 10 as a "chattering classes issue", meaning that the need for change is understood only by people who are reasonably well-informed. As the numbers of such people are likely to be small, the promise can safely be broken. If, as Jörg Haider claims, there are "similarities" between his programme and Tony Blair's, then this is surely where they lie.

Instead of the democratisation promised, the government is now speeding up the planning process in response to "business need", relaxing development constraints "to promote competition", transferring the right to question major developments from local people to a cruelly whipped parliament and toying with restricting the number of objectors who can speak at public inquiries.

Unheard, unrepresented, we can only watch as the subtle threads which tie our surroundings together are snapped. We were promised a people's Britain, but in what sense does it belong to us if we cannot determine how it develops?

webTitle: Making a continent work is dreary, but we've got to do it

fields.headline: Making a continent work is dreary, but we've got to do it
fields.standfirst:
Paranoia is the easy model for Euro-reporting. Better to tell the story straight

The European Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Next week, something big will start to happen in Brussels. Fancy the thought of an inter-governmental conference? The words hardly turn you on. Rather hear about another plot to destroy Britain's independence? How much more appealing!
fields.body:
Next week, something big will start to happen in Brussels. Fancy the thought of an inter-governmental conference? The words hardly turn you on. Rather hear about another plot to destroy Britain's independence? How much more appealing!

A year of national victimhood stretches ahead, until the IGC concludes in December with the treaty of Nice. Paranoia is the easy model for the reporting of Europe. The cliche has been in service for so long that no other language is understandable. It has fathered the steadiest, most enduring betrayal of truthful journalism now visible in the free world. Any chance of 2000 being different?

Like all IGCs, this one is, at one level, a playground for anoraks. It is complex. The issues are dry, subtle and intertwined. It's about real life among delicate national relationships, the very stuff of what is called governance. It cannot, by cleaving to its own arcane realities, be made intensely interesting. The mind glazes over when invited to penetrate too deeply into questions about the size of the European Commission, the weighted voting of EU members or the methodology and range of qualified majority voting, the three matters that are the essence of this IGC's agenda.

At a deeper level it is different. It's about how to bring more members into the EU without the whole thing collapsing into gridlock. This is a very British (as well as German, Italian, Belgian and just about every other nation) objective, which could be the reporter's paradigm for making public sense of the aridities unfolding. In a contest between large and smaller EU members, with different interests in the working out of these reforms, who is gaining? That would be one useful and gripping way to track the complexities. But it is unlikely to be the British question. Instead, the paradigm of menace and defeat is being trotted out once more.

The IGC, it is said, is the final chance to stop the emergence of the Euro-superstate. Depending on which way it goes, the doom of Britain is at hand. A complete European constitution is being readied for foisting upon us. European law, product of the infamous Code Napoleon, is about to efface habeas corpus and the rest of the common law. A European army beckons, wiping out national control, by-passing Nato, and giving corrupt or incompetent Brussels bureaucrats a handle on the life and death of British soldiers. Tax is about to be forcibly harmonised. And, of course, the secret agenda is being furthered, by Britain's very participation in this monstrosity, of the merger of the pound into the euro.

None of this is going to happen during the IGC. Yet all of these things have been canvassed by reputedly serious papers as the hidden purpose behind it, the insidious pattern of which Britain must beware, the test therefore of how the British negotiators perform. In the defence field, Lord Owen and Sir Malcolm Rifkind, once persons of measured judgment, were displaying their lurid plumage of alarm yesterday. Across the whole arena, William Hague, who occupies a position from which some faint vestige of veracity was once expected, sprays generalised terrors that long ago stopped even attempting to connect with the truth.

But they escape unexamined. Because they fit the paradigm, they suit the mind-set which, the public has been taught, is the only one that can help it understand what is going on. So strong is this model - so pervasive, so enduring, so constrained by narrow nationalistic sentiments - that the brainwashing is all but complete. Any other way of looking at Europe risks being seen as irksome and unintelligible gibberish.

Part of this is due to the idleness of editors and journalists. The challenge of making the truth about Europe interesting defeats us. For the truth is usually worse than uninteresting, it is unbearably complicated. Even an unprejudiced journalist working for an agenda-less proprietor reaches for a pattern than might enliven the bureaucratic miasma, and the Battle for Britain comes easily to hand.

But much more than a lack of imagination is at work here. A propaganda drive against Europe is most easily sustained by the maintenance of these simplicities. They consciously diminish the audience they address. Anyone who doubts the systemic nature of this performance should take a look at a recent academic study which marshals the evidence of two years' worth of coverage to shaming effect. In Insulting the Public?: the British Press and the European Union (Longman £16.99), Peter J Anderson and Anthony Weymouth conclude that the insult is threefold.

First, there's a presumption that readers can't understand anything except in "a trivialised, personalised and simplified form". Second, it's assumed that "even if they could understand the issues represented in more complex ways, the readers do not desire to know". Third, by ensuring that the public is constantly deprived of enough information to form an opinion, the press is party to "an abuse of ... fundamental democratic rights". This verdict is too judicious. Systematic twisting and calculated concealment, concerning the majority of events in the EU, seem to be the poles of mendacity between which most of the coverage has oscillated, ever since John Major's weakness alerted newspaper bosses and editors to the decisive power that now lay in their hands.

Is there any chance that the next IGC will break the pattern? The truth about it will be important, but, as ever, complex. The outcomes will not be primarily victories but, as ever, compromises. The British position remains what it has been for years, to favour a smaller commission. Along with France and Germany, we are a large member determined to secure a voting strength aligned with population size. Again, like other countries, we will look at more QMV on issues where it might suit us (transport, location of institutions, court appointments), but adamantly reject it where it's against our interest (tax, defence, EU financing, treaty change, border controls). If defence does come into it, we will not compromise Nato's position.

The way each of these things works out will involve some exceptionally tedious detail, readily available for the propagandists who are thirsting for Britain's defeat to convert into the hype that bears out their prediction. The less glamourous thing to do would be to try and tell the story straight. That sounds like an outlandish suggestion only in a country where a change that made it harder for Poland to block the single market must be seen, in Hague's brainless phrase, as Blair showing the white flag of surrender. This IGC is about making Europe function, with Poland and another dozen on the way in. It is hard work, dreary work, essential work, real stuff, of greater moment than the easy shrieking of the Sun. Will we ever measure up?

webTitle: Blair's Welsh stitch-up comes apart at the seams

fields.headline: Blair's Welsh stitch-up comes apart at the seams
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Wales: special report
fields.trailText: Prime minister's questions was a disaster for Tony Blair yesterday. For those of us who detest spin doctors, control freaks and media manipulators, it was joyful. Mr Blair was outspun, outwitted and out-bleeped.
fields.body:
Prime minister's questions was a disaster for Tony Blair yesterday. For those of us who detest spin doctors, control freaks and media manipulators, it was joyful. Mr Blair was outspun, outwitted and out-bleeped.

Alun Michael, first secretary of the Welsh assembly, resigned at 3.08pm, just before his colleagues had the satisfaction of voting him out. We are told by Downing Street - these days what we call a usually unreliable source - that Mr Blair knew this was about to happen. What he did not know was when. Mr Michael finally chose to resign just eight minutes into question time.

He could not have chosen a worse moment. Getting the timing wrong is the greatest offence anyone can commit against the spin doctors' Hippocratic oath.

At around 3.14, the Tory MP Archie Hamilton accused the prime minister of using "strongarm tactics" to get Mr Michael the job. (I heartily recommend Dragons Led By Poodles, a book by the Welsh Labour MP Paul Flynn, which reveals what an appalling stitch-up the whole sorry event was, a classic example of the way New Labour uses nominally democratic means to give two fingers to the will of the people.)

Mr Blair, not surprisingly, defended Mr Michael. "I believe he is doing an excellent job," he said. At least Dr Frankenstein finally went off his monster.

Then, promptly at 3.16, the Tory pagers began to bleep, vibrate, or offer personal massage services, according to the setting their owners had selected. They bore the news that Mr Michael had resigned, and the prime minister didn't even know!

It was a wondrous moment. The stitch-up had come unstitched, and at the precise time when it could do most damage to the seamstress himself.

Mr Hague was on his feet almost immediately, demanding to know whether it was true.

"Will you confirm whether or not this has actually happened, and will you confirm that the next big test of devolution will be the choice of a new first secretary - without any interference whatever from you?"

The prime minister replied rather limply that we could all be sure the next first secretary would not be a Tory. Or grand vizier of the planet Thaarg, he might have added. According to the last byelection, the Tories are almost as unpopular in Wales as Labour. Mr Hague demanded a non-intervention pledge again. Mr Blair said, amazingly with a straight face, "the decision is for the people of Wales", a remark that elicited hoots of sarcastic pleasure from the Tories.

The prime minister then airily dismissed "the fun and games down at the assembly". He might come to regret this remark. He and the lads at Millbank may regard the assembly as a toy, but my impression is that Welsh people take it rather seriously.

There was another worrying moment. Maria Eagle was asking an unusually, for her, sycophantic question about the NHS (would Mr Blair pledge to keep it as a public service - as if he might say anything else) when I noticed that the prime minister had swivelled round in his seat and was nodding frantically at each of her honeyed words. In New Labour, obedience is its own reward.

It made me almost, though not quite, nostalgic for the days of John Major, who at lunchtime made a graceful short speech accepting the award for best political book of the year. He had visited the United States, he said, where he met a mayor who had just been returned unopposed.

"I told him, 'If I'd run unopposed in 1997, I'd still have come second.' "

"No, third," shouted some churlish fellow, who sounded unnervingly like me.

fields.headline: Lies and myths about rape
fields.trailText: Nicci Gerrard and Clare Dyer (The price of crying rape, G2 February 9) highlight some important issues in relation to making allegations of rape.
fields.body:
Nicci Gerrard and Clare Dyer (The price of crying rape, G2 February 9) highlight some important issues in relation to making allegations of rape.

The perplexing case of Lynn Walker who was ordered to pay £400,000 in damages has brought out the need to consider what actually underpins false allegations, for - while some feminists may be reluctant to entertain the notion - sometimes women do make false accusations. In the Walker case, however, the motives remain unclear.

A colleague and I recently probed newspaper reports where women had been found guilty in court of making false allegations of rape. Such reports are usually brief and short on facts. Nevertheless, the motivation seemed complicated, but rarely fuelled by a wish to get a particular man in trouble. More usually, there seemed to be a desire to get herself "out of trouble". In each case the woman probably found herself in a difficult situation which she thought she could control by using the accusation of rape.

Since the 1976 act, consent has been identified as the central issue in rape cases. Sadly, dangerous myths and misleading stereotypes tend to be combined in "normal" cases to construct a false picture of pervasive false accusations surrounding consent. One powerful myth is that women have consensual sex followed by a false allegation of rape with the intent of getting the man into trouble.

Sadly, the Walker case will contribute to the mythology that women tend to lie abut rape. But he important point is that the case was not about consent. The most appropriate assumption regarding the normal behaviour of women who cry rape is that women do not lie about consent. The main problem is that the courts seem to think otherwise.

Lancaster University
Keith.Soothill@btinternet.com

 I'm afraid I must forsake my fellow women and say that Lynn Walker deserves what she has got. Yes, rape is unthinkable, yes the conviction rate of rapists is very low, yes the judicial processes of rape trials are unjust. But Lynn Walker wasn't raped. She is not a victim, she is a liar who, but for a lack of subtlety, nearly ruined the lives of a man and his family who have done nothing wrong. Let's not confuse the issues.
Claire Ragan
London
tl8201@qmw.ac.uk

 If the judge was wrong to deny anonymity to Lynn Walker, resulting in her face being "plastered across every newspaper", was the Guardian right to join in, plastering her face on the top of its front page, G2 front page and G2 page 3?

Cheltenham

 Women Against Rape said that it was "appalling and possibly illegal" for a judge to have named a woman who falsely accused a man of raping her, and that the ruling was "outrageous". Was it not appalling, possibly illegal and outrageous for her to have cried wolf in the first place?
Andrew Wolny
London

webTitle: How Kilfoyle was elected to sainthood

fields.headline: How Kilfoyle was elected to sainthood
fields.trailText: Ceredigion is Tony Blair's wake-up call for changing the way we vote. Peter Preston (Comment, February 7) asserts incoherence of Britain's electoral systems, which have been highlighted by the very reforms that New Labour set in motion.
fields.body:
Ceredigion is Tony Blair's wake-up call for changing the way we vote. Peter Preston (Comment, February 7) asserts incoherence of Britain's electoral systems, which have been highlighted by the very reforms that New Labour set in motion.

That absurdity has been exacerbated by the Jenkins Commission's timidity in recommending the alternative vote-plus as the only runner in a referendum against first past the post. Oh ye of little faith.

The adoption of the single transferable vote would revolutionise Westminster by maximising voter choice and minimising party political management. Its appearance as the runner against FPTP in a referendum on voting reform would be a clear indication that New Labour is serious about creating a new, plural politics that can legitimise Westminster within a federal Britain.
Richard Denton-White
Electoral Reform Society

 What disappoints me about Hugo Young's article (Blair knows the Kilfoyleite tendency represents reality, February 8) is that he fails to grasp that New Labour's abandonment of its core support is an inevitable by-product of our present voting system. Under FPTP, the only vote that counts is that which stands the greatest chance of robbing your nearest rival of a marginal seat. Cold logic dictates that until some form of PR is introduced for Westminster elections, a single Labour vote in Tunbridge Wells will continue to be worth more to Tony Blair than 10 such votes in the Rhondda Valley. It is time for Old Labour to put up or shut up on electoral reform. Either they back calls for PR, or they stop whingeing about Labour's attempts to woo Middle England.
Joe French
Luton

 Is Peter Kilfoyle, champion of the dispossessed, the same man who was plucked from obscurity by Neil Kinnock? Seven years on from unleashing a process which has resulted in Labour being reduced to a rump in Liverpool politics, with an impotent, decimated rank and file pushed out of the decision-making process, he is now cast as the conscience of Labour. This historic conversion puts him up there with St Paul.
Tony Mulhearn
Liverpool
Tony@tutor.fsnet.co.uk

fields.headline: The French connection
fields.trailText:
If Pierre-Yves Gerbeau (PY relishes 'best job in world', February 8) wishes to know where he should focus, I would suggest he starts in the Rip-Off Zone. My seven-year-old daughter went on a school trip to the Dome clutching £5 for the souvenir shop. She came home with a small pad for which we would pay no more than a couple of pounds at WH Smith. I hope he can make a success of it, but not by continuing to rip off children.
Andy Winter
Brighton

fields.headline: Why Craigie was queen
fields.trailText: Your interview with Michael Foot (Enduring love, February 7) omitted to make the link between Jill Craigie's last film, Two Hours From London, and the fact that there is to be a celebration of her in Dubrovnik, where she is "uncrowned queen".
fields.body:
Your interview with Michael Foot (Enduring love, February 7) omitted to make the link between Jill Craigie's last film, Two Hours From London, and the fact that there is to be a celebration of her in Dubrovnik, where she is "uncrowned queen".

Craigie and Foot were among the few public figures in Britain to speak out against the international policy of appeasement in the 1991-95 war in Croatia and Bosnia and their documentary was a powerful indictment of that policy led by the Major and Mitterand governments.

Had its challenge been taken up, atrocities such as the massacre of over 8,000 men and boys following the sacking of the UN "safe" area of Srebrenica by Serbian General Ratko Mladic's forces, would have been forestalled. As it is, Srebrenica remains an ethnically segregated Serb enclave and Mladic and his political masters, Karadzic and Milosevic, all indicted war criminals, are still at large and continue to influence events in the region.
Carole Hodge
University of Glasgow

fields.headline: Hack work
fields.trailText: Delighted to see somebody at last writing about the rank hypocrisy of journalists when it comes to drug consumption (By golly, it's good, February 9). In my years as a television reporter, I continually found myself at parties where colleagues would smoke, snort and swallow their way through the evening, and then go into work the next day to write more sensationalist stories about the "drugs menace".

fields.headline: We're still a family
fields.trailText: I write as the mother of three young children whose father happens to be homosexual. During the debate over section 28, I have seen nothing mentioned about the needs of such children, and mine are not alone.
fields.body:
I write as the mother of three young children whose father happens to be homosexual. During the debate over section 28, I have seen nothing mentioned about the needs of such children, and mine are not alone.

As a family we live in separate houses, my ex-husband and I each with new partners and the children calling each house "home". We have taught the children that, no matter what, we are still a family, working together to meet their needs, and that what is important is the quality of the relationship, not the gender of those involved,

As with children who are perceived to be gay, my children have also suffered abuse in the playground (Ministers seek deal on section 28, February 9). Our solution has always been to hold their heads up high and reply "So what?" The school has always been quietly supportive. However, until teachers can stand up in class and assert that families are about love and respect and not about fitting into a certain mould, I shall feel that the burden of social education falls unfairly on children like mine who can only, in all honesty, say that their dad is as good a dad as anyone's.
Gillian Darton
York

 Well done, Jonathan Freedland for walking out of a synagogue during a sermon which denounced homosexuals as "abnormal deviants" (Goodbye to all this, February 9). But, thankfully, all is not totally dark in our religious institutions. Last Sunday at St George's, here in Scunthorpe, I preached about the despicable way in which the church, over the years, has treated women, non-whites, divorcees and gays. I spoke from my own experience as a gay priest. I have never before had a sermon received with such warmth and support. Nobody walked out or uttered any protest. Yes, some of our religious leaders may still be living in the dark ages, but the people in the pews, thank God, are not necessarily taking their lead from them.
Rev Jonathan Thacker
Scunthorpe
Jon@han195.freeserve.co.uk

 I hate to disappoint Lady Young and the snarling prelates but their judicial colleagues in the Lords have already abolished part of section 28 right under their noses. Last October, in the case of Fitzpatrick v Sterling Housing Association, the law lords ruled that same-sex partners living together as couples should be defined in law as "a family". So in outlawing "the teaching ... of the acceptability of homosexuality as a pretended family relationship", section 28 is irrelevant.
Tony Bird
London

fields.headline: Bogged down, boxed in
fields.standfirst:
The outlook in the Balkans grows bleaker

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The divided town of Mitrovice, scene of a new upsurge in Albanian-Serb violence, symbolises the growing impotence of western policy in the Balkans.
fields.body:
The divided town of Mitrovice, scene of a new upsurge in Albanian-Serb violence, symbolises the growing impotence of western policy in the Balkans. French K-For troops are criticised for failing to halt the killing and acquiescing in Mitrovice's partition.

But the deep, abiding ethnic hatred which so disfigures Kosovo nearly a year after the war against Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic began, coupled with unresolved difficulties of political and economic reconstruction, has become a debilitating problem for all 40,000 Nato-led peacekeepers. Theirs is a thankless task, and one increasingly ignored by western politicians conscious of their own embarrassing inability either to empower or extricate them.

This failure of reconciliation in Kosovo handicaps the renewal programme led by Bernard Kouchner, the UN administrator, who fights against the odds to create a new interim governing council embracing ethnic Serbs and Albanians. It is exploited by unreconstructed Kosovo Liberation Army hardliners who seek outright independence, in defiance of both the west and Serbia, and who intimidate moderates within their own community. It discourages the return to their homes of Kosovan Serbs who fled post-war reprisals. It undermines international agencies like the OSCE which is struggling, for example, to render credible a judicial system which lacks a single Serb judge or prosecutor, and in which thousands of criminal cases are left pending. It leaves the door open, as in Mitrovice, to a resurgence of the cross-border, Belgrade-inspired mayhem which precipitated Nato's intervention.

The west's Balkan dilemmas extend far beyond Kosovo. Despite economic sanctions, opposition threats, criminal indictments, and odd assassinations, Mr Milosevic remains unmoved in Belgrade. Despite grandiose promises at last year's Sarajevo summit, countries like Macedonia complain, with justice, that they have yet to derive much concrete benefit from the west's Balkan "stability pact". Independence-minded Montenegro warns almost daily of Belgrade's sinister machinations and appeals, logically enough, for Nato protection in the event of a conflict. In Bosnia, meanwhile, yet another peacekeeping force languishes in indefinite political limbo. With so many dangerous loose ends left dangling, Britain and her allies are plainly courting a fresh disaster in the Balkans - and one they seem powerless to stop.

fields.headline: No defence
fields.trailText:
So Mr Straw "has made no secret of his desire to see the report [on Pinochet's health] in the public domain" (Report, February 9). But the Spanish newspaper El Pais on January 3 revealed that the offer not to disclose the report was made to Michael Caplan of Pinochet's defence team on November 5 by Fenella Tayler of the extradition branch of the home office. Caplan gratefully accepted. How does Ms Tayler's letter square with Mr Straw's claim?
Stuart Hood
Brighton

fields.headline: A lieutenant departs
fields.standfirst:
Mr Michael was seen as Blair's man

Devolution in Wales: special report

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Rhodri Morgan should pause before celebrating. Now installed as the acting leader of Welsh Labour, he should reflect on the fate of his two predecessors - and wonder if the top job in Cardiff is not ever so slightly jinxed.
fields.body:
Rhodri Morgan should pause before celebrating. Now installed as the acting leader of Welsh Labour, he should reflect on the fate of his two predecessors - and wonder if the top job in Cardiff is not ever so slightly jinxed. First Ron Davies had a "moment of madness" on Clapham Common which saw him off.

Now, in circumstances only slightly less humiliating, Mr Davies's reluctant replacement, Alun Michael, has been removed from office. Yesterday he jumped before he was pushed from his perch as leader of the Labour group in the Cardiff assembly and first secretary of Wales. It is clearly a personal blow for Mr Michael. But it could be bad news for Wales, and for the wider project to spread power away from Westminster and throughout Britain.

It is hard to feel much sympathy for Mr Michael himself. In common with many in the Welsh Labour party, this newspaper was unhappy about him from the beginning, chiefly due to the manner of his selection. The hand-picked choice of Tony Blair, Mr Michael had to rely on the machine politics of the past - a dodgy electoral college stuffed with unballoted trade union block votes - to beat Mr Morgan and become Labour's man in Cardiff. Rhodri was the man the members wanted, but they got Alun anyway. They got their revenge at the assembly elections last May, refusing to turn out even in the party's traditional heartlands - leaving Mr Michael to lead a minority administration.

Once installed in office, he did little to win confidence. Cardiff politicos complained that his manner was high-handed and control-freakish - a letter to one of his "ministers" would come back signed by him - and he never lost his awkwardness with the press and public. It is true that Donald Dewar in Edinburgh is not exactly Mr Charisma, but Mr Michael's task was harder than that of his counterpart in Scotland. Devolution was clearly the "settled will" of the Scots, while Wales has always been much more ambivalent: the Yes vote in 1997's referendum was won by a wafer-thin margin. The Welsh jury remains out on devolution, forcing the assembly to prove its worth. Mr Michael failed in that task. In this respect, the precise trigger of his downfall is revealing. He was castigated for failing to persuade London to provide the matching funds which might have delivered £1.2bn of European, so-called "objective one" money. If the first secretary could not persuade Gordon Brown to open his wallet, asked the critics, then what was the point of having him?

Some in Wales will provide an extreme answer to that question. They will decide that the problem was not Mr Michael himself, so much as the institution he led. They will decide that, since ultimate power remains in Downing Street, then the body in Cardiff is no more than a talking shop. Voters will be tempted to save themselves the bother, and go back to centralised habits of thought. But others will draw a less harsh lesson. They will conclude that devolution can work - but only if it is run by people with genuine independence of mind. This has a direct relevance to Mr Blair himself. For Alun Michael was his chosen candidate, foisted on a party that did not want him.

What yesterday proves is that if London tries to install a puppet, the people will rebel. The prime minister would be wise to learn from this mistake, even as he seems bent on repeating it in London. For if he is not careful, he risks despatching a team of Blairite loyalists around the country - only to see them rejected a few months later. Wales has provided another useful reminder: devolution means learning to let go.

He was castigated for failing to persuade London to provide the matching funds which might have delivered £1.2bn of European, so-called "objective one" money. If the first secretary could not persuade Gordon Brown to open his wallet, asked the critics, then what was the point of having him? Some in Wales will provide an extreme answer to that question. They will decide that the problem was not Mr Michael himself, so much as the institution he led. They will decide that, since ultimate power remains in Downing Street, then the body in Cardiff is no more than a talking shop. Voters will be tempted to save themselves the bother, and go back to centralised habits of thought. But others will draw a less harsh lesson. They will conclude that devolution can work - but only if it is run by people with genuine independence of mind. This has a direct relevance to Mr Blair himself. For Alun Michael was his chosen candidate, foisted on a party that did not want him. What yesterday proves is that if London tries to install a puppet, the people will rebel. The prime minister would be wise to learn from this mistake, even as he seems bent on repeating it in London. For if he is not careful, he risks despatching a team of Blairite loyalists around the country - only to see them rejected a few months later. Wales has provided another useful reminder: devolution means learning to let go.

fields.headline: Israel vents fury at Hizbullah
fields.standfirst:
Minister says soil of Lebanon will burn as jets launch new strikes
Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: As Israeli planes inflicted a third wave of air-raids on Lebanon last night and gunboats shelled the coast, the Israeli foreign minister, David Levy, warned Hizbullah: "The soil of Lebanon will burn if Katyusha rockets fall on northern Israel."
fields.body:
As Israeli planes inflicted a third wave of air-raids on Lebanon last night and gunboats shelled the coast, the Israeli foreign minister, David Levy, warned Hizbullah: "The soil of Lebanon will burn if Katyusha rockets fall on northern Israel."

Convinced that the Islamic organisation would use its traditional weapon of last resort in retaliation for the blitz on Lebanese power stations, residents of northern Israel - where a state of emergency has been declared - spent most of the day in underground shelters emerging only briefly to stock up on supplies.

So far, Hizbullah has confined itself to continued attacks on Israeli soldiers in their "security zone", and the signs are that, unless Israel causes loss of civilian life in further raids, it will hold back from launching rocket attacks.

No civilians have died in the latest flare-up. Three theology students were wounded in Tyre yesterday when Israeli planes attacked an 11-storey apartment block.

As diplomatic initiatives to defuse the tension got underway, the United States appeared to align with Israel. Administration officials were quoted as saying that the crisis had grown out of "provocative attack by Hizbullah to sabotage the reactivated Middle East peace process".

The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright said that, with the attack on the power stations, "what the Israelis have done is to send a very strong signal about the fact that they don't want this escalation". She supported the Israeli claim that Hizbullah attacks on Israeli soldiers came from villages and violated the US-brokered "understandings" of April 1996, which govern the "rules" of war in South Lebanon.

The French foreign minister, Hubert Vedrine, said in Riyadh the Israeli bombing was a "flagrant violation" of the April understanding. He called it a "revenge operation" and said that France supported Lebanon and its wounded civilians.

France called for an emergency meeting of the five-nation group which, under the April agreement, monitors fighting in the south and reprimands violators of the "rules". Together with the US it co-chairs this body. The US was initially reluctant to convene such a meeting in the south Lebanese town of Nakoura but, after Ms Albright consulted the Syrian foreign minister, it accepted the proposals. The US also took comfort from a statement from Syria that Syria and Lebanon were "particularly keen to spare civilians on both sides of the border and they therefore demand that the US and France impress on Israel the need for strict adherence to the terms of the April understanding."

Israel gave conflicting signals about its attitudes to the "rules".

Prime minister Ehud Barak said that "our operation was designed to tell the Lebanese government, Hizbullah, and indirectly Syria, that we are not prepared to accept a one-sided violation of the April understanding." That seems to imply that Israel still stood by the understanding.

But when a journalist told his deputy defence minister Moshe Sneh that in fact Hizbullah had not violated the understanding, he said: "that doesn't matter. They have killed Israeli soldiers and therefore they must be killed."

webTitle: Monti tested in arena of public opinion

fields.headline: Monti tested in arena of public opinion
fields.standfirst:
Earliest rulings by EU's new competition chief will have an impact beyond British boardrooms
The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: Mario Monti, the European commission's competition chief, is a quietly spoken, reflective man who might be expected to be happier in the corridors of an upmarket business school rather than patrolling one of Brussels' most bruising beats. But Mr Monti, although markedly less outgoing than his predecessor Karel van Miert, shows an equal appetite for the fray.
fields.body:
Mario Monti, the European commission's competition chief, is a quietly spoken, reflective man who might be expected to be happier in the corridors of an upmarket business school rather than patrolling one of Brussels' most bruising beats. But Mr Monti, although markedly less outgoing than his predecessor Karel van Miert, shows an equal appetite for the fray.

In a sense Mr Monti's appointment as competition commissioner is a logical move from his previous role as single market commissioner. Unfair competition and state aid are, after all, issues which can distort the efficient workings of the single market.

There is no shortage of files in Mr Monti's in tray. Yesterday, for example, some aspects of Microsoft's Windows 2000 system joined the issues at which Mr Monti and his teams are preparing to look.

Two of the files in the tray are hugely important to the UK, not only as issues in their own right but in how they can affect British public opinion towards Europe, too. They are the inquiry into the British government's support for BMW's plans to invest heavily in the Rover plant at Longbridge and the Vodafone AirTouch acquisition of Mannesmann.

The EC's concerns over both are complex enough in isolation. In the case of state aid for the Rover plant the EC wants to be sure that BMW's threat to invest in a greenfield site in Hungary, rather than in the existing plant at Longbridge, was a real one.

If the Hungarian option was a runner the aid was within the rules. If Hungary was just a stalking horse to get money out of the authorities and BMW had no real intention to invest Mr Monti would have a word or two to say.

Establishing the facts will not be easy - how do you determine "intention"? Whichever side the competition commission comes down on it will meet with protests - either from BMW or from rivals such as Porsche, which has already told the commission that it is unhappy about state aid.

Inquiries into state aid always run into a degree of political flak. Politicians never like to be told they were wrong to spend taxpayers' money on projects which are close to the hearts of at least a section of the electorate.

BMW's investment in Longbridge is a case in point. On the face of it the German company might be thought unlikely to scrap its investment plans because it lost all or part of a state-aid package which amounted to only a relatively modest percentage of the overall total.

It is worth remembering the background to the deal, however - a row which split the BMW board and led to the departure of the company's two most senior executives - and the continuing strength of the pound. Plenty of fingers remain crossed in the midlands.

The Vodafone decision could be tough, too. The commission is said to be considering whether to look beyond the impact of the merger on national markets where - with the exception of the UK - there is little overlap, and to include the merged group's "European footprint". Companies have long sought to persuade competition authorities to think widely when assessing competition issues, but usually when it suits them.

Vodafone is already reconciled to giving up Orange - any competition watchdog would jib at being asked to allow one company to own two of the four mobile phone companies in a single, national market. It would, however, be less than happy if it felt that, having blazed a trail for Anglo-Saxon capitalism in Germany, it was being robbed of at least some of the fruits of victory by being forced to sell assets it wanted to keep in order to get clearance from the EU. Mr Monti will decide at the end of the month just how deeply he wants to study the Vodafone-Mannesmann case.

Although Rover and Vodafone might be regarded as standing at opposite ends of the business spectrum - the first a long established industrial company fighting an uphill battle, the second riding a boom in one of the fast growing areas in the service sector - they both have a particular place in the UK's corporate landscape.

Rover may be a reminder of Britain's industrial past but it is still an important part of the manufacturing present. Vodafone is fast acquiring the status of a national champion showing that, even though quite big bits of the company are outside Britain, the UK can still produce world leaders.

With British attitudes towards the EU drifting towards scepticism, especially but not exclusively - remember BSE and the withholding tax - over the question of signing up for the single currency, Mr Monti's decisions will have a resonance well beyond Brussels and the boardrooms of BMW and Vodafone.

fields.headline: Safety catch
fields.standfirst: No one seems to talk about Aids anymore. Yet there has just been a huge jump in HIV infection among young heterosexual women.  Raekha Prasad  asks why we stopped worrying about a killer disease
fields.trailText: In many circumstances, a "first" is a cause for celebration: it marks a step forward. So the news that for the first time the number of people in the UK who contracted HIV through heterosexual sex was higher than via homosexual sex gives us reason to celebrate another year when the rate of infection among gay men has fallen and then ask what on earth went wrong. When we learn that it is young women who are showing the sharpest increase in heterosexually acquired HIV infection, the future looks bleak.
fields.body:
In many circumstances, a "first" is a cause for celebration: it marks a step forward. So the news that for the first time the number of people in the UK who contracted HIV through heterosexual sex was higher than via homosexual sex gives us reason to celebrate another year when the rate of infection among gay men has fallen and then ask what on earth went wrong. When we learn that it is young women who are showing the sharpest increase in heterosexually acquired HIV infection, the future looks bleak.

Twenty eight per cent of infection among women last year was in the 25-29 age group, according to the public health laboratory service. In the past nine months, Positively Women, the support group for women living with HIV, has seen a 23% increase in women using its services compared with 14% for the whole of the previous year. Although the majority of these women probably became infected in sub-Saharan Africa as tourists or before coming to Britain and much of this increase is the result of increased detection (the government's new policy of offering universal antenatal screening), it's clear that there is a young generation of women who don't consider HIV to be relevant.

And why should they? It is only through knowing and seeing someone who is infected that the threat becomes real. Compared to other sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), HIV is still relatively rare in Britain. In the 80s, Aids was everywhere. Billboard and television warnings were designed to put fear into people and did. The very visible and ominous Don't Die of Ignorance campaign of that decade has passed this generation by.

Whereas young people of the 80s were warned about the dangers of HIV, those of the 90s were fed images of ecstasy casualty Leah Betts on a ventilator and told they would die not through reckless sex but from reckless drug-taking. The lethal unknown is not whether a one-night stand is carrying an infection but if that night's drugs are bad.

Women are still more concerned about avoiding unplanned pregnancy than about STDs, according to research by Durex. For young women, unwanted pregnancy remains a close and visible fear. Pregnancy could happen to them because it has happened to friends, sisters, mothers. They have been told that getting pregnant as a teenager is a tragedy and fear of an unwanted child often overshadows concern about STDs.

Women find carrying condoms difficult, too. "There's still a stigma about women who carry condoms being loose," says Paula Doran of the Family Planning Association, who has spent 10 years listening and advising at the end of HIV helplines and counselling people before they take the HIV test. "It says, I'm ready for it. The idea that women should have to be seduced and persuaded to have sex continues."

Perhaps this goes some way to explaining the news this week that actresses Dervla Kirwan and Mina Anwar are to market a "safe sex" bra with a condom sized pocket in one of the cups. Like those sanitary towels individually wrapped in multi-coloured plastic, the discreet design reflects the anxiety girls feel about carrying condoms.

Men buy almost twice as many condoms as women, according to last year's Durex report on sexual attitudes in Britain. Although more men than women said they disliked using them, 10% more women did not use a condom with a new partner. It seems that while the sexually active young woman has learned to say what turns her on, she struggles to find the words to insist on a condom.

The difficulties for women infected in sub-Saharan Africa are even greater. Miriam, now 29, was diagnosed with HIV when she arrived from Uganda 10 years ago and four months pregnant. "It never crossed my mind I'd be positive," she says. "I didn't know about the disease and condoms just weren't used."

She has had two partners. Fortunately, her son and long-term partner are both negative. Elizabeth Kawonza, of the Terrence Higgins Trust African team in London says women from Africa who have come to Britain face pressures to have a child because it bestows honour and status. "It's often difficult for married women to insist on condoms. In many parts of Africa condoms are understood to be for prostitutes so 'good girls' don't carry them."

For those women who have succeded in introducing rubber into that first intimate moment, another more delicate vocabulary is needed when a relationship becomes long-term. This month's Cosmopolitan magazine identifies the HIV test as "the new marriage" - the moment a couple decides to get tested, it says, has become a new mark of commitment.

The analogy is exaggerated. Although the number of heterosexual couples taking an HIV test has doubled in the last 10 years, in reality many women find asking a partner to take a test can be difficult in case it's construed as a character slur.

Susan Ross, 27, asked her partner to have a test after months of using condoms because she wanted to switch to the pill. She went, he didn't. "He refused to engage with me about why he wouldn't," she says.

"It made me feel he wasn't interested in keeping me safe and suspicious of what he might have to hide. I didn't feel confident enough to force it. I felt alone in having the responsibility for babies and sexual health on my shoulders."

Protection from HIV for women is so dependent on cultural pressures: how much she can say, ask for, demand. Infection rates are part of a bigger picture where teenage pregnancies are not decreasing and young women have the highest rates of the STD chlamydia. Behind these statistics are young women going all the way with a sexual vocabulary that only goes so far.

Paula Doran of the FPA argues that messages about pregnancy and STDs should be integrated. "The message should be about enjoyment," she says. "Young women's sexuality is seen as problematic: they get pregnant, they're a drain on the state, they get infections.

"There is no positive view of their sexuality. We learned from gay men that explicit and erotic material was the most effective way to convey messages about how to practise safe-sex."

Here's the rub. The longer young women's sexuality is seen as a problem rather than something worth celebrating, the longer it will be before they develop a language that keeps them safe.

Contact Positively Women's helpline on 020 7713 0222

fields.headline: Quotes of the day
fields.trailText:
"No sport is a woman's sport, and women who pretend otherwise (especially women who pretend to like football) think they're being modishly post-feminist and laddish, when actually they're being pre-feminist and sappish. Some women think that just because they play good sport or shout very well this means they're not being culturally tryannised, they're winning in a man's world. This is bogus; just by trying, they've lost already."
Zoe Williams disapproves of Catherine Zeta Jones's stint on the golf course this week, London Evening Standard
fields.body:
"No sport is a woman's sport, and women who pretend otherwise (especially women who pretend to like football) think they're being modishly post-feminist and laddish, when actually they're being pre-feminist and sappish. Some women think that just because they play good sport or shout very well this means they're not being culturally tryannised, they're winning in a man's world. This is bogus; just by trying, they've lost already."
Zoe Williams disapproves of Catherine Zeta Jones's stint on the golf course this week, London Evening Standard

"God, I feel so sorry for her. She was young and unmarried. He was the creep."
Luciana Morad, the Brazilian model who recently gave birth to Mick Jagger's child feels sympathy for Monica Lewinsky, Marie Claire

"You should not be over-critical . . . You should praise your man. Men love this . . . You should try to have a loving and happy sexual relationship so don't keep rebuffing his advances. If you are always tired then you must reassess your work schedule and what you really want from life."
Vanessa Lloyd Platt, "Britain's leading divorce lawyer" argues that women are to blame for high divorce rates and offers tips for a happy marriage, Daily Mail

"Starting a relationship is like taking a cable car to the top of a mountain. It's exhilarating and scenic. When you get to the top, you ski down. This, too, is brilliant. But when you reach the bottom, you find the cable car has gone. Now you have to climb up the mountain, foothold by foothold. This is working at the relationship."
William Leith philosophises, Elle

"[Modelling is] the only thing you can do that you really don't need to use much of your brain for."
Model and actress Milla Jovovich on posing for a living, Arena

"People have described me as "luminous" in the past . . . It's a beautiful word but when it's the only word used to describe a woman's acting technique or her abilities on-screen, it's just a kind of fobbing off. I find women's performances aren't analysed - there's this kind of laziness."
Cate Blanchett, Marie Claire

"Because of the age difference, I can really enjoy her career. That's one of the nice things. We don't have to compete. I've done it all."
Michael Douglas on being with a younger woman, Hello!

fields.headline: Gene governs muscle power
fields.trailText: Evidence that athletes are born, not made, has been found by British scientists with the discovery of a gene that can increase muscle efficiency like a dose of anabolic steroids.
fields.body:
Evidence that athletes are born, not made, has been found by British scientists with the discovery of a gene that can increase muscle efficiency like a dose of anabolic steroids.

Everyone has two copies of the gene, appropriately named ACE, but it comes in two versions, long and short.

Those who happen to have inherited a double set of the long ACE gene will significantly increase their muscle power by physical training, while those with two copies of the shorter gene will not. Most people are in the middle, with one short and one long.

Researchers at the British Heart Foundation and the royal defence medical college tested 58 army recruits on exercise bicycles before and after an 11-week course of physical training. The muscles of 35 recruits with the double long ACE gene became 8.6% more efficient; those of the others, with the double short gene, hardly changed.

"Exercise benefits everybody," said Steve Humphries, the foundation's professor at University College London. "But if you wanted to be a muscle-builder, you'd have to work a hell of a lot harder if you had two short ACE genes than if you had two long ones."

The army had no plans to start genetic testing, he added, but would use the results to adapt its training courses.

The news is not all bad for short ACE people, who appear to be born for speed rather than endurance. Last year researchers looking at the ACE genes of the British Olympic squad found a higher than average proportion of double long genes among long distance runners, but a higher proportion of double short genes among the sprinters.

webTitle: Forbes pulls out of race for White House

fields.headline: Forbes pulls out of race for White House
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: To the undisguised relief of his family and his political rival, George W Bush, Steve Forbes abandoned his 2000 presidential bid last night, after squandering an estimated $88m (£55m) of his personal fortune on an increasingly fatuous quest for the White House.
fields.body:
To the undisguised relief of his family and his political rival, George W Bush, Steve Forbes abandoned his 2000 presidential bid last night, after squandering an estimated $88m (£55m) of his personal fortune on an increasingly fatuous quest for the White House.

The event that finally persuaded Mr Forbes to see his candidacy in the same light as most dispassionate Americans was his third place position in Tuesday's Republican presidential primary in Delaware.

Despite campaigning hard in the tiny east coast state, Mr Forbes finished with only 20% of the votes - 31 points behind Mr Bush and, more humiliating, five points behind Senator John McCain, who had not spent a single dollar or a minute in Delaware.

The decision to quit means Mr Forbes's five daughters, who had reportedly become anxious about the effect the publisher's campaign spending was having on their inheritance, can relax about their financial prospects.

Mr Bush, too, will have a fresh spring in his step, since a majority of Mr Forbes's supporters are expected to swing towards the Texas governor in next week's key South Carolina contest against Mr McCain.

Mr Forbes's departure follows a poor third place showing in last week's New Hampshire primary, where he won only 13% after a good showing in the January 24 Iowa caucuses. In retrospect, Iowa was the Forbes 2000 campaign's high-water mark. The Republican nomination race is now down to the last three men standing: Mr Bush, Mr McCain, and the anti-abortion conservative Alan Keyes.

As with other Republican wannabes who fell by the wayside, the surprise about Mr Forbes's candidacy was that it was ever launched at all. If, as some suspect, the whole thing was a promotional exercise for his Forbes magazine publishing empire, it has been one of the least cost-effective advertising drives in modern times.

Though Mr Forbes, with an estimated net wealth of at least $440m, has never held elective office and has now run twice unsuccessfully for the White House, he never seemed to believe the overwhelming evidence that most Americans do not think the US presidency should be an entry-level job.

His campaign wanted for nothing except voters. Aides were given the run of the candidate's chequebook in setting up offices nationwide. They were awash with brand new computers and other equipment. His hi-tech campaign bus was equipped to beam photographs and soundbites to his website. Digital photographs of the candidate greeting voters were processed on the bus and circulated immediately. Mr Forbes even travelled with his own full-time film crew.

But the uncharismatic Malcolm Stevenson Forbes, who inherited most of his father's money and a controlling stake in his empire, had little of his style. Malcolm Forbes Sr had his own Boeing 727 called The Capitalist Tool. Before his death in 1990, he divided his time between a south Pacific island, a French chateau and a castle in Morocco.

Steve Forbes, on the other hand, has deeply conservative politics and is not noted for his humour. In the 1970 Princeton yearbook, he wrote of himself: "He is a widely respected economic prognosticator."

In his first presidential bid, in 1996, Mr Forbes was dismissed initially as just another rich, rightwing egomaniac trying to emulate Ross Perot's spectacular success in 1992, when the Texas oil tycoon took 19% of the vote as a third party candidate.

But Mr Forbes's unlimited funds began to have an impact. He won two primaries in 1996 and helped to prevent the Republican party's nominee Bob Dole from developing the kind of bandwagon that could have threatened Bill Clinton.

That experience, and the threat of a second Forbes bid in 2000, shaped the tactics of Mr Bush. The Texas governor's campaign focused on huge fundraising at a much earlier stage than in previous years. Mr Bush amassed a $68m war chest in 1999 because he was determined to match and outspend Mr Forbes.

Mr Forbes's campaign never had the momentum of 1996, but his spending was again unstinting. Officially, he admits to spending $33.5m on his campaign up to the end of last year. The eventual total is likely to be nearer to $55m.

A third Forbes run in 2004 seems improbable, though it cannot be ruled out. A more serious possibility is that Mr Forbes, a New Jersey native, may be tempted to spend more millions on a senate challenge there in November in a seat held by the retiring Democrat Frank Lautenberg.

fields.headline: National roundup
fields.trailText: Body parts inquiry pledge
fields.body:
Body parts inquiry pledge

The chairman of an inquiry to investigate how body organs were removed without permission at Alder Hey hospital yesterday pledged to "leave no stone unturned in establishing the facts".

Michael Redfern QC, a crown court judge and medical negligence specialist, made the promise after meeting representatives of be reaved families for the first time at the inquiry's office in Liverpool. He said: "We will get to the bottom of what happened and we will do it quickly."

The independent inquiry was set up by the health secretary, Alan Milburn, to look into the removal, retention and storage of organs at the Liverpool hospital. Many parents claim that they did not give consent for removal of their children's organs.

Mr Redfern said the inquiry was concerned with families who had had the birth of a child with severe disability or illness, the tragedy of death, and the grief of postmortem and burial. A large number of organs had been retained without full parental knowledge or consent, said Mr Redfern, and postmortems remained incomplete.

"The parents are affronted by these harrowing events. They are entitled to a full explanation," he concluded.

New film centre for South Bank

The National Film Theatre, which has long been the poor relation in London's South Bank arts complex, is to be rebuilt as part of a radical re development to be announced next week.

A national film centre is to be created, combining a new cinema complex, a refurbished Museum of the Moving Image, a film library, educational facilities, and the headquarters of the British Film Institute, which are currently in the West End.

There are also plans to move the National Film and Television School from Buckinghamshire to the South Bank.

The fresh start for film on the South Bank is part of a scheme to give coherence to the 30-acre area along the river from the Millennium Wheel. Redevelopment has already begun on the Grade 1 listed Royal Festival Hall. The much-maligned 60s brutalist-style Hayward Gallery, Queen Elizabeth Hall and Purcell Room will either be replaced completely or substantially remodelled.

The South Bank centre hopes that much of the finance for the redevelopment will come from rents and leases. The remainder will be raised from lottery funds, urban regeneration grants and private sponsorship.

"We will start work in 2003 and hope to complete it by the end of the decade," said South Bank centre spokeswoman Sue Rose.

Thief took dead man's bank cards

A burglar who broke into a house ignored the body of a man hanging from the stairs and went on to steal his bank cards, police said.

Detectives are convinced that the burglar discovered the body of Brian Dear, 59, at his house in Hyson Green, Nottingham, but made no effort to summon help.

Mr Dear was eventually found when neighbours spotted a broken window at the house.The burglar's act emerged at an inquest into Mr Dear's death, which concluded that he had committed suicide.

Police said that after the break-in, which happened last month, Mr Dear's bank cards were used at several shops in the area. A TV and video recorder were later found to be missing.

Detective Constable Alexander Warburton told Nottingham coroner's court: "Clearly there had been a burglary, but having examined the area I am satisfied nobody else was involved in Mr Dear's death."

A neighbour reported seeing a figure wearing dark clothing and a balaclava running from the house on the day before Mr Dear's body was discovered.

Veterans see bridge returned

Pegasus Bridge, the historic first objective of the allied invasion of Europe, was yesterday rescued from a field and returned to the Caen Canal, where it will form the centrepiece of a memorial to one of the second world war's most celebrated battles.

A 96-wheeled trailer moved the 130ft structure a few hundred yards from the field to its new position. It had been unceremoniously dumped in 1993 when it was replaced by a modern bridge.

Locals and old soldiers turned up to watch the operation, the result of pressure from veterans' groups.

The bridge will be restored and displayed beside a museum which is due to be completed in April. The Prince of Wales, the commander-in-chief of the parachute regiment, will inaugurate the memorial in June.

Pegasus Bridge was captured by the glider-borne British and Canadian troops of the 6th Airborne Division on June 5 1944. It was the start of a two-month struggle to protect the D-Day bridgehead from counter-attack. The division lost 1,000 men in the campaign.

Gen Sir Michael Gray, the chairman of the Airborne Assault Normandy Trust which helped fund the museum, said the restoration and construction work will cost £1m.

fields.headline: 'Blairite' Archers criticised
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: A scene in The Archers in which two of the main characters talked favourably about the government's countryside policy was deemed "inappropriate" by the BBC yesterday.
fields.body:
A scene in The Archers in which two of the main characters talked favourably about the government's countryside policy was deemed "inappropriate" by the BBC yesterday.

The Radio 4 soap had organic farmers Tony and Pat Archer discussing favourably the speech that Tony Blair gave to the National Farmers Union last week.

The pair backed the prime minister's pledge for a partnership with producers. At the conference, farmers booed and hissed as Mr Blair left the podium.

Pat Archer suggested the government would provide help for hard-hit pig farmers in the long-term, even though Mr Blair himself did not go that far in his speech. She also picked out other policies for praise.

Yesterday, BBC staff were reminded of the need to stick to guidelines to prevent further incidents which could be interpreted as bias at the corporation.

The move follows complaints from countryside groups, farmers and Conservative MPs who accused the BBC of peddling "Blairite propaganda".

A spokesman for the NFU said: "We wish that all farmers could have as much hope as the ones in The Archers."

A BBC spokeswoman said: "The Archers covers stories relevant to our audience and touches on very topical issues. On this occasion the way the scene was depicted was inappropriate and we are taking steps to ensure it doesn't happen again."

BBC bosses are thought to have been particularly sensitive to the lapse as it coincided with suggestions that the government wanted to influence soap storylines.

The Labour party had hatched a plan to persuade scriptwriters to include more favourable comment on government policy within TV soap operas. It was suggested that plot lines could contain political messages.

webTitle: Villages mourn Solway Harvester crew buried

fields.headline: Villages mourn Solway Harvester crew buried
fields.trailText: The families of the seven men drowned on the Solway Harvester began laying them to rest yesterday.
fields.body:
The families of the seven men drowned on the Solway Harvester began laying them to rest yesterday.

After waiting three weeks for the bodies to be raised from the sea, the communities from the villages that make up the Machars of Whithorn turned out to pay their respects.

In the morning the Priory Church of St Ninian was filled with the mourners of Wesley Jolly, 17. The streets were deserted, the cortege the only movement. Mr Jolly lost his life when the scallop dredger sank off the Isle of Man on January 11.

After the church had filled, the community gathered outside to hear the minister, Alexander Currie, say that Mr Jolly's was a young life "snuffed out by the power of the sea".

Later David Lyons, 17, was buried. Again the communities of Whithorn, Isle of Whithorn, and Garlieston united behind the dead man's family. "His cheeky smile would get him out of tight corners. He was a typical 17-year-old lad," said David Conroy, parish priest of St Martin's and St Ninian's.

In the afternoon at the Isle of Whithorn's church, villagers mourned the three members of the Mills family: the boat's skipper, Andrew Craig Mills, 29, his brother Robin, 33, and their cousin David Mills, 18.

Today Martin Milligan, 26, and John Murphy, 22, will be buried in private services.

fields.headline: Satanic abuse row erupts
fields.trailText: Fresh controversy over the existence of satanic or ritual child abuse erupted yesterday when it emerged that two psycho-therapists received a £22,000 government grant to produce evidence of the practice.
fields.body:
Fresh controversy over the existence of satanic or ritual child abuse erupted yesterday when it emerged that two psycho-therapists received a £22,000 government grant to produce evidence of the practice.

The author of an official report which found no evidence of satanic abuse, and was said by the then health secretary to have proved it a myth, dismissed the new research as "ludicrous".

Concern over ritual abuse arose in the early 1990s following controversies in Nottingham, Rochdale and the Orkneys. Jean La Fontaine, an anthropologist, was commissioned by the department of health to investigate alleged cases.

Of 84 cases reviewed in her 1994 report, none was considered satanic and three found to have shown any evidence of ritual. Virginia Bottomley, the then Conservative health secretary, declared that the report had exposed satanic abuse as a myth.

It was yesterday confirmed, however, that Valerie Sinason and Rob Hale, who were leading critics of the report, had subsequently received £22,000 from the health department to document evidence of ritual abuse from the reported experiences of their patients.

Ms Sinason, who is based at the Tavistock clinic in London with Dr Hale, who is also a psychiatrist, said 46 of her patients claimed to have witnessed murder of children or adults during ritual abuse ceremonies that had involved up to 300 people at a time. Some 70% of the reported abuse was carried out by paedophiles and the rest by satanists.

Interviewed on BBC radio, Prof La Fontaine accused Ms Sinason of being "out of her depth" and unable to produce any hard evidence for her beliefs. "It's depressing to find someone who has a position at leading London hospitals who is so cut off from what research methodology is, and what rational evidence is."

A health department spokeswoman said Ms Sinason and Dr Hale were expected to submit their report, which had the status of a pilot study, in the spring.

webTitle: Straw pledge in doubt as police numbers tumble

fields.headline: Straw pledge in doubt as police numbers tumble
fields.trailText: The number of police officers in England and Wales has fallen by a further 600 in the past six months, it was disclosed last night.
fields.body:
The number of police officers in England and Wales has fallen by a further 600 in the past six months, it was disclosed last night.

The latest home office figures, which put the number of officers at 125,464, raised new doubts that the home secretary's promised extra 5,000 recruits would not be sufficient to reverse the fall in police numbers over the next three years.

Chief constables gave a mixed welcome to the announcement yesterday of the detailed allocation of the extra 5,000 recruits between forces.

Humberside's chief constable, David Westwood, who bid for 251 extra officers but only received 74, described the decision as a "body blow". However the Norfolk police warmly welcomed its extra 66 officers as part of a serious attempt to tackle rural crime.

The home office figures show that police numbers have now fallen by 1,600 since the May 1997 general election, from 127,158 to 125,464.

In the past six months the biggest falls have been in the Metropolitan police (down 188); Merseyside (down 140) and West Yorkshire (down 105).

Jack Straw said that police numbers had been in decline since the early 1990s. "I have listened to the concerns of chief officers, and have taken action to stem this decline," he said. "But effective policing is not solely about numbers of officers. It is also about how best the police use their time and their technology, assets and skills available to them."

He said that there would be £35m of new money available from April to kick-start the first year of the scheme.

The home secretary's conference pledge to recruit 5,000 more officers sparked a storm when a leaked treasury memorandum showed that Mr Straw had been warned not to claim that the initiative would provide 5,000 additional officers but would be used to make up for numbers lost through resignations and retirements.

Police forces were invited to bid to the "crime fighting fund" for their share of the extra 5,000 officers. The total bids came to 8,220 so many police forces have been disappointed.

For example, Greater Manchester asked for an extra 1,000 officers but has only been given 378. The Metropolitan police bid for 1,600 and is to get 1,113. The Merseyside force asked for 360 and is to receive only 201.

The Liberal Democrats' home affairs spokesman, Simon Hughes, said the figures showed that there had been a massive fall in the number of police officers since Labour came to power.

"It is clearly now impossible for Labour to say it has met its manifesto pledge to get more officers back on the beat. They know they have failed. The new funding announced today is welcome but is no guarantee there will be enough to replace officers lost over the last three years."

He added: "Because of low ordinary recruitment and the number of officers retiring and resigning, today's additional recruits are no guarantee that there will be more police at the end of this parliament than at the beginning."

The latest home office figures, which put the number of officers at 125,464, raised new doubts that the home secretary's promised extra 5,000 recruits would not be sufficient to reverse the fall in police numbers over the next three years. Chief constables gave a mixed welcome to the announcement yesterday of the detailed allocation of the extra 5,000 recruits between forces. webTitle: MP's wife 'told doctor of her fear'

fields.headline: MP's wife 'told doctor of her fear'
fields.trailText: The former wife of a Labour MP confessed to a hospital doctor that an eye injury was the result of domestic violence which made her scared to return to the family home, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The former wife of a Labour MP confessed to a hospital doctor that an eye injury was the result of domestic violence which made her scared to return to the family home, a court heard yesterday.

Catherine Wray, 50, alleges that Jimmy Wray, MP for Glasgow Ballieston, held a knife to her throat, verbally abused and punched and kicked her on various occasions during their 12-year marriage.

On one occasion Mrs Wray alleges that her husband, a former boxer, hit her with such force that she required hospital treatment for a vision problem.

While undergoing the treatment at Western Infirmary, Glasgow, in February 1990, Mrs Wray told her doctor, Gordon Dutton, of the attack, the court heard.

Professor Dutton told the court of session in Edinburgh that Mrs Wray had asked him not to write down the cause of her injury, but she had stuck in his mind because of her considerable distress.

Prof Dutton was giving evidence in a £1.5m defamation action by Mr Wray, 61, following the publication of an article on his marriage in the Mail on Sunday which accused him of beating his wife.

Associated Newspapers, the publisher, is contesting the action, claiming the story is true.

The court heard that Prof Dutton had treated Mrs Wray, from Milngavie, near Glasgow, for eye injuries on more than one occasion. When she came to him with her first injury, Mrs Wray told Prof Dutton that she had an accident with a broom handle. But on her second visit she was upset. Mrs Wray confessed that her first injury had been caused by a "male assailant", and her most recent injury had been caused by her partner.

Prof Dutton told the court Mrs Wray had admitted her injuries were the result of domestic violence, but she did not want it noted on her medical records, nor did she want to go to the police. "She explained to me she was frightened to go home," he said.

Questioned by Leeona Dorrian QC, for Mr Wray, the doctor said it was hard to distinguish between an injury from violence and that from a fall. He added: "It is difficult to know whether a patient gives a false story to a doctor - it is unusual."

The hearing continues.
