fields.headline: Spice Girl denies tricking sponsor
fields.trailText: The Spice Girls never believed that Geri Halliwell would leave the group, Baby Spice Emma Bunton told the high court in London yesterday.
fields.body:
The Spice Girls never believed that Geri Halliwell would leave the group, Baby Spice Emma Bunton told the high court in London yesterday.

Ms Bunton, 24, was giving evidence in a two-way legal action between the Spice Girls and the sponsor of the group's 1998 world tour, which is claiming that Ginger Spice's departure just weeks into the series of concerts cost it £1.6m in lost profits.

Italian motor cycle manufacturer Aprilia, which signed a £500,000 deal with the group to promote its products, claims the Spice Girls were aware of Ms Halliwell's plans to quit when they signed the contract. Aprilia - which filmed a commercial featuring all five members and launched a special range of Spice Sonic scooters adorned with images of all five - says the band turned into a "total marketing flop" when Ms Halliwell left in May 1998.

The remaining four Spice Girls and Ms Halliwell have launched a counter-suit, claiming £212,000 in unpaid sponsorship and royalty fees from Aprilia.

Ms Bunton said she had not believed that Ms Halliwell would leave the group. This was despite claims by Ms Halliwell in her autobiography, If Only, that she had confided in Ms Bunton on two occasions in March 1998 that she planned to leave.

Ms Bunton said: "Things were said quite flippantly all the time. We never believed she would go."

During 40 minutes of questioning before Mrs Justice Arden, Ms Bunton said she had a "terrible memory". She told Andrew Sutcliffe, representing Aprilia, that she had forgotten a conversation on the tour coach in Frankfurt with Ms Halliwell, during which she announced plans to leave the Spice Girls in September 1998, at the end of their tour.

Mr Sutcliffe said that when Ms Halliwell made her first announcement about leaving in March, just weeks into the group's tour, everyone stopped talking.

Ms Bunton recalled that band member Melanie Chisolm had said Ms Halliwell was trying "to do a Robbie" - a reference to Robbie Williams who left his band Take That to start a solo career - but that Ms Halliwell said she would "stick it out" until September.

Mr Sutcliffe asked whether the Spice Girls had made their minds up not to tell Aprilia that Ms Halliwell would be leaving, rendering its promotional work for its Spice Sonic scooter out of date.

"That would not have occurred to me," she replied.

She also denied claims by Aprilia that the group had been "bolshie" in their public appearances for the company, saying: "I know that I would always be smiling. We were always 100% professional."

Giving evidence earlier, the group's solicitor Andrew Thompson admitted that he knew in April 1998 that Ms Halliwell was planning to leave, before the Spice Girls signed the Aprilia deal, but said the company should have known there was always a risk that the line-up could change.

The hearing continues tomorrow, when Ms Halliwell will give evidence for the band.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Pinochet ruling next week
fields.body:
Pinochet ruling next week

Judgment was reserved yesterday in the high court action by Belgium and six human rights groups seeking a ruling that home secretary Jack Straw acted unlawfully and unfairly when he refused to disclose a medical report on Augusto Pinochet.

Lord Justice Simon Brown hoped to give the court's decision "sometime next week" but could give no immediate indication of what it would be.

Pupils to learn citizenship

MPs yesterday approved citizenship as a new subject on the national curriculum.

All secondary schools will have a legal obligation to teach it from 2002, but David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, urged them to start voluntarily.

Fatal wait for ambulance

Rose Hillman, 85, waited seven hours with a fractured pelvis when Royal Sussex hospital called an ambulance to return her to a nursing home in Bevendean, East Sussex, the Brighton and Hove coroner heard yesterday.

She died a day later of a heart attack. The inquest was told the usual 12 ambulances were down to eight that night, but an internal inquiry was being held. Verdict: accidental death.

Census debate on 'family'

The number of children brought up within a step-family will outstrip children being raised by both natural parents by 2010, Stepfamily Scotland predicted yesterday.

As wording of the census, due next year, is debated in the Scottish parliament, the charity has been advising ministers how to define families in light of the fact couples increasingly live together rather than marry new partners.

Three jailed for murder

Adam Shepherd, 18, Paul Wallington, 19, and Christopher Hills, 22, all of High Wycombe in Buckinghamshire, were jailed for life at Reading crown court yesterday for kicking to death Bradley Bolton, 34, in July last year.

The jury had convicted them after seeing a CCTV video of the attack. The three had denied murder.

Near miss by novice pilot

A novice pilot flew his microlight plane up to a height of 11,000 feet and then came within 100 feet of a Boeing 767 flying over Merseyside from Manchester airport, before the airliner took avoiding action.

Civil aviation authority investigators report they were "amazed" the learner was totally unaware of the near-miss.

webTitle: Bishop steps in as time runs out for Ulster

fields.headline: Bishop steps in as time runs out for Ulster
fields.standfirst:
Lukewarm reaction to church leader's offer of arms guarantor role as Clinton, Blair and Ahern struggle to save Good Friday agreement

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: President Clinton, Tony Blair and Irish premier Bertie Ahern were last night locked in frantic efforts to save Northern Ireland's 10-week-old power-sharing government before tomorrow night's deadline on a start to arms decommissioning - with the focus shifting to a Dublin proposal linking British troop withdrawals to movement on IRA arms.
fields.body:
President Clinton, Tony Blair and Irish premier Bertie Ahern were last night locked in frantic efforts to save Northern Ireland's 10-week-old power-sharing government before tomorrow night's deadline on a start to arms decommissioning - with the focus shifting to a Dublin proposal linking British troop withdrawals to movement on IRA arms.

Amid a flurry of diplomatic activity, the three governments were also studying an intervention from the Catholic church to help break the long-standing deadlock over paramilitary weapons.

They believe the offer, from the Bishop of Derry, Seamus Hegarty, to take immediate charge of IRA weapons for a year, could form a part of any solution.

The leaders were in contact throughout yesterday, and Mr Clinton pleaded for a breakthrough. He said: "We have come too far."

Mr Blair and Mr Ahern were also talking to the province's party leaders at Downing Street. David Trimble, the leader of the Ulster Unionists and Northern Ireland's first minister, cheekily described a 30-minute meeting as "just routine".

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, was in discussion with Brian Cowen, the Irish foreign affairs minister, in London last night. Irish officials were locked in negotiations with republicans in Belfast. They had already spent two days with them in the Irish Republic.

Dr Hegarty, 60, who is being backed by the Catholic hierarchy, said that he was prepared to be a middleman between the IRA and General John de Chastelain's independent commission on decommissioning. He said he would act as "guarantor and supervisor for the safekeeping of a quantity of weapons of war". His sole condition was that they were to be "put beyond use".

Dr Hegarty said: "I consider it my moral responsibility to do everything I can to ensure that progress and cooperation between our peoples is allowed to continue. We cannot go back, and this offer of time and space would enable the political progress to continue and develop for the good of all the people."

Unionists, nationalists, Mr Ahern, and Mr Mandelson gave a tentative welcome to the bishop's offer. Sinn Fein appeared to rule it out, despite Gerry Adams, the party president, accepting the contribution as well-intentioned.

As the emergency bill paving the way for the restoration of direct rule completed its legislative passage, Mr Mandelson indicated that he was hopeful of a new IRA statement, which could come as late as tomorrow. He said Gen de Chastelain was on standby to issue another report.

Mr Mandelson told the Commons: "Nobody is asking for surrender by the IRA. Nobody is asking for humiliation to be heaped on the IRA. I just say that if politics is to work, and if we are to see the decommissioning that is an essential part of the peace process, then there must be certainty. There must be definiteness if confidence in all the institutions is going to be rebuilt."

It is understood that Brian Keenan, the IRA army council member who is acting as the IRA go-between to the decommissioning body, told Gen de Chastelain he was unable to discuss the modalities of weapons decommissioning because he did not have the necessary authority to do so.

That can only come after an IRA army convention votes by a two-thirds majority to begin decommissioning. No such meeting has taken place, and such a result would seem highly unlikely.

But Mr Mandelson pleaded with leaders in Northern Ireland to keep an open mind even at this late stage. That sparked jitters among some Ulster Unionists that he might put pressure on Mr Trimble to accept a formula which falls short of a start to decommissioning.

Mr Trimble is known to be unhappy with the Irish government's attempts in negotiations with republicans this week to link demilitarisation with decommissioning.

He said the Continuity IRA bomb in Irvinestown, Co Fermanagh, on Sunday night meant any such moves were now impossible.

Mr Mandelson last night denied he had asked the recently knighted Sir Josias Cunning ham, the Ulster Unionist president, for a meeting tomorrow.

There was speculation that he might ask Sir Josias, who holds Mr Trimble's letter of resignation as first minister, to postpone Saturday's crucial meeting of the party's 860-strong ruling council.

One UUP MP said: "There is no way the meeting can be put off. There would uproar."

Mr Trimble persuaded the council delegates in November to allow him to go into government immediately with Sinn Fein only after he promised to resign as first minister before a reconvened meeting if there had been no start to IRA decommissioning.

His letter is dated for last Friday, but Sir Josias has held on to it pending this week's negotiations.

Mr Mandelson is reluctant to suspend the power-sharing executive. Sinn Fein is threatening legal action if a suspension takes place.

But if Mr Trimble instead quits as first minister or is defeated in a vote forced at the meeting, it will be difficult to rescue the ailing agreement even if a second review proves successful.

Under the cross-community voting rules in the assembly, it is highly unlikely he could be re-elected, and that would spark fresh elections to the 108-seat body, with hardliners expected to fare best.

webTitle: New music director aims for the top

fields.headline: New music director aims for the top
fields.trailText: The new music director of the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra introduced himself to Merseyside yesterday with a snatch of Elgar beneath the town hall chandeliers.
fields.body:
The new music director of the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra introduced himself to Merseyside yesterday with a snatch of Elgar beneath the town hall chandeliers.

Gerard Schwarz, music director of the Seattle Symphony since 1985, led his new orchestra through a couple of Enigma Variations and then praised the personality of the players, "their willingness and desire to make great music".

He also promised to play the three symphonies by Max Bruch, one of his predecessors in Liverpool, and the two violin concertos by the same composer which the public rarely hears. Other plans include performances of the best American and British music.

The upbeat announcement of Mr Schwarz's appointment, which will not start until September 2001, heralds a determination by the RLPO to enhance its artistic reputation as it emerges from seasons dominated by crippling debts.

It is to apply to the arts council for stabilisation funding to eradicate its £2.5m deficit and is snuggling up to the city council and other authorities in the hunt for bigger grants.

Ruth Davies, oboeist and chairwoman of the RLPO's players committee, said Mr Schwarz was "extremely motivated, inspired and articulate" and understood "the aspirations of a symphony orchestra".

Anthony Lewis-Crosby, the orchestra's chief executive, said: "He went to Seattle at a time when the city had no music reputation and developed the orchestra into one of the leading ensembles in the US."

Mr Schwarz, 52, has signed a five-year contract and plans to spend up to 14 weeks a year with the RLPO. "My job is to lead the artistic flagship of Merseyside to the pinnacle," he said yesterday. "I will not rest until this organisation takes its rightful place as one of the world's great musical institutions in one of the world's great cultural cities."

He hopes to experiment with concerts at unconventional times and pay-what-you-can nights.

webTitle: Police to question doctor MP who let boy die

fields.headline: Police to question doctor MP who let boy die
fields.trailText: Detectives are investigating an MP who admitted allowing a young leukemia sufferer to die, police said yesterday.
fields.body:
Detectives are investigating an MP who admitted allowing a young leukemia sufferer to die, police said yesterday.

Peter Brand told a House of Commons debate that he had withdrawn treatment from a two-year-old boy after the patient and his parents became too distressed at the effect it was having.

The woman who made the complaint to police said last night she was concerned at the "arrogance" of doctors and wanted them called to account. Dr Brand, a GP on the Isle of Wight and the island's Liberal Democrat MP, said he would be happy to cooperate with the police.

Dr Brand made his remarks during a debate on the medical treatment (prevention of euthanasia) bill put forward by a backbench Tory last month. He told MPs that, had the bill been law when he qualified as a doctor in 1971, he would now be a "multi-murderer".

He described his experience of treating a "very brave" child in 1973, when he was a senior house officer specialising in paediatrics. The child was receiving unpleasant treatment, and it was unclear whether any further medical help would have been successful.

"One afternoon, during yet another flare-up, the parents said that neither they nor the child could cope with it any more. They asked for all the tubes to be taken away and to be allowed to sit with him. They did, and he died 48 hours later.

"That was a profound experience. Clearly, I did not withdraw the treatment with the purpose of killing that child, but to prevent further distress to that child and his family. I allowed a death to occur, and that removed distress. The pur pose of my action was, therefore, to promote death or at least to enable death to occur."

Jean Williams, of Weybridge in Surrey, who alerted police, said last night that Dr Brand's comments during the debate had been arrogant and should be investigated. The case of Harold Shipman had highlighted the debate about euthanasia, she said - although there is no suggestion that Dr Brand committed murder.

Mrs Williams said she opposed euthanasia, and that doctors should not be allowed to "play God" with patients. "I was shocked when I heard what Dr Brand said on the radio. I felt it was something that the police should look into."

Dr Brand said last night that he had been informed by Hampshire police that they had not looked at the Hansard transcript of his comments before announcing the investigation. "It is absolutely right that police investigate any complaint they get," he said. But it is most extraordinary that the police didn't check their facts before putting out a statement."

He said that doctors often face difficult decisions, and the bill, proposed by the rightwing Tory MP Ann Winterton, would make their job far more difficult. "The bill is quite explicit that any withholding or stopping of treatment would be illegal if even part of the purpose is the death of the patient. My purpose was not the death of the child, but to allow this child to be at peace."

The parents of the leukemia sufferer had expressed a wish for treatment to be removed and doctors should be allowed to respect those wishes, Dr Brand said. It was also right that any views recorded by patients before reaching a state when they can no longer express them should be taken into account. But he added: "I think it is quite right that doctors should be challenged."

Hampshire police released a statement that said: "Hampshire police received a complaint from a member of the public following comments made by Isle of Wight MP Dr Peter Brand in the House of Commons on Friday January 28. The comments were made during the debate on the proposed medical treatment (prevention of euthanasia) bill and Hampshire police are to investigate the complaint."

fields.headline: Revealing lifestyle of 'president' Blair revealed
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is to be forced to disclose the full scale of his "presidential lifestyle" in Downing Street following the biggest expansion of jobs ever seen at No 10.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is to be forced to disclose the full scale of his "presidential lifestyle" in Downing Street following the biggest expansion of jobs ever seen at No 10.

The prime minister has tripled the number of special advisers and civil servants and imported "interns" - young political aides - from the United States to assist him. The aides work on short term contracts similar to White House appointments to President Bill Clinton's staff.

Mr Blair is also said to have appointed four staff to the office which handles Cherie Blair's public engagements. Norma Major relied on a part-time secretary.

Sir Richard Wilson, the cabinet secretary, promised yesterday to reveal details of the changes after coming under fire from the Tory MP Andrew Tyrie at the Commons public administration committee.

Mr Tyrie pressed Sir Richard to explain not only the big increase in special advisers - from 8 to 22 - but also a big increase in civil servants.

Sir Richard defended the changes, describing how the volume of mail to Downing Street was rising. In 1995 John Major received 20,000 letters from members of the public. Last year Tony Blair received 135,000.

fields.headline: MPs to champion England
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: England is finally to be given special recognition at Westminster with the formation of a distinctive committee designed to champion the country's affairs and represent its different regions.
fields.body:
England is finally to be given special recognition at Westminster with the formation of a distinctive committee designed to champion the country's affairs and represent its different regions.

An English regional committee will be based on the model of the old Scottish and Welsh select committees - abolished when powers were devolved to Edinburgh and Cardiff nine months ago.

The new committee, which will be able to quiz ministers, question their spending decisions and commission research, could hold meetings around England as part of a plan to bring politics closer to voters.

Labour's restless English backbenchers, who believe Scotland and Wales have been given over-generous annual block grants - around £15bn and £8bn respectively - are certain to use the committee to champion England's case for more Whitehall cash. They believe English regions are disadvantaged because public spending per head is much lower than in Scotland and Wales - often by as much as 20%.

Moves to form the committee have been given added urgency by mounting back bench concern that Labour is neglecting its heartlands. Earlier this week Tony Blair told Labour councillors it was a "false illusion" that answers to the problems of the north could be solved by "punishing the south".

But ministers have been rattled by claims from the Liverpool Walton MP Peter Kilfoyle - who resigned last week as junior defence minister - that the party was losing touch with its core supporters. The government will shortly challenge critics by launching a special unit to co-ordinate work in the eight English regions.

webTitle: Hague 'still in charge on tax' say aides

fields.headline: Hague 'still in charge on tax' say aides
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The Tory leadership yesterday warned supporters of Michael Portillo not to stir up divisions between William Hague and his new shadow chancellor in the run-up to the coming election.
fields.body:
The Tory leadership yesterday warned supporters of Michael Portillo not to stir up divisions between William Hague and his new shadow chancellor in the run-up to the coming election.

"We know there are people out there who think they are working in Michael's interests, but they are not. They should shut up," a senior Hague adviser said as Conservative MPs acknowledged Mr Portillo's growing impact on party policy making. Mr Hague himself yesterday reaffirmed his controversial pledge to cut the overall burden of taxes in the face of Labour taunts that the policy amounts to a formula for cuts in popular public spending programmes like health and education.

Hague aides deny that the 38-year-old party leader has conceded virtual autonomy over economic policy to Mr Portillo, as the Guardian reported yesterday.

He was not even consulted before getting the job, they say, keen to prevent voters starting to think that Mr Hague is Mr Portillo's puppet. Yesterday the Conservative leader deputed David Heathcoat-Amory, shadow chief secretary, to raise the tax issue on Radio 4's Today programme. Mr Heathcoat-Amory, Michael Portillo's deputy in the Tory treasury team, spoke 24 hours after Mr Hague had reinforced doubts about the so-called "tax guarantee" by saying that it is only an "aspiration" to lower the tax burden in the lifetime of the next parliament.

"He may have used a different word at a different specific time, but he has absolutely reinforced the promise that over the period of a parliament we will get the overall burden of tax down. That's what counts for people. It's not the rate of income tax at any one time, it's the total tax that they pay," Mr Heathcoat-Amory said.

webTitle: Stop anti-Hague spin, Portillo aides told

fields.headline: Stop anti-Hague spin, Portillo aides told
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo's allies have been told to "shut up" and to stop briefing against William Hague, in a move by Conservative central office to break up a rival leadership camp.
fields.byline: Michael White, Kevin Maguire and Nicholas Watt
fields.body:
Michael Portillo's allies have been told to "shut up" and to stop briefing against William Hague, in a move by Conservative central office to break up a rival leadership camp.

Alarmed that Tory central office appears to be dividing into rival factions, Mr Hague's aides have made clear to the "Portillistas" that they owe their first loyalty to the party leader.

"We know there are people out there who think they are working in Michael's interests, but they are not. They should shut up," a senior Hague adviser said as Conservative MPs acknowledged Mr Portillo's growing impact on party policy making. One of the first casualties is expected to be the arch-Portillo supporter Robbie Gibb, chief of staff to the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, who was moved sideways last week to make way for Mr Portillo.

Mr Gibb, who is said to keep a cardboard cutout of his hero at his flat, was expected to take up a similar role with Mr Portillo. But he is thought to have been blocked and will now stay with Mr Maude.

The Hague camp acted against the "Portillistas" after a report in yesterday's Guardian that the 38-year-old leader has conceded virtual autonomy over economic policy to his new shadow chancellor.

Within days of his appointment last week, Mr Portillo dropped the Tories' opposition to the minimum wage and to Bank of England independence. Over the weekend Mr Portillo appeared to distance himself from Mr Hague's key tax-cutting pledge, forcing the Tory leader to describe his "tax guarantee" on Tuesday as an aspiration.

Mr Hague, whose aides insisted that he set economic policy in consultation with Mr Portillo, added to the confusion yesterday by reaffirming his commitment to his controversial pledge. "The tax guarantee stands and the tax guarantee will continue to stand," the Tory leader said in the Commons.

His remarks came after David Heathcoat-Amory, the shadow chief secretary, appeared on Radio 4's Today programme to explain the apparent difference between the Tory leader and the shadow chancellor.

"He may have used a different word at a different specific time, but he has absolutely reinforced the promise that over the period of a parliament we will get the overall burden of tax down," Mr Heathcoat-Amory said.

"That's what counts for people. It's not the rate of income tax at any one time, it's the total tax that they pay."

It was "totally untrue" that Mr Portillo had unchallenged authority over economic policy. "Michael Portillo works under William Hague," he said.

Tory MPs are likely to be disappointed - though hardly surprised - that relations between the Hague and Portillo camps appear to have soured so soon after Mr Portillo's triumphant return to the Commons.

Mr Hague's aides were stressing that they were not pointing the finger at Mr Portillo himself, merely at over-enthusiastic acolytes.

The whole episode has echoes of the relationship between Tony Blair and Gordon Brown. Mr Hague gave Mr Portillo a free hand in setting the party's economic policy in a private handwritten letter, echoing the Blair-Brown deal of 1994 when the future chancellor agreed, after lengthy negotiations, to give Mr Blair a free run for the Labour leadership.

Since then the Blair and Brown camps have sniped at each other, although the two men are still close.

webTitle: Kurdish separatist group declares peace with Turkey

fields.headline: Kurdish separatist group declares peace with Turkey
fields.standfirst: The Kurds: special report
fields.trailText: The Kurdistan Workers party (PKK) yesterday formally abandoned its 15-year separatist rebellion in south-east Turkey and adopted the democratic political programme pleaded for by its imprisoned leader, Abdullah Ocalan.
fields.body:
The Kurdistan Workers party (PKK) yesterday formally abandoned its 15-year separatist rebellion in south-east Turkey and adopted the democratic political programme pleaded for by its imprisoned leader, Abdullah Ocalan.

At a secret meeting, believed to have been held in the mountains of northern Iran, Kurdish rebel commanders confirmed they would make their hitherto temporary ceasefire permanent.

A statement dismissed reports of a fundamental split within the movement - although the PKK has disowned a renegade group active in the eastern province of Tunceli, which has rejected the new policy.

"Our congress has confirmed the decision of the party leader to stop the armed struggle," the official PKK announcement said. "The problems of Turkey will find resolution by democratic means."

The extraordinary conference was the first since Ocalan appealed for peace after his capture by Turkish special forces in Kenya last year.

The PKK leader was sentenced to death for launching the insurrection in Turkey's mainly Kurdish south-east, which is estimated to have cost 37,000 lives.

But last month Turkey's prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, said he would suspend the capital sentence pending an appeal to the European court of human rights in Strasbourg. Turkish security officials claim the rebels have not yet disarmed or withdrawn from Turkey's borders.

Many of the guerrillas have withdrawn to northern Iraq, where they are still engaged in heavy skirmishes with the Kurdistan Democratic party's peshmerga fighters.

fields.headline: Nice one, John
fields.standfirst: In 1971, when John Lennon was recording Imagine in his country mansion, he was filmed with a home-movie camera mucking around with his friends.  Richard Vine  finds that, 30 years later, the result has become riveting
fields.trailText: All you need is love. Well, love and a handy broadcast-quality cine camera. When you're a category-A rock legend like John Lennon, a guaranteed way to capitalise on your fame in later years is to make sure you've got a huge stock of memorabilia to leave behind. People will snap up any old napkin you've scribbled on - do you really think the Hard Rock Cafe could get restaurants all around the planet if there wasn't so much stuff?
fields.body:
All you need is love. Well, love and a handy broadcast-quality cine camera. When you're a category-A rock legend like John Lennon, a guaranteed way to capitalise on your fame in later years is to make sure you've got a huge stock of memorabilia to leave behind. People will snap up any old napkin you've scribbled on - do you really think the Hard Rock Cafe could get restaurants all around the planet if there wasn't so much stuff?

In the 60s and 70s it became a lot easier to leave useful artefacts behind, because this was a time when new technology to make them on became available and affordable, to rock stars, at least. Would Paul, George and Ringo have been able to cobble together Real Love or Free As A Bird if John hadn't had the foresight to tape himself mucking about at home? And would we be able to watch something like Sunday's Gimme Some Truth (10.30pm, BBC2) if he hadn't got one of his mates to run off loads of footage of him in his early 70s prime as he hung out in his Berkshire mansion, recording the Imagine album? No. But luckily for the BBC, he had the technology, and he used it.

It's filled with the kind of studio scenes that we have become familiar with, after films like One Plus One when the Rolling Stones hammered out Sympathy For The Devil, or the Anthology series which exhaustively documented Lennon's earlier career with the other three. And you get the same kind of feeling watching him with his band here, jamming How Do You Sleep? or struggling with Phil Spector to get a good take for the backing vocals on Oh Yoko! that you do watching any studio footage: at one stage, these songs were new, were actually works in progress. Access to that progress, hearing all the mistakes, seeing Lennon calling the studio engineer a cunt while he records a tender love song, allows you to hear the music without its hallowed Classic Album status.

Watching Gimme Some Truth also makes you realise how interesting everything becomes when you're famous. When you're John Lennon, nothing is banal. Few of us have ever filmed ourselves while we sit around having lunch with our work mates, and if we did, no doubt it would not provide fascinating viewing to millions 29 years later. But if you're John Lennon, and you're at work in 1971 having lunch with your work colleagues, you're taking a break from recording Imagine or Jealous Guy, and you're being filmed having lunch with Yoko Ono, George Harrison and Phil Spector, and it's fascinating. They tell jokes about who the real Beatle Wife Number One is - John or Yoko - ad-libbing in a way that makes you realise they're not really ad-libbing. Without the A-grade celebrity presence that's in the room it wouldn't be an ad-lib. It would just be friends chatting. We're so used to seeing famous people being witty on chat shows that it's kind of weird seeing them making casual remarks over lunch, mucking about for their own amusement.

You might have taken the opportunity to try out your new camera when you had a few friends round. But, like seeing other people's holiday snaps, frankly, it's not really the sort of thing you want to sit through for long, and it certainly won't be shown to a national TV audience in 2029.

But when you're John Lennon and film your friends coming over, you're also documenting a moment in pop culture when Andy Warhol, Jack Nicholson, and Miles Davis were hanging out together, not being seen celebrating the opening of a thrilling new line of handbags in order to get onto the back page of OK! like today's rentafame personalities, but just hanging out, talking, having a good time.

With its latest branch of fusion TV, When Changing Rooms Met Ground Force, the BBC is trying hard to squeeze some kind of excitement into the imploding DIY genre. But a few minutes in the company of John and Yoko, and it's painfully obvious where Charlie Dimmock and Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen are going wrong. No matter how hard they or the BBC try, they will always be people who are famous for knowing a lot about something that isn't really that interesting. Which is fine, but it doesn't really make them stars.

But when you've got a man whose band defined a generation and can accurately be said to have changed not just a few formica-stained rooms with a cunning application of MDF and purple gloss, but millions of lives with his music and politics, and he's on film talking about something as utterly dull and mundane and everyday as his garden, it's suddenly fascinating. Where are they going to erect their summer house? Will it be north facing or south? Can John get a window put in the back so they can see out from all sides?

It's an indulgent exercise, of course, the ultimate kind of trivial pursuit, sitting alongside studio footage of the recording of songs that we've probably heard too often to listen to with any degree of critical understanding. Fame, and Lennon's death add weight and poignancy in retrospect to events that probably wouldn't matter that much otherwise. But when you see and hear Lennon teaching Imagine to the band, and they're all nodding, "that's a nice one, John", it's hard not to agree.

But, like seeing other people's holiday snaps, frankly, it's not really the sort of thing you want to sit through for long, and it certainly won't be shown to a national TV audience in 2029. But when you're John Lennon and film your friends coming over, you're also documenting a moment in pop culture when Andy Warhol, Jack Nicholson, and Miles Davis were hanging out together, not being seen celebrating the opening of a thrilling new line of handbags in order to get onto the back page of OK! like today's rentafame personalities, but just hanging out, talking, having a good time. With its latest branch of fusion TV, When Changing Rooms Met Ground Force, the BBC is trying hard to squeeze some kind of excitement into the imploding DIY genre. But a few minutes in the company of John and Yoko, and it's painfully obvious where Charlie Dimmock and Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen are going wrong. No matter how hard they or the BBC try, they will always be people who are famous for knowing a lot about something that isn't really that interesting. Which is fine, but it doesn't really make them stars. But when you've got a man whose band defined a generation and can accurately be said to have changed not just a few formica-stained rooms with a cunning application of MDF and purple gloss, but millions of lives with his music and politics, and he's on film talking about something as utterly dull and mundane and everyday as his garden, it's suddenly fascinating. Where are they going to erect their summer house? Will it be north facing or south? Can John get a window put in the back so they can see out from all sides? It's an indulgent exercise, of course, the ultimate kind of trivial pursuit, sitting alongside studio footage of the recording of songs that we've probably heard too often to listen to with any degree of critical understanding. Fame, and Lennon's death add weight and poignancy in retrospect to events that probably wouldn't matter that much otherwise. But when you see and hear Lennon teaching Imagine to the band, and they're all nodding, "that's a nice one, John", it's hard not to agree.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: A Personal Journey With Martin Scorsese Through American Movies
fields.body:
A Personal Journey With Martin Scorsese Through American Movies

6pm, FilmFour

The cumbersome title at least proves accurate, and this three-part documentary makes for a comprehensive history lesson. Its intelligent structure serves to break down what would otherwise be a long, long trawl, while Scorsese's personality is less obtrusive than his enthusiasm.

Breakdown

(Jonathan Mostow, 1997)

8pm, Sky Premier

Married couple Kurt Russell and Kathleen Quinlan's jeep breaks down in the middle of nowhere, USA, and passing trucker JT Walsh gives her a lift into town while Kurt fixes the car. When he reaches town, Walsh and assorted rednecks deny ever seeing his wife. Like George Sluizer's The Vanishing, Mostow's unsettling thriller builds an air of taut menace around the disappearance.

Postcards From The Edge

(Mike Nichols, 1990)

9pm, Living

Carrie Fisher's adaptation of her broadly autobiographical novel is an intelligent, snappy comedy providing juicy roles for two fine actresses. Meryl Streep plays the drug-addicted film star who after an overdose is forced to go back to mum Shirley MacLaine for safekeeping - but she's an alcoholic. A caustic, loving campaign ensues, with witty sideswipes at Hollywood too. The men - Gene Hackman, Dennis Quaid, Richard Dreyfuss - are left in the shade.

Kill Me Again

(John Dahl, 1989)

10pm, FilmFour

Dahl takes a shot at a modern film noir but maybe tries just a little too hard. (He circulated a compilation of classic noir scenes before shooting started.) The actual story's a real grabber: femme fatale Joanne Whalley-Kilmer gets a private dick (then real-life hubby Val Kilmer) to fake her death, so she can escape psycho boyfriend Michael "Reservoir Dogs" Madsen. He's seriously heavy, and while the Kilmers are no Bogart and Astor, they are pretty convincing.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Though there is credible medical evidence that it killed Jane Austen, it then took 40 years before Thomas Addison could give his name to the lethargy and anaemia which carried off the writer in 1817. In A Name To Remember (9.30am, Radio 4) Barbara Myers tells the story of the manic depressive doctor who is now seen as one of the founders of modern medicine. He did not live to enjoy his fame, committing suicide at 65.

In A Name To Remember (9.30am, Radio 4) Barbara Myers tells the story of the manic depressive doctor who is now seen as one of the founders of modern medicine. He did not live to enjoy his fame, committing suicide at 65.

There are about 250 tons of military plutonium stored around the world, much of it housed with other fissile materials in nuclear warheads. Since the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty forbids experiments on bigger or better bombs, the nuclear powers are now stuck with their present ageing stockpile. But, as Alun Lewis explains in Testbeds (9.0pm, Radio 4), no one has much idea how stable the various ingredients will prove. Tritium deteriorates quite quickly: how safe are the rest of the elements?

fields.headline: Born to be wild
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: It was either a stroke of genius, or an unfortunate accident, that led to BBC1's unofficial surrogacy double-bill last night.
fields.body:
It was either a stroke of genius, or an unfortunate accident, that led to BBC1's unofficial surrogacy double-bill last night. The second part of Surrogate Babies was a painful 50 minutes of tears, fears and recriminations; and if that wasn't enough to put anybody off surrogacy, or indeed child-bearing in any shape or form, it was immediately followed by an X Files episode dealing with the impregnation of women by Satan himself.

The latter was the more predictable and palatable of the two. For those who remember The X Files as exciting, must-see TV a few years ago, the latest series comes as a bit of a shock. Last night's episode, irrelevantly titled Terms Of Endearment, concerned Virginia salesman Wayne and his pregnant wife Laura, who was in the third trimester of pregnancy. An ultrasound scan revealed "bony formations in the upper vertebrae and the plates of the skull"; no sooner had the worried couple got home than Laura freaked out and had a vision of the Devil at the foot of her bed in sheets of flame. Then she woke up, and it was all a dream - or was it? In a scene that set a new low for bad taste, Laura discovered that her night dress was drenched in blood and that she had lost the baby. Lost quite literally: she seemed not to notice that there was no sign of the foetus, and didn't understand why slimy Wayne started burning "leaves" in the middle of the night.

Fortunately, Mulder got hold of the case and pronounced it "a classic case of demon foetal harvest". David Duchovny delivered this line with a straight face, and should be nominated for some kind of award for his troubles. Thereafter it was downhill all the way, as Wayne revealed not only that he had weird cat eyes when he blinked, but also that he kept a harem of pregnant wives all over Virginia. Mulder and Scully (Gillian Anderson) had lots more great lines ("Protuberances? You mean, like, horns?") and lurched towards conclusions that the rest of us had reached hours ago. Of course "Wayne" was not a wholesome American salesman at all but a nasty foreigner (Czech, in fact) who had been doing this sort of thing for ages. Finally, Wayne (alias Ivan) met his match in Betsey, a she-devil with ambitions to be the Anti-Madonna. As she burned off down the freeway with her little bundle of hellspawn grizzling in its carry-cot, Wayne/Ivan sobbed "A normal life - a family - that's all I ever wanted." Sympathy for the Devil, indeed.

The lengths to which some people are prepared to go for a normal family life were clearly outlined in Surrogate Babies . Lurking dimly behind the portmanteau of stories that make up the series is the threat of a government "review" of the whole issue; it's evidently an issue that BBC1 should be addressing. Why, then, did Surrogate Babies concentrate on the intimate lives of a handful of couples and prospective host mothers in such toe-curling detail? Of course this is a difficult process: nobody would resort to surrogacy if they didn't face reproductive problems in their own lives. It must be awkward, embarrassing and painful, as well as an answer to the prayers of childless couples. But in order to labour the point, Surrogate Babies turned the story of Michelle and Paul, who can't have children, and Marsha, their would-be surrogate, into an emotional bloodbath. The last 20 minutes of the programme showed the collapse of the arrangement in a welter of suspicion, bad temper and mutual distrust. By the end of the show, the editors were gleefully cutting between Michelle and Paul abusing Marsha ("she's wicked") and the latter getting her revenge by talking about Michelle's weight.

If this was intended as a warning to anyone considering surrogacy, it was pointless. Nobody would expect it to be a bed of roses. If it was presented merely as human interest, it was unkind. Michelle, Paul and Marsha bared their souls when they were stressed out and vulnerable, and now have to live with the consequences. The rest of the stories featured in the show were happier; thus it made good editorial sense to show that things can also go wrong. But the reasons, in this case, had nothing to do with surrogacy, more to do with an unpleasant personality clash - and to expose it in such detail did nothing to inform the debate.

Thank God for the comic relief of The X Files. What next? A documentary on adoption followed by a screening of Mommie Dearest?

webTitle: The price is right: Which of these films will receive the most Oscar nominations?

fields.headline: The price is right: Which of these films will receive the most Oscar nominations?
fields.trailText: American Beauty 4/7
fields.body:
American Beauty 4/7

The Informer 5/4

Cider House Rules 8/1

Being John Malkovich 10/1

The nomination date is almost on us for the 72nd annual Academy Awards. It's a year with seemingly no clear-cut Oscar favorites, although the world wide web will post a number of betting sites and readers' polls any day now. When industry experts calculate the odds they'll be looking to key indicators like the Golden Globe Awards.

But the Oscars are also an example of there being no such thing as a safe bet, as was demonstrated when last year's best picture award went to Shakespeare In Love instead of Spielberg's Saving Private Ryan.

For American Beauty, with Kevin Spacey playing a middle-class wage slave embarking on a reckless quest for self-discovery, Ed Nicholson, Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler, suggests a Best Picture Oscar as well as Best Actors/Actresses. "American Beauty has transfixed America and the film received a glut of Golden Globe nominations."

Spotting a surprise hit in the little seen but critically acclaimed exposé of the tobacco industry, The Informer, Nicholson picks Russell Crowe instead of Al Pacino as the star turn. "The Informer is a power-packed film based on the real-life story of Jeffrey Wigand (played by Russell Crowe), who got the nerve to blow the whistle on the tobacco companies. It's bound to get Crowe a best actor nomination."

The quality of acting in Cider House Rules, with old-hand Michael Caine alongside up-and-coming Charlie Theron and Tobey Maguire, is vital to its appeal. "Based on John Irving's book, it's sure to have support for an acting award."

And Being John Malkovich takes a bizarre look at the world through somebody else's eyes. "Cameron Diaz fans are in for a surprise here, as she appears frumpy," says Ed."If that's possible", he adds. "Which could pitch her for a best supporting actress award."

webTitle: Work in progress: Scott Adams, writer and animator

fields.headline: Work in progress: Scott Adams, writer and animator
fields.trailText: My first job - sixteen hours washing dishes - was my most rewarding. After all, everyone needs clean dishes. After that I worked 17 years in the corporate environment, and therefore did nothing of any value to anyone. If you could go back in time sci-fi style and kill me in the womb, the gross product of the world would be exactly the same.
fields.body:
My first job - sixteen hours washing dishes - was my most rewarding. After all, everyone needs clean dishes. After that I worked 17 years in the corporate environment, and therefore did nothing of any value to anyone. If you could go back in time sci-fi style and kill me in the womb, the gross product of the world would be exactly the same.

Now, I work full-time (and then some) on Dilbert. I work from home, which cuts me off from the direct influence of my work (the office), but I receive hundreds of e-mails a day from people who live the life. I get all kinds of reactions to the strip and cartoon, mostly people who are happy to see they're not suffering alone. People enjoy the shared victimhood. Some, of course, are offended I would mock such a revered institution as management - but these complaints only come from people in management. With the internet many can now work from home, but there'll always be offices: only they'll become increasingly populated by people who are getting dumber and dumber because they couldn't get out. I think there's a kind of Darwinian thing going on here - the way you'll spot the dumbest people is because they'll be stuck in office cubicles.

When I started Dilbert I wouldn't let anyone refer to him as a nerd, but now with Bill Gates having $90 billion being a nerd is more a badge of honour. He's a nerd and I am too. Well, more of a geek than a nerd: a nerd is more bookish and introverted and a geek just loves technology, but could be otherwise normal. I'm just grateful I can do all my promo work from home now. Am I starved of human contact? No, my motto is the less the better.

Dilbert I and II are available to buy on Columbia TriStar

Interview by Phelim O'Neill

webTitle: In the beginning was the gluon

fields.headline: In the beginning was the gluon
fields.standfirst: Matter not seen since the Big Bang may have been recreated.  Frank Close  reports
fields.trailText: Matter not seen since the Big Bang may have been recreated. Frank Close reports
fields.body:
Solid as a rock, liquid like the seas, or gas like the air we breathe: everything on earth exists in these three states. But most of the universe is not like this.

The stars are so hot that the atoms of solid, liquid or gaseous matter are ripped into their components: our sun consists of electrons and protons - the component particles of the hydrogen atom - flowing independently. This fourth state of matter is known as "plasma". It is a seething mass of electrically charged particles, as near to Dante's inferno as we have yet known. Until now.

Today, physicists working at Cern, the European organisation for nuclear research, including a team from Birmingham university in the UK, announce "compelling evidence" that they have created a "new [fifth] state of matter" with "many of the characteristics of the theoretically predicted quark-gluon plasma".

Such a result would provide another important plank to support our theories of creation in the Big Bang. For some years theorists have speculated that this fifth state existed in the very early moments of the universe. While the million degree temperatures within the sun disrupt atoms, they are still cool on the nuclear scale; protons and neutrons of atomic nuclei retain their identities.

According to the theory, in the searing heat of the Big Bang the fundamental quarks and gluons, that theorists believe were among the basic particles of the creation and which in today's cold universe are trapped inside protons and neutrons, would have been too hot to stick together. In the aftermath of the Big Bang, says the theory, matter consisted of a "Quark-Gluon Plasma" (QGP for short).

Physicists believe that quark gluon plasma (QGP) might still exist in the hearts of neutron stars so dense that a piece the size of a pinhead would weigh more than the Eiffel Tower. Even if QGP does exist there, we cannot access it and have to recreate it in the laboratory in order to understand the first moments of the universe.

Physicists have concentrated on heavy elements, such as gold and lead, whose atomic nuclei contain around 200 protons and neutrons tightly packed together. For several years they have suspected that in high energy collisions between heavy nuclei such as these, the protons and neutrons would crush one another. Then quarks and gluons would freely roam within the volume of the resulting fireball. This freedom state is known as QGP.

But positive identification of the quark gluon plasma in these collisions is extremely difficult. The QGP state would have only a very transient existence before cooling, its quarks and gluons rapidly coalescing into the familiar stuff of which we are made. Even within an atom's length of the QGP, familiar matter is the rule and the detectors at Cern are far more remote than this. So the catch 22 is that you have smashed pieces of conventional matter together, and detected the same, while hoping to prove that for a brief moment within a minuscule volume they have been utterly transformed into a state unknown since the start of time.

The evidence collected at Cern is indirect since it stems from detecting particles that have undergone significant changes since their formation in and around the QGP and their final observation in the huge detectors. Still, they retain enough memory of the initial quark-gluon state to provide evidence for its for mation, like the grin of the Cheshire Cat in Alice in Wonderland that remains even after the cat had disappeared.

For example, the relative abundance of different varieties of the familiar particles is predicted to change when QGP has been present relative to what is the case in more normal circumstances.

So-called "strange" particles are expected to become more important while the ephemeral "psi" particles become rarer. The relative speeds and distributions of some of the particles can, by quantum theory, enable one to infer the size of the QGP region; the result here also is in line with what the theorists expected.

Experimenters at Cern have seen tantalising glimpses of each of these phenomena but feared there might be some mundane explanation, rather than them being fossil relics of the QGP.

As the experiments have gathered more data over the months their quality has improved and interpretations of the phenomena without invoking the existence of QGP have become increasingly untenable.

These, and other technical observations, have led to today's announcement. Even so, the Cern teams admit that this is "proof by circumstantial evidence". Conclusive proof should come from more direct measurements, such as the detection of electromagnetic signals that are emitted direct from the quarks within the QGP. In the immediate future this will become possible at the much higher fireball temperatures about to be provided by RHIC, the relativistic heavy ion collider, now beginning operation at Brookhaven National Laboratory in the USA.

Today's announcement by Cern will create great excitement as to what the RHIC experiments will reveal during the next few years.

 Frank Close's latest book, Lucifer's Legacy - The Meaning Of Asymmetry, will be published by Oxford University Press on March 16.

Experimenters at Cern have seen tantalising glimpses of each of these phenomena but feared there might be some mundane explanation, rather than them being fossil relics of the QGP. As the experiments have gathered more data over the months their quality has improved and interpretations of the phenomena without invoking the existence of QGP have become increasingly untenable. In the immediate future this will become possible at the much higher fireball temperatures about to be provided by RHIC, the relativistic heavy ion collider, now beginning operation at Brookhaven National Laboratory in the USA. fields.headline: Eros is waiting
fields.standfirst: At last astronomers are to get their first close up view of a near-Earth asteroid, explains  Duncan Steel
fields.trailText: At last astronomers are to get their first close up view of a near-Earth asteroid, explains Duncan Steel
fields.body:
This must be the satellite malfunction that Nasa engineers planned. Just before Christmas in 1998 a faulty rocket burn by the Near-Earth Asteroid Rendezvous (NEAR) space probe meant abandoning the plans to meet its target on February 6 last year. Of course, the world jeered yet another expensive failure. But the engineers may have the last laugh, because they re-targeted Near to reach its destination on February 14.

Why is that amusing? Because that's Valentine's Day, and the target is Eros. Asteroid Eros, that is. Actually it gets better, and sub-editors will soon be able to have all manner of fun writing headings about this erotic encounter.

Neargets its name because it is to rendezvous with this asteroid: that is, be inserted into an orbit circling the space rock in order to allow researchers to map its surface and make a host of other measurements.

Astronomers call such trajectories "osculating" orbits, and if you look up that in a dictionary you'll find that it means "kissing", or "bringing into a close contact or union". All made possible because Eros is attractive. Gravitationally attractive, I mean.

Properly this heavenly body is called 433 Eros: the 433rd asteroid (or minor planet) to have a well- determined orbit about the Sun, and so be added to the definitive list and given a name. It was found in 1898, and as many of these early discoveries were given names for classical deities, this one was called after the Greek god of love. The Roman equivalent needed to wait a few more decades before 763 Cupido [sic] was named. And the goddesses of love? Well, next came 1388 Aphrodite. However, the Roman love goddess, Venus, has long had a very special place in our skies, of course.

Eros qualifies as a near-Earth asteroid because it comes within about 12 million miles of the terrestrial orbit, even though it does not cross our path, remaining fur ther than us from the Sun at all times.

It was discovered independently by French and German skywatchers in 1898, so we've had plenty of time to determine its orbit with some precision, making the planning of the Near mission possible.

But modern French and German astronomers, joined by some Italian experts on orbital evolution, studied the evolving trajectory of Eros just a few years back. The bad news is that they found that it might well gradually change its orbit, under gravitational tugs dominated by Jupiter, such that it could strike the Earth. The good news is that this is not due to happen for a million years.

Nevertheless, the possible consequences of Eros slamming into our planet bear thinking about. It is shaped somewhat like a potato, being around 25 miles long with an oval cross-section around eight miles across.

This makes it bigger than the projectile that seems to have seen off the dinosaurs 65 million years ago, leaving a hundred-mile wide crater in Mexico. If asteroid Eros were to plunge to Earth, perhaps landing on top of the Statue of Eros in Piccadilly Circus, the rim of the resulting crater would stretch out to Cardiff, Manchester and Paris, and the crater as deep as the Channel is wide. This would be the end of life as we know it on planet Earth.

While Eros itself is not a danger to us in the foreseeable future, space researchers want to know more about it because it can give us important information about the host of smaller asteroids regularly being discovered on Earth-crossing orbits.

Eros was just a good target opportunity, as Comet Halley was in 1986, being a large object with a well-known orbit. As time goes by space probes will be sent to other such objects.

The only close-up views we have of asteroids are of 243 Ida and 913 Gaspra (both whizzed past by Nasa's Galileo satellite as it made its way to Jupiter in the first half of the 1990s), and 253 Mathilde. NEAR itself waltzed by the latter in mid-1997, showing it to be a huge body reflecting only a tiny fraction of the sunlight impinging upon it. Thankfully, Mathilde inhabits the main belt of asteroids, and so never comes vaguely close to Earth.

After its launch four years ago Near has taken a convoluted path to Eros. Out into the main belt, and then back home again, using a flyby of the Earth and Moon two years ago to get the gravitational slingshot boost required to meet Eros in January 1999. But the rocket misfire mentioned earlier meant that instead of slowing down to rendezvous, it shot past at more than 2,000 mph.

After some wizardry with their computer programs and measurements of the propellant left in the tanks, Nasa's engineers managed to plan a series of burns taking Near back to Eros, this time at a more reasonable speed. All being well - and you can keep informed by checking http://near.jhuapl.edu/ - on February 14 the satellite will stop orbiting the Sun, and instead go into orbit around the asteroid, swooping as low as 30 miles above its surface to give scientists a close-up.

This in itself is remarkable, because Eros has such a low gravitational attraction. It may be big as asteroids go, but it's tiny compared to a planet. Huge rockets are needed to launch a satellite from the Earth, our escape speed being about seven miles per second. But the escape speed for Eros is merely 22 miles an hour. The slowest of cricket's slow bowlers, standing on the surface of Eros, could throw a ball fast enough to make it fly off and never come back.

Low gravity is nice, but it can be a problem: how do you land on a space rock that pulls so weakly? In fact there are no plans for Near to attempt a landing, but this is a problem for future spacecraft designers who would like to bring a lump back for analysis. Some sort of cosmic grappling hook will be needed.

What will we find when the first pictures are received? One basic rule in the solar system is that all surfaces have been cratered by impacts by cosmic projectiles, and it is expected that Eros will be similarly pock-marked. There is already a competition underway for the suggestion of names for these: see http://planetary.org/ Nothing in bad taste, or really erotic, is allowed, of course.

 Duncan Steel researches asteroids and comets at the university of Salford.

fields.headline: Every molecule counts
fields.standfirst: Microchips are far too big for the next generation of chemical computers, writes  David Bradley
fields.trailText: Microchips are far too big for the next generation of chemical computers, writes David Bradley
fields.body:
Imagine a penny-sized computer memory that can hold as much information as a million million CD-roms or the computing power of a thousand PCs crammed into a space no bigger than a sugarcube. Welcome to the future world of molecular computers.

Here, a single molecule will carry out each logical step in a calculation that takes place on silicon chip. A whole network of such molecules might be joined together, perhaps by other wire-like molecules that shuttle photons of light or electrons around and make the connections with the monitors and keyboards.

Prasanna "AP" de Silva is one of the chemists building seemingly simple molecules that can carry out the basic logical functions of mathematics - AND, NOT, OR, NOR and so on.

He and his team at Queen's University Belfast began thinking logically about molecules about 10 years ago and have gradually increased the repertoire of functions their minute mathematicians can carry out. Their first success was to build a molecule that could carry out the AND logic function. When the AND "gate" sees two 1s of computer binary code it gives an output of 1. 1 AND 1 => 1.

If there is only one 1 and a 0 or two 0s then there is no output, in other words a 0.

Their molecular AND "gate" is made from a small ring-shaped molecule called a crown ether which has another molecular group called an anthracene sticking out the side. The crown ether part is quite clever - it can recognise and trap ions of the metal sodium, and only sodium, in solution. If a sodium ion is present, it fits into the centre of the crown ether ring.

A potassium ion, on the other hand, can attach itself to the anthracene group. We can think of attached sodium and potassium ions as representing the 1s in binary code. Their absence means 0.

The chemists put the logical molecule into solution and observe what happens with different combinations of their metal ions. But how do they read the output?

That's where anthracene comes in. When stimulated in the right way, it glows with an eerie blue light. That stimulation just happens to be the presence of a trapped sodium ion nearby with a potassium ion stuck to the anthracene. Both metals present means the crown ether is saying "1 AND 1", the anthracene glows and the chemists read this as an output of 1. If either one of the ions is not present then the anthracene cannot glow and we have 0 output.

More recently, the team has taken the first tentative steps to more complex func tions of the sort need for real computer calculation.

"Digital computers and computer chips, the devices that control mobile phones microwave ovens, washing machines, and many toys these days, use binary arithmetic," explains former team member Thorfinnur "Thorri" Gunnlaugsson. "The elementary mathematical operations that drive these devices use data in the form of ones and zeroes, which we are finding is perfectly amenable to our special chemistry."

De Silva's latest molecule uses chemical inputs and light as output to carry out the logical functions NOR and INHIBIT. NOR represents the combination of the logical NOT and OR, while INHIBIT or "INH" to its friends, is equivalent to a special combination of NOT and AND. Imagine three binary inputs to the INH molecule - an output signal, represented by 1 in binary code is only seen if the inputs are all 0 for the NOR logic gate while '110' gives an output for INH. "INH," explains de Silva cryptically, "is a normal AND gate with an extra disabling input. When this input is live, the entire AND operation is disabled so the third input goes through a NOT gate before the AND."

He also points out that by combining two different logical functions in a single molecule he and his team have shown that it should be possible to overcome one of the major obstacles facing scientists hoping to build a molecular computer. "Both our brains and modern silicon-based electronics rely heavily on integration," he explains, "now we can join together simple molecular logic systems to make more complex devices - the ultimate goal is getting closer."

Meanwhile, Gunnlaugsson now at Trinity College Dublin is working with "molecular programmer" Dónall Mac Dónaill and Durham university's David Parker to create another version of the INH molecule with just two inputs instead of three.

This makes it simpler than de Silva's INH molecule and also fills the gap in the so-called logic "truth table" of possible outputs. Their INH molecule with a terbium metal ion at the centre gives out a strong, sharp green light when two chemical inputs are met. These inputs are "the presence of a hydrogen ion" and bizarrely "the absence of an oxygen molecule".

If a hydrogen ion is present and there is no oxygen the molecule glows - a 1 is output. If there's hydrogen and oxygen present, they see no glow. If there's no oxygen and no hydrogen then again there's no light.

"We get a strong signal with little noise," explains Gunnlaugsson, "which is a desirable feature in digital devices and reduces the possibility of errors."

The teams are working on yet more logical molecules that might one day carry out the complex tasks done by chips of silicon in our desktops. So, when might we have a chemical computer on our desks?

"We might think of today's computers as small, but a molecular computer might be so small that a billion billion would fit in a sugar cube," enthuses Gunnlaugsson. "The power of such machines is almost unimaginable but it is still very early days."

 For more information see: www.ch.qub.ac.uk/staff/personal/apds/apds.html

fields.headline: Welsh oust Blair's man
fields.standfirst:
'Reject' Morgan steps in as Michael forced to quit before vote of no confidence
Devolution in Wales: special report
fields.trailText: Rhodri Morgan was last night set to become first secretary in the Welsh assembly at his third attempt after Alun Michael was forced to resign the post minutes before a vote of no confidence was carried against him in Cardiff.
fields.body:
Rhodri Morgan was last night set to become first secretary in the Welsh assembly at his third attempt after Alun Michael was forced to resign the post minutes before a vote of no confidence was carried against him in Cardiff.

Within hours of doing so the man whom Tony Blair made his reluctant standard-bearer in Wales had any last hope of survival dashed when Labour's 28 assembly members made clear they would not re-submit his name to the assembly.

Instead they made the popular Mr Morgan acting first secretary, then agreed unanimously to put him forward for the job itself. Previously Mr Michael's economic minister, Mr Morgan will be ratified on Tuesday. There will be a price: wider consultation, especially with the Liberal Democrats.

Downing Street and Labour HQ at Millbank are acutely aware that Ken Livingstone, front-runner to be Labour's candidate for "devolved" mayor of London, will be watching for further attempts to steer events.

So they were quick to embrace Mr Morgan as as man they could do business with. "He's earned his spurs, there's no question of not being able to deal with him," said one party official. Mr Blair's spokesman said: "I know you think we're an absolute bunch of control freaks. But devolution has happened."

In the most dramatic day of political infighting since devolved governments took over in Wales and Scotland, Mr Michael finally abandoned a series of increasingly desperate manoeuvres to cling to office that left Mr Blair wrong-footed 150 miles away in Westminster.

The prime minister, who had backed Mr Michael to succeed Ron Davies despite grassroots support for Mr Morgan, knew at lunchtime of his protege's intention to stand down.

But he dared not reveal it when faced with William Hague's taunts at Commons question time lest Welsh voters concluded that - yet again - Downing Street and Millbank were calling the shots. Mr Blair was left looking silly.

In the event Mr Michael resigned at 3.08pm, minutes after the prime minister had expressed his "full confidence" in him. It allowed Tory MPs - who quickly heard the news on their pagers - to demand that Mr Blair promise not to interfere in the choice of Mr Michael's successor.

In reality the situation had long since slipped beyond Downing Street's control. Opposition assembly members in Cardiff used an attack on what was seen as Whitehall's lack of support for EU funding for south and west Wales to press home what was chiefly a personal attack on Mr Michael's uncharismatic and over-centralised style of management.

Last night Labour AMs met in secret session to decide how best to fill the leadership vacuum created by Mr Michael's decision to jump before being formally pushed by the combined 31-27 majority of the Tories, Plaid Cymru and Liberal Democrats. One Labour AM abstained.

Mr Michael, 57, the MP for Cardiff South and Penarth, became Welsh secretary and Downing Street's man in Wales after Ron Davies was forced to resign over his "moment of madness" on Clapham Common in October 1998.

But he only narrowly beat Cardiff West's Mr Morgan, 60, in Labour's electoral college. Under the proportional voting system, Mr Michael then scraped home as an AM only via the top-up list of members with no assembly constituency.

It was a shaky start that he failed to put right by bridge-building with either Labour voters or AMs in the minority administration he chose to set up - after spurning Lib Dem overtures for the kind of coalition created in Edinburgh.

Last night Plaid Cymru signalled that it would not now table the motion to strip the first secretary of his powers, and give them to the assembly as a body, as it would have done if Mr Michael had insisted on being renominated to the top post.

The assembly's speaker, Lord Dafydd Ellis-Thomas, rebutted suggestions that devolution was being reduced to chaos. "This is the beginning of true devolution because the assembly has asserted its views," he said.

webTitle: Troops alert MoD stretching forces to breaking point , say MPs

fields.headline: Troops alert MoD stretching forces to breaking point , say MPs
fields.trailText: International commitments and other costs are stretching the armed forces to the point where there is "serious concern" about the state of the £22bn-plus defence budget, a cross-party committee of MPs warned yesterday. The armed   forces risked "stumbling from one crisis to the next" unless commitments and resources were brought back into line and it was time the government engaged in an open debate about defence priorities, they said.
fields.body:
International commitments and other costs are stretching the armed forces to the point where there is "serious concern" about the state of the £22bn-plus defence budget, a cross-party committee of MPs warned yesterday. The armed forces risked "stumbling from one crisis to the next" unless commitments and resources were brought back into line and it was time the government engaged in an open debate about defence priorities, they said.

The Commons defence committee attacked the ministry for "dithering" over the choice of a new heavy lift aircraft, the lack of which was highlighted in the Kosovo conflict. "This gap must be filled urgently," the MPs said.

Kosovo and the rising cost of fuel had forced the cancellation of important training exercises. "With out regular exercises for high intensity conflict, standards in our armed forces will plummet, whatever the quality of the people and equipment," the report said.

The MPs also sharply criticised the MoD for charging personnel in the Falklands Islands unreasonable amounts - only recently reduced from £1 a minute - to telephone the UK.

fields.headline: Darling braves welfare anger anger
fields.standfirst:
Further radical reform of benefits is signalled
More about welfare reform
fields.trailText: The government will today infuriate Labour backbenchers by indicating the need for further radical reform to keep benefits spending under control and the welfare state alive for the next 50 years.
fields.body:
The government will today infuriate Labour backbenchers by indicating the need for further radical reform to keep benefits spending under control and the welfare state alive for the next 50 years.

The social security secretary, Alistair Darling, today publishes a sweeping overview of spending since the creation of the welfare state. Though the document does not give the shape of reform in detail, Labour MPs will see it as a clear signal of further means testing and greater use of compulsion in the system to force people to work or to forfeit benefits.

Published some 18 months before the next general election, the paper will also be seen as an attempt to flag up the next phase of welfare reform in a second Labour term.

Indicating the government's desire to demonstrate to middle England that it is serious about cutting benefits bills, Mr Darling said yesterday: "Every time you change welfare there are always people who complain. There will be more [parliamentary] revolts. I am sure there will be people who say there are problems.

"But if you spend more on the wrong things you end up with more poverty and more division. Spend it on the right things and you get on the right track."

The document, The welfare state - social security spending, says that in spite of Britain's ageing population welfare spending in the next half century is affordable, provided the economy is not rocked by boom and bust.

The government has taken demographic changes into account in planning for pension provision. It forecasts that the welfare budget, standing at about £100bn, will grow at about 2.5% a year, matching the present growth rate of the economy, plus 1% real growth, totalling around £1bn a year extra in real terms.

However, Tories last night pointed out that the forecast was based on assumptions including no increase in unemployment, currently at 1.3m, and no economic downturn.

The paper acknowledges that "the system will only remain affordable if we tackle the causes of past failures". That will mean further steps to tackle "worklessness", by which the government means both unemployment and the unknown numbers who will fall out of work because of sickness or disability.

The document argues: "Unless these problems are tackled successfully, the benefits system could again be put under pressure from external events. To remain affordable, the system will constantly have to evolve to meet new challenges."

Only tight controls on spending would allow the government to tackle its priority areas of child and pensioner poverty, Mr Darling said yesterday. He insisted that the government was still on course to meet its targets of halving child poverty within 10 years and eradicating it within 20.

"The outlook for social security for the first time is one where, provided we carry on with the stability and the culture in the benefits service is under control, we have spending under control," he said.

The paper's analysis of welfare spending since 1949 highlights dramatic increases in the 1960s and in the 1980s and early 90s. The government says the pattern reflects a broadening of state benefits under Labour governments in the 1960s, followed by a "loss of control" of benefits under the Conservatives.

It argues that its policy of "work for those who can; help for those who can't" addresses the problem of spiralling spending by helping the jobless back into work.

fields.headline: Morgan earns his spurs
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Wales: special report
fields.trailText: Rhodri Morgan, a loveable but chaotic figure, cast himself into the New Labour darkness in the late 1980s when he invited Tony Blair to stay the night at his house in Cardiff. The houseproud future prime minister was so appalled by the state of the Morgan household - even friends describe it as a tip - that he made a mental note never to rely on him in future.
fields.body:
Rhodri Morgan, a loveable but chaotic figure, cast himself into the New Labour darkness in the late 1980s when he invited Tony Blair to stay the night at his house in Cardiff. The houseproud future prime minister was so appalled by the state of the Morgan household - even friends describe it as a tip - that he made a mental note never to rely on him in future.

Since that day the donnish Mr Morgan, who boasts degrees from Oxford and Harvard, has been passed over on countless occasions by Blair in favour of the bland, but reliable, Alun Michael.

After the general election, Mr Morgan failed to win a ministerial post - despite his success in harrying the Tories in opposition - and Downing Street wasted little time in opting for Mr Michael to lead the Welsh Labour party after Ron Davies' "moment of madness'' on Clapham common.

Soon after Mr Michael's fall yesterday, however, New Labour spinners appeared to have forgotten their past misgivings about Mr Morgan as they resigned themselves to his assuming the leadership of the party in Wales.

"Rhodri's been a loyal and able lieutenant to Alun, doing the business," one Millbank official said. "He's earned his spurs, there's not question of not being able to deal with him. He ain't Ken.''

As he returned home last night Mr Morgan must have savoured the thought that New Labour now believes he represents their only chance in Wales.

His leadership is guaranteed to be livelier and should give Labour a fighting chance of reviving its fortunes in Wales, which have plummeted under Mr Michael. It was no accident that in the recent Ceredigion byelection - where Labour trailed in fourth place - there were lots of Morgan pictures, but none of Mr Michael.

As first secretary of the assembly, Mr Morgan, 60, whose wife Julie is MP for a neighbouring Cardiff seat, will not be a relentless "oppositionist'' to Downing Street in the style of Ken Livingstone. But he will not shy away from taking on central government, no doubt with his customary wit.

There will still be misgivings. "Rhodri's great entertainment and nobody can doubt his erudition,'' one Labour source said. "But if you asked him to deliver a letter, would he remember?''
