fields.headline: Art Hoppe
fields.standfirst: Almost the last of a generation of American humorous columnists
fields.trailText: Art Hoppe, who has died aged 74, was a gentleman satirist, columnist and reporter with the San Francisco Chronicle for 50 years. An under-recognised humorist, he was equal to Art Buchwald and Russell Baker, of the New York Times.
fields.body:
Art Hoppe, who has died aged 74, was a gentleman satirist, columnist and reporter with the San Francisco Chronicle for 50 years. An under-recognised humorist, he was equal to Art Buchwald and Russell Baker, of the New York Times.

Hoppe died three years to the day - and from the same disease, lung cancer - as his fellow Chronicle city diarist Herb Caen. Their departure, with Baker's retirement, Buchwald's increasing years, and the death of Chicago's Mike Royko, brings attention to a passing generation of writer-humorists in American journalism who are not being replaced. Hoppe's column had appeared five, then three times a week since 1960, when he left the reporters' desk, and he acquired a loyal, loving following.

Hoppe started work on the Chronicle in 1949 as a copy boy - the old entry method into journalism - and was promoted to reporter after seven months. But unlike most of his contemporaries in those days, he had not only gone to college, but Harvard.

His father, a prosperous lawyer, and his mother, a social worker, lived in Honolulu but moved to San Francisco when Hoppe was five. He never left the city, except for wartime service in the US navy as a pharmacist's mate on a destroyer. He liked to say: "I single-handedly dispatched millions of our country's enemies" - a reference to his issues of antibiotics to sailors.

Hoppe's humour was interspersed with occasional serious columns, which had a wide impact. His most famous was his turn against the Vietnam war in 1971, when he wrote: "The radio this morning said the allied invasion of Laos had bogged down. Without thinking, I nodded and said, 'Good.' And having said it, I realised the bitter truth. Now I root against my own country. This is how far we have come in this hated and endless war. This is the nadir I have reached in this winter of my discontent. This is how close I border on treason."

His humour was sharp but never vicious, with a vivid series of characters that included the curmudgeonly everyman Joe Sikspak, the pundit and bore Homer T Pettibone, Hoppe's long-suffering wife Glynda, their boorish son Mordred, and insufferable daughter Malphasia, whose name cunningly indicated her slavish aping of every teenage fad. Some of his wryest columns were devoted to the Archangel Gabriel's eagerness to sound on his golden trumpet the eviction notice for the inhabitants of earth, but the heavenly landlord always prevailed, giving his exasperating tenants yet another chance.

Hoppe received his share of irate letters, including a record number over a mock proposal to bomb Turkey, written after President Clinton's missile raids on Sudan in 1998. Many readers took it seriously. To those who threatened to stop buying the paper because of his liberal views, Hoppe would reply personally that if they continued to complain, the Chronicle management would be forced to cancel their subscription.

He wrote two plays and eight books, and an autobiography last year, Having A Wonderful Time. But none of them sold well, leading him to remark: "Some people collect rare books; I write them."

Arthur Hoppe, journalist, born April 23 1925; died February 1 2000

fields.headline: Wade Walton
fields.standfirst: Blues singer who never gave up his day job in the barbershop
fields.trailText: Musical tourists visiting the hallowed sites of the blues routinely arrive in Clarksdale, Mississippi, where Bessie Smith died and Muddy Waters grew up. Yet those in the know would always make a special trip to a small business on 4th Street, in the hope of hearing some off-duty blues from its proprietor. Wade Walton, who has died aged 76, was undoubtedly the blues' most celebrated singing barber.
fields.body:
Musical tourists visiting the hallowed sites of the blues routinely arrive in Clarksdale, Mississippi, where Bessie Smith died and Muddy Waters grew up. Yet those in the know would always make a special trip to a small business on 4th Street, in the hope of hearing some off-duty blues from its proprietor. Wade Walton, who has died aged 76, was undoubtedly the blues' most celebrated singing barber.

The world outside Clarksdale first began to hear about Walton after he was visited by blues researchers Dave Mangurian and Don Hill in 1958, and Paul Oliver and Chris Strachwitz two years later. Oliver published parts of his interview in Conversation With The Blues, while Strachwitz issued recordings of Walton ruminatively picking his guitar while a rooster crowed, then stropping a razor as rhythmic accompaniment to a friend's guitar playing.

In 1962, at Mangurian's suggestion, Walton was invited to New York to record for Prestige Records' Bluesville series and made a sturdy album of blues standards, titled after the first one he learned, Shake 'Em On Down. The timing of the series was unlucky. It was several years before the international discovery of the blues, and Walton's album rapidly became - and, unconverted to CD, remains - a collectors' item. Although he continued to sing and play, he never extended that brief discography.

The 16th of 17 children, Walton was born in Lombardy and grew up in Goldfield, small towns in northwestern Mississippi not far from the infamous state penitentiary at Parchman. He began to play guitar and harmonica aged 12, learning from his brother Honey and local musicians like Tony Hollins, who also impressed Walton's near-contemporary, Clarksdale-born John Lee Hooker. Walton studied at Booker T Washington High School in Memphis, earned his professional qualifications at Lupkin Barber College and took his first job in 1943 at the Big Six barbershop in Clarksdale.

It was here he met the young and ambitious Ike Turner, who was forming his band the Kings of Rhythm, and played with him for a while. But when Turner moved to St Louis to promote his hit Rocket 88, Walton stayed in Clarksdale, hearing only the call of strop and scissors.

Paul Chevigny, a blues enthusiast who travelled in Mississippi in 1963, wrote of Walton: "He is a quick and talented man. He has worked up a series of country jokes and routines to draw customers to the Big Six. He has installed a jukebox near the door, and he plays along with the records on his razor strop. He has sprinkled talc in his wallet, and when anyone asks him to lend or break a ten, he says, 'Just a minute, let me look,' and blows the dust out of his wallet. Despite these country routines, there is nothing old-fashioned about Wade; to him everything is style. People ought to dress neatly, play music cleanly, handle the police coolly."

Coolness was certainly necessary in a town where the African American majority was subject to a midnight curfew and church meetings held by the National Association for the Advancement of Coloured People, of which Walton served a year as a chapter officer, were surrounded by squad cars and police. Before leaving for New York to record his album Walton had to explain his journey to the local police; when he returned, with the record company's $400 cheque in his pocket, he had to have it countersigned by a local businessman before a bank would cash it.

He worked at the Big Six until 1972, when he opened his own premises. Behind the shop was Wade & Rose's Coffee Bar & Poolroom, with a jukebox stuffed with blues records from the 1960s. A guitar hung on the wall, to be taken down and played in slack moments, and somewhere to hand there was a harmonica for entertaining restless children.

In recent years Walton opened a second barber shop and performed at Clarksdale's Sunflower River Blues & Gospel Festival. He is survived by his second wife Rose, his daughter and son.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Spain dumbs down its army
Spain has lowered intelligence requirements to a minimum for soldier recruits in an effort to boost its armed forces, the daily El Pais reported yesterday.
fields.body:
Spain dumbs down its army
Spain has lowered intelligence requirements to a minimum for soldier recruits in an effort to boost its armed forces, the daily El Pais reported yesterday.

The government has dropped the minimum IQ requirement from 90 to 70. But psychologists say a person with an IQ as low as 70 may have difficulties in understanding. [Reuters, Madrid]

Space vehicle lost on earth
Russia said yesterday it had successfully tested a new, reusable space launch vehicle with engines that can be switched on and off in orbit but that it was still missing after returning to earth.

Helicopters and planes were searching for the vehicle, which had blasted off earlier from the Baikonur cosmodrome in Kazakhstan [Reuters, Baikonur]

Police arrest sportsmen
Italian police yesterday arrested two professional basketball players for alleged involvement in the kidnap of members of Italy's Chinese community, Phillip Willan writes from Rome.

Guido Curtarello, 33, and Marco Mattarello, 26, were among four suspects detained yesterday on suspicion of having kidnapped the 19-year-old daughter of a Chinese restaurant owner from the northern town of Saronno and the owner of a Milan factory. The kidnap of the young woman netted a £50,000 ransom.

webTitle: Belated pangs in Austria over slaves of Nazis

fields.headline: Belated pangs in Austria over slaves of Nazis
fields.standfirst:
Hoping to make his rightwing government palatable to allies, the chancellor upgrades the compensation scheme for neglected war victims

The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: In an effort to prove to an unconvinced world that Austria is a mature democracy that has conquered its Nazi past, Chancellor Wolfgang Schüssel yesterday appointed a government officer to compensate Nazi victims.
fields.body:
In an effort to prove to an unconvinced world that Austria is a mature democracy that has conquered its Nazi past, Chancellor Wolfgang Schüssel yesterday appointed a government officer to compensate Nazi victims.

"The new government will press [the compensation case] for former slave labourers, who are, after all, at an age at which they need help quickly in order to get justice," Mr Schüssel said.

Unlike Germany, which has paid the equivalent of about £36bn to the Nazis' victims since 1951, Austria avoided paying out any money for decades, claiming it was a victim of the Nazi regime and not a willing collaborator with it. In 1995 the government finally established a compensation fund, but payments were limited to £4,000 per victim.

The chancellor presented his government programme to parliament after easily surviving a confidence vote on Tuesday. He used the opportunity to try to quell foreign concerns that Austria has lurched radically to the right with the entry into government last week of Jörg Haider's Freedom party.

"Austria is today a stable democracy despite the current demonstrations - radical outbursts which are normal in many other countries but have been as rare in the second republic as major strikes or conflicts with minorities," he said.

Despite the alliance between his conservative People's party and Mr Haider's party, "this Austria has not changed in the last few days", Mr Schüssel said. But he acknowledged that the country's Nazi past required "special vigilance".

He delivered his speech to a parliament whose audience included President Thomas Klestil and former president Kurt Waldheim, who caused consternation in the west 14 years ago when his wartime links to the Nazi SS during the second world war were revealed.

The announcement of the appointment of a former president of the Austrian national bank, Maria Schaumayer, to the post of government officer to deal with the compensation claims of forced labourers under the Nazis was an attempt to placate those who say Austria has never properly dealt with its National Socialist history.

The appointment of Ms Schaumayer follows the submission at the end of January of a report by a historical commission set up by the last government.

The appointment was seen as the "right step" by the Green party, but Madeleine Petrovic of the Greens' parliamentary group said yesterday: "In this government coalition, Schaumayer is really standing on shaky ground."

In Washington the deputy US treasury secretary, Stuart Eizenstat, told the house of representatives that the way Austria deals with unresolved issues would be an "important benchmark" for the future of US-Austrian relations.

The Austrian chancellor, in a parliamentary speech lasting more than 90 minutes, presented a programme that in cluded pledges of free-market reforms, budget consolidation and a reduction in bureaucracy. Mr Schüssel said Austria was committed to European Union enlargement and wanted to deepen its relations with Nato in hopes of possibly joining the defence alliance one day.

In further attempts to win over foreign critics, particularly Austria's 14 EU partners which are reducing contacts with it, the government placed a £33,000 full-page advertisement in Tuesday's International Herald Tribune newspaper.

It reproduced a government declaration which President Klestil forced Mr Schüssel and Mr Haider to sign last week, stating that Austria was a land of tolerance that recognised its role in crimes of the Nazi era.

But adding to criticisms that Mr Haider - despite opting out of taking a position in government - is "reigning supreme" from the Austrian state of Carinthia where he is governor, Alexander Van der Bellen, the leader of Austria's Greens, asked why it had been signed "by the Chancellor and Upper Chancellor".

The head of the opposition Social Democrats in the parliament, Peter Kostelka, said the coalition cabinet was "a government to be terrified of".

Last night hundreds of people gathered near the parliament building, which has been sealed off by police brought in from around the country.

Protesters set up an "embassy for worried citizens" in a tent outside the chancellery on Ballhaus Square. The first pro-government demonstration took place outside Vienna's Burgtheater, but only 50 people turned up. The organisers blamed rain.

"The new government will press [the compensation case] for former slave labourers, who are, after all, at an age at which they need help quickly in order to get justice," Mr Schüssel said. Unlike Germany, which has paid the equivalent of about £36bn to the Nazis' victims since 1951, Austria avoided paying out any money for decades, claiming it was a victim of the Nazi regime and not a willing collaborator with it. In 1995 the government finally established a compensation fund, but payments were limited to £4,000 per victim. The chancellor presented his government programme to parliament after easily surviving a confidence vote on Tuesday. He used the opportunity to try to quell foreign concerns that Austria has lurched radically to the right with the entry into government last week of Jörg Haider's Freedom party. "Austria is today a stable democracy despite the current demonstrations - radical outbursts which are normal in many other countries but have been as rare in the second republic as major strikes or conflicts with minorities," he said. Despite the alliance between his conservative People's party and Mr Haider's party, "this Austria has not changed in the last few days", Mr Schüssel said. But he acknowledged that the country's Nazi past required "special vigilance". He delivered his speech to a parliament whose audience included President Thomas Klestil and former president Kurt Waldheim, who caused consternation in the west 14 years ago when his wartime links to the Nazi SS during the second world war were revealed. The announcement of the appointment of a former president of the Austrian national bank, Maria Schaumayer, to the post of government officer to deal with the compensation claims of forced labourers under the Nazis was an attempt to placate those who say Austria has never properly dealt with its National Socialist history. The appointment of Ms Schaumayer follows the submission at the end of January of a report by a historical commission set up by the last government. The appointment was seen as the "right step" by the Green party, but Madeleine Petrovic of the Greens' parliamentary group said yesterday: "In this government coalition, Schaumayer is really standing on shaky ground." In Washington the deputy US treasury secretary, Stuart Eizenstat, told the house of representatives that the way Austria deals with unresolved issues would be an "important benchmark" for the future of US-Austrian relations. The Austrian chancellor, in a parliamentary speech lasting more than 90 minutes, presented a programme that in cluded pledges of free-market reforms, budget consolidation and a reduction in bureaucracy. Mr Schüssel said Austria was committed to European Union enlargement and wanted to deepen its relations with Nato in hopes of possibly joining the defence alliance one day. In further attempts to win over foreign critics, particularly Austria's 14 EU partners which are reducing contacts with it, the government placed a £33,000 full-page advertisement in Tuesday's International Herald Tribune newspaper. It reproduced a government declaration which President Klestil forced Mr Schüssel and Mr Haider to sign last week, stating that Austria was a land of tolerance that recognised its role in crimes of the Nazi era. But adding to criticisms that Mr Haider - despite opting out of taking a position in government - is "reigning supreme" from the Austrian state of Carinthia where he is governor, Alexander Van der Bellen, the leader of Austria's Greens, asked why it had been signed "by the Chancellor and Upper Chancellor". The head of the opposition Social Democrats in the parliament, Peter Kostelka, said the coalition cabinet was "a government to be terrified of". Last night hundreds of people gathered near the parliament building, which has been sealed off by police brought in from around the country. Protesters set up an "embassy for worried citizens" in a tent outside the chancellery on Ballhaus Square. The first pro-government demonstration took place outside Vienna's Burgtheater, but only 50 people turned up. The organisers blamed rain.

webTitle: Moonies join hands across the border

fields.headline: Moonies join hands across the border
fields.standfirst:
Korea Web Weekly
Democratic People's Republic of Korea
fields.trailText: Signs that North Korea is opening up a little more to the world have been bizarrely strengthened by a mass wedding project to be staged on Saturday in South Korea by the Unification church, often referred to as the "Moonies".
fields.body:
Signs that North Korea is opening up a little more to the world have been bizarrely strengthened by a mass wedding project to be staged on Saturday in South Korea by the Unification church, often referred to as the "Moonies".

Prospective North Korean couples have sent their photos to a centre in north-east China, where they will be "matched" by church officials.

The photos are to be displayed on a live video link while a mass wedding ceremony for 10,000 couples is conducted by the church founder, the Rev Moon Sun-myung, in the South Korean capital Seoul. The newly matched couples will continue to live in North Korea's self-styled "socialist paradise", but will be deemed to have been married in the church.

The Rev Moon is also to celebrate his 80th birthday in Seoul today at a ceremony that Britain's former prime minister Ted Heath and the former US vice-president Dan Quayle are expected to attend.

The long-range mass wedding comes at a time when the north is expanding diplomatic relations with the capitalist world and may be heading for a breakthrough with the US.

The Rev Moon, who runs his evangelical church from Brazil, is back in his homeland to officiate at the mass wedding, where the fiancés will be joined by thousands more married couples who will "rededicate their vows".

According to the official biography, the Rev Moon was once put in a North Korean labour camp for three years. In 1991 he returned to the north and was welomed by the late North Korean leader Kim Il-sung. This unlikely relationship between two ideological opposites has continued under Kim's son and successor, Kim Jong-il.

Last week it was reported that the Unification church was working on an automobile plant as a joint venture in Nampo, North Korea, with Fiat of Italy. Associates of the Rev Moon and Mr Kim cut the ribbon at the ground-breaking ceremony.

Italy last month agreed to open diplomatic relations with North Korea; a high-level Australian delegation hopes to begin talks later this month.

The Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, arrived yesterday in Pyongyang seeking to improve relations which have slumped since the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991.

On Tuesday the US said it was prepared to talk to North Korea about removing the country's name from the official list of "terrorist sponsors" in return for Pyongyang's agreement to halt its missile programme. Both sides are discussing a long-awaited visit by a senior North Korean official to Washington.

Observers in Seoul still expect the North Koreans to mask their diplomatic moves by periodic propaganda blasts against the US and South Korea. But they believe that the combined effect of many years of western food aid and the "sunshine policy" of South Korea's president, Kim Dae-jung, is producing results.

In another sign of easing tension, North Korea last weekend allowed two groups of foreign residents in South Korea to join a tour of the scenic Mount Kumgang across the border on the east coast. The first group included the BBC's correspondent in Seoul. There are plans for a cruise ship of Japanese tourists to visit at the end of this month.

The Rev Moon hoped to be the first to open up Mount Kumgang but the Hyundai tycoon Chung Ju-yung clinched the deal first.

webTitle: Haider race to power was helped by Reebok

fields.headline: Haider race to power was helped by Reebok
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: The Austrian far-right leader, Jörg Haider, was helped at a critical stage in his party's rise to power by the Austrian subsidiary of the sports and leisurewear giant Reebok.
fields.byline: John Hooper  in Berlin and  Jan Fossgard
fields.body:
The Austrian far-right leader, Jörg Haider, was helped at a critical stage in his party's rise to power by the Austrian subsidiary of the sports and leisurewear giant Reebok.

The firm yesterday acknowledged that Reebok Austria had "provided support for the production of The Jörg Haider Video" six years ago. It said the help had been given without the knowledge of the group's parent company, which had secured the resignation of Reebok Austria's general manager after learning of its subsidiary's involvement in the project.

Mr Haider's athletic prowess is a key ingredient in the daredevil, macho image he has projected so successfully to the Austrian public. In November he claimed to have completed the New York marathon in less than four hours, though the race official Alan Steinfeld said "we have no record of him running".

Mr Haider has been at the centre of an international furore over his Freedom party's entry into government as an equal partner in coalition with the mainstream conservatives. The inclusion of ministers from Mr Haider's movement triggered an unprecedented decision by other European Union states to cut bilateral links with Austria.

Reebok Austria's involvement in promoting him was sharply at odds with the group's image as a firm dedicated to the cause of racial integration. It claims to have been the first company in its field to have left South Africa in protest against apartheid, in 1986.

The US sportswear giant has given money to a number of liberal causes, and funds a human rights foundation and human rights awards. Reebok's literature proclaims: "Human rights are at the centre of our corporate culture."

In the year the video was made, Mr Haider demanded tough measures to rid Austria of illegal immigrants. They included systematic identity checks, more detention centres and special deportation flights.

He had been emboldened by two stunning electoral victories. In March he swept back to power as governor of the southern province of Carinthia - a post he had left three years earlier after an outcry over his praise of Adolf Hitler's employment policies. In October, at a general election, his party's share of the vote soared to 23%, netting it 42 of the 183 seats in parliament.

A statement from Reebok International said: "In 1994, Reebok Austria provided support for the production of The Jörg Haider Video without the knowledge of Reebok International. Upon learning of the video, Reebok International conducted a formal investigation into the matter and then promptly asked for the resignation of the general manager of Reebok Austria. He then left the company."

A spokeswoman for Reebok International was unable to say how much Reebok's support had been worth. In 1999 Reebok sold goods worth $3bn and made profits of $50m. Its brands include Rockports, Ralph Lauren footwear and the Greg Norman collection of golfing apparel.

Additional research by Peter Backe and Julia Finch.

webTitle: Clue to Romans' head start on Columbus

fields.headline: Clue to Romans' head start on Columbus
fields.trailText: A tiny black terracotta head locked away for years in a Mexican museum may prove that the Romans reached the New World 1,200 years before Christopher Columbus.
fields.body:
A tiny black terracotta head locked away for years in a Mexican museum may prove that the Romans reached the New World 1,200 years before Christopher Columbus.

The sculpted head of a bearded man, dug up in the Toluca valley, 65 miles west of Mexico City in 1933, has been identified as Roman by art experts and dated to the third century AD by a sophisticated new dating technique.

When it was originally unearthed, the artefact, only a few centimetres high, was in a burial chamber under three floors which, archaeologists concluded, could not have been sealed earlier than 1510, a decade before the first known European landing in central America.

According to Roman Hristov, a US anthropologist, this is the first real proof of human contacts across the Atlantic before the arrival of Columbus in 1492.

This week's New Scientist reports that Hristov and a Mexican colleague, Santiago Genovés, had read about the head and finally tracked it down, locked in the vaults of a museum in the Mexican capital.

The head looks unlike the artwork produced by the native peoples of the region before Columbus.

But the notion that it proves Roman contacts with pre-Columbian America will face stiff resistance from hordes of academics in a bitterly contested field.

Scientists have suggested that Vikings, Celts and Africans may have crossed the Atlantic before Columbus. Remains of a settlement in Newfoundland have been identified as the gateway to the Vikings' fabled Vinland.

David Grove, an archaeologist at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, told the New Scientist that the head was Roman, but pointed out it could have been washed ashore from a Roman shipwreck in the Gulf of Mexico - not exactly a Roman "discovery" of the New World.

fields.headline: All together now
fields.standfirst: 'March! March! That their impure blood may drench our furrows!' Is the French national anthem too aggressive? Some say so - and want it changed. But, argues  Jonathan Glancey , they're missing the point
fields.trailText: Antoine Capella, a singer-songwriter from Angers, wants to replace the bloodthirsty lyrics of the French national anthem, the Marseillaise, with something altogether less aggressive. The existing song, he claims, is "outrageous". "It's fascist," he says. "In this day and age, it's not right."
fields.body:
Antoine Capella, a singer-songwriter from Angers, wants to replace the bloodthirsty lyrics of the French national anthem, the Marseillaise, with something altogether less aggressive. The existing song, he claims, is "outrageous". "It's fascist," he says. "In this day and age, it's not right."

If Capella manages to persuade France's national assembly to make the changes - the speaker, Laurent Fabius, is, he says, on his side - out will go: " March! March! That [their] impure blood may drench our furrows!" And in will come: "March! March! That an azure sky may shine on the horizon."

Will the French make such a change? It seems unlikely, if only because blood is the currency of national anthems: the word is invoked in many of these political hymns. And although national anthems are altered, it tends to happen rarely, and then usually at times of major change.

So do the words matter? Like all good hymns, they can be a delight to sing, whether your personal politics are left, right, centre or raving fascist. They are the soundtrack to football matches, concerts, operas, state occasions and the Olympic games. In genuinely friendly international games, national anthems are sung to raise team spirits. The same people who sang these bloodcurdling verses may well be waltzing down streets, rues and strassen arm-in-arm when the game is over.

Any of us might sing in our heads or in the bath with tough, even vicious lyrics. This doesn't mean we're about to climb out of our baths and chop our neighbours to pieces with an axe. We just like the sound of lyrics fused with great tunes: "Mine eyes hath seen the coming of the glory of the Lord/He is trampling out the vintage where the grapes of wrath are stored." (The Battle Hymn of the American Republic)

In any case, does anyone take the words of national anthems to heart? In time of war, yes, but in peace? Maybe, but this is unlikely if you're British, and not a dedicated Orangeman. Most of us find the words and doleful tune of the British national anthem sombre and rather silly.

Few know the words to more than the first verse - every bit as xenophobic and bloodthirsty as those of the Marseillaise, but when did you ever hear a band launch into a second verse? The words to the remaining stanzas may be archaic and irrelevant, yet as we never have occasion to sing them, who cares? They haven't meant anything for a very long time, perhaps since they were written - when the British feared invasion by Napoleon.

As for the Marseillaise, it was penned, overnight, by Captain Claude-Joseph Rouget de l'Isle in 1792 while his men, from Marseilles, were defending Strasbourg from Prussian forces. What was then known as the War Hymn of the Army of the Rhine was created to help stir French soldiers into action. The words are sung to a swaggering tune. They sounded right in that moving scene in Casablanca when the Germans play Deutschland Über Alles in Rick's cafe, but the French drown them out with the Marseillaise. Again, in time of war, especially in a war against an enemy bent on genocide and the curtailment of freedom, Captain Rouget de l'Isle's words weren't so very silly after all.

The German national anthem, even though the infamous first stanza has now been replaced by the innocuous third which talks of "brotherliness" and "freedom", will forever be associated with Hitler. As soon as Haydn's air, scored in 1797, stirs into life, we feel our right hands rising in mock salute before pulling them down again. The fact that this was originally the tune for the Austrian anthem (the Germans adopted it in 1922) makes it even more associated in our minds with extreme rightwing politics today, as Jörg Haider storms to power in Vienna.

As for the rest, you can mix and match their lyrics: the words of most are interchangeable. The Irish anthem starts: " We'll sing a song, a soldier's song ." And it's not long before we're into the " cannon's roar and rifle's peal ", while " out yonder waits the Saxon foe " . Saxon foe? The words may refer to the English, but there aren't many true-blooded Saxons anywhere between Penzance (Celts, for the most part in Cornwall) and Newcastle-upon-Tyne. (Geordies are descended from Vikings, aren't they?)

Oddly, while some of the most bloodthirsty anthems, as you might expect, are meant to represent the spirit of Latin countries, some of the most gruesome are from nations we associate with liberty, democracy and all-round decency. These lyrics are from the Mexican national anthem: "War! War without truce against [those] who would attempt/To blemish the honour of the Fatherland./War! War, the patriotic banners/Saturate in waves of blood."

But, how about these lines from the Danish anthem? "King Christian stood by the lofty mast/In mist and smoke/His sword was hammering so fast/Through Gothic helm and brain it passed/Then sunk each hostile hulk and mast/In mist and smoke."

Who today would call the Danes warmongers or fascists? Vikings, yes, which takes us back to King Christian and his mighty sword. The US anthem, The Star Spangled Banner (originally The Defence of Fort McHenry) written by Francis Scott King (God save him!) takes us back to anti-British sentiment. The Brits (so often the enemy) can be recognised in the lyrics by their " foul footsteps' pollution". What most people remember, though, are the stirring chorus lines: "And the star-spangled banner in triumph doth wave/O'er the land of the free and the home of the brave."

God bless America. God bless Africa, too. These latter words form the name of the moving alternative anthem sung by black South Africans (and those crusading with them to end apartheid) throughout much of the 20th century and before Nelson Mandela was elected president in 1994. In the Xhosa language, Nkosi Sikelel'i Afrika was written by Enoch Sontonga in Johannesburg in 1897. The words have been customised many times since and are sung as an anthem across black Africa. Today they have been fused with the earlier South African national anthem, Die Stem (the Call of South Africa) to make a convincing post-apartheid hymn. Of all anthems, Nkosi Sikelel'i Afrika is one of the gentlest, with lyrics such as:"Bless agriculture and stock raising/Banish all famine and diseases/Fill the land with good health/And bless it."

It's a hygienic alternative to the blood and soil, we hate foreigners and want to kill them stuff. But try willing your team to win at Wembley with a blessing for agriculture and stock raising. "We're children of a fighting race/That never yet has known disgrace." [Ireland, again.] Sounds better, doesn't it?

On the tip of your tongue . . . match the anthem to the country
1) With glowing hearts we see thee rise,

The true north strong and free.

2) From Zambezi to Limpopo, may leaders be exemplary,

And may the almighty protect and bless our land.

3) And as we wait the morning's light,

Here in the silence of the night,

We'll chant a soldier's song.

4) She has wreathed her head,

With the helmet of Scipio.

Where is Victory?

5) Hasten to battle, men of Bayamo,

For the homeland looks proudly to you.

You do not fear a glorious death,

Because to die for the country is to live.

6) Peace not war shall be our boast,

But should foes assail our coast,

Make us then a mighty host.

7) O Lord our God arise,

Scatter her enemies,

And make them fall;

Confound their politics,

Frustrate their knavish tricks,

On Thee our hopes we fix,oh, save us all!

Answers: 1) Canada, 2) Zimbabwe, 3) Ireland, 4) Italy, 5) Cuba, 6) New Zealand, 7) Britain

The US anthem, The Star Spangled Banner (originally The Defence of Fort McHenry) written by Francis Scott King (God save him!) takes us back to anti-British sentiment. The Brits (so often the enemy) can be recognised in the lyrics by their " foul footsteps' pollution". What most people remember, though, are the stirring chorus lines: "And the star-spangled banner in triumph doth wave/O'er the land of the free and the home of the brave." God bless America. God bless Africa, too. These latter words form the name of the moving alternative anthem sung by black South Africans (and those crusading with them to end apartheid) throughout much of the 20th century and before Nelson Mandela was elected president in 1994. In the Xhosa language, Nkosi Sikelel'i Afrika was written by Enoch Sontonga in Johannesburg in 1897. The words have been customised many times since and are sung as an anthem across black Africa. Today they have been fused with the earlier South African national anthem, Die Stem (the Call of South Africa) to make a convincing post-apartheid hymn. Of all anthems, Nkosi Sikelel'i Afrika is one of the gentlest, with lyrics such as:"Bless agriculture and stock raising/Banish all famine and diseases/Fill the land with good health/And bless it." It's a hygienic alternative to the blood and soil, we hate foreigners and want to kill them stuff. But try willing your team to win at Wembley with a blessing for agriculture and stock raising. "We're children of a fighting race/That never yet has known disgrace." [Ireland, again.] Sounds better, doesn't it? On the tip of your tongue . . . match the anthem to the country 1) With glowing hearts we see thee rise, The true north strong and free. 2) From Zambezi to Limpopo, may leaders be exemplary, And may the almighty protect and bless our land. 3) And as we wait the morning's light, Here in the silence of the night, We'll chant a soldier's song. 4) She has wreathed her head, With the helmet of Scipio. Where is Victory? 5) Hasten to battle, men of Bayamo, For the homeland looks proudly to you. You do not fear a glorious death, Because to die for the country is to live. 6) Peace not war shall be our boast, But should foes assail our coast, Make us then a mighty host. 7) O Lord our God arise, Scatter her enemies, And make them fall; Confound their politics, Frustrate their knavish tricks, On Thee our hopes we fix,oh, save us all! Answers: 1) Canada, 2) Zimbabwe, 3) Ireland, 4) Italy, 5) Cuba, 6) New Zealand, 7) Britain

fields.headline:
No: 1574
 Garibaldi
fields.trailText: Age: Long dead, sadly.
fields.body:
Age: Long dead, sadly.

Dates then: 1807-82, pedant. He was born in Nice.

Biscuits seem to have been significant in his life: Can we deal with that later.

Appearance: Wherever there was a war going on.

Yes, but what did he look like? Fierce and resolute, except when he was wearing that ridiculous hat.

Christian name: Giuseppe.

What was he? A brilliant Italian general.

Can't have been too many of those: Please, no national stereotypes. The International Court of Justice is still investigating our dodgy Pass Notes on Belgium.

Why is he back in the news? Some argument over an atrocity? No, despite being a mercenary, Garibaldi's record is pretty well spotless. He fought for republican causes in the 1830s, battled with the forces of oppression in Brazil and Uruguay in the 1840s, and, backed by just a thousand of his legendary Redshirts, overthrew the Bourbon dynasty in the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies in 1860-61, thus uniting Italy under King Victor Emmanuel II.

Ah, the famous Battle of the Biscuits: Sorry?

When the Garibaldis beat the Bourbons: Try to take this seriously. The Garibaldi biscuit didn't appear until 1864, when it was created to mark the hero's visit to Britain.

You still haven't told me why he's in the news: Ah, yes. An Italian historian called Arrigo Petacco claims to have proved that in 1862 President Lincoln offered Garibaldi command of the union forces in the American civil war.

Lincoln - another biscuit! Oh stop it.

Interesting coincidence, though. Pray continue: Petacco's claims have angered US historians, who can't imagine the federal forces being run by an ageing Italian with a taste for squashed currants.

Not to be confused with: Gary Barlow, former lead singer with Take That.

Do say: "Up the Risorgimento!"

Don't say: "I'll have a Viennese Finger."

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a report headed Prisoners in paradise, page 16, G2, February 8, about people serving prison sentences in Thailand, we said, "The British Embassy provides vitamins, and Prisoners Abroad also helps as much as it can". In fact, the UK charity Prisoners Abroad provides the vitamins, not the British embassy. Prisoners Abroad sends the vitamins to the relevant consulate which then distributes them to the charity's clients. It was perhaps understating things to say "Prisoners Abroad ... helps as much as it can."

Prisoners Abroad sends the vitamins to the relevant consulate which then distributes them to the charity's clients. It was perhaps understating things to say "Prisoners Abroad ... helps as much as it can."

In the same piece we misspelt the name of Sheila Buckette. Apologies.

The village in Cornwall is Stithians (not Stythians, page 6, February 5).

Alan Shipman, the author of a piece headed Clinton's embarrassment of riches, Economics page, page 21, February 7, has asked us to point out that he is no longer at the Judge Institute of Management Studies, Cambridge. He is an independent economist.

Kate Ashbrook, general secretary of the Open Spaces Society, Birthdays column, page 24, February 1, is no longer the chairman of the Ramblers' Association. She is chairman of its access committee.

In our television notes for Tuesday's episode of The Bill, page 74, The Guide, February 5, we said it was about a detective who "may actually be in cohorts" with the people he was investigating. Cahoots, that would be.

In an interview with Mike Leigh, page 2, Friday Review, February 4, we quoted him as saying, "I enjoyed ... standing next to where Queen Victoria used to crap." That, we had been told, was an experience afforded by the Transport Museum when it used to be at Clapham, "because there in Queen Victoria's garage was her personal toilet". That would be [railway] carriage, not garage.

Homophone corner, from our hijack story, page 3, yesterday, "The negotiators operate in teams of three - usually two in a speaking roll ..."

Our late changes, meant to accommodate the Celtic report on the sports pages yesterday, went awry in one edition, depriving some readers of the Celtic report while giving them other reports twice. Apologies to those who suffered.

fields.headline: Diageo
fields.trailText: Diageo, the drinks conglomerate whose shares have been looking as flat as yesterday's gin and tonic, resorted to what has become the last refuge of failing stocks - it promised big investment in the internet.
fields.body:
Diageo, the drinks conglomerate whose shares have been looking as flat as yesterday's gin and tonic, resorted to what has become the last refuge of failing stocks - it promised big investment in the internet.

The group - whose shares ended down 1p at 466p last night - has failed to attract much interest from new shareholders despite talk that a de-merger of the company's fast food business, Burger King, is again under consideration.

Shares may not quite have hit bottom - they have been as low as 442p over the past 12 months - but John McGrath and his team must have been wondering what on earth they could do to regain its earlier 745p level.

After all, the merger between Grand Metropolitan and Guinness was supposed to be delivering such convincing benefits of scale that investors would be killing to buy shares.

But with new technology pyrotechnics from the likes of Vodafone, old-style booze and burgers appear distinctly unappealing, even with brands such as Smirnoff, Gordon's Gin, Johnnie Walker, Häagen-Dazs and Jolly Green Giant canned foods.

So yesterday Nick Rose, the group's finance director, said the company was planning a major investment in the internet and web-related strategies, directed mainly at enhancing marketing and advertising campaigns.

He said the company has already established an e-procurement system and some small investments in hi-tech venture funds. The company - recognised as a leader in brand management - will also been looking at how it can use the web to enhance brand awareness. "The internet is rapidly changing the way business is done. Together with our existing marketing department it is fast becoming a powerful tool which will enable the group to enhance total shareholder value," Mr Rose said.

The group is also looking at business to business strategies to make savings in its supply chain.

webTitle: Italian oil group jumps into consolidation fray

fields.headline: Italian oil group jumps into consolidation fray
fields.trailText: Creation of another energy supergroup was on the cards yesterday as Italy's Eni oil and gas group confirmed it was in talks. But Eni played down reports that its preferred partner was Spain's Repsol.
fields.body:
Creation of another energy supergroup was on the cards yesterday as Italy's Eni oil and gas group confirmed it was in talks. But Eni played down reports that its preferred partner was Spain's Repsol.

Eni and Repsol combined would create the world's fifth largest quoted energy conglomerate, with a market capitalisation of around $60.8bn (£38bn). However, executives from both companies yesterday denied reports that a merger was imminent.

The Italian oil group has made no secret of its expansionist ambitions. It does not wish to be left behind in the consolidation of the industry, which has already created massive companies such as Exxon Mobil, BP Amoco and the merged Totalfina-Elf Aquitaine - a deal which was given the green light by the European commission yesterday - subject to certain disposals being made.

Sources at Totalfina, which had unsuccessful merger talks with Eni last year, said they were surprised by the reports of an Eni-Repsol deal.

Industry analysts said that bringing Totalfina and Elf Aquitaine together created a group more capable of striking a deal with Eni.

Gian Maria Gros-Pietro, Eni's chairman, said his group was in alliance negotiations but declined to name the potential partner.

Repsol said it was looking at possible mergers and alliances with companies in the whole energy sector not just other oil companies, but it was not negotiating with anyone.

A spokesman said: "In that context we have spoken to Eni, but that does not mean we are in negotiations."

However, speculation about a possible merger deal with Eni lifted Repsol's shares by more than 4% on the Madrid stock exchange and also boosted the prices of other energy groups.

Energy analysts had mixed views about a full merger between Eni - which is still 36% owned by the Italian state - and Repsol.

Javier Valverde, at Banco Santander Central Hispano, said: "This merger makes too much sense not to work towards it. Repsol has an eighth of the market capitalisation of Exxon. They have to move."

However, Caroline Cook, at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell in Edinburgh, said: "You have to stretch hard to find the advantages of such a deal."

Industry sources thought that an alliance was more likely at a time when the Italian and Spanish gas markets were being deregulated.

webTitle: The rate rise that no one really requires

fields.headline: The rate rise that no one really requires
fields.standfirst: Brown's medicine is no tonic
fields.trailText: Predicting what will happen to interest rates is a mug's game, and never more so than on the day that the Bank of England's monetary policy committee announces its monthly decision. But it would come as a real shock - not least to Gordon Brown - were rates not to go up today.
fields.body:
Predicting what will happen to interest rates is a mug's game, and never more so than on the day that the Bank of England's monetary policy committee announces its monthly decision. But it would come as a real shock - not least to Gordon Brown - were rates not to go up today.

The chancellor has made his feelings clear. He wants rates higher to prevent the strength of demand from igniting inflationary pressure. In fact Mr Brown is pushing at an open door; a majority of the monetary policy committee is concerned enough about the tightness of the labour market, rising house prices and the re-emergence of equity withdrawal to fund consumption to nudge up rates.

So far, so predictable. But whether a further modest tightening of monetary policy is what the economy needs is another matter. There are really two points at issue: does the UK actually need higher rates to curb inflation, and will the drip-drip approach work if it does?

On the first question, the argument is far more finely balanced than the hawks on the MPC and in the treasury would have us believe. Inflation excluding mortgage interest payments is at 2.2%, below the government's 2.5% target. Without the effect of oil prices it would be 1.5%, the level at which Eddie George would be obliged to write a letter to Mr Brown explaining what he planned to do to get inflation up.

Of course, a 150% increase in oil prices can have inflationary consequences, but only if there are second-round effects on domestic wages and prices. Thus far, there is no indication that there has been; competition remains cutthroat in the retail sector and pay settlements have been edging downward.

One reason why wages have been well-behaved is that headline inflation has been low.

Inflation according to the all-items retail prices index hit 1.1%, its lowest since 1963, last summer but has since been heading higher due to dearer mortgages. Most pay deals still use the headline inflation rate as a benchmark, so higher rates may have a perverse effect at a time when workers seem to have little fear of losing their jobs.

Finally, there is the pound. Hoisting up rates by a quarter-point will have zero impact on those bits of the economy in the south east that are overheating, but will inflict great damage on those parts of Britain still heavily dependent on manufacturing. None of this will prevent the inevitable happening today but it may explain why Labour faces growing trouble in its heartlands.

Sky high

It would be easy to dismiss BSkyB's £250m internet-linked investment programme as another example of "me too" thinking. Embracing the brave new worldwide web is always good for a boost in the share price.

Think no further back than Tuesday, when Reuters announced a £500m investment programme to move its business online. Reuters' shares went up 23% on the news. Yesterday BSkyB was similarly blessed with the market brushing a first-half pre-tax loss of £61.5m and sending the share price up by a fifth. There is a world of difference, however, between the unthinking rush into anything dot.com and serious investment by heavyweights like Reuters and BSkyB. Given the way the industry is going they have little choice.

The stock market is right to focus on forward-looking strategies designed to exploit the opportunities presented by the internet rather than what has happened over the last six months - although that said, the increase in BSkyB's subscriber base is to be welcomed, too.

A Life too far

Yesterday as Standard Life was helping to settle NatWest's fate, a group of policyholders was opening its own campaign to force the life insurer to change from a mutual to a public company.

The threat seems little more than a small cloud on a far horizon. The Stan dard Life Members Action Group has done no more than clear the first, easy, hurdle - collecting the signatures to requisition a meeting.

Unfortunately the numbers being dangled before with-profits policyholders - anything up to £6,300 - mean the issue is unlikely to go away.

The mutual movement has already lost too many members for it to be able to shrug off the loss of a company like Standard Life, and it is hard to see what arguments - other than of the "greed is good" variety - could be advanced for turning Standard Life into a public company.

It is a formidable competitor in its traditional market and its recent initiative, Standard Life Bank, is taking on established mortgage lenders to considerable effect. Indeed, some of Standard Life's rivals might like to see it floated on the stock market, where it would have to divert resources to pay shareholders.

webTitle: Wake up call for Deutsche Telekom

fields.headline: Wake up call for Deutsche Telekom
fields.trailText: Is there no end to the boom in telecoms stocks? Barely a week after Vodafone sealed its 181.4bn euro friendly merger with Mannesmann the European sector as a whole continues to froth and bubble, with no hint yet of boiling over - despite the best efforts of the monetary authorities on both sides of the pond.
fields.body:
Is there no end to the boom in telecoms stocks? Barely a week after Vodafone sealed its 181.4bn euro friendly merger with Mannesmann the European sector as a whole continues to froth and bubble, with no hint yet of boiling over - despite the best efforts of the monetary authorities on both sides of the pond.

Yesterday, as National Grid cashed in with its placing of a further 10% stake in Energis, eyes turned firmly to the sleepy, almost forgotten university town on the Rhine: Bonn, the home of Deutsche Telekom.

Shares at one point hit a new record high of 93.65 euro before nudging back on Wall Street fears of Greenspan to close at 92.50 euro, or up 25% in five days. Of course some of this, as even more strongly with Vodafone in London, reflects the greater weighting DT will acquire once Mannesmann drops out of the DAX-30 in the next few days.

The Schröder government, reaffirming its share boosting commitment to cut capital gains tax on sales of crossholdings in corporate Germany, is also helping with its plans for floating off a further tranche of DT - it has 66% now and aims to cut this to 44% by late June.

Fletcher Research, in its latest internet analysis newsletter, speculates that the owner of One2One could get seriously burned in the battle for third generation mobile phones licences in the UK, suggesting that failure to win could prompt a "fire sale" of its UK mobiles operation.

Much, it says, depends on Orange - which it values at £30-35bn or up to £15bn more than Mannesmann paid for it in October.

News travels at Mach 5 in this sector and, before one could say dot.com its tip of NTT DoCoMo, the Japanese group, seemed dead in the water as NTT president Junichiro Miyazu said DoCoMo had no interest.

France Telecom, DT's arch-rival and partner of NTL in the bidding battle, is favoured to win one of the five UMTS licences - along with, perhaps, MCI WorldCom or SpectrumCo, the Virgin-led consortium as well as the three present incumbents.

The French, riding high on a euro-fed boomlet, could snaffle Orange. Götterdämmerung on the Rhine?

Fletcher Research, in its latest internet analysis newsletter, speculates that the owner of One2One could get seriously burned in the battle for third generation mobile phones licences in the UK, suggesting that failure to win could prompt a "fire sale" of its UK mobiles operation. Much, it says, depends on Orange - which it values at £30-35bn or up to £15bn more than Mannesmann paid for it in October. News travels at Mach 5 in this sector and, before one could say dot.com its tip of NTT DoCoMo, the Japanese group, seemed dead in the water as NTT president Junichiro Miyazu said DoCoMo had no interest. France Telecom, DT's arch-rival and partner of NTL in the bidding battle, is favoured to win one of the five UMTS licences - along with, perhaps, MCI WorldCom or SpectrumCo, the Virgin-led consortium as well as the three present incumbents. The French, riding high on a euro-fed boomlet, could snaffle Orange. Götterdämmerung on the Rhine?

fields.headline: Britain's aid budget rises
fields.trailText: Western aid budgets are rising for the first time in five years as Britain and other countries increased spending in the aftermath of the Asian crisis and on writing off the debts of the world's poorest countries.
fields.body:
Western aid budgets are rising for the first time in five years as Britain and other countries increased spending in the aftermath of the Asian crisis and on writing off the debts of the world's poorest countries.

Official development assistance rose in 1998 by nearly 10% to $53bn (£33m), the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development reported yesterday.

However, aid budgets in most western countries average just 0.25% of national income, well below the official United Nations target of 0.7%. The OECD estimates that if western aid budgets had stayed at their 1970s and 1980s peaks spending today would be nearly $20bn higher.

Britain's aid budget increased by nearly 10% between 1997 and 1998, despite the freeze on departmental budgets in the first two years of the Labour government.

A spokeswoman for the department of international development said extra money had been found for debt relief and the for World Bank from other sources.

As a proportion of national income, spending rose to 0.27% in 1998, from 0.26% the previous year, but this still puts Britain in the bottom half of the OECD for generosity.

Denmark, Norway, the Netherlands and Sweden all spend more than the UN target. Denmark, the most generous OECD country, spends nearly 1% of its annual income on aid.

Initial figures for 1999 and 2000 should show Britain's aid spending increasing significantly, however, as the impact of the government's spending review takes effect.

fields.headline: Grid wants £1.1bn for Energis stock
fields.trailText: National Grid yesterday surfed the wave of euphoria for telecoms stocks by placing 10% of its holding in Energis, the fibre optic network, in the hope of raising £1.1bn.
fields.body:
National Grid yesterday surfed the wave of euphoria for telecoms stocks by placing 10% of its holding in Energis, the fibre optic network, in the hope of raising £1.1bn.

The sale of 30m shares, reducing the Grid's stake to 36% - worth £4.2bn - could herald a bidding war for Energis or swift moves by the telecoms group to lead a fresh round of consolidation among Europe's alternative operators.

Energis, industry sources said, has received informal approaches from leading players but no formal bid has been lodged.

German group Mannesmann had considered a £12bn bid in the event of beating off Vodafone; it failed, sparking the European rise in telecoms stock.

A strategic investor, it is thought, could launch an offer to buy 29.9% of the Grid's residual stake before pursuing an outright offer. Energis is worth around £11.5bn, but would fetch more in a bidding war.

Stephen Box, the Grid's finance director, who admitted the placing was designed to cash in on the post-Vodafone and Mannesmann fervour, said a trade sale within the next two or three years was still a favoured option.

He conceded, however, that this was not a hard and fast target, with any subsequent sales of the Grid's stake dependent on the state of the appetite for telecoms. "We would not be surprised if something happened early," he said.

Energis, which claims to be the biggest rival to BT in British corporate telecoms and supports many of the biggest internet portal operators, is pursuing a pan-European strategy which should boost its value even further. It was worth just £846m when the Grid floated a 25.7% stake in December 1997.

Mindful that its residual Energis stake will still provide 57% of its overall value when the placing is completed by tomorrow, the Grid said it would use the proceeds to boost its own stock through a rolling share buy-back.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Techmark 100 hits record high
fields.body:
Techmark 100 hits record high

London's Techmark 100 index of technology stocks reached a record high in its short history yesterday, doubling its November launch value in a move highlighting investor clamour for growth stocks.

Rises of 10% or more across an array of software companies propelled the index to 4,983 points by mid-afternoon - up 6% on the day and more than 100% ahead of its November 4th start at 2,430 - before settling at 4,971.18.

"It's really just gone bananas since the final quarter of last year. There is a general revaluation going on and I think it's here to stay," said Michael Lenhoff, portfolio strategist at money manager Capel Cure Sharp.

London launched its Techmark indices in the face of competition from Germany's Neuer Markt and the more mature American Nasdaq index, drawing together existing companies from the telecom, IT, pharmaceutical and related sectors.

Counterfeit ring smashed

Six people were being held in City police stations last night after police officers smashed a currency counterfeiting ring which could have flooded the market with millions of pounds' worth of forged banknotes.

The arrests followed raids yesterday morning at addresses in south east London, one of which was described by police as "a counterfeit supermarket".

City police, working with the national criminal intelligence service, found "illicit printing machinery" at three of the addresses, including printing presses and computers. They uncovered also new £20 notes, other British and Irish notes, Spanish pesetas and forged documents including car tax discs and test certificates.

National Power cleans house

The old and not so old guard at National Power were swept away yesterday after a prolonged "beauty parade" as the proposed demerger of the group into International Power and Npower, the UK integrated energy business, took shape.

Sir John Collins, brought in as executive chairman after the demise of former chief executive Keith Henry, chief operating officer Graham Brown, and Roger Witcombe, the finance director, will quit once the demerger is complete later this year.

Sir Neville Sims, the chairman of Carillion - itself formed from the demerger of Tarmac - will chair the international group where Peter Giller, German-born president of ABB Energy Ventures, becomes chief executive.

Ross Sayers, chief executive of China Light & Power, Hong Kong, will head Npower where Brian Count, managing director of National Power's UK business, will be chief operating officer.

EasyJet fights with Luton

The long-running battle between EasyJet and the directors of Luton airport, the low cost airline's hub, reached a new low yesterday.

The airline said it was considering asking the civil aviation authority to regulate the charging structure of Luton after negotiations related to a new pricing structure at the airport collapsed.

webTitle: Versailles backers appear closer to home counties

fields.headline: Versailles backers appear closer to home counties
fields.trailText: Versailles, the collapsed trade-finance house at the centre of a serious fraud office inquiry, used a multimillion-pound system of parallel funding to bankroll its activities, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
Versailles, the collapsed trade-finance house at the centre of a serious fraud office inquiry, used a multimillion-pound system of parallel funding to bankroll its activities, the Guardian has learned.

A small group of wealthy individuals, most of them living in the home counties, pumped at least £2.5m into Versailles during the mid-1990s in return for a cut of the profits.

This disclosure throws new light on the group's unorthodox finances and on its publicity shy financial backers, previously thought to have been based offshore.

One of these investors said yesterday that the funding group was made up "really by various people who knew each other". William Greig, of Buntingford, Hertfordshire, added that he had been both a shareholder and one of the parallel investors.

These investors - referred to as "traders" in Versailles' docu mentation - seem clustered in Hertfordshire, Buckinghamshire, Berkshire, Surrey and London, although one is listed in Aix-en-Provence, France, and one in Monte Carlo.

No investment is listed at less than £50,000. Mr Greig said he was owed "a lot more" than the £100,000 stated in documents seen by the Guardian. The Monte Carlo creditor is shown as having provided £250,000 in total, and an individual in West Byfleet as owed £140,000.

Although described as "traders", the backers did not actually trade with Versailles but provided funding for the company's deals.

Versailles specialised in advancing payment to small traders against the value of their stocks. By the time of its collapse earlier this year, Versailles owed its principal bankers, NatWest, Royal Bank of Scotland and Barclays, more than £55m. It is not known if bankers were aware of the funds supplied by the traders.

Versailles ran into trouble late last year when it announced it had discovered irregularities in some of its accounts. Shortly afterwards the company admitted it had been the department of trade and industry that had found the irregularities, which came to light before founder Carl Cushnie sold shares equivalent to 5% of the company, worth £29m, at a time when he knew and the market did not that Versailles was under a DTI-prompted accounts inquiry.

fields.headline: Return of the hippie
fields.standfirst: This time last year, Carlos Santana was a neglected relic of San Francisco's 70s scene. Now he's collaborating with the likes of Lauryn Hill and laden with Grammy nominations. He talks to  Adam Sweeting
fields.trailText: Have moustache, will travel: Santana through the ages
fields.body:
Have moustache, will travel: Santana through the ages

1947 Born in Mexico. Grows up in Tijuana before moving to San Francisco, where he forms the Santana Blues Band.

1968 Santana (as they're now known) play San Francisco's Fillmore ballroom for first time.

1969 Santana take their Latin-influenced music to the hippies at Woodstock. Debut album hits number four. Support Rolling Stones at infamous Altamont concert.

1970 First US hit single is a cover of Fleetwood Mac's Black Magic Woman. Plays Albert Hall and Bath Festival. Abraxas album sells 1m copies.

1971 Santana III top US chart.

1973 Carlos marries Urmila, follower of guru Sri Chinmoy, and makes album with like-minded John McLaughlin. Adds name Devadip.

1976 Plays on Bob Dylan's Rolling Thunder revue and benefit for Hurricane Carter.

1977 Cover of the Zombies' She's Not There is only UK hit.

1985 Band appear on Live Aid in Philadelphia.

1991 Arrested for cannabis possession in Houston. Gets six-month deferred sentence.

1998 Plays on multi-award winning album The Miseducation Of Lauryn Hill as Latin revival hots up.

1999 Releases album Supernatural. Five million copies sold to date

When the American record industry dishes out its annual awards later this month, all eyes at LA's Staples Center will be on Carlos Santana, the 52-year-old guitarist who's been nominated for no fewer than 10 Grammys. That would be a remarkable achievement in any circumstances, but only a year ago Santana was thought of as a 70s throwback with nothing to say to today's listeners. When, that is, he was thought of at all.

The album that has reignited his career is Supernatural, a laid-back stew of fashionable Latin rhythms pulled together by Carlos's own distinctive guitar tones. What helped to push it into pop-crossover territory is its list of guest artists. Lauryn Hill wrote and rapped on Do You Like the Way, while Wyclef Jean co-wrote and co-produced Maria Maria. Eagle-Eye Cherry and the Dust Brothers feature on the blues-shuffle Wishing it Was. Writing and vocal contributions from Rob Thomas (of Matchbox 20) helped to lodge Smooth at number one in the singles chart for 12 weeks. Throw in a guest spot from Dave Matthews and an Eric Clapton duet, and you have a recipe that has shifted 5m copies of the album since its release last June.

So why has all this happened now? "That's a good question," Carlos says, during a brief visit to Britain. "I've been saying that most people are not happy unless they're miserable, but when an individual pulls himself out of that zone, he's able to embrace a new dimension of thinking. Most people think life is crap and they have to scream, so they're paranoid. That's why kids in America get guns and shoot each other. But when you realise you have a chance to change the frequency, you start attracting what I'm attracting right now, which is enormous possibilities and opportunities."

That's not the sort of speech you get from most rock stars, but you can't separate Carlos Santana the musician from Carlos Santana the spiritual being spreading global good vibes. Rock critic Joel Selvin described the Santana of 1970 as "a guarded personality who tried to exert control through more devious ways", but today his calm, lilting tones and Tibetan-style skull cap give him the air of an itinerant mystic. He appears to have reached a place where everything is in harmony and nothing happens without a reason. He even saw the creation of Supernatural as a predestined experience, commenting that "all the people on the album said they had heard my music before I called them, or that I appeared in their dreams, or something".

The downside is that Carlos tends to lapse into beatific hyperbole, notably on Supernatural's sleeve, where he thanks his collaborators a little too profusely. "Lauryn Hill - To my dearest sister of light. My heart's gratitude for your soul's vision and your heart's music." "Eric Clapton - Dearest brother-friend Eric, you are truly an archangel of the highest order". And so forth.

But Santana has managed to survive the long haul from the Haight-Ashbury dawn of late-60s San Francisco: he is renewing himself when most of his contemporaries are dead or burnt out. If he's found what works for him, who's arguing? "People have been swinging with this pendulum of good and evil, beautiful or ugly," Carlos says. "Why don't we try this other one that goes like this: beauty, grace, excellence, peace, light, love, joy, quality, harmony. I'm really bored with the last 1,000 years of blaming the devil or blaming this or that for some shit that each person should take responsibility for. On Supernatural the music is working with grandparents, parents, teenagers and kids. It's inviting people to celebrate the divine side of yourself, to validate the existence of something that is paranormal, but is with us all of the time." And you thought it was just a pop album.

Growing up in the rough-and-tumble Mexican border town of Tijuana, the adolescent Carlos found himself playing the blues in clubs into the early hours, sharing the bill with hookers and strippers. It was probably just as well that his father, also a professional musician, moved the family to San Francisco's Spanish-speaking Mission district in 1961.

Carlos was sucked into the creative ferment of the 60s, where the psychedelic underground and anti-Vietnam war protest collided with the new musical directions being pioneered on the West Coast. He was soon rubbing shoulders with local musicians like the Grateful Dead, Jefferson Airplane, Moby Grape and the Paul Butterfield Blues Band, and hooked up with organist Gregg Rolie to assemble the first Santana band. With encouragement from San Francisco's influential promoter and entrepreneur Bill Graham, who booked the band at his Fillmore West concert hall and became their unofficial manager, Santana became one of the hottest acts in the Bay area.

"Bill Graham made it possible for the hippies to be educated," Carlos says now. "He said, 'You wanna listen to the Grateful Dead? First hear Miles Davis. If you wanna listen to Santana, first listen to Roland Kirk.' He believed in a balanced meal - salad, vegetables, main course, dessert. He always said that people like Bruce Springsteen and the Police and the Rolling Stones were the steak."

The bullying, abrasive Graham acted as a self-appointed critic to the artists he booked. He scared a lot of people, but Santana remembers him with fondness. "What I miss about him is that he took notes at every concert, on everybody - Sinatra, Barbra Streisand, Dylan, Eric Clapton, Jimi Hendrix. He would show the notes to you at the end of the concert. He would say, 'OK, the first song was excellent, the second really sucked, and the third one was too long.' How many promoters would have the cojones to tell you that? The problem is, you knew he was right. He wasn't into being a promoter or impresario or whatever; he was into the music."

An appearance at the 1969 Woodstock festival broke Santana nationwide. Maybe the fact that Carlos was tripping on mescaline gave them an extra edge, but the band were one of the major hits of the festival.

Carlos's earliest musical idols had been bluesmen like Muddy Waters, Buddy Guy and Otis Rush, but he began to listen to a more diverse palette of sounds. To the basic rock and blues base, Santana added Latin rhythms and the freer shapes of modern jazz, absorbed from records like John Coltrane's My Favourite Things and Miles Davis's rock-jazz fusion, Bitches Brew.

"Miles used to call at my house and he was funnier than anyone I ever heard, man," Carlos reminisces. "He had a tremendous sense of humour. A lot of people saw him as a different kind of angry Black Panther, but with me he was a real sweetheart. On the musical side, he changed the course of music seven times. Stravinsky only did it one time. Even John Coltrane, who's my musician of the century, said, 'Everything I'm discovering, Miles played it already'."

Santana's first albums - up to and including the fourth, the complex, jazz-inflected Caravanserai of 1972 - were some of the most original and powerful of their time. Carlos's version of his band's history tends to gloss over the power struggles and drug abuse which grew worse with success, until the conflicts drove Carlos to embrace the Hindu teachings of Sri Chinmoy. Between 1973 and 1981 he was known as Devadip Carlos Santana, and embarked on a string of collaborations with similarly spiritual jazz musicians, including John McLaughlin, Stanley Clarke, Wayne Shorter and Herbie Hancock.

In the 80s he gradually moved back to his original brew of rock, Latin and blues. "Jazz is an ocean," says Carlos. "Rock'n'roll is a swimming pool. I hang out on a lake." He continued to work regularly, but younger audiences stayed away, and the Santana name began to seem little more than a historical curiosity.

Much credit is due, then, to Arista boss Clive Davis, who offered Santana their first recording deal when he was at Columbia in 1968, and laid the groundwork for Carlos's comeback when he offered him a new contract in 1995. Davis asked Carlos what his artistic aspirations were, and was apparently satisfied with the reply: "I want to unify the molecules with the light through music."

"I give everybody all the credit," Carlos says. "I give my wife all the credit, I give Lauryn Hill all the credit for inviting me to appear with her at the Grammys, I give Eric Clapton all the credit for being so gracious and dignified and elegant. I don't need credit, man. I'm into progress, not success. Success is one beautiful cake. You cut it and you eat it yourself, and you choke on it. Progress, you cut it and you feed people with it, and hopefully you save a little piece for yourself. That's where I'm coming from." Maybe there's a little of that 1969 flower child left, at that.

The Grammys are on February 23. For details and the live webcast, go to www.grammy.com Supernatural is out on Arista.
