He was soon rubbing shoulders with local musicians like the Grateful Dead, Jefferson Airplane, Moby Grape and the Paul Butterfield Blues Band, and hooked up with organist Gregg Rolie to assemble the first Santana band. With encouragement from San Francisco's influential promoter and entrepreneur Bill Graham, who booked the band at his Fillmore West concert hall and became their unofficial manager, Santana became one of the hottest acts in the Bay area. "Bill Graham made it possible for the hippies to be educated," Carlos says now. "He said, 'You wanna listen to the Grateful Dead? First hear Miles Davis. If you wanna listen to Santana, first listen to Roland Kirk.' He believed in a balanced meal - salad, vegetables, main course, dessert. He always said that people like Bruce Springsteen and the Police and the Rolling Stones were the steak." The bullying, abrasive Graham acted as a self-appointed critic to the artists he booked. He scared a lot of people, but Santana remembers him with fondness. "What I miss about him is that he took notes at every concert, on everybody - Sinatra, Barbra Streisand, Dylan, Eric Clapton, Jimi Hendrix. He would show the notes to you at the end of the concert. He would say, 'OK, the first song was excellent, the second really sucked, and the third one was too long.' How many promoters would have the cojones to tell you that? The problem is, you knew he was right. He wasn't into being a promoter or impresario or whatever; he was into the music." An appearance at the 1969 Woodstock festival broke Santana nationwide. Maybe the fact that Carlos was tripping on mescaline gave them an extra edge, but the band were one of the major hits of the festival. Carlos's earliest musical idols had been bluesmen like Muddy Waters, Buddy Guy and Otis Rush, but he began to listen to a more diverse palette of sounds. To the basic rock and blues base, Santana added Latin rhythms and the freer shapes of modern jazz, absorbed from records like John Coltrane's My Favourite Things and Miles Davis's rock-jazz fusion, Bitches Brew. "Miles used to call at my house and he was funnier than anyone I ever heard, man," Carlos reminisces. "He had a tremendous sense of humour. A lot of people saw him as a different kind of angry Black Panther, but with me he was a real sweetheart. On the musical side, he changed the course of music seven times. Stravinsky only did it one time. Even John Coltrane, who's my musician of the century, said, 'Everything I'm discovering, Miles played it already'." Santana's first albums - up to and including the fourth, the complex, jazz-inflected Caravanserai of 1972 - were some of the most original and powerful of their time. Carlos's version of his band's history tends to gloss over the power struggles and drug abuse which grew worse with success, until the conflicts drove Carlos to embrace the Hindu teachings of Sri Chinmoy. Between 1973 and 1981 he was known as Devadip Carlos Santana, and embarked on a string of collaborations with similarly spiritual jazz musicians, including John McLaughlin, Stanley Clarke, Wayne Shorter and Herbie Hancock. In the 80s he gradually moved back to his original brew of rock, Latin and blues. "Jazz is an ocean," says Carlos. "Rock'n'roll is a swimming pool. I hang out on a lake." He continued to work regularly, but younger audiences stayed away, and the Santana name began to seem little more than a historical curiosity. Much credit is due, then, to Arista boss Clive Davis, who offered Santana their first recording deal when he was at Columbia in 1968, and laid the groundwork for Carlos's comeback when he offered him a new contract in 1995. Davis asked Carlos what his artistic aspirations were, and was apparently satisfied with the reply: "I want to unify the molecules with the light through music." "I give everybody all the credit," Carlos says. "I give my wife all the credit, I give Lauryn Hill all the credit for inviting me to appear with her at the Grammys, I give Eric Clapton all the credit for being so gracious and dignified and elegant. I don't need credit, man. I'm into progress, not success. Success is one beautiful cake. You cut it and you eat it yourself, and you choke on it. Progress, you cut it and you feed people with it, and hopefully you save a little piece for yourself. That's where I'm coming from." Maybe there's a little of that 1969 flower child left, at that. The Grammys are on February 23. For details and the live webcast, go to www.grammy.com Supernatural is out on Arista.

webTitle: Warning: this woman is inside your head

fields.headline: Warning: this woman is inside your head
fields.standfirst: Susan Hiller wants to lay bare your dreams and unravel your unconscious. As part of our occasional series on curators, she talks to  Jonathan Jones
fields.trailText: Susan Hiller's studio is full of noises. Small speakers hang from the ceiling in a cluster, a sculptural shape in space, and when she turns them on a babble of voices fills the air, forming a tangible physical mass like bees in a hive or the legion voices of the devil in The Exorcist. Go in closer and you hear different stories told in many accents: "It seemed to have wings like a bat and came stumbling towards us. We didn't wait to investigate..."; "My friend and I were walking in the countryside when we saw three tiny figures..." The voices, Hiller explains, belong to witnesses relating encounters with alien visitors.
fields.body:
Susan Hiller's studio is full of noises. Small speakers hang from the ceiling in a cluster, a sculptural shape in space, and when she turns them on a babble of voices fills the air, forming a tangible physical mass like bees in a hive or the legion voices of the devil in The Exorcist. Go in closer and you hear different stories told in many accents: "It seemed to have wings like a bat and came stumbling towards us. We didn't wait to investigate..."; "My friend and I were walking in the countryside when we saw three tiny figures..." The voices, Hiller explains, belong to witnesses relating encounters with alien visitors.

Susan Hiller is an artist who makes collections. Her art is curatorial in that it assembles, preserves and documents. What she collects are what she calls "cultural artefacts", from old seaside postcards to recordings of alien encounters and, in the exhibition Dream Machines which she has selected and which has just opened at Dundee Contemporary Arts, the work of other artists who, like her, are fascinated by altered states of consciousness.

"We're all collectors," Hiller tells me. She is sitting amid old projectors, Mr Punch puppets, paintings - she has been known to burn her paintings and exhibit the ash - and relics from a synagogue wrapped in brown-paper parcels. "We're collectors and sorters and archivists. This is what we are as people, this is how we make sense of everything, and I suppose this exhibition is made up of a large number of artworks that I've collected mentally, but never had a chance to bring together in one place. They existed in my own mental museum."

Dream Machines is an exhibition that looks at contemporary art like an anthropologist exploring another culture. Famous artists are held up as case histories, and works normally exhibited as fine art are displayed as experiments in what drugs, drink, dreams and even death can make you feel. Drunkenness in two cultures can be compared by watching a 1972 Gilbert and George video called Gordons Makes Us Drunk and then seeing Mexican artist Minerva Cuevas drink an entire bottle of tequila until she becomes totally incoherent. Gordons or tequila - they do something to your mind. So do the magic mushrooms German artist Carsten Höller consumes in a hotel room, and the poetry in a video in which the British artist Mark Francis reads Baudelaire to cannabis plants.

It's this desire to create an effect, to make you feel something, that distinguishes the art of Susan Hiller. American-born but based in Britain since the early 70s, Hiller has become one of our most influential and revered artists. She even has a room to herself in the opening displays at Tate Modern. The reason for her huge reputation among critics, curators and other artists is that she has asserted things about art that, until quite recently, were forgotten: that it can access the unconscious; that, as she says of Dream Machines, the most hard-headed conceptual artist secretly wants to be a "visionary".

Yet Hiller's prestige among artists has never translated into public celebrity, perhaps because she just doesn't conform to any of the things that sell artists. As one young British artist featured in her show pointed out, it's absurd that such a significant figure now falls outside the age limit for the Turner Prize. Hiller is an intellectual, a graduate student in anthropology before she gave it up to become an artist. She's written a book about Primitivism in art and co-authored a cultural history of dreams. Her celebrated installation From The Freud Museum sounds like a treatise. In Britain, with its lingering anti-intellectual prejudices, that just about writes her off as an art star. Even worse, she is widely respected as a teacher.

Hiller was born in 1942 and grew up in Cleveland, Ohio. "I always wanted to be an artist," she says, "but I had never heard of any women artists and when I did hear of them they were all second-rate. I went to art classes at the Cleveland Art Museum and then at a certain point went off to university and decided not to be an artist, although the reasons were not clear to me. I went to graduate school in anthropology because it fascinated me. I was primarily interested in things like African art; but also, looking back, I can see that the first generation of really famous anthropologists in the US consisted of a great many women."

At a precise point in her graduate career - she remembers suddenly starting to draw rather than take notes in a lecture - she abandoned her plan to be the next Margaret Mead and became an artist instead. It's almost out of Henry James, her flight from American intellectualism to have fun abroad. "Six months later I left and came to Europe - which was a classic way of escaping. What I didn't realise at the time about this interest in African and Native American artefacts was that it was a kind of modernist entry into art - Picasso - the lure of the unknown, which nowadays we see through as a form of exoticism, with its colonialist aspects. But nevertheless there is a very sincere and genuine visual charge which you get from these works which are so unfamiliar."

What is brilliant and original about Susan Hiller is the way she has turned her anthropological eye on to what is familiar. She collects the artefacts of our culture and makes us see them as utterly strange. As an American in London she has a slight displacement that helps her to see how weird we really are. One of the objects in her Freud Museum installation is a jug in the shape of a cow, which has a personal meaning because, she remembers, she had never heard a woman called a cow before coming to this country. Perhaps her most "British" piece is An Entertainment, a video installation that takes Punch and Judy and reveals the savage, primitive violence at the heart of this seaside theatre. "When you start to look at anything and think about it, tremendous meanings start to unravel. Of course we couldn't live like that - we couldn't live thinking about everything or we'd never be able to survive. But art can slow you down enough to think about those things."

Hiller's art seems increasingly about the unconscious of our culture, the margins of the collective psyche, as recorded in UFO reports and horror films. Her recent video installations Wild Talents and Psi Girls delve into the world of psychic phenomena, and the exhibition Dream Machines comes clean about her addiction to the unconscious. You might say this urge to unveil the world of dreams makes her a successor to the surrealists; but Hiller believes surrealism has totally crippled the way artists think about dreams. Hiller characterises western culture as "the Freud museum". She wants to get away from what she calls the "crisp paintings" of Dali and their Freudian assumption that dreams can be translated into words. The art in Dream Machines is far harder to describe: the altered states it evokes are intended to be inexplicable.

What she is trying to do in Dream Machines, says Hiller, is to make the viewer experience what a painting by Dali only describes. Art can actually change the way you think and feel. The artists in Dream Machines do this in various ways. They trick you with light, like James Turrell, whose art disrupts our perception with hidden light sources that seem to make space tangible. They mesmerise you, like Gilbert and George repeating their mantra "Gordons makes us very drunk". Or, in the case of Kurt Schwitters reading his Dadaist sound poem The Primeval Sonata on a 20s gramophone record, they reduce you to paroxysms of laughter.

"The primary altered state of consciousness that we're all familiar with is dreaming," says Hiller over nothing stronger than a cup of tea. "Others are slightly more rarefied: hypnosis, hallucination, induced by drugs or trance states of various kinds. Everything in the show is intended to provoke you into an effect."

Booze, drugs and weird machines feature in Hiller's exhibition but at its core are artworks that transport you to another state of mind by the power of imagination. Douglas Gordon's installation 30 Seconds Text takes you into a totally darkened room where you feel disoriented. A lightbulb flashes on. There's a text on the wall telling how a doctor attempted to talk to a man's head after it had just been cut off by the guillotine. The head could communicate for 25-30 seconds, relates Gordon - exactly the time, he concludes, it should have taken you to read this. The light cuts off. You're in total darkness. It would be fair to say Susan Hiller wants to mess with your head.

Dream Machines is at Dundee Contemporary Arts (01382 432000) till March 26, then at Mappin Art Gallery, Sheffield, from July 8-August 20, and at Camden Arts Centre, London NW1, from September 7-October 29.

fields.headline: Cash drive for deprived areas
fields.trailText: Ronald Cohen, chairman of venture capitalist Apax Partners, is to head a treasury-backed social investment taskforce which will work out how to attract private finance into socially oriented businesses in deprived areas.
fields.body:
Ronald Cohen, chairman of venture capitalist Apax Partners, is to head a treasury-backed social investment taskforce which will work out how to attract private finance into socially oriented businesses in deprived areas.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, launched the taskforce yesterday as part of the government's drive to boost the voluntary sector. He told the annual conference of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations: "I want to see more investment in the UK in social enterprises - projects which have social objectives, and are not simply profit-orientated."

Mr Cohen, who has been behind a string of initiatives to help growing businesses including the Easdaq stock market, said there was a role for new institutions working between conventional venture capital and traditional philanthropy "As venture capitalists we have come across many situations where the economic justification might not be up to the required hurdle rate, but which would be of benefit.

"There hasn't been a clear view on what is worth doing and how to do it. I am interested in seeing what the private sector can do and how to multiply the investment that might be available."

The taskforce is due to report in the autumn on tax and other measures which could attract additional funds for organisations such as credit unions, community loan funds and other community finance initiatives.

The move follows last year's report by the government's social exclusion unit, which argued that creating small businesses in deprived areas was likely to provide significant social spin-offs, but identified a lack of access to finance as a crucial obstacle.

webTitle: Do you quote colleagues pay when negotiating your own?

fields.headline: Do you quote colleagues pay when negotiating your own?
fields.standfirst: What to do when you feel short changed
fields.trailText: What to do when you feel short changed.
fields.body:
The problem

I'm an editor for a large news organisation. After nine months being freelance I was offered a permanent contract. Great, I thought, I can look forward to an editor's salary.

But I was offered 30% lower than my colleagues. Moreover, the previous person who was offered the very same job told me he was offered the higher amount. My boss that it was because of my inexperience. I'm very young to have this position, I obtained it in a year when it usually takes five. Still, if I am young talent, as they say I am, am I not entitled to commensurate pay. I'm now in a dilemma. I said I'd think about their proposition but my plan at the moment is to say that, for financial reasons, I cannot accept the amount being offered because I feel its not commensurate with other news organisations. Although I like my job, and finding a similar one will be tricky, I do feel sufficiently short-changed enough to leave.

The solution

Dear short-changed editor,

Normally I would advise that the pay your colleagues get is irrelevant to your own argument for a pay-rise. However, in your case, the situation is a little different in that you have three sources of comparison to boost your pitch: your colleagues who earn 30% more for the same work, the previous incumbent who was offered the same as your colleagues, plus your peer group at other companies who all seem to earn this higher amount. All sound reasons for you to be paid the same.

On the other hand, you are not, apparently, as skilled as these other comparative people, because you do not have as much experience as them. Perhaps you need a little more supervision, help, input etc. from others? If so, there is a reasonable argument to pay you less.

I think that it might be a little unwise to gamble with your job for the chance of earning the same as the others, given that the discrepancy may be justified. You like your job, are doing well and would find it hard to get a similar one. So, rather than go the route you are suggesting, here is another idea. Tell your boss you are not happy with being paid less than your market value but that you understand that you may not have quite as much experience as your colleagues. Agree to accept what is on offer, but ask for the gap to be narrowed (say to 15%) after a further six or nine months, and then again six-nine months later. This should bring you in line with your colleagues after about 12-18 months - by which time you will be far more experienced. They may well accept this since they don't want the hassle of trying to replace you and hopefully, it is a compromise that everyone can live with.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work
(Purple House, £9.99) and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't (Element, £9.99)

fields.headline: BBC Symphony Orchestra/ Berio
fields.standfirst:
Royal Festival Hall, London/Radio 3
*****
fields.trailText:
BBC Symphony Orchestra/ Berio
Royal Festival Hall, London/Radio 3
*****
fields.body:
If you had to choose one work to sum up what European music achieved in the second half of the 20th century, Luciano Berio's Coro would fit the bill. It's rarely performed - Coro needs an expert choir of 40 soloists and an orchestra of the same size, as well as plenty of rehearsal time to master its complexities - but every encounter with the work is memorable. This performance, part of the BBC Symphony Orchestra's Composer Portrait series and conducted by Berio himself, reworked the magic.

What begins simply, with a solo soprano singing an American Sioux text over a dappled piano accompaniment, is soon sending out tendrils in all directions. The vocal line is shared; the other instruments first reinforce the piano, then take off on their own trajectories. Folk poetry sung in English, French, German and Italian is one strand in Coro's hour-long tapestry; the poetry of Pablo Neruda is the other. A line from one of his fiercest polemics - "Venid a ver la sangre por las calles" (Come and see the blood on the streets) - haunts the work. Only in the last section is his poem sung complete, so that this devastating line is heard in context.

Before that moment, though, there are many wonderful ideas. Voices are twinned with solo instruments - a soprano duets with a flute, a tenor with a horn, a baritone with a trombone - or are brought together to create a cloud of slowly shifting chords against which the orchestra etches in fine detail. Sometimes the whole ensemble combines to create climaxes of terrifying power. Though ideally Coro needs a more generous acoustic than the Festival Hall to put a halo around the luxuriant sounds, the sense of its majesty and originality was perfectly conveyed by the BBC Singers and the BBCSO.

Earlier Berio and the orchestra, with the saxophonist Claude Delangle, had introduced to this country the latest expansion of one of the solo Sequenzas. Récit takes the solo line from Sequenza IX for saxophone and surrounds it with a web of other instrumental lines, fleshing out its harmonic implications or taking off tangentially from what the original work implies. If it isn't a major work, then Sequenza XIII, for solo bassoon, in which Pascal Gallois repeated his tour de force of appearing not to breathe conventionally for almost 20 minutes, certainly is. Only a composer of Berio's genius could sustain a single woodwind line over such a span with so much detail and musical drama.

It's rarely performed - Coro needs an expert choir of 40 soloists and an orchestra of the same size, as well as plenty of rehearsal time to master its complexities - but every encounter with the work is memorable. This performance, part of the BBC Symphony Orchestra's Composer Portrait series and conducted by Berio himself, reworked the magic. What begins simply, with a solo soprano singing an American Sioux text over a dappled piano accompaniment, is soon sending out tendrils in all directions. The vocal line is shared; the other instruments first reinforce the piano, then take off on their own trajectories. Folk poetry sung in English, French, German and Italian is one strand in Coro's hour-long tapestry; the poetry of Pablo Neruda is the other. A line from one of his fiercest polemics - "Venid a ver la sangre por las calles" (Come and see the blood on the streets) - haunts the work. Only in the last section is his poem sung complete, so that this devastating line is heard in context. Before that moment, though, there are many wonderful ideas. Voices are twinned with solo instruments - a soprano duets with a flute, a tenor with a horn, a baritone with a trombone - or are brought together to create a cloud of slowly shifting chords against which the orchestra etches in fine detail. Sometimes the whole ensemble combines to create climaxes of terrifying power. Though ideally Coro needs a more generous acoustic than the Festival Hall to put a halo around the luxuriant sounds, the sense of its majesty and originality was perfectly conveyed by the BBC Singers and the BBCSO. Earlier Berio and the orchestra, with the saxophonist Claude Delangle, had introduced to this country the latest expansion of one of the solo Sequenzas. Récit takes the solo line from Sequenza IX for saxophone and surrounds it with a web of other instrumental lines, fleshing out its harmonic implications or taking off tangentially from what the original work implies. If it isn't a major work, then Sequenza XIII, for solo bassoon, in which Pascal Gallois repeated his tour de force of appearing not to breathe conventionally for almost 20 minutes, certainly is. Only a composer of Berio's genius could sustain a single woodwind line over such a span with so much detail and musical drama.

fields.headline: A cold kind of comedy
fields.standfirst:
Coppélia
The Royal Ballet at the Royal Opera House
***
fields.trailText:
Coppélia
The Royal Ballet at the Royal Opera House
***
fields.body:
A few years ago, when the Royal's budget had a more elastic waistband, there was talk of a new production of the comedy classic, Coppélia. In leaner, meaner times the plan's been dropped. In its place the company have revived Ninette de Valois's 1954 staging of the ballet, and Osbert Lancaster's original, delicious designs.

Lancaster's flat, posterpaint sets look almost naive to a modern eye, yet they're animated by such droll and fanciful energy that they seem classic rather than dated. When the curtains open on his whimsical sunlit square, then on the surreal treasure trove of Dr Coppélius's workshop, it's like turning the pages of a precious children's book.

Less successful are the costumes, whose fake folkloric sometimes looks fussy rather than comic. An erratic line between charm and fustiness runs through this very mixed production.

Coppélia is a French ballet with an Imperial Russian past, and it was the latter which de Valois adhered to, making the work look grander and more formal than the more vernacular British productions that followed it. The mime is dominated by classical gesture rather than demotic body language and the choreography is emphatically virtuoso.

In Acts 1 and 2 the mix of French and Russian works engagingly well. The folk dances rattle along with a rhythmic and acrobatic extravagance and I loved the prettily choreographed "dialogue" for Swanilda's friends. When Swanilda is feeling sorry for herself, her friends echo the sighing curve of her phrase; when she challenges them with a tricky step, they respond in a giggling canon.

In Act 3, however, the structure so rigidly follows the old Russian formula (set piece divertissements, grand pas de deux) that we lose all sense of Coppélia as a distinctive world and Franz and Swanilda as distinctive lovers. While more recent stagings keep the action flowing, giving comic moral force to the newly grown up lovers as they're reconciled with Dr Coppélius, de Valois's staging virtually abandons the plot.

When Swanilda (Miyako Yoshida) enters in her ballerina tutu with Franz (Carlos Acosta) in his immaculate jacket, they're like overdressed strangers. With a different cast we may feel otherwise. Yoshida and Acosta are very conventional lovers (flouncy flirt meets oversexed dude), and though the glorious expertise of their dancing conceals their limitations in Acts 1 and 2, there's no emotion in their final pas de deux. However beautifully they dance, we don't warm to them. Worse still, given that this production bars them from repenting of their bad behaviour towards Dr Coppélius we don't, by the end, even like them.

In rep until May 14. Box office: 0171-304 4000

fields.headline: Bowlers on Broadway
fields.standfirst:
Fosse
Prince of Wales Theatre, London
****
fields.trailText:
Fosse
Prince of Wales Theatre, London
****
fields.body:
No American showbiz choreographer had a more distinctive signature than Bob Fosse. The tip-tilted bowler hat held between thumb and forefinger, the jutting buttocks, the hand raised high: all these are much in evidence in this rousing anthology of his work ranging from Kiss me Kate and The Pajama Game to the movie All That Jazz.

For me, the best of Fosse often lies in the vintage setpieces from book musicals, where his irony and wit match that of the score. Here, for instance, we get two classics from Sweet Charity. In Big Spender the lewd hip movements of the taxi-dancers who drape their legs over the railing as if they were folding Dali clocks evoke a world of sleazy sex. Rich Man's Frug, in which smooth men dance with cigarettes poised in parodic Coward style, also summons up a kind of yuppie ecstasy.

Obviously in a show that includes so much you sense Fosse's limitations as well as his brilliance. He did not come from the world of classical ballet and his occasional nods in that direction reveal his fundamental lack of lyricism. He could also occasionally be pretentious. But his best work has an extraordinary mix of muscularity, sexiness and energy.

The climax to the evening, from his exuberant 1978 show Dancin', is a version of Benny Goodman's Sing, Sing, Sing in which the movements match those of the instruments: one particular dancer, Emma Tunmore, doesn't so much accompany the trumpet solo as make music visible with her mane-tossing head movements, her pelvic gyrations and her breathtaking floor-slide. In fact, one great virtue of the show, directed by Richard Maltby Jr and Ann Reinking and co-choreographed by Reinking and Chet Walker, is that the dancers emerge as individuals. They are, I note, predominantly British, which says a lot for the way we can now match American showbusiness expertise.

In most musicals you sit patiently waiting for the few patches of choreographed excitement. Here you get the ecstasy without the boredom.

Until June 17. Box office: 0171-839 5972. This review appeared in some editions of yesterday's paper

fields.headline: Carpetbaggers target Standard Life
fields.trailText: Standard Life, the largest mutual in Europe, yesterday faced the threat of demutualisation after it was targeted by a Monaco-based carpetbagger.
fields.body:
Standard Life, the largest mutual in Europe, yesterday faced the threat of demutualisation after it was targeted by a Monaco-based carpetbagger.

If it is successful 2.5m existing with-profits policyholders could receive average windfall payouts of £5,000-£6,000.

Standard Life said it was committed to mutuality but was studying the proposals. It immediately suspended membership rights on new policies to prevent a rush of investors hoping for a windfall.

Behind the move is Fred Woollard, a former fund manager and coordinator of the Standard Life Members Action Group. The group lodged a resolution backed by 90 policyholders, requesting for a special general meeting at which the board should consider taking steps to demutualise the company and release assets worth £12bn-£15bn.

Mr Woollard is the first to attempt to force a leading life company to convert, although other companies have been subject to speculation by carpetbaggers. Success could open the floodgates for hostile bids against other mutuals.

Mr Woollard, an Australian national, said his move was prompted by comments from Iain Lumsden, Standard Life's finance director, to the treasury select committee inquiry into demutualisation.

On the issue of whether Standard Life should demutualise, Mr Lumsden told the committee: "It is actually going to be quite difficult to satisfy oneself arithmetically that the existing policyholders as a whole are not going to profit."

Mr Woollard said Mr Lumsden's comments showed board members understood members would gain from demutualising. "I'm doing this because I believe it is the right thing to do. It's good for the policyholders, it's good for the employees and it's good for the people of Britain in general because of the charitable windfall."

The resolutions lodged by Mr Woollard and his 90 supporters suggest the company distribute up to 1.5% to employees, and that each participating policy holder - regardless of the number, size or type of participating policies held - shall receive free shares worth approximately £500.

The balance of the free shares should be distributed to participating policyholders in proportion to the asset share held by each. The resolution also calls for shares worth £120m-150m to be given to the Standard Life Anniversary Appeal, a registered charity established to give money to health-related good causes.

It is likely the meeting will take place on April 24 or 26.

Although some of the 90 signatories to the resolution were raised through the bulletin board of the carpetbagger.com website, Mr Woollard stressed that there was no other connection between his group and the carpetbagger website.

In the frame

 Scottish Provident
Assets: more than £6bn. The carpetbagger's favourite. Too small to remain independent if it demutualises. Minimum single premium investment is £10,000.

 Scottish Life
Assets: more than £6bn. Another small life office on the takeover agenda. Believed to have been approached in the past by potential buyers. Minimum investment is £25 per month for with-profit savings policies.

 Equitable Life
Assets: £22bn. Once proud mutual hit by £1.5bn court case over annuities and weakening investment performance. Low free reserves suggest windfall payouts could be small.

 Friends Provident
Assets: £18bn. Acquisitive mutual. Could float independently but Alliance & Leicester tipped as potential buyer.

 Wesleyan
Assets: £2bn. Strong financial reserves, so a juicy target. Membership via £25 a month regular savings plans.

webTitle: Brown tax deal aims to revive charity giving

fields.headline: Brown tax deal aims to revive charity giving
fields.trailText: Charity leaders welcomed plans set out yesterday by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, for a national campaign to promote giving which could boost voluntary sector income by £1bn a year.
fields.body:
Charity leaders welcomed plans set out yesterday by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, for a national campaign to promote giving which could boost voluntary sector income by £1bn a year.

The campaign will aim to foster what Mr Brown called a new "civic patriotism", renewing people's sense of community and giving charities a central role in the government's social programmes.

To kick start the drive and help reverse five years of decline in charity donations and volunteering, the chancellor confirmed a series of tax changes expected to increase annual voluntary sector income by up to £350m.

Stuart Etherington, chief executive of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations, said the changes - foreshadowed in Mr Brown's last autumn statement - would create a tax regime which would be "one of the best in the world for making giving easy".

Mr Brown's key announcement was a campaign to promote the giving of money and time. "Unless this sort of favourable tax regime is made clear to people, and the ease with which they can give is communicated to them, we might not see the turnaround," Mr Etherington said.

Mr Brown outlined his hopes for a reborn civic society, building upon Tony Blair's vision of a "giving age", in a wide-ranging address to the annual NCVO conference in London.

He said: "At a time when some countries even in Europe are finding themselves defined by xenophobia and race, I believe it is more important than ever that we remember what defines us as a nation: the most precious things, our tolerance, strong sense of fair play, our sense of civic responsibility."

Labour had "learnt from the mistakes of the past" and no longer saw charities as a threat to what government should do, but as more in touch with local people and issues and better placed to innovate.

"Put it this way: once we thought the man in Whitehall knew best. That was a long time ago. Now we know the woman from the WRVS, or the playgroup movement, might know better," he said.

The chancellor said his goal was for the nation to give £1bn more to charity by the end of 2002. In particular, he wanted to see a sharp rise in company donations which, at an average 0.2% of profits, were a mere fifth of those in the US.

Michael Portillo, the Conservative shadow chancellor, said that while any help for the voluntary sector was welcome, the tax changes would not compensate for what charities had lost in Labour's "stealth tax hits" - primarily the abolition of advance corporation tax credits.

The Charities' Reform Group said the sector was losing £400m a year in irrecoverable VAT. Ministers have repeatedly refused to lift this burden citing reasons of cost and principle.

The main points

Tax relief of 28p on every £1 individual donation to charity.

Relief extended to gifts of shares by individuals and companies.

Bonus relief of 10p for every £1 donated through payroll giving for next three years. For higher rate taxpayers, total relief will be 50p.

Cap on payroll giving lifted.

Paperwork for tax relief on company donations scrapped

National campaign to promote giving and volunteering

fields.headline: Quatuor Mosaïques
fields.standfirst:
Wigmore Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
Quatuor Mosaïques
Wigmore Hall, London
****
fields.body:
The members of Quatuor Mosaïques, three Austrians and one Frenchman, seem to communicate more by telepathy than by obvious gestures. Leader Erich Höbarth is decidedly in control, but appears at times, eyes closed, to be playing in his own world. Yet their performances are polished, thoughtful and very together.

The quartet's programmes are always based around works by the classical masters, repertoire that in the wrong hands can sound all too standard. Their performances are "authentic", not so much in that they use period instruments, more in the manner in which they play. A certain style of bow stroke and phrasing and the use of gut strings (rather than modern metal combinations) make for rich, characterful readings.

These gut strings can sound softer or harsher than their modern counterparts, depending on how they are played. They made their presence felt most of all in the spiky Menuetto from Haydn's B minor quartet, Op 64 No 2. Höbarth's short, tight bow strokes gave a tinny sound to the tensest harmonies, in sharp contrast to the sweetness of the second melody. This harshness suited that particular moment, but also crept in at other times when it was less welcome. Yet the work as a whole received a warm, energetic performance. Each variation of the adagio assumed its individual character from the first notes, and the throwaway ending of the finale was wittily understated.

Haydn's quartets were among the works studied by Schumann in early 1842, before he embarked on a prolific few months of chamber music writing. His A major quartet, Op 41 No 3, speedily written, taps into his calm, romantic side.

The work opens tentatively, only settling into the home key at the end of the first phrase. But the melodies should be long and seamless. Höbarth handed them around the quartet so that one could hardly tell where one player stopped and another began, and Christophe Coin floated his first movement cello solo effortlessly. Finely detailed playing and taut ensemble contributed to a rounded and satisfying performance.

webTitle: Freeserve bets on tax free gambling

fields.headline: Freeserve bets on tax free gambling
fields.standfirst:
Freeserve
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Freeserve, the UK's largest internet service provider, yesterday entered the potentially lucrative online gaming market after agreeing an exclusive fixed odds football betting service with Sports Internet.
fields.body:
Freeserve, the UK's largest internet service provider, yesterday entered the potentially lucrative online gaming market after agreeing an exclusive fixed odds football betting service with Sports Internet.

The deal will make tax free betting through Sports Internet's Guernsey based subsidiary Surrey Group available to Freeserve's 1.7m users from March. Analysts expect the move to put further pressure on traditional bookmakers who fear their market share will be hit by the industry exodus offshore to escape the government's 9% levy on bets.

Racecourse operator Arena Leisure has unveiled a joint venture with American betting technology group Autotote to operate an internet betting service for horseracing around the world.

Sports Internet is cementing its relationship with Freeserve by issuing it a warrant to subscribe 400,000 new shares at 750p each, representing a potential investment of £3m.

The deal reunites Freeserve chief executive John Pluthero and Sports Internet deputy chairman Peter Wilkinson, who together played a crucial role in creating Freeserve.

A Freeserve spokesman said it had been particularly attracted by the optasoccer.com football statistics website.

Sports Internet chief executive Jeremy Fenn said the company was actively looking at ways to expand into horseracing and golf. He dismissed speculation that BSkyB and NTL were battling to join Freeserve as shareholders in the company. "There is nothing on the table at this time," he said.

Freeserve shares edged back 4p at 775p, but Sports Internet climbed 42p to 800p.

fields.headline: Just2Clicks stock snapped up
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Just2Clicks, a business to business facility backed by former Cellnet chairman Sir Michael Bett and entrepreneur Luke Johnson, is next week set to float for around £130m.
fields.body:
Just2Clicks, a business to business facility backed by former Cellnet chairman Sir Michael Bett and entrepreneur Luke Johnson, is next week set to float for around £130m.

The issue of 34.6m shares at 150p each was more than twice oversubscribed, and illustrates the growing desire of institutions to invest in internet companies which allow businesses to communicate and trade on-line, not just those selling directly to consumers.

"Since we announced our intention to float in September there has been a sea change in the City's attitude towards business to business," said chief executive Karl Watkin. "We came to the market hoping to raise £20m and have actually raised £50m."

Just2Clicks operates vertical B2B trading portals that serve the pulp and paper, electric power and road transport industries. The new funds will be spent on improving existing services and a likely expansion into the packaging and automotive sectors.

Mr Watkin, who spent 16 years working in the packaging industry, believes the experience and contacts of his board placed Just2Clicks in a strong position to expand into new sectors.

Mr Betts is chairman designate of Pace Micro Technology and has held senior positions at British Telecom and GEC. Non-executive director Alan Donnelly is a former Labour party MEP and finance director of the GMB blue collar union, while Mr Johnson is a renowned networker.

"Our ability to get in front of people is almost unmatched," Mr Watkin claimed.

Revenues come from commissions on transactions and by charging for access to specialised content on websites.

Analysts at Merrill Lynch believe third party sites such as Just2Clicks will account for up to 20% of e-commerce and institutions have been eager to take significant positions in the market.

VerticalNet - a Nasdaq listed company which approximates closely to Just2Clicks - was floated at $16 (£9.90) a share a year ago and now trades at $275.

Just2Clicks also has a partnership agreement with Entrade, another Nasdaq listed B2B firm, to take its goods and services. The relationship could be cemented by the American company taking an equity stake in Just2Clicks.

Mr Watkin will own 11% of the enlarged share capital while the other board members will hold around 2% each.

fields.headline: Swing out, sister
fields.standfirst:
Marcella Detroit
The Spitz, London
***
fields.trailText:
Marcella Detroit
The Spitz, London
***
fields.body:
For a band who once spent eight weeks at number one in the singles chart, Shakespear's Sister are little-remembered today, and Marcella Detroit, the half who wasn't married to Dave Stewart, even less so. She may have possessed an air-horn voice, but as soon as they split up (onstage, while collecting the 1992 Ivor Novello award for best album) she entered the way-station reserved for former members of semi-famous bands.

Eight years and two solo albums later, Detroit is still best remembered as a Sister, but she's doing it for herself these days, with the help of a passionate following. There are enough fans of her songwriterly guitar-pop to pack this small room in the middle of the City and leave a queue of people in rectangular glasses trailing down the block.

It's hard to distinguish the similarly-bespectacled Detroit from her people, except that her long black hair means that Nana Mouskouri is never far from one's thoughts. In every other sense, Detroit is one with the audience, vocalising the expectations of thirty-somethings poised between Nikes and Sainsbury's. Playing guitar and sometimes perching on the edge of the low stage, she's melancholy and regretful. "I've got a lust for life," she broods, sounding anything but lustful on a song that lifts the chorus - but none of the joie de vivre - from the Iggy Pop hit.

A slow start, aggravated by her refusal to speak between numbers, gives way to peaks of intensity during which she scales mountains and heads for the stratosphere. She really has got a powerful voice, and sometimes the songs are almost worthy. They fall into three camps: dull countryish, vibrant R&B and Shakespear's Sister, which she saves till the end and makes a show of reluctance about playing.

"I don't know that one," she claims when someone requests Stay, the million-selling single that put her and Siobhan Fahey on the map. "Well, I do but they don't," she gestures at her hired hands.

But why so coy? It's what the people have come for, after all, and she finally obliges with a version whose rancour probably owes something to the lack of diplomatic relations between her and Fahey. Lay Down Sally, the tune she wrote with Eric Clapton when she was only 18, if you believe her biography, follows, and that's it. Back to the Renault Espaces for the crowd and back to a quiet California life for Detroit, both parties fulfilled.

webTitle: Unions signal rise of the cyber picket

fields.headline: Unions signal rise of the cyber picket
fields.trailText: Trade unionists may soon be extinguishing their braziers and hanging up their donkey jackets in favour of cyber-picketing from computers, according to the TUC general secretary, John Monks.
fields.body:
Trade unionists may soon be extinguishing their braziers and hanging up their donkey jackets in favour of cyber-picketing from computers, according to the TUC general secretary, John Monks.

Mr Monks, launching a new electronic database for trade unionists in Liverpool, said the future of organised labour lies with the internet. He likened it to Labour's Excalibur computer system which proved so effective in the run-up to the 1997 general election.

The union database, which is being piloted in Liverpool, will include a bulletin board detailing disputes, in Britain and around the globe, and details of the latest cyber-picketing techniques. It will also build up data on the 47% of workplaces in Britain which have no union representation.

Mr Monks said: "The TUC has long aspired to having a map of the country showing where firms are unionised and where they are not. The database will enable us to build up information on employers and focus our energies.

"We have been slow to pick up on information technology but it is where unions in the future need to be."

Comparing the new software package, known as the Organising Database, to the Excalibur system, he said: "Labour built up information about its members and potential members in the run-up to the election and we're doing much the same. We will have target areas in the same way as the Labour party have key seats."

He predicted that the divide between those with and those without internet access would disappear in under five years.

"Access to the internet is increasing rapidly, especially in the workplace. In a few years I have no doubt it will be as accessible as TV - which some people thought would divide the country in the 1950s."

Paul Nowak, the policy and campaigns officer for the TUC in the north-west, said the database, which runs on the internet but is accessible only to union organisers, will help members to communicate with unions worldwide.

Striking dockers in Liverpool used this kind of technology to successfully petition for supportive action in the US during their two-year dispute.

Mr Nowak said: "If striking workers have to rely on traditional news media their impact can be limited during a long dispute. We need to harness this technology to get our message across."

Details of the latest methods of disruptive action will also feature on the database.

Two years ago the Communications Workers' Union deluged Critchley Labels, a Welsh telecommunications firm, with emails to stop it receiving electronic orders as part of a union recognition dispute.

Mr Nowak added that the pilot project would be particularly effective in targeting workers in small businesses and new media firms beyond the reach of traditional recruitment methods.

David McCall, the north-west regional secretary of the transport union TGWU, welcomed the technological revolution but said cyber-picketing and online campaigning were only supplementary to traditional methods.

"We are not going to abandon the brazier just yet. But we are always adding to ways of resolving disputes," he said.

He added that one of the main benefits of the database, developed by the north-west TUC, would be greater communication between unions.

"It will help us avoid the kind of damaging inter-union competition we have seen in the past."

Disputes on the internet

Liverpool dockers, sacked for refusing to cross a picket line in 1995, maintained their 28-month campaign using the internet. They built a network of solidarity which stretched to ports as far away as Australia.

By publicising their dispute globally and giving the impression of a strike-bound port they were able to disrupt shipping trade in the city.

In 1998 workers at Rentokil Initial were denied representation on the firm's European works council and launched an international campaign on the internet. The resulting support throughout Europe was of particular embarrassment to the company's chief executive, Sir Clive Thompson, who is also president of the CBI.

In November last year Battersea and Wandsworth TUC published the names, photographs and attendance figures of Wandsworth borough councillors on their internet site during a dispute over sick pay and days off for council workers.

The web address was published in the local newspaper, the Wandsworth Borough News, and received more than 8,000 hits the next day.
